profile.name: panhead

title: Facts instead of hysteria
body: I approached this book with more than a little trepidation. I read all the 1 star reviews, I watched an Indigenous elder on TV emotionally describing the book as being filled with "racism and hatred", I researched the organization that published it. I had no desire to read or support some crazy alt-right conspiracy-laden rant. Despite my caution, I needed to try and get another side of the IRS story, as I have been deeply troubled by the events of the last three years, by having my parents, grandparents and their whole generation accused and convicted of "genocide" without any proof being offered, just "anomalies" and shocking stories. This book offered a breath of fresh air, a confirmation that others share my concern. There is not one whiff of racism or hatred in this book that I could find. It is a well researched (there is barely a paragraph in it that does not contain a footnote with references) and calmly argued investigation into the wild claims that have been made about the Indian Residential School system. Much of the hysteria I have heard on the news in the past three years reminds me of the "satanic cult" daycare scandals of the 80's and 90's - lives and reputations ruined based just on wild claims with no evidence. "Believe the Children!" they said at the time...well children sometimes tell stories, especially when "encouraged". Grave Error in no way denies that in a system like the IRS there were bound to be some abuses and mismanagement, but this is true of any large institution in that day and age (British boarding schools, Irish orphanages etc). The IRS system was certainly not perfect, but that doesn't make it "genocidal". I found the book treats Indigenous people and their culture with respect and sensitivity, but it doesn't let that keep it from presenting cold, hard facts. If anyone finds racism or hatred in this book, it is because they need to find it, whether it is there or not. I will say that the book is a bit bloated - each chapter is written by a different author and it can be repetitive in its presentation of facts and could have done with a better editing job to tighten it up. Other than that I thoroughly enjoyed it and it highly recommend it - don't be scared to read it, you should be skeptical about most of what you have heard about this book, just like most of what you have heard about "mass graves" and "genocide".

I found the book treats Indigenous people and their culture with respect and sensitivity, but it doesn't let that keep it from presenting cold, hard facts. If anyone finds racism or hatred in this book, it is because they need to find it, whether it is there or not.
I will say that the book is a bit bloated - each chapter is written by a different author and it can be repetitive in its presentation of facts and could have done with a better editing job to tighten it up. Other than that I thoroughly enjoyed it and it highly recommend it - don't be scared to read it, you should be skeptical about most of what you have heard about this book, just like most of what you have heard about "mass graves" and "genocide".

profile.name: ccoffey

title: An important book that disturbs the current narrative
body: This is a serious study of claims made about deaths and burials (and conditions) at Indian Residential Schools. It challenges many of the stories currently in circulation, particularly after the Kamloops IRS “revelations”. Almost all the claims do not stand up to the scrutiny given here. What is difficult to absorb about this work, which is far ahead of the current popular view, is that it is so different from what most people have been led to believe. Is it accurate? Have we been had? It sure looks that way. While many authors here are on the “conservative” side of the political spectrum, and the publisher is obviously of that persuasion also, don’t let that deter you if you are a progressive. If you’ve been skeptical of some claims, or the cancelling of Canada Day, the lowering of flags, the hostility of debates, the political posturing, you will find this book confirming and shocking. I would have liked to have seen a couple articles in this collection supporting the “mass graves narrative”, assuming credible evidence was provided. But maybe it wouldn’t be convincing placed beside these essays. This is a very important book. Read it and spread it around. I hope many Indigenous people read this and consider pushing back against some leaders who may be misleading their bands. [Graphs indicate significantly higher death rates in residential schools but they decline dramatically with the introduction of vaccines, to similar rates as the general population.]

profile.name: Robin Collins

title: This should be REQUIRED READING in schools across Canada!
body: It's hard to imagine that one book could be such a comfort, but this was! I felt like I'd finally stepped out of the twilight zone that Canada has been becoming! I'm so sick of the government's, the media's, and yes, the Native Indians' CONTINUAL narrative that aims to shame every non-aboriginal/indigenous/native person in this country, whether dead or alive, for the problems of the natives in Canada! This book illustrates very clearly WHAT IS TRUE AND WHAT IS NOT and does a superb job of referencing the information gathered. To the writers and contributors of this book, THANK YOU for having the courage and integrity to publish this information in a time when the whole bloody country is afraid to ask, "How do we know this is fact?"!

profile.name: Holly Craig

title: Very interesting read
body: I found this book quite intresting. I think many people were skeptical of some of the stories surrounding this issue, but were afraid to express an opinion. The fact that people were bullied into silence is concerning. As for the content of this book, I did agree with much of it, especially those aspects that provided solid data and evidence. Some things I felt needed a bit more research. But on the whole I thnk that this book needed to be printed, published and sold without fear. Hopefully we can all take a step away from the false rhetoric and the political posturing surrounding this serious topic. I do not see how we can have reconciliation until this issue is fully studied. I do think a proper Index and a proper appendix would have been heplful. and I second the motion that "verified" purchasers should do the reviews. Books should not be reviewed by people who clearly have not read them, it is unfair to the both the author and the publisher

profile.name: tony Marissink

title: This Book is Revelatory!
body: This book is revelatory! If you want to know the complete story surrounding the many claims made against Indian Residential Schools in Canada, this book is invaluable. The evidence presented here also shines a light on the current state of disinformation in our modern culture The book explains in detail the how and why of false claims, the methods used to disseminate and ‘frame’ them, the benefits to those making false claims, and the pressure on the media, politicians, and others to endorse these claims.

profile.name: Bob

title: Long time coming
body: The authors provided information on how they found what they did and how it can be searched. They have not once denied that many residential schools were abusive and many were not. I did not detect prejudice, hatred, or racism in this novel. How many people have actually read this work that has stated that it contains these? The authors did well at treating native and indigenous people with respect and diplomacy. They also treated their culture with respect. If readers believe they found racism or hatred in this work, it's because they are looking for it, whether it is there or not. Everyone deserves the right to make informed decisions. Having all the facts enables them to do so. This work does reveal harsh facts that many will find hard to admit or accept. There could still be facts not known. I am both native and white. I have hoped for a long time to see healing between both of these cultures. It is time for peace and reconciliation between both, not driving them further apart. Before all the truth can surface, it must be revealed regardless of what is found. The facts support unearthing these apparent gravesites most respectfully. This remains true whether burial remains are found or not. We should all be on the side of the facts, what happened, and how we move forward. Everyone should remain open-minded and be allowed the opportunity to read this work. This book should be in every library, college, university, and school in Canada. The explanations describe the circumstances around the information offered and researched. It does not judge anyone's circumstances now or in the past, nor does it aim to offend.  Just a note: This book is independent and self-published. I applied to several traditional publishers with my work. They said they would not consider me because I'm unpublished. Yet they offered me their self-publishing site, which I could pay to use to publish my work. Like many other authors, I tire of the groundless remarks about independent and self-publishing companies. Remember, traditional publishing owns many of these companies today.

profile.name: Tasha

title: A Classic of Social Science Objectivity
body: Empirical social science research can't get much more rigorous than this, in backing up all its claims with numerous references to official documentation and subsequent studies. I'm a social scientist by professional education. I'm over 80, so I have some relevant experience of this time period. I attended a small town school on the prairies in the 1950's. I belonged to the Boy Scouts, a blessing to boys in a grim, mediocre school system. One thing I really benefited from was when our Scout Master arranged with the Scout Master of an Indian residential school on a reserve south of our town to have us more senior boys of both troops get together to do scouting activities in their marvelously unblemished woodlands. We really bonded as fellow scouts. They seemed to really like their life at the residential school, which seemed a very nice setting. I think it was an Anglican Church school. School brutality did exist, at least at my school. Both the principal and vice-principal in elementary school (grade 7 and 8) whacked and roughed up the boys quite frequently. The worst incident was when our woman teacher in grade 5 attacked young Melvin with a steel-edged ruler, drawing blood by nearly gouging out his eye. His immigrant parents were afraid to complain. We had some very bad teachers and some very good ones. Schoolyard bullying came as much from some teachers as from classmates. But most importantly they did teach us much of substance unlike today.

profile.name: Will

title: What ever happened to evidence based decision making?
body: I am not a Conservative, nor am I a fan of Conrad Black, who wrote the introduction to this book, or of Tom Flannigan who contributed to it. However, I purchased this book in the hope that it could shed a light on some of the questions I had concerning the recent moral panic regarding the soil disturbances found around some Residential Schools, Churches and Hospitals in Canada. I say moral panic because that is what it was and still is unfortunately. Without a shred of evidence, not a single body recovered, Canadians assumed the worst and as the days progressed the stories grew more and more macabre. Our Prime Minister had photo ops taken looking sorrowful as he clutched a teddy bear, First Nations were saying "see, I told you so!", money was dispensed and Canada willingly bore the shame of being a genocidal nation for all the world to see. It has become equivalent to the "Satanic Panic" of the 1980's. We have turned Residential Schools into Canada's own Tuol Sleng. Yet, not a single forensic study has been made. Not a single body has been exhumed and now the topic has become so taboo that we cannot even have a frank and open discussion about it for fear of being called a "Denier". Or protestors outside our homes. How does this happen? How does this fit with the "evidence based decision making" once promoted by our Government? If this is the current zeitgeist in which we live then I am fearful for our Nation.  This book does not deny the existence of Residential Schools, as many people who appear not to have read it wish to say. It only states, through a collection of essays, that there is an absence of evidence for some of the claims being made regarding the soil disturbances detected by ground penetrating radar.  We need this book. We need to be able to debate this topic because extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence. And evidence, not hearsay, must be presented before reconciliation can occur.

profile.name: Martin C.

title: Truth Hurts can you Hear it?
body: A very well researched, non-partisan and balanced approach to the hysterical outpourings of recent years. The very fact that a vocal minority want to ban the book without ever having read any of this book is testament to its veracity. Its a good non-academic read where Champion and Flanagan et al lay out the FACTS behind and beyond the lies, myths and untruths about the Govt of Canada, the church and the then contemporary approach to integrate native peoples into a modern world. Whatever your opinion, this is a must read book.

profile.name: Will BUCKINGHAM

title: This Ivory Tower Book is not the Whole Story
body: I purchased this book because I was curious on how the learned professors from our esteemed Universities would frame this chapter of Canada's history. Also, I was curious about their research that would explain why there was no RCMP or Coroner's investigation into the mass grave site at KIB after more than 2 years had gone by since the discovery.  After finishing this book, I felt like this book was Swiss cheese with so many gaps. Had anyone of these writers even visited a Rez? Because they came off as Ottawa-centered!  I have lived in Kamloops and the South Okanagan for most of my life and have a first hand deep understanding of the issues of our neighbours on the Rez from the generational trauma that the residential school system brought to their families. They were raised outside of a family unit and when it was time to have families, there was no role modelling on how to be a parent because they were not raised by by loving parents themselves. As well with all traumatized humans, self medicating became rampant. This is not addressed in the book.  Neither is addressed the lack of freedom at that time to leave the reserves without permission, no access to the court system, or not having the right to vote in federal elections. There was no mention in this book that a delegation from South Africa visited Canada to assess the reservation system and based their Apartheid system on what we had set up here. That is a big gap to leave out!  During Christmas of 1947, a letter went out from the Kamloops Residential school to the parents informing them that the students would be NOT be coming home for Christmas that year because the students overstayed with their parents the previous Christmas. This was punitive and keeping the children away from the parents only because they didn't return after the holidays on the exact date expected. These sort of facts and stories are not included in the essays in this book.  Please read this book to actually see what systemic rascism actually looks like! The road to hell is paved with good intentions, right?!  If anyone is interested and in reading another book to gain a more well rounded and informed knowledge base of the lingering effects of the residential school system, please get yourself a copy of "Rez Rules" written by Chief Clarence Louie of Osoyoos, BC. I hope this review helps!

Also, I was curious about their research that would explain why there was no RCMP or Coroner's investigation into the mass grave site at KIB after more than 2 years had gone by since the discovery.

After finishing this book, I felt like this book was Swiss cheese with so many gaps. Had anyone of these writers even visited a Rez? Because they came off as Ottawa-centered!

I have lived in Kamloops and the South Okanagan for most of my life and have a first hand deep understanding of the issues of our neighbours on the Rez from the generational trauma that the residential school system brought to their families. They were raised outside of a family unit and when it was time to have families, there was no role modelling on how to be a parent because they were not raised by by loving parents themselves. As well with all traumatized humans, self medicating became rampant. This is not addressed in the book.

Neither is addressed the lack of freedom at that time to leave the reserves without permission, no access to the court system, or not having the right to vote in federal elections. There was no mention in this book that a delegation from South Africa visited Canada to assess the reservation system and based their Apartheid system on what we had set up here. That is a big gap to leave out!

During Christmas of 1947, a letter went out from the Kamloops Residential school to the parents informing them that the students would be NOT be coming home for Christmas that year because the students overstayed with their parents the previous Christmas. This was punitive and keeping the children away from the parents only because they didn't return after the holidays on the exact date expected. These sort of facts and stories are not included in the essays in this book.

Please read this book to actually see what systemic rascism actually looks like! The road to hell is paved with good intentions, right?!

If anyone is interested and in reading another book to gain a more well rounded and informed knowledge base of the lingering effects of the residential school system, please get yourself a copy of "Rez Rules" written by Chief Clarence Louie of Osoyoos, BC.
I hope this review helps!

profile.name: Gracie Lee

title: Every Canadian should read this book!!
body: I read this over a period of time. I believe in evidence based facts and this book questions the stories as handed down by elders. Everyone jumped on the bandwagon without obtaining "all" the facts, if the stories are true then the "alledged" graves should be dug up to settle this "fantasy" once and for all. I'm extremely disappointed in our elected officials that have accepted these "stories" and jumped to the conclusion that they did.......very disappointed in our Government. Some individuals that attended residential schools actually benefited from an education that has helped them through their lives.

profile.name: Tree Faller

title: An important treatise on how misinformation rewrites history
body: The residential school era is a difficult and sensitive topic and much has been said and examined about it - it must never be forgotten.  During the pandemic and lockdown of Canada, and following in the footsteps of the Floyd tragedy in the US, opportunism trumped facts and Canadians were crassly manipulated into a period of shame and embarrassment - all for the political benefit of the misinfo peddlars.  This well researched book is an important step towards correcting the false and facile narratives of the past few years. I hope one day, and after proper investigation, the real facts come out so that Canadians can better understand an important piece of our history.
body_html:
The residential school era is a difficult and sensitive topic and much has been said and examined about it - it must never be forgotten.

During the pandemic and lockdown of Canada, and following in the footsteps of the Floyd tragedy in the US, opportunism trumped facts and Canadians were crassly manipulated into a period of shame and embarrassment - all for the political benefit of the misinfo peddlars.

This well researched book is an important step towards correcting the false and facile narratives of the past few years. I hope one day, and after proper investigation, the real facts come out so that Canadians can better understand an important piece of our history.
date.raw: Reviewed in Canada on June 1, 2024
profile.name: Lian Zerafa

title: Reconciliation requires truth
body: It has been reported in the media that this book is denialism. I disagree. The authors in the book don’t deny that abuses happened at IRS. And anyway, shouldn’t you actually read the book before making such judgments? This book contains 18 essays by journalists, judges and researchers, most of them retired. Interesting that the authors are mostly retired. One must have nothing to lose to criticize anything to do with indigenous affairs - because you could be fired for speaking out. I preferred some of the authors over others. But all agreed that no evidence of graves has yet to be provided. This book has many footnotes provided for further reading. I am pro choice and pro-science. I also believe that evidence should be presented before accusing an entire nation of genocide. GPR does not constitute evidence. Sarah Beaulieu stressed her findings cannot be confirmed “unless excavations are done at the scene: Which is why we need to pull back a little bit and say that they are ‘probable burials,’ they are ‘targets of interest,’ for sure.” And yet almost 3 years later no further investigation has occurred at the Kamloops IRS despite hundreds of millions of taxpayers dollars being dispensed. Is there any accountability for that money? Since Trudeau axed the First Nations accountability act, likely not. How can reconciliation occur without the truth part?

profile.name: s c

title: The truth about the graves and other alleged atrocities.
body: The book Grave Error was excellent. It was honest and fair with every statement, fact proven and documented and referenced. Far too many lies have been spread about the residential school. Generally the children were happy there, monitored by the Federal government, the children only sent if the parents requested and only about 30% of all the First Nations children even went and the average stay was about 4 years. Read it to find the truth. I hope you are willing to see the facts.

profile.name: Biscuit

title: Truth helps everyone
body: I read the book and came away thinking we have experienced a collapse in media scrutiny a significant number of times in the past 30 years in this Country but none more damaging to both indigenous as well as the rest of Canadians than the Mass Graves story.  Canada has spent in total related to Indigenous issues in the last few years more money than on the total for National Defense.  These two facts should be of major concern to all.  A criticism I have of the book is that it doesn’t unpack in clear and cogent language how this all occurred nor why. Was it a narrative that caught fire fuelled by agendized MSM propaganda, used by a willing treacherous Federal Govt looking for one more virtue signalling issue to champion, coupled with a complete cowardice in the intellectual/institutional class and capitalized by those who rake in those billions of dollars?  We as a Country, need the courage to look for and find the answer.  HD

title: Essential Reading for all Canadians
body: This book is a collection of articles and essays examining the facts surrounding the claims of atrocities allegedly committed at Indian Residential Schools. As such, it is often repetitive and does not flow as well as a document composed by a single author. This in no way detracts from the value of the work. It is a meticulously referenced and documented work that seeks to examine the facts about Indian Residential Schools that we do not get from the mainstream media, and certainly not from our Liberal government. An extremely thought-provoking work that is a must-read for anyone concerned about the welfare of our aboriginal peoples, and the misinformation rampant in Canadian society today.

title: well-written and intriguing
body: As I sat down to read "The Housemaid's Secret" by Freida McFadden, I was immediately drawn into the mysterious and eerie atmosphere that the author had created. The book was a perfect blend of suspense and intrigue that had me captivated from the very beginning.  The themes of secrecy and hidden intentions that pervaded the book were expertly woven into the narrative. As the story progressed, I found myself constantly questioning the true motives of the characters and wondering what secrets they were hiding.  One of the elements of the book that I particularly enjoyed was the characterization. Each character was distinct and well-developed, with their own motivations and agendas that kept me guessing throughout the book. The portrayal of the wealthy couple, the Garricks, and their luxurious lifestyle was done in such a way that it added to the sense of unease and tension that permeated the story.  The pacing of the book was excellent, with the tension building slowly but surely as the story progressed. The twists and turns in the plot kept me guessing until the very end, and the resolution of the story was both satisfying and unexpected.  Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed "The Housemaid's Secret". The mysterious tone of the book was expertly crafted, and the themes and elements of secrecy and hidden intentions were seamlessly integrated into the story. The characters were well-developed, the pacing was excellent, and the twists and turns in the plot kept me engaged until the very end. I would highly recommend this book to anyone who enjoys a good mystery with a hint of suspense.
body_html:
As I sat down to read "The Housemaid's Secret" by Freida McFadden, I was immediately drawn into the mysterious and eerie atmosphere that the author had created. The book was a perfect blend of suspense and intrigue that had me captivated from the very beginning.

The themes of secrecy and hidden intentions that pervaded the book were expertly woven into the narrative. As the story progressed, I found myself constantly questioning the true motives of the characters and wondering what secrets they were hiding.

One of the elements of the book that I particularly enjoyed was the characterization. Each character was distinct and well-developed, with their own motivations and agendas that kept me guessing throughout the book. The portrayal of the wealthy couple, the Garricks, and their luxurious lifestyle was done in such a way that it added to the sense of unease and tension that permeated the story.

The pacing of the book was excellent, with the tension building slowly but surely as the story progressed. The twists and turns in the plot kept me guessing until the very end, and the resolution of the story was both satisfying and unexpected.

Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed "The Housemaid's Secret". The mysterious tone of the book was expertly crafted, and the themes and elements of secrecy and hidden intentions were seamlessly integrated into the story. The characters were well-developed, the pacing was excellent, and the twists and turns in the plot kept me engaged until the very end. I would highly recommend this book to anyone who enjoys a good mystery with a hint of suspense.

profile.name: Jessica

title: Good but not as good as the first for me
body: 📚BOOK REVIEW📚  “The Housemaid’s Secret” Author: @fmcfaddenauthor ⭐️⭐️⭐️  ✨“This perfect house has one rule. Don’t look behind closed doors.”✨  I have been anxiously awaiting this sequel to “The Housemaid” wondering what Millie is going to get up to next! So let’s dive in!  The book starts out with a time jump, and we find our Millie is a nanny to a rich couple. Very quickly we find out that the baby she has been helping to watch along side her cleaning duties starts calling her Mama (as Millie spends more time with baby, Olive, than her actual mother Amber does) and she quickly gets fired by the jealous child’s mother for this offence.  Then Millie gets an interview to clean and do some light cooking for a new couple, The Garricks. This seems like a dream come true to Millie until Douglas Garrick quickly explains that his wife, Wendy, is not well and spends the majority of her time in the guest bedroom “resting” and she is not to be disturbed by Millie under any circumstances.  *Cue ominous music*  And before we know it, our favourite main character is sleuthing around and plotting revenge once again.. 🫣  While I enjoyed this book, I found it didn’t pull me in quite like the first one. It was definitely a great lazy Saturday read, but I just found myself with the feeling of wanting “more”. More of what exactly? I’m not quite sure, I just found that the way the storyline turned out was just a little too “out there” for me. (I don’t want to include spoilers), so I’ll just say that I found the storyline was a bit convoluted and all over the place in the back half of the novel.  Overall, I’m glad I read it, but unfortunately for me, it didn’t live up to the hype, that I think everyone was hoping for.
body_html:
📚BOOK REVIEW📚

“The Housemaid’s Secret”
Author: @fmcfaddenauthor
⭐️⭐️⭐️

✨“This perfect house has one rule. Don’t look behind closed doors.”✨

I have been anxiously awaiting this sequel to “The Housemaid” wondering what Millie is going to get up to next! So let’s dive in!

The book starts out with a time jump, and we find our Millie is a nanny to a rich couple. Very quickly we find out that the baby she has been helping to watch along side her cleaning duties starts calling her Mama (as Millie spends more time with baby, Olive, than her actual mother Amber does) and she quickly gets fired by the jealous child’s mother for this offence.

Then Millie gets an interview to clean and do some light cooking for a new couple, The Garricks. This seems like a dream come true to Millie until Douglas Garrick quickly explains that his wife, Wendy, is not well and spends the majority of her time in the guest bedroom “resting” and she is not to be disturbed by Millie under any circumstances.

*Cue ominous music*

And before we know it, our favourite main character is sleuthing around and plotting revenge once again.. 🫣

While I enjoyed this book, I found it didn’t pull me in quite like the first one. It was definitely a great lazy Saturday read, but I just found myself with the feeling of wanting “more”. More of what exactly? I’m not quite sure, I just found that the way the storyline turned out was just a little too “out there” for me. (I don’t want to include spoilers), so I’ll just say that I found the storyline was a bit convoluted and all over the place in the back half of the novel.

Overall, I’m glad I read it, but unfortunately for me, it didn’t live up to the hype, that I think everyone was hoping for.
date.raw: Reviewed in Canada on March 14, 2023
profile.name: Jamie Mason

title: really fun read!
body: I usually read high fantasy, so for me I get massive book hangovers—a little break here and there is needed from a heavy 1000 pager. I love that you can sit in one session and chew through this, it’s ultimately satisfying and keeps you guessing. A genuinely fun read following the first one.  As someone who can usually predictively see the ending, the plot twists sometimes are foreseeable, and then again some aren’t - and I loved that.  If you’re somebody who needs realistic psychological thrillers, this isn’t for you. This is for my desperate housewives, and pretty little liars tv fans - who like a bit of cheeky salacious writing in their murder mystery.

title: Super food recipes for your best friends!
body: I was so excited to receive my hard cover copy however while waiting there was a pre release in our area of the book where I also received a free signed copy and met the authors. This is not just a book of knowledge but has beautiful photographs to inspire your mind while you make new recipes for your beloved pet. Rodney is a bit of a local hero in his home town and I have had the pleasure of working with him years ago to help two of my pets. One with cancer and one with stomach issues. His help helped them both live longer and healthier lives. Dr.Becker is also amazing and the co authors work so well together,to give us easy to ready and follow instructions,to make our pets lives longer and healthier. There is nothing else out there that I’d rather follow or use in the everyday care of my pets. Thank you for all you do for our pets!

title: Best purchase I've made
body: I preordered this book several months ago and just received it last night, and all i can say is WOW!!! This is the book I have dreamed about. As a holistic pet parent who has worked in the pet health industry there have been very few resources for pet parents looking to actively make changes in their dog's diet, lifestyle and product use. title: My expectations have been outdone!
body: Awesome in content, appearance, intention, and energy. Informative, educational, functional, and fun! The recipes aren't all about food, but also about the household environment and the body too. Suitable for beginners worried about doing it "right" when it comes to nutritional gaps through to experienced fresh feeders looking for creative ideas and new recipes. You don't need to "do it all" to make a difference, and you don't have to be overwhelmed by needing to do it all at once either: small steps will take you great distances.

profile.name: Kym Van rooyen

title: A book of love!!
body: I started following Dr. Karen Becker since 2017 and she shocked my perception as to how to be a good dog parent and what is truely good for our dogs, was totally overwhelmed when i watched the documentary 'Pet Fooled' and i couldn't believe what people would do to our beloved dogs for money, ever since i see the commercial dog food/product world in a different way so when the 'Forever Dog' came out i was really excited, the book mentions over and over again food is the key and i thought to myself if we could have some sort of guideline/recipes would be great since we all want to prolong our dogs' lives and i accidentally saw they were going to publish this recipe book, and today afternoon i finally received it and it is beautiful, informative, and fun! i wish i could open up a doggy bakery that sells all the ready-to-eat snacks in this book, the most important thing is they are simple and easy to follow, you don't need to buy 12 new ingrediants just to make a new snack/dish for you dog, not only recipes but it also has useful information like what kinda dog bowl is non-toxic and what kinda eggs are the most nutritious, or what kinda water - all of that is something a lot of people never think of, including the vets, so it is not just a cookbook s it is also a book to help your dog to live longer, i am so happy that we are improving for our dogs because they deserve it for the way they love us no matter what and it is indeed a book of love! thank you Dr. Karen Becker and Rodney Habib!  my babygirl Joelis is going to be 9 in Oct/Nov and as much as i want to, i know she's not going to be here forever, she's the best thing that ever happened to me and even one day she might be gone but i know she'll always be with me, encouraging me to face life's challenges like she did, she's taught me so many things which i will never forget - until then i'll keep cooking for her and be happy that we are still together!

profile.name: Neal C.

title: Feed your pets what you yourself would eat
body: I pre-ordered this books several months ago and just could not wait to receive it. For years we were led to believe that kibbles contained everything a dog needed to stay healthy and prosper. As time went on I turned to raw food for the first meal of the day followed by kibbles at night. Even though I knew I was meeting their needs everything looked really plain and boring so I started adding little toppers. We've been told what we should and should not feed our pets for so long that it's absolutely mind boggling to find out that a lot of this was completely wrong. I'm so excited to be able to offer my 2 girls appetizing and varied meals. No more eating the same old, same old everyday. I haven't gotten very far reading the book yet because there are so many things I need to add to my grocery list that it keeps interrupting me. I can't wait to start offering them what they deserve to be fed.  My recommendation - buy this book and treat your pets like the valued members of the family they truly are. You won't regret it and neither will they.

profile.name: gsdlover

title: Best animal health book EVER!!!!
body: I have been following the work of Dr.Becker and Rodney for years and absolutely LOVED their first book The Forever Dog - it has been my bible for animal health. After loosing every single dog I have EVER owned to cancer and working in the veterinary and animal care field, seeing what our modern dog goes thru - it has been my sole focus to do everything in my power to help my little dog Jersey live a healthy life - thriving everyday. The Forever Dog has helped me do exactly that and now The Forever Dog Life only helps put more of what I have learned into practise - this is a book for EVERY dog owner. All the amazing recipes and tips - I’ve never felt more empowered to help my little girl. Thank you Karen and Rodney. I have bought multiple copies of this book and will be gifting them to family and friends.

profile.name: Cathie & Jersey

title: Fantastic book! A must read for pet parents everywhere!
body: I , like so many others , pre-ordered this book in Jan. It was released and arrived on the promised date of June 4. I could not wait to dig in and learn as much as I can. My pets have always eaten human grade food, now I can take it to the next level. The recipes are not complex, and are easy to follow. The visuals are beautifully done! I love the inclusion of treats and toppers- Chapter 3, and the easy to make, home cleaning products! This book is long overdue. I hope pet parents everywhere are able to purchase this well thought out and well researched book. Vets should have this in their clinics! Thank you Rodney and Dr. Karen. FANTASTIC work to provide the best possible preventative medicine for our 4 legged family members! An ounce of prevention, is worth a pound of cure! You and your pets will not be disappointed!

profile.name: Eleni Xidos

title: Great Book- A bit contradictory
body: I love this book. I am very familiar with feeding whole foods and real food diet and had great expectations for this book to get more people on board with feeding real food. I think this book will be a great tool for those who know very little about pet nutrition as well as a great recipe book for those of us who are wanting new ideas to supplement our dogs and cats.  My only issue which removed a 5 star review is the contradiction in adding oats to recipes. We all know processed carbs are not good for dogs and cats, the book even talks about this briefly. I wish the authors didn’t include oats in this book as it may be confusing for people as to what is acceptable and what isn’t. Because we all know oats are very high in carbohydrates and have no place in our dogs diet.

profile.name: Sarah

title: chef's kiss 5/5 <3
body: **SPOILER  ACOTAR This was my first fantasy romance series, and OMG I’m hooked. Was I confused the entire time, yes, but that didn’t stop me from eating this up bc everything made sense at the end. I don't like the Beauty and Beast trope, but those last 100 pages were incredible. Tamlin wearing a mask, I got the ick. I couldn’t solve the riddle either, don’t worry Feyre.  ACOMAF I laughed, I cried. I was mad, then happy. WOW ACOMAF came and just flipped my whole world around. I was up till 5am reading. Feyre changed bc of what she went through under the mountain, but so did Tamlin, and because they are both struggling with their own separate traumas neither can communicate what they need from each other. The relationship became unhealthy and no longer compatible. There was a ton of additional world building and character introductions that I was just not prepared for. Feyre’s character development, incredible. Rhys brings out the best in Feyre, always treating her as an equal with autonomy and her own choices. Rhys has that dark edge, charm, wit and humour, but you also get to see his vulnerabilities, his huge capacity to love and found family of the Inner Circle. Also I love how SJM writes every character as the most beautiful. Despite a seemingly 'happily ever after ending,' the horrors of the end !!! The cliff hanger is making me need to read the third book ASAP.  ACOWAR I loveddddd the politics in this one! I’m so obsessed with this series. I was loaning the books out from the Library and after reading this buckled down bought the entire series knowing I was going to be re-reading this. There were so many tiny small details from ACOTAR that come back in ACOWAR. The last 100 pages are like being in a tornado of emotions - sad, happy, joy, anger, understanding, forgiveness, hope etc TBH, I kinda wish someone actually died in the battle :/ but SJM loves a ‘happily ever after’ ending after all.  ACOFAS I read this novella in 1 sitting. She’s small, but she throws punches! I really liked the domestic story and all the POVs. But they say “mate” 20 million times. I’m patiently waiting for the next part of the series: Nesta, Elain, Lucien, Cassian and Azriel. I really hope that Nesta and Elaine’s mates are not Cassian and Azriel tho. That would be too cliche if the 3 sisters were mated to the 3 Night Court warriors. SJM needs her happy ending. The sneak peak at the next book is, chefs kiss :* but seriously ofc Nesta and Cassian get together.  ACOSF There are drugs in this, and I couldn’t stop reading all 750 pages. I had to put this book down so many time and just stay silent with my thoughts. Cassian’s passion to train the women to fight back against anyone who attempt to hurt them like they had his mother, and Nesta still feeling nothing after having been Made against her will… woah it broke my heart. Nesta character development INCREDIBLE. She constantly was taking steps forward, but back tracking. The friendship with the House, yes. Building her found family of Gwen and Emrie, amazing. Her internal battle for her own self-worth is heartbreaking and inspiring all at once. I kinda hate how Rhys didn’t tell Feyre about the pregnancy scare and health risks… like this dude for 3 books (plus 1 novella) always gave Feyre autonomy and choices of what to do, and he took that away from her. It’s a no from me.
body_html:
**SPOILER

ACOTAR
This was my first fantasy romance series, and OMG I’m hooked. Was I confused the entire time, yes, but that didn’t stop me from eating this up bc everything made sense at the end.
I don't like the Beauty and Beast trope, but those last 100 pages were incredible.
Tamlin wearing a mask, I got the ick.
I couldn’t solve the riddle either, don’t worry Feyre.

ACOMAF
I laughed, I cried. I was mad, then happy. WOW
ACOMAF came and just flipped my whole world around. I was up till 5am reading.
Feyre changed bc of what she went through under the mountain, but so did Tamlin, and because they are both struggling with their own separate traumas neither can communicate what they need from each other. The relationship became unhealthy and no longer compatible.
There was a ton of additional world building and character introductions that I was just not prepared for. Feyre’s character development, incredible. Rhys brings out the best in Feyre, always treating her as an equal with autonomy and her own choices. Rhys has that dark edge, charm, wit and humour, but you also get to see his vulnerabilities, his huge capacity to love and found family of the Inner Circle.
Also I love how SJM writes every character as the most beautiful.
Despite a seemingly 'happily ever after ending,' the horrors of the end !!! The cliff hanger is making me need to read the third book ASAP.

ACOWAR
I loveddddd the politics in this one! I’m so obsessed with this series. I was loaning the books out from the Library and after reading this buckled down bought the entire series knowing I was going to be re-reading this. There were so many tiny small details from ACOTAR that come back in ACOWAR.
The last 100 pages are like being in a tornado of emotions - sad, happy, joy, anger, understanding, forgiveness, hope etc
TBH, I kinda wish someone actually died in the battle :/ but SJM loves a ‘happily ever after’ ending after all.

ACOFAS
I read this novella in 1 sitting. She’s small, but she throws punches! I really liked the domestic story and all the POVs. But they say “mate” 20 million times.
I’m patiently waiting for the next part of the series: Nesta, Elain, Lucien, Cassian and Azriel.
I really hope that Nesta and Elaine’s mates are not Cassian and Azriel tho. That would be too cliche if the 3 sisters were mated to the 3 Night Court warriors. SJM needs her happy ending.
The sneak peak at the next book is, chefs kiss :* but seriously ofc Nesta and Cassian get together.

ACOSF
There are drugs in this, and I couldn’t stop reading all 750 pages.
I had to put this book down so many time and just stay silent with my thoughts.
Cassian’s passion to train the women to fight back against anyone who attempt to hurt them like they had his mother, and Nesta still feeling nothing after having been Made against her will… woah it broke my heart.
Nesta character development INCREDIBLE. She constantly was taking steps forward, but back tracking. The friendship with the House, yes. Building her found family of Gwen and Emrie, amazing. Her internal battle for her own self-worth is heartbreaking and inspiring all at once.
I kinda hate how Rhys didn’t tell Feyre about the pregnancy scare and health risks… like this dude for 3 books (plus 1 novella) always gave Feyre autonomy and choices of what to do, and he took that away from her. It’s a no from me.
date.raw: Reviewed in Canada on August 31, 2023

title: 4.5 stars, worth the hype
body: Book 1 is slow (and the middle of the book is a little underwhelming), but the ending is awesome. It’s basically a prequel for book 2. If you don’t like book 2, this series might not be for you.  I only give 4+ stars for books that i would reread. ACOMAF, ACOFAS and ACOSF to all get 4+ stars was surprising even for me. I dont love war books, but ACOWAR was even a 3.9 for me. And i would read ACOTAR for the easter eggs and to set up ACOMAF again.  Worht the hype. Well written.  Books came in good condition

profile.name: Amazon Customer

title: A story for the years.
body: I remember looking at it from afar while browsing my favourite bookshop. The bright pink cover got my attention, but it wasn't until the next visit that I decided to pick it up. I didn't get past the first chapters, but months later, I tried again, pushed through it, and found myself unable to put it down.  I rushed through the rest of the series, and in less than a week, I was left staring at my ceiling, wondering why I had ever stopped reading. This series reminded me of what I love about books and a good story: the thrill, the sadness, the relatability of certain characters and the incredible bliss that comes with losing oneself in faraway worlds.  Sarah brought back my passion and gave me Rhysand to dream about every night.
body_html:
I remember looking at it from afar while browsing my favourite bookshop. The bright pink cover got my attention, but it wasn't until the next visit that I decided to pick it up. I rushed through the rest of the series, and in less than a week, I was left staring at my ceiling, wondering why I had ever stopped reading. This series reminded me of what I love about books and a good story: the thrill, the sadness, the relatability of certain characters and the incredible bliss that comes with losing oneself in faraway worlds.

profile.name: NathyReads

title: The first series I've fallen in love with as an adult
body: As a kid, I loved to read. I remember devouring books, staying up way too late reading "one more chapter". As an adult, I've struggled to find my groove with books. I don't know what genres to read, and I hate paying money for something I don't love.  I started ACOTAR because it was all over my TikTok feed. I borrowed all the books from our library, but I was sad every time I had to take one back. After I finished ACOSF, I knew I needed to own the set. I already wanted to reread them!  This set arrived and is everything it promised to be. The books are there, the case is a perfect fit. The problem now is I need a second set... one to read and one to leave pristine on the shelf!
body_html:
As a kid, I loved to read. I remember devouring books, staying up way too late reading "one more chapter". As an adult, I've struggled to find my groove with books. I don't know what genres to read, and I hate paying money for something I don't love.

title: Wonderful page turner
body: It took me almost halfway through the first book to get into the storyline and characters. That being said this isn’t my normal kind of read. But I gave it time and fell in love the characters and their stories, their fight for each other and their mated love. I was saddened when I read the last page because I wanted more, and I felt there was still more to be told. Characters that got cut short of their stories. I’ve re-read certain parts of each book over, because I just the way it is written and how it draws you in to how the characters feel. Beautifully written ❤️.

title: Love, love, love!

This author really immerses you in this world. There are great love stories, family tragedies and triumphs and wars fought. It's like reading a roller coaster. I am now on the last book. I am dreading finishing it because normal life is boring! Lol! Highly recommend!

title: A masterpiece in pages
body: “The Lost Bookshop”, is pure gold, a masterpiece that implements the here and now into the magical forces of the other world, a world beyond reality. What a glorious book! It’s a story that weaves together three extraordinary, charming and peculiar characters in Opaline, Martha and Henry, each striving to write their own stories or to simply find them. Either way, this book is hypnotic in its prose, it takes fictional writing to a whole new level for those who truly love books. It is an enchanting illustration in a world where books are fundamentally important, playing a pivotal role for those who choose to hold those majestic gems in their hands. When a book whispers, you listen intently to what it has to say. This book speaks volumes, it absolutely peaked my curiosity, it was definitely a page turner and it was so hard to put it down. I basically plowed through it full steam ahead, like I was under some type of hypnotic spell compelling me to read on.  Life can cause individuals to view their own lives from the sidelines, not fully engaged within the confines of what life has to offer. It goes without saying that at times we all need a Madame Bowden in our lives just to add clarification to the things we don’t yet fully comprehend, a unique wizard of sorts who has the power to unlock secrets just sitting on a shelf. This vanishing bookshop has something to offer both Martha and Henry, they just need to conjure up the confidence to read between the lines and to see what cannot be seen, the author magically intertwines Opaline’s past life with the present. It’s pure genius, a fantastical journey where something lost can eventually be found if you stay on the majestical current path.  This book adhered the conforming gender roles during Opaline’s storyline, a time when women were viewed as the weaker sex and therefore not taken seriously at all. Women had voices, but were never heard. It is noted that women writers used pseudonyms when writing back in the day, otherwise they wouldn’t get published as efficiently. Author Evie Gaughan used pseudonym Evie Woods at the author of this particular book, just to drive that point home.  This novel incorporates great classic books, manuscripts and its authors into its storyline, and I liked that Sylvia Beach and her bookshop Shakespeare & Company were included as I read and enjoyed “The Paris Bookseller”. I am compelled to mention the cover, the concept brilliantly designed. My book was on my coffee table and the lights from the television changed the colour of the leaves on the front cover, the leaves twinkled with different shades, it was magical just as its content is.  This novel will take the reader to a place of mystical magic with a dash of myth and I highly recommend it. Evie Woods lives Ireland and has created the most amazing book using her magical mind. It’s an intricately woven story with two vivid timelines that will burrow its way into your heart.  LOVED THIS BOOK!!!!!  ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

“The Lost Bookshop”, is pure gold, a masterpiece that implements the here and now into the magical forces of the other world, a world beyond reality. What a glorious book! It’s a story that weaves together three extraordinary, charming and peculiar characters in Opaline, Martha and Henry, each striving to write their own stories or to simply find them. Either way, this book is hypnotic in its prose, it takes fictional writing to a whole new level for those who truly love books. It is an enchanting illustration in a world where books are fundamentally important, playing a pivotal role for those who choose to hold those majestic gems in their hands. When a book whispers, you listen intently to what it has to say. This book speaks volumes, it absolutely peaked my curiosity, it was definitely a page turner and it was so hard to put it down. I basically plowed through it full steam ahead, like I was under some type of hypnotic spell compelling me to read on.

Life can cause individuals to view their own lives from the sidelines, not fully engaged within the confines of what life has to offer. It goes without saying that at times we all need a Madame Bowden in our lives just to add clarification to the things we don’t yet fully comprehend, a unique wizard of sorts who has the power to unlock secrets just sitting on a shelf. This vanishing bookshop has something to offer both Martha and Henry, they just need to conjure up the confidence to read between the lines and to see what cannot be seen, the author magically intertwines Opaline’s past life with the present. It’s pure genius, a fantastical journey where something lost can eventually be found if you stay on the majestical current path.

This book adhered the conforming gender roles during Opaline’s storyline, a time when women were viewed as the weaker sex and therefore not taken seriously at all. Women had voices, but were never heard. It is noted that women writers used pseudonyms when writing back in the day, otherwise they wouldn’t get published as efficiently. Author Evie Gaughan used pseudonym Evie Woods at the author of this particular book, just to drive that point home.

This novel incorporates great classic books, manuscripts and its authors into its storyline, and I liked that Sylvia Beach and her bookshop Shakespeare & Company were included as I read and enjoyed “The Paris Bookseller”. I am compelled to mention the cover, the concept brilliantly designed. My book was on my coffee table and the lights from the television changed the colour of the leaves on the front cover, the leaves twinkled with different shades, it was magical just as its content is.

This novel will take the reader to a place of mystical magic with a dash of myth and I highly recommend it. Evie Woods lives Ireland and has created the most amazing book using her magical mind. It’s an intricately woven story with two vivid timelines that will burrow its way into your heart.

LOVED THIS BOOK!!!!!

title: A mystical time traveller of a romance novel and a love of books
body: It took me a little while to get used to moving between the 1920s and the 2020s partially because of the large cast of characters in both eras. Once I got my bearings and knew where I was in time, I began to enjoy the book for all the treasures it held. This is not just another story about a bookshop, past and present, but an intimate look at Opaline, Martha, and Henry and how their stories intertwine. There is some fantasy involved and a little mysticism but though I seldom read that kind of novel, I enjoyed this one because it was essentially about books. And there are few things I enjoy more in life than a good book.

title: A beautiful story of personal growth
body: This book is an easy read and is full of insight. Monique looks for the best in others and finds the best and herself as she seeks to create the best in the world. This is a reminder that there is so much beauty in the world to be enjoyed, not just as a spectator in our travel. We can and should stop and enjoy the positive benefits of nature. We do not have to be on a vacation to disconnect from our busy lives. Nature’s energy is healing and we can find peace in a park or even in our backyard.

title: Very insightful book
body: "The 48 Laws of Power" by Robert Greene is a thought-provoking and insightful book that delves into the dynamics of power and influence. Greene presents 48 laws that have been used throughout history by powerful figures to gain and maintain control. Each law is accompanied by examples from historical events, literature, and real-life situations, making the book engaging and relevant.  One of the strengths of the book is its ability to challenge readers to think critically about power dynamics and human behavior. Greene's writing is clear and concise, making complex concepts accessible to a wide audience. Whether you are interested in history, psychology, or leadership, "The 48 Laws of Power" offers valuable insights that can be applied to various aspects of life.  However, it is important to approach the book with a critical eye, as some of the laws may be controversial or morally questionable. Readers should consider the ethical implications of applying these laws in their own lives and relationships.  Overall, "The 48 Laws of Power" is a compelling read that encourages readers to reflect on the nature of power and how it shapes our interactions with others. It is a book that will challenge your thinking and leave you with a deeper understanding of human nature.

title: A Controversial Exploration of the Dynamics of Influence and Mastery
body: The 48 Laws of Power" by Robert Greene is a controversial and thought-provoking exploration of the dynamics of power and influence. Drawing on historical examples and philosophical insights, Greene presents a comprehensive guide to understanding and mastering the art of power in all its forms.  One of the most striking aspects of "The 48 Laws of Power" is its unapologetic examination of human nature and the lengths to which individuals will go to acquire and maintain power. Greene's laws range from the strategic and cunning to the ruthless and manipulative, offering readers a glimpse into the darker aspects of human behavior.  Central to Greene's philosophy is the idea that power is a fundamental aspect of human society, and those who understand its dynamics are better equipped to navigate the complexities of social and professional life. Through his laws, he offers practical advice on how to wield power effectively, whether in personal relationships, business dealings, or political arenas.  Moreover, "The 48 Laws of Power" is filled with compelling anecdotes and historical examples that illustrate each law in action. From the cunning tactics of Machiavelli to the strategic maneuvers of Napoleon, Greene draws on a wide range of sources to demonstrate the timeless principles of power and influence.  However, it's important to note that some readers may find Greene's approach to be Machiavellian or morally dubious. While the book offers valuable insights into human psychology and social dynamics, some of the tactics described may be seen as manipulative or unethical. As such, readers should approach the text with a critical eye and consider the implications of applying its principles in their own lives.  In conclusion, "The 48 Laws of Power" is a provocative and compelling read that offers valuable insights into the nature of power and influence. Whether viewed as a Machiavellian handbook or a pragmatic guide to success, Greene's laws provide a fascinating glimpse into the dynamics of human behavior and the pursuit of power.

title: great book and really got my mind in the game
body: The "48 Laws of Power" by Robert Greene is an extraordinary book that left me spellbound from the very first page. It is a captivating and enlightening masterpiece that truly got my mind in the game. With its profound insights and strategic wisdom, this book has the potential to transform the way you perceive power dynamics in various aspects of life.  Greene's meticulous exploration of power, illustrated through historical anecdotes and examples, is nothing short of brilliant. Each of the 48 laws presented in the book offers invaluable guidance on how to navigate the complex terrain of power with cunning and finesse. From understanding the importance of timing to mastering the art of deception, this book provides an intricate roadmap to achieving personal and professional success.  What sets this book apart is its ability to delve deep into the human psyche, unraveling the intricacies of power struggles and unveiling the underlying motivations behind human behavior. The author's analysis of historical figures and their strategies serves as a thought-provoking reflection on the nature of power and its pervasive presence in our lives.  Moreover, "48 Laws of Power" serves as an awakening for readers, prompting them to question their own approaches to power and encouraging them to develop a more nuanced understanding of its dynamics. It challenges conventional beliefs and provides alternative perspectives, allowing readers to broaden their horizons and become more astute observers of the power dynamics around them.  The book's engaging writing style, coupled with its wealth of examples and stories, makes it an enjoyable and compelling read. Each law is presented concisely, yet profoundly, allowing readers to absorb and internalize the lessons effectively.  In conclusion, "48 Laws of Power" is a great book that captivates and empowers its readers. It is a potent tool that opens doors to a world of strategic thinking, enhancing one's ability to navigate power dynamics successfully. Whether you're a business professional, an aspiring leader, or simply an individual looking to gain a deeper understanding of human interactions, this book is an invaluable resource that will leave you motivated, inspired, and equipped with a newfound sense of empowerment.

title: Unlock the Secrets of Sovereignty with 'The 48 Laws of Power': The Magnum Opus of Mastery
body: In the grand tapestry of human history, where the ebb and flow of power shapes the destiny of nations and individuals alike, there exists a timeless tome that stands as a beacon of wisdom and enlightenment: "The 48 Laws of Power" by Robert Greene. With its profound insights, timeless principles, and unyielding guidance, this magnum opus of mastery promises to illuminate the path to sovereignty and unlock the secrets of influence and authority for those bold enough to heed its teachings.  Crafted with the meticulous precision of a master strategist, "The 48 Laws of Power" is more than just a book – it is a blueprint for success in the ever-shifting landscape of human interaction and ambition. Drawing from centuries of history, philosophy, and psychology, Robert Greene distills the essence of power into 48 laws, each a potent weapon in the arsenal of those who seek to rise above the fray and claim their rightful place in the annals of greatness.  From the art of deception to the mastery of persuasion, "The 48 Laws of Power" leaves no stone unturned in its quest to unveil the secrets of influence and dominance. Whether you're navigating the treacherous waters of politics and diplomacy or charting your course through the cutthroat world of business and entrepreneurship, this timeless tome provides the tools and strategies you need to thrive in any environment and emerge victorious in every endeavor.  But perhaps the true magic of "The 48 Laws of Power" lies in its ability to awaken the latent potential within each of us – to inspire greatness, cultivate ambition, and unleash the full force of our inner sovereignty upon the world. With its profound insights and practical wisdom, it empowers us to transcend the limitations of our circumstances and seize control of our destiny, forging our own path to greatness with courage, conviction, and unyielding determination.  So, as you embark on your journey to mastery and self-mastery, let "The 48 Laws of Power" be your guide and companion. With its timeless wisdom and unwavering guidance, it promises to illuminate the path to sovereignty and unlock the secrets of influence and authority that lie dormant within us all. With "The 48 Laws of Power" as your ally, the world becomes your playground, and the pursuit of greatness becomes a triumph of the human spirit.

profile.name: Leigh

title: Heart-breaking, emotional and thought-provoking!
body: This is my first read by this author and I was impressed with the heart-breaking, emotional and, apparently, real-life story of two couples both trying to have a family through the IVF process in Australia. There is a devastating conundrum within the Empona Clinic which leads to an eventual court case, leaving readers struggling with their loyalties to both couples, and I actually felt empathy towards the female judge. Although I liked both couples - none of them was perfect, with all of them showing deception in various ways. Nick and Priya who were separated during a good part of the story became reunited prior to the court case, but that situation didn't seem to be used greatly in deciding the case one way or another.  I gave this book a 4-star because it certainly held my interest, it was a roller-coaster of a story, but I felt there were full chapters in the story which seemed somewhat redundant, e.g. the story of Martin and Leslie Crawford, the various trips by Dr. Ashley Li and by Grace and Dan near the end and some of the details on Priya's life while living alone. I know some of it is to flush out the characters' personalities a bit but I wanted to get on with the story and come to a satisfactory ending. I did have a question that I would like to ask the author about a certain little blond haired girl, but I don't want to put in spoilers. I also thought the story didn't fully present the terrible emotional trauma that is experienced in any pregnancy loss, whether through normal processes or IVF processes, and felt that the author didn't have enough experience or didn't do enough interviewing to get the full and deep emotional devastion that is felt.  Overall, an interesting read that kept me up late at night reading, gave me some thought-provoking periods, some tears and even a smile from time to time.

profile.name: Emma

title: Must Read!
body: I really loved this novel. I know The Mothers is based on real life IVF mix-ups.. but I still find the whole premise completely mind blowing. After recently having a baby myself, I literally cannot imagine the situation Priya & Grace find themselves in. To be told your embryo was implanted in another woman’s uterus? Or to be told the baby you carried for 9 months and gave birth to wasn’t yours? No.. I can’t fathom either situation. It’s heartbreaking for both women.  The situation is obviously very complex, but I particularly enjoyed the cultural component that further complicated the situation Priya and Grace found themselves in. It had me evaluating just how important culture is when raising children. I don’t want to give away too many details, but I definitely found myself emotionally invested in the outcome.

title: Excellent Book.... a must read for any woman
body: This book has a lot of wonderful information to help a woman navigate through peri and full on menopause. It has many different options for different situations. Explains risks of HRT very well... some of the risks, for example, are far outweighed by the positives which the old studies never mentioned. Also gives info on various kinds of HRT should you choose to go that route. This is a guidebook to work through with your doctor to determine what is good for you. Helps you ask the right questions, and make sure you have the right tests completed to properly assess risk of HRT if that is the chosen path.

profile.name: MichMel

title: This book has saved me! Don’t hesitate, purchase this now!
body: The New Menopause is a game changer! I have been suffering for many years and been run through more CT’s, MRI’s, x-rays and blood tests - you name it! ALL coming back normal! I honestly thought I was very ill. Yes, I had hot flashes that’s normal, but I have all the other issues! My body kills me (including a frozen shoulder) and now being informed, I feel like there’s a light at the end of the tunnel and it’s not all in my head, as I’ve been told. I am 54 and was very physically fit and worked out all the time. I cannot now. A walk is even difficult on my joints. I am so grateful to Mary Claire and many of her colleagues for smashing the myths of menopause. An excellent personal read that informs and educates about solutions! Thank you thank you thank you!

profile.name: alana

title: Really very informative
body: Unfortunately, many of the referred to resources are very USA based (only makes sense considering she is located there), but over all the book is very well written, and you really do get that you are NOT alone.  Sadly, I am older and more than likely missed the window of opportunity to even start MHT, as far as the potential health benefits of someone who starts during per-menopause, or right after they 'go through the change', such as how estrogen loss is so related to many changes a woman who is post menopausal, such as Alzheimer, osteoporosis, muscle loss, weight gain and its redistribution on your body, etc. I over the last few years have had many bad problems in regard to some of the areas of concern that starting MHT may have helped prevent. But again, even if I start now, it is too late to reap all the Potential benefits going on MHT can give. This is a very informative book that would be beneficial to any woman who is just starting their journey with per-menopause and/or menopause just starting. Particularly if you are in the USA as many of the referred website access really is USA based.  Regardless, women from all over the world can benefit from learning more on the latest in research regarding menopause and the decision to start or NOT to start MHT.  I recommend this book for any of these women and or their spouses if they so choose to read this book

title: A must read at least after the age of 35
body: I’ve been in peri menopause since I was 42; but I can only say this now, because I didn’t have a clue until 3 months ago. I’ve been in pain for more than 7 years and no doctor could help me. I’m 49 now, still dealing with menopause symptoms every day, but thanks to Mary Claire’s book, I not only have the necessary tool kit to deal with it all but also I built a good knowledge to stand grounds with doctors. I have read “woman on fire” from Sheila de Liz prior to reading this book, but this one beats it with an exhaustive view on symptoms and appropriate strategies to deal with them in great details. A god’s sent gift to all women over 35…. It is not too early to read it! Go get it, read it and keep it throughout your journey. Thanks Mary Claire!!

profile.name: Agr8scot

title: An Indispensable Resource!
body: "The New Menopause: Navigating Your Path Through Hormonal Change with Purpose, Power" is an insightful and empowering guidebook that sheds light on a topic often shrouded in mystery and misunderstanding. The author's comprehensive approach to navigating menopause is both informative and eye-opening, providing readers with valuable insights into the physical, emotional, and psychological aspects of this natural transition. Through a combination of research-backed information and personal anecdotes, the book offers practical advice and strategies for managing symptoms, embracing change, and reclaiming control over one's health and well-being. What sets this book apart is its emphasis on empowerment and purpose, encouraging women to approach menopause as a time of growth, transformation, and renewed vitality. Overall, "The New Menopause" is an indispensable resource for women seeking to navigate this stage of life with confidence, purpose, and power.

title: A must have !!!! ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
body: The media could not be loaded. If you are woman you NEED this book. If you are any age and want to know what life will be like starting at 35- 55 years old and want to know what’s going to happen to your body and not be clueless and left lost by the health care world this is your book. This is everything you need to know and what to do about it! I’ve recommended this book to 2.5k women!!! It’s easy to read, straight to the point. Anyone can read and understand it. It will give you peace of mind and help you realize what will happen or is happening is normal. All the answers are in this book! No women should go without this book as a map of peri menopause and menopause. Really this book should be read prior to 35 years old and to all young women so they have an idea and help for what’s to come. ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

profile.name: Emma

title: Must buy for your Dad!!
body: Must buy these books for your parents! I have been on my own since age 16 when my parents left for the Middle East and lived overseas 19 years. And I honestly don't know a whole lot about my parents or their history. My dad is now 86 (this is my stepdad) and my mom is 84. I bought one book for each and my dad has told me he has already started completing it. They live in the Northwest and I'm in Washington, DC and they won't let the kids come home to visit because of the Coronavirus so I can't be there to fill this book out asking him questions and really didn't expect him to complete it but apparently he is and I am so thrilled! I can't wait to get it back from him and my mom. For $9, This book is fun for my dad to fill out with my mom as they reminisce over the questions and it will be something I will treasure for the rest of my days. When I receive it I'm going to print photocopy every page to send a set to my brothers and sister. On Facebook they are promoting something called my story for about a $100. This is fabulous and I highly recommend you buy it as well and perhaps if you are a new dad or a new mom, buy the books yourself so that you can pass this information on to your own children as they grow up, because we never know what tomorrow will bring.

profile.name: Jamie

title: Great purchase!
body: Great purchase! I’m so happy with this. I call my 92 year old dad every night and he after talking about the weather, what he had for dinner, what he did during the day, and what are you watched on TV we are out of things to talk about. Now most nights I will say “do you want to do the book?” And he will say “yes” or” a short one.” This really gets him thinking and remembering stories to share from the past. Instead of sending it to him to fill out, which I knew he would probably never do, it works out perfectly for me to keep the book and ask him questions over the phone. I bring it with me when I go to visit him and we will sometimes do a question after dinner. Just about the only reason why I can get him to turn off the TV for a few minutes!

profile.name: Paulette Zak

title: Great way to bond
body: This was so cool. I got one for my Dad, and I got the Mom version for my Mom. Knowing my Mom way better, it was a fun way to get some more details in writing. But for my Dad, it was totally different. Without divulging too much information, my parents divorced over twenty years ago, and my Dad and I have stayed close, and he's always been there for me, but a lot of times in a way that I felt was superficial, having a few meaningful conversations in my adult life, but not many. This book opened the door for him to share much more personal information about his life, his feelings, and his experiences growing up. It made me feel a lot closer to him, and started some new dialogue on similarities I had no idea existed between us. It made who I am make more sense, and cast my Dad in a new light. Don't hesitate to purchase this book, regardless of your relationship with your parent. The worst it can do is expose your political differences, the best, is open up dialogue that brings you closer than ever before, or at least give you a better understanding of who your parent is outside of being your parent.

profile.name: Craft1

title: Goes Too Far Back
body: I truly want to learn more about my dad, but this journal was not the way to go for me. The first few questions ask things like, "What was your length and weight at birth? What were your first words? ......What were you like as a toddler?". Not only do these questions lack substance, but they also require Dad to have second hand information from his parents. The assumption there is that he had involved, caring parents. That is a pretty huge assumption, especially for a person of his generation. I'm afraid giving him this journal would just make him sad.

profile.name: NP21

title: Great Workbooks! Will be purchasing them every summer!
body: I have 3 boys that need things to do during the summer to keep the skills they learned at school in their heads. This summer I bought Grade K-1, 4-5, and 7-8 to torture them with!  I loved the variety of activities so that they weren't getting bogged down with math everyday. They were entertaining enough that the kids didn't get too bored but educational enough that they had to do some serious thinking. The pages were entertaining with quick facts to read and some drawings. I love that they incorporated physical fitness by having them do some jumping jacks or other quick exercise routine.  There were only a couple issues I had with the workbooks...  Some of the answers in the answer key were wrong! Not too big of a deal for the younger kids but when it comes to advanced Algebra, I need something reliable telling me if my sons answers are right!  The workbooks also don't do a lot of explaining how to do things because it assumes you've already learned that skill and are just brushing up. But that worked out OK since my kids learned how to research questions online, which is an ability you have to be good at nowadays.  There are more pages then there were summer vacation days for my kids. Which isn't too big of a deal for me but a WAY big deal for the kids who had to do, *gasp* 2 pages a day!  Overall this is a great workbook that I will be using every summer!
