date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2024
profile.name: Danielle Ouellette

title: Cinnamon Roll Hero. Lovable Heroine. Crappy Family
body: I discovered Abby's work a few months ago and read everything she wrote as soon as possible. This is another one of those books that will tug at your heartstrings. In the past, it was usually between the two main characters. What's different in this love story is that the heartache is caused by external forces—family. Right person, wrong time and crappy family.  Abby does an excellent job of making both Justin and Emma REALLY LIKABLE because Emma's mom (Amber, yes the same mom from A Part of Your World) is SUPER UNLIKABLE. Having personally dealt with someone whose mom was neglectful, but watching the person I love wait for crumbs of affection hit hard for me. I felt like both Justin and Emma's best friend Maddie...WHY EMMA WHY?! Justin's mom isn't a terrible person. She's just a mom who was drowning in grief who didn't reach out to anyone and is paying the price for her bad behavior. This leaves Justin in a tough position to be the primary guardian for his younger siblings.  I highly recommend this book if you're looking for all the swooning words and gushy feelings with low 🌶. The flirty banter is well-written, Justin is the most EXTRA book-boyfriend, and cameos from other books were fun.

profile.name: D

title: Abby did it…again
body: I always forget how much I love Abby Jimenez books. The characters are human and they always make me cry. Just for the summer is everything…a great romance story between a man and a woman, a woman and her best friend. I love that she does not demonize anyone. And the cameos from other characters I have loved in her other books are golden and definitely not cliche. Worth a read…make time because you won’t want to put the book down.

profile.name: ASEEZAT S. ARAOYE

title: New all time favorite romance!
body: ‘just for the summer’ by abby jimenez came to me at the perfect time - it was an immaculate romance that I read on my kindle during some hard nights of sickness and insomnia.  why I loved it so much: 🧡 the character growth was SO good 🩷 it was emotional and at times dark, but not to the detriment of the love story - it made the HEA all the more worthwhile 🧡 the hero was cinnabun golden retriever goodness, but didn’t feel *too* perfect + he was a silly goose which was cute 🩷 loved the use of setting (the island) that corresponded with our heroine and her arc (IYKYK) 🧡 all the connections with ‘part of your world’ and ‘yours truly’ 🩷 overall plot was just really fun and unique - loved that the characters met on a Reddit thread!  If I could give this book 10 stars I would - it is a contender for my favorite book of the year!
body_html:
‘just for the summer’ by abby jimenez came to me at the perfect time - it was an immaculate romance that I read on my kindle during some hard nights of sickness and insomnia.

why I loved it so much:
🧡 the character growth was SO good
🩷 it was emotional and at times dark, but not to the detriment of the love story - it made the HEA all the more worthwhile
🧡 the hero was cinnabun golden retriever goodness, but didn’t feel *too* perfect + he was a silly goose which was cute
🩷 loved the use of setting (the island) that corresponded with our heroine and her arc (IYKYK)
🧡 all the connections with ‘part of your world’ and ‘yours truly’
🩷 overall plot was just really fun and unique - loved that the characters met on a Reddit thread!

If I could give this book 10 stars I would - it is a contender for my favorite book of the year!

profile.name: Amazon Customer

title: Emotional and heartwarming
body: One of the things I love most about all of Abby’s books is the depth of her characters. She writes such wonderfully complex and relatable characters. This book is no exception.  Emma is tough, smart, understanding and empathetic. Given her childhood, that’s an amazing testament to her character. Justin is reliable, steadfast, compassionate, and generous. He’s the definition of if he wanted to he would.  Watching their relationship unfold in the pages of this book was both humorous and heartbreaking. Emma has lived through childhood trauma and neglect. Justin is dealing with losses of his own.  Watching Justin step up for his family and Emma learn to set boundaries and deal with her trauma in a healthy way is beautifully written. Abby takes you on an emotional journey and handles difficult topics with compassion and understanding.
body_html:
One of the things I love most about all of Abby’s books is the depth of her characters. She writes such wonderfully complex and relatable characters. This book is no exception.

Watching their relationship unfold in the pages of this book was both humorous and heartbreaking. Emma has lived through childhood trauma and neglect. Justin is dealing with losses of his own.

Watching Justin step up for his family and Emma learn to set boundaries and deal with her trauma in a healthy way is beautifully written. Abby takes you on an emotional journey and handles difficult topics with compassion and understanding.

title: I would give it 6 stars if I could!
body: Just for the Summer is a wonderful novel with an actual plot, unlike most romcoms I've read. It feels mature and real, well-written, and will definitely pull at your heart strings and have you laughing at various points along the way. It's sweet and sexy, gritty and raw, and cute and believable. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

profile.name: Kristie N Davis

title: Well Written but Heavy
body: There was a lot to like here: fun premise, great writing, and a wonderful golden retriever type book boyfriend  However, this story tackles some really heavy topics such as abandonment, child neglect, abuse, and mental illness, and overall left me feeling a bit down. I also felt like the author went really hard during the 3rd act, but then tied everything up too easily? Almost like using short term therapy as a magic wand.  Overall, this is a great story that I would recommend with some content warnings ⚠️ but probably would not read again.
body_html:
There was a lot to like here: fun premise, great writing, and a wonderful golden retriever type book boyfriend

However, this story tackles some really heavy topics such as abandonment, child neglect, abuse, and mental illness, and overall left me feeling a bit down. I also felt like the author went really hard during the 3rd act, but then tied everything up too easily? Almost like using short term therapy as a magic wand.

Overall, this is a great story that I would recommend with some content warnings ⚠️ but probably would not read again.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2024
profile.name: Sdy

title: Psychologically astute romance
body: I am a huge fan of Abby Jimenez. I don't think I've ever given any of her books less than 5 stars. This one is no different. I think one of the things I love so much about her writing is how complex her characters are, how truly believable. I also very much appreciate how psychologically minded she is. It makes her characters and stories richer, and this particular book is no exception. In fact, it's that particular quality that really makes this book great. I think many people will be able to relate to the heroine in this story on some level and that's a great gift--the empathy the writer shows to her characters and in this way also her readers. The other great thing is that her heroes are emotionally healthy, respectful men. She advocates for women to find that type of partner, and what a great example that is for readers. This is such a heart-warming, slow burn romance. I highly recommend it.

profile.name: JoanMCR

title: Didn't love it, but I still liked it.
body: I love Abby Jimenez as she is one of my favorite authors. One thing I do admire about Abby Jimenez's writing is the way she incorporates important issues and themes into her stories and makes them flow. This one felt a little too much. The story seemed all over the place at times, with many things happening at once. The romance between Justin and Emma was not as strong for me. Sometimes their relationship felt more like a friendship and other times more romantic. I will say though the dates were pretty cute, the moments between Justin’s siblings and Emma was sweet, and the fact that they supported each other who are dealing with past trauma and experiences.  I liked Justin as the main male character. He is portrayed as strong, caring, devoted to the people he loves, and having a great sense of humor. Emma was an okay main female character. I did enjoy the other characters such as Emma's best friend, Maddy, and Justin's siblings and friends. I was stuck on whether to rate this a 3.5 or 4. I went with a solid four stars.  ☆ 4 stars

profile.name: Perla

title: I’m obsessed. Again.
body: Abby Jimenez has quickly become one of my fave authors, especially after “Yours Truly”, and most DEFINITELY after this read. She has a way of writing such raw characters that I can relate to and I feel like I am feeling what they’re feeling so deeply. Her way of incorporating mental health and other human difficulties in her stories is breathtaking. Heartbreaking, yes, but genius. It shines light, doesn’t romanticise or use it as shock value. It’s informative. It tells a story. A story that so many in the world can relate to. Abby, thank you for creating two stories (that I’ve read so far) that have completely and utterly captured my heart. I can’t wait to read more of your work.  Also, long live the toilet king, and I’m sure Brad is not that ugly.  Yours, for longer than the summer, Alex, xoxo

profile.name: Sasha

title: This book is everything!
body: Wow! This was my first book by Abby Jimenez & it did not disappoint! I fell in love with the characters from the very beginning, the banter was perfect, & the storyline took me on a journey I wasn't expecting!  This is a book about two people who believe they have "curses" when it comes to dating. This leads them to "fake date" one another in attempts to break the curse.  For me, the characters felt like real life people. The main characters specifically, Emma & Justin, both had very believable past & current issues that affect their day to day.  Abby truly did an amazing job with her representation of Emma's childhood trauma that carried over into her adult life. I felt for Emma so much throughout the book.  I highly recommend this book & can't wait to read more from this author!!!

Wow! This was my first book by Abby Jimenez & it did not disappoint! I fell in love with the characters from the very beginning, the banter was perfect, & the storyline took me on a journey I wasn't expecting!

For me, the characters felt like real life people. The main characters specifically, Emma & Justin, both had very believable past & current issues that affect their day to day.

Abby truly did an amazing job with her representation of Emma's childhood trauma that carried over into her adult life. I felt for Emma so much throughout the book.

I highly recommend this book & can't wait to read more from this author!!!

profile.name: Trista T

title: best read of the year
body: I normally don’t leave reviews even for five stars unless it’s something special. And this book is very special. I thought it was a rom com, silly little summer book, but halfway through it, I was crying with these beautiful characters and their story. This is my first Abby Jimenez book but it won’t be the last. This book has left an indelible mark on my heart and it’s a story I will never forget and will re-read it many times. Recommend it to everyone, but there may be some triggers for abandonment, child neglect and other sensitive topics, so I know it’s not for everyone. And even though I had a very happy childhood, I could relate to feeling small. Lovely lovely lovely!

profile.name: DJY

title: This book
body: You might think a book called JUST FOR THE SUMMER is the next good beach read romance, and it is if you like to alternate between laughing out loud and crying while you are reading on the beach.  This is a unique story that is heart tugging in so many ways. The premise of the book has the two deciding to meet to break their mutual curse by dating then breaking up to find their soulmate, who will be their next partner.  The twists come in the form of obstacles, relived traumas, and almost insurmountable burdens. I loved being along for this ride. It’s really an excellent book.

title: Fun book with nice picture about a father and son doing things together
body: This is a nice book to get. It is a fairly large size so if you are reading it to someone they will have no problem seeing it. It has some nice art that shows nice expressions on the characters (bears) faces, while telling a nice story.  The story itself is cute. It is about a father and son spending time together doing activities while the son learns about the world and become confident and independent. Without spoiling it, it also works really well as a nighttime book. Our kiddos have asked for it to be put into our nighttime rotation.  Overall, a very solid addition to our book collection at a very reasonable price. I like it!

profile.name: Amazon Customer

title: My son's favorite book (19 months old)
body: We've bought this book repeatedly. My son originally had it in hardcover and ripped one of the pages pretty badly when he was a few months old. We switched to the board book version, and it's been awesome.  1) Teething. My kid loves to chomp on board books. He does end up eating some of the paper and that's less than ideal, but it really seems to soothe his teething pain more than his plastic and wood teethers.  2) The actual story has good flow. The wording is slightly different ("Just be quick" v. "Don't be scared" when Daddy bear advises him about the bees) in this version compared to the full version and the ending is simpler (doesn't have the part about the den, if you're familiar).  My son LOVES the bees in this book and does pretend bee stings whenever he sees them on the page. He also likes to mime patting himself on the head like Daddy Bear does to Little Bear in the story.
body_html:
We've bought this book repeatedly. My son originally had it in hardcover and ripped one of the pages pretty badly when he was a few months old. We switched to the board book version, and it's been awesome.

1) Teething. My kid loves to chomp on board books. He does end up eating some of the paper and that's less than ideal, but it really seems to soothe his teething pain more than his plastic and wood teethers.

2) The actual story has good flow. The wording is slightly different ("Just be quick" v. "Don't be scared" when Daddy bear advises him about the bees) in this version compared to the full version and the ending is simpler (doesn't have the part about the den, if you're familiar).

My son LOVES the bees in this book and does pretend bee stings whenever he sees them on the page. He also likes to mime patting himself on the head like Daddy Bear does to Little Bear in the story.

title: It's an ok book, but looks very different from what is pictured
body: Look at the recent pictures of reviewers, the bright green polka dot cover is what you will probably get, not what's advertised on the listing. Very weird choice for sure, no clue why they would change it - original looked so nice) Also, the picture quality is a bit questionable, seems it has gone down from the original. The writing is also very repetitive - you will read Daddy Bear and Little Bear at least 3 times on each page. These are the reasons I returned the book.  Pros: the book is overall an ok book, pictures are quite cute - illustrator did a really good job for sure, but I found other I love you Daddy and Mommy books that are so much better.

profile.name: Cristina

title: Good summer prep book 📚
body: ### **Review: Summer Bridge Activities 5th to 6th Grade Workbooks**  As a parent who’s keen on keeping my child engaged and learning over the summer, I was thrilled to find the *Summer Bridge Activities 5th to 6th Grade Workbooks*. This comprehensive workbook set has been a fantastic tool for preventing the dreaded summer slide and ensuring my child is prepared for the upcoming school year. Here’s why I love it:  #### **Content and Coverage** The workbook covers an impressive range of subjects—Math, Reading Comprehension, Writing, Science, Social Studies, and even Fitness. Each section is thoughtfully designed to reinforce concepts from 5th grade and gradually introduce 6th-grade material. My child has particularly enjoyed the reading comprehension and writing activities, which are engaging and just challenging enough to keep her interested without causing frustration. The inclusion of fitness activities is a fun bonus, promoting physical activity alongside academic work.  #### **Structure and Organization** The workbook is divided into daily activities, which makes it easy to manage and track progress. Each day’s work is laid out clearly, with a mix of subjects to keep things interesting. I love that it doesn’t feel overwhelming; the bite-sized chunks are perfect for summer when kids want to balance learning with fun. The progress tracking stickers have been a hit with my daughter, giving her a sense of accomplishment as she completes each day’s activities.  #### **Educational Value** The educational value of this workbook is outstanding. It does a great job of reinforcing key skills while introducing new concepts in a way that’s accessible and engaging. The math problems are varied and practical, covering everything from basic arithmetic to introductory geometry and fractions. The reading passages are diverse and interesting, promoting critical thinking and comprehension. The science and social studies sections are well-rounded, offering a broad spectrum of topics that are both informative and intriguing.  #### **Flash Cards** The inclusion of flash cards is a fantastic addition. They’ve been great for quick reviews and practice, especially for math facts and vocabulary. My child enjoys the interactive aspect of using the flash cards, and they’ve been a useful tool for reinforcing what she’s learned in the workbook. They’re also convenient for on-the-go learning, making it easy to keep up with studies during car rides or while waiting for appointments.  #### **Ease of Use** One of the best things about this workbook is how user-friendly it is. The instructions are clear, and the layout is intuitive, making it easy for kids to work independently. As a parent, I appreciate the answer key in the back, which makes it simple to check work and provide feedback. The workbook also includes tips and strategies for parents, which have been helpful in guiding my child’s learning.  #### **Pros:** - **Comprehensive Coverage:** Includes a wide range of subjects, ensuring a well-rounded review. - **Daily Structure:** Organized into manageable daily tasks that prevent overwhelm. - **Engaging Content:** Keeps kids interested with diverse activities and topics. - **Flash Cards Included:** Great for quick review and reinforcing key concepts. - **Easy to Use:** Clear instructions and layout promote independent work.  #### **Cons:** - **Paper Quality:** The pages could be a bit thicker to prevent bleed-through with markers. - **Limited Summer Themes:** More summer-themed activities could make it feel more seasonal.  #### **Conclusion** Overall, the *Summer Bridge Activities 5th to 6th Grade Workbooks* are a fantastic resource for any parent looking to keep their child’s brain active and engaged over the summer. The mix of subjects, engaging activities, and clear structure make it a hit in our household. My daughter has enjoyed using it, and I’ve seen a noticeable improvement in her readiness for the next school year. I highly recommend this workbook for any parent wanting to combine learning with fun over the summer.  This workbook has made our summer learning routine enjoyable and effective, and I’m confident it will be a great asset for your child as well!
body_html:
### **Review: Summer Bridge Activities 5th to 6th Grade Workbooks**

As a parent who’s keen on keeping my child engaged and learning over the summer, I was thrilled to find the *Summer Bridge Activities 5th to 6th Grade Workbooks*. This comprehensive workbook set has been a fantastic tool for preventing the dreaded summer slide and ensuring my child is prepared for the upcoming school year. Here’s why I love it:

#### **Content and Coverage**
The workbook covers an impressive range of subjects—Math, Reading Comprehension, Writing, Science, Social Studies, and even Fitness. Each section is thoughtfully designed to reinforce concepts from 5th grade and gradually introduce 6th-grade material. My child has particularly enjoyed the reading comprehension and writing activities, which are engaging and just challenging enough to keep her interested without causing frustration. The inclusion of fitness activities is a fun bonus, promoting physical activity alongside academic work.

#### **Structure and Organization**
The workbook is divided into daily activities, which makes it easy to manage and track progress. Each day’s work is laid out clearly, with a mix of subjects to keep things interesting. I love that it doesn’t feel overwhelming; the bite-sized chunks are perfect for summer when kids want to balance learning with fun. The progress tracking stickers have been a hit with my daughter, giving her a sense of accomplishment as she completes each day’s activities.

#### **Educational Value**
The educational value of this workbook is outstanding. It does a great job of reinforcing key skills while introducing new concepts in a way that’s accessible and engaging. The math problems are varied and practical, covering everything from basic arithmetic to introductory geometry and fractions. The reading passages are diverse and interesting, promoting critical thinking and comprehension. The science and social studies sections are well-rounded, offering a broad spectrum of topics that are both informative and intriguing.

#### **Flash Cards**
The inclusion of flash cards is a fantastic addition. They’ve been great for quick reviews and practice, especially for math facts and vocabulary. My child enjoys the interactive aspect of using the flash cards, and they’ve been a useful tool for reinforcing what she’s learned in the workbook. They’re also convenient for on-the-go learning, making it easy to keep up with studies during car rides or while waiting for appointments.

#### **Ease of Use**
One of the best things about this workbook is how user-friendly it is. The instructions are clear, and the layout is intuitive, making it easy for kids to work independently. As a parent, I appreciate the answer key in the back, which makes it simple to check work and provide feedback. The workbook also includes tips and strategies for parents, which have been helpful in guiding my child’s learning.

#### **Pros:**
- **Comprehensive Coverage:** Includes a wide range of subjects, ensuring a well-rounded review.
- **Daily Structure:** Organized into manageable daily tasks that prevent overwhelm.
- **Engaging Content:** Keeps kids interested with diverse activities and topics.
- **Flash Cards Included:** Great for quick review and reinforcing key concepts.
- **Easy to Use:** Clear instructions and layout promote independent work.

#### **Cons:**
- **Paper Quality:** The pages could be a bit thicker to prevent bleed-through with markers.
- **Limited Summer Themes:** More summer-themed activities could make it feel more seasonal.

#### **Conclusion**
Overall, the *Summer Bridge Activities 5th to 6th Grade Workbooks* are a fantastic resource for any parent looking to keep their child’s brain active and engaged over the summer. The mix of subjects, engaging activities, and clear structure make it a hit in our household. My daughter has enjoyed using it, and I’ve seen a noticeable improvement in her readiness for the next school year. I highly recommend this workbook for any parent wanting to combine learning with fun over the summer.

This workbook has made our summer learning routine enjoyable and effective, and I’m confident it will be a great asset for your child as well!

profile.name: Dalia

title: Great Way To Keep The Skills Fresh Over The Summer!
body: This is a great activity book to help keep your child stay mentally active when out of school for the summer. Over the years we have purchased a few different Summer Bridge books for our daughter. These books are not meant to be a full school curriculum, but instead a way to keep children mentally active during the summer break. Each summer we do our best to keep skills active and minimize the loss during the extended break. While we sometimes mix in other work to help her to increase skills, we are more worried about the atrophy that happens when not in school. It can be tough returning to school after 3 months without any schoolwork and we try to help her keep topics fresh without filling her summer with full days of 'school' work.  As with other books in this series, this is a solid mix of skills with some being easy and others more of stretch. The difficulty level will likely depend on the schooling your child got during the academic year. I suspect most kids heading into sixth grade will find much of the work in this book at least a strong refresher and potentially give them a nudge in some areas. The exercises are organized to be a roughly 15 minute daily regime but you may decide to enhance it with other work if your child has areas that need more attention (i.e., add in more math or spelling activities). This book is not deficient in an area, we just occasionally add a little extra for topics that we feel could use a bit more work while still keeping the total workload to around 45-60 minutes per day. The Summer Bridge Activities book is a constant though with at least one page used almost every day and the other work rotated.

title: Comprehensive practice good for review!
body: As a Special Education Teacher I love to review workbooks! For students who need extra help, it would be a good resource to use working one on one. This one was selected and purchased for our 10 almost 11 year old son going into 6th grade gifted class. He is using it as a review over the summer to reinforce math and ELA skills. Has opportunities to rewrite sentences, create engaging paragraphs using sentence stems. Algebra, order of operations and practice with all operations. Simple directions. Challenges the student to read the instructions/directions and not just give an answer. Very good for independent practice. Hope this helps. Highly recommend! Blessings.

title: Don't buy it! Missing pages and answer key!
body: I love these books and buy them to keep my daughter's skills up during the summer. I'm terribly disappointed this time at receiving a book that is missing pages and the answer key. It was brand new and sent to me by Amazon and my return window has closed so I just have to go ahead and recycle it. You can see in the picture that I took that the last page of the book I have that it ends on page 118 and according to the index, the Answer key is on page 145. The flashcards per picture #2 are supposed to follow the Answer key after page 145. I am missing pages 119 through 145. Be warned mamas, don't buy this book for your kids! You'll be spending your summer manually figuring out all the answers for them in order to grade it.

profile.name: Kalah

title: Wonderful blend of subjects in a manageable chunk for each day
body: As a parent and educator, I love the blend of disciplines and subjects within this summer workbook. In addition to this version, I bought my son also the version for going into third grade. In both grade levels, the pages are broken into two sections of manageable activities. It is the perfect mix of all levels of questions – from fact regurgitation to intuitive leaps and analysis at an age appropriate level. I find that it builds confidence in my children because of how it allows them to focus on subjects that are strengths as well as areas they find more difficult. There were a few activities so far that relied on a different type of explanation or learning style than my kids were used to, but I appreciated the chance to help them understand those areas.  The two pages per day are easy for both children to finish in 10 to 15 minutes, and they enjoy the extra activities in the back. We have tried different publishers of summer workbooks in the past, and these Summer Bridge activity workbooks are much better. Not only are they easy to follow according to days and months, but they also are very colorful with fun pictures throughout.  This is such a great way to keep the mind sharp over the summer!

I like this book enough that I already bought the one for next year.

profile.name: Sparrow

title: Worthwhile workbook
body: This is a good tool to keep the rust off the gears of bridging to the next grade. The only criticism I have is that one doesn't always have the necessary resources to complete the task, for example, my son doesn't have wifi access on a portable device to do the super exciting longitude latitude coordinates discoveries. (We waited until we got home to the computer for him to do that assignment.) But the assignments are very doable with 3 sections of 2 pages of assignments per day which helps pace and keep the interest. There are also physical breaks (do 30 jumping jacks) at the end of a section. Though the answers are available in the back (which I tear out and keep with me) there are not many examples shown which was tough on my lil guy for math. All in all I feel this is a worthwhile purchase to assist keeping the mindset of schoolwork glowing.

title: Boring and takes way too long

The fractions were very complex, they could have been a lot simpler, and there were a ton of them! We had to watch many a YouTube video to figure it out. Overall, I do think it helped him understand fractions more but it could have started out more simply and built from there. This is really just busy work and not fun at all.

profile.name: Gary T.

title: Dad joke battle secret weapon
body: I purchased this for my husband so that he can be prepared for showdowns with my dad on the dad joke battlefield. My dad is in IT and works from home, so he has a lot of free time to research new dad jokes. We visit multiple times a week and he is usually waiting at the door to drop his first punchline (although many will follow for the next few hours). As their most frequent guests, my mom is glad for someone else to fall victim to the endless jests so we endure for her. My husband enjoys the laughs and rebuts with his own one liners and knock knock jokes, so this book was a welcomed reload of ammunition for battles to come. Highly recommend for any new dads or even seasoned father figures who need new material.

title: An Indispensable Resource!
body: "The New Menopause: Navigating Your Path Through Hormonal Change with Purpose, Power" is an insightful and empowering guidebook that sheds light on a topic often shrouded in mystery and misunderstanding. The author's comprehensive approach to navigating menopause is both informative and eye-opening, providing readers with valuable insights into the physical, emotional, and psychological aspects of this natural transition. Through a combination of research-backed information and personal anecdotes, the book offers practical advice and strategies for managing symptoms, embracing change, and reclaiming control over one's health and well-being. What sets this book apart is its emphasis on empowerment and purpose, encouraging women to approach menopause as a time of growth, transformation, and renewed vitality. Overall, "The New Menopause" is an indispensable resource for women seeking to navigate this stage of life with confidence, purpose, and power.

title: A must have !!!! ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
body: The media could not be loaded. If you are woman you NEED this book. If you are any age and want to know what life will be like starting at 35- 55 years old and want to know what’s going to happen to your body and not be clueless and left lost by the health care world this is your book. This is everything you need to know and what to do about it! I’ve recommended this book to 2.5k women!!! It’s easy to read, straight to the point. Anyone can read and understand it. It will give you peace of mind and help you realize what will happen or is happening is normal. All the answers are in this book! No women should go without this book as a map of peri menopause and menopause. Really this book should be read prior to 35 years old and to all young women so they have an idea and help for what’s to come. ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

This is everything you need to know and what to do about it! I’ve recommended this book to 2.5k women!!! It’s easy to read, straight to the point. Anyone can read and understand it. It will give you peace of mind and help you realize what will happen or is happening is normal. All the answers are in this book! No women should go without this book as a map of peri menopause and menopause. Really this book should be read prior to 35 years old and to all young women so they have an idea and help for what’s to come. ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

title: Amazing, incredible information.
body: I am in awe of this book and the information you provided. I also listened to the podcast you were recently on as well. I am so obsessed with learning about menopause after my personal journey and listening to yours and those of others. I am reading everything I can get my hands on (journals, books, articles, websites, etc) including the homeopathic side of things, just so that I have clarity with all of the information that is out there. I have been on MHT for about 3 years now and am still working with my gyn to figure out dosing. Like menopause as a whole, everytime you think you figured something out, you haven't completely. I am trying to find a way to further my studies and somehow become more involved in women's health. An athletic trainer for over 30 years, I am not sure I have the capacity to go to nursing school at this point in my life, but want to help others in their journey, somehow and I will find a way to make that happen. Thank you so much....I pre-ordered your book and the wait was so worth it. I am planning on telling my gyn about it!

title: Lots of good information in one spot
body: I found this book to be extremely informative and interesting. As a woman who is in perimenopause and just starting MHT, I appreciate all of the information about MHT, especially since so many doctors are unaware of the most recent guidelines and are reluctant to prescribe it. I also like that non-pharmacological options are discussed. My biggest complaint is that when other pages of the book are referenced (for example, “See page 145 for a discussion on fiber supplements.”) the page numbers are wrong. When you find the page referenced, there is no mention of the information you are looking for (see photos.) Hopefully this can be addressed in an upcoming reprint. Otherwise, it’s a great book and I’m glad to have read it!

profile.name: Cayte Castrillon

title: One Chapter needs a little more information
body: Dr. Mary Claire has really helped me understand my perimenopause symptoms and helped me to be an advocate for myself. One chapter needs a little more information on it is the recommendation on getting a calcium score test done. Patients need to know that Calcium test or CAC isn't a desirable test because it doesn't show soft plaque. Soft plaque is what causes stenosis of the coronary arteries and is only seen on a CTA. If I have high cholesterol and high LDLs and go and get a CAC, test, and it comes back zero that doesn't mean I am not a risk for coronary artery disease. For example, if I go on Lipitor, a statin drug, and my calcium score is zero and I go back and get a CAC in a couple of months of being on Lipitor, your calcium score of zero will go up! My doctor told me that statin drugs are raising people's CAC scores! When his patients see this they can't understand why this is happening. Statin drugs harden the soft plaque. Soft plaque, the plaque that is more thrombogenic, is hardened from statin drugs and now is calcified plaque. Thus, bringing up your calcium score. I highly recommend a CTA and not a CAC. CTA will show soft plaque and where it is. The location of the soft plaque, too is very important. My own mom had a very high CAC score because she was on Lipitor for years. Research has proven this with a large analysis of the MESA dataset that demonstrated that statins are associated with increasing CAC score.

profile.name: Karma

title: Nine years of “mystery” symptoms and it was all hormones
body: This is THE quintessential reference guide for all women as they age into their mid-thirties and beyond. Dr. Haver covers the expected but also the many non-traditional symptoms of menopause, which I endured for NINE YEARS. I saw a multitude of specialists with no solutions. From asthma to frozen shoulder to tinnitus, it’s all here. My toughest symptom was debilitating joint pain. So much so I thought I had rheumatoid arthritis. Turns out it was estrogen deficiency, so I have given HRT another shot. Life changing! She talks a great deal about HRT but also emphasizes lifestyle changes critical to successfully treating the multitude of woes associated with this massive chapter of transition. Well referenced, with simple strategies that are immediately actionable and empowering, The New Menopause delivers a powerful message around the need for better education and advocacy around women’s healthcare.

title: Groundbreaking and brave
body: I'm only 1/3 of the way through the book, but I was an early MHT patient (thank you California, 2013!) and this is the information I have been defending, recommending, praising, advocating for since life-changing intervention 12 + years ago. My horrible symptoms abated, and I wasn't ever really aware then of the long term benefits including cardiovascular, osteo, cognitive, etc. until Dr. Haver and her peers have lately gained notoriety and attention to this. I have to commend the bravery this author demonstrates in utilizing language. These are not friendly times and this incredibly dense medical information presented factually but also with an acknowledgment to the patriarchal history of medicine, racism, sexism, etc. PHEW! and Texas! Thank you, I'm really feeling validated and vindicated for my choices.

title: Skip the manifesto and buy this book instead
body: I read the "other" big menopause book last year, and The New Menopause blows it out of the water. It's less academic, less angry feminist (that's coming from a feminist!), easier to digest and more actionable than the manifesto. I had an HRT appointment already scheduled three days after I received it, and I was way more prepared for it using Dr. Haver's guidance. I've also always been big on using nutrition, supplements, and exercise to support my health and it's great to read guidance on those things as well. I'm telling ALL my girlfriends about it!

profile.name: Sharon Larsen

title: Informative Book for Alternative Healing Methods
body: Love this book! The book is structured with clarity, dividing its content into various sections that include detailed descriptions of herbs, their medicinal uses, and clear, vibrant photographs for easy identification. One of the standout features of this guide is its practical approach; not only does it describe the herbs, but it also provides instructions on how to prepare remedies at home.  While the book is incredibly informative, it is essential for readers to approach herbal treatment with caution. The authors do advise consulting with healthcare professionals before starting any new treatment, which is a responsible disclaimer. However, some may find the depth of information slightly overwhelming if they are new to herbalism.  Overall, "The Lost Book of Herbal Remedies" is a valuable resource for those interested in expanding their knowledge of natural healing practices. It encourages a connection with nature and empowers readers with the knowledge to harness the earth’s healing properties. This book is highly recommended for anyone curious about herbal remedies or seeking alternative healing methods.

profile.name: JESS

title: It gets the job done, but makes summer practice a most boring chore!
body: I bought K to 1, 1st to 2nd, and 3rd to 4th. These are definitely better than the First Grade Bound (etc) that I bought last year (those ones had no order, no plan, and didn't match grade levels well). I really liked the daily break down of the Summer Bridge books. It was a clear and easy to follow - so easy the kids didn't need me to tell them what to do each day. They matched grade level fairly well. But holy cow these books are BORING! It's just work. Blah. There is no attempt to actually engage the children, just busy work. My husband and I are college graduates and are education-minded. We push our kids to learn for learning's sake, but these books make education as boring as it can get. If you want bland just-do-this-and-get-it-over-with work to keep the brain going, these are more than adequate. I'm looking forward to trying out the Brain Quest Summer books which seem to make it more of a game and the activities are not just long lists of boring-ness.  My other complaint is the inconsistency in the grade levels. The 1st to 2nd grade was the best one - well balanced and challenging enough to keep the brain going, but easy enough for light summer work. It had a particularly good ratio of math, language, reading, writing, and social studies and pretty much all of the activities were manageable with the right amount of challenge.  The K to 1 book was mostly ok. The first of the three sections was so ridiculously easy that my daughter did it all on her own before school was even over (she wanted to!). It was activities like circling the right number of apples or just writing a single letter a bunch of times. She finished what was supposed to be a month's worth of work in about a week in her spare time. Fortunately we didn't need all three sections since their summer is only 9 weeks, so the other two sections got us through the rest of the summer doing a two-sided page "day" 5 days a week.  The 3rd to 4th grade book had the opposite problem. It started off great, but halfway through the second section much of the math was getting overly busy and sometimes too complex. There were many division problems that are beyond what he had learned in 3rd grade, and he's in G.A.T.E. In class they only covered multiplication and division 0-12. Example: 496 / 4 = ___. Example: A word problem where he has to work out either 162 / 18 or 18 x __ = 162. He got the concepts as I taught them, but it was frustrating. Some activities were just too lengthy for a quick summer book, such as a set of 10 addition problems like this: 8214 + 7716 + 6389 = ____. It's not that it was hard, but does he really need to do 10 of those, on top of three other activities? One of which is MORE math? There were many times his brother and sister would be done with their books plus 20 minutes of reading and in the pool while he was still working. Granted he likes to stall, so I always had him finish it to avoid rewarding his stalling, but I have to admit that I thought it was too much busy work. That and I found myself teaching him stuff he'd never seen before.  Bottom line is that these books were inconsistent and tedious and I will try others before I buy them again.

My other complaint is the inconsistency in the grade levels. The 1st to 2nd grade was the best one - well balanced and challenging enough to keep the brain going, but easy enough for light summer work. It had a particularly good ratio of math, language, reading, writing, and social studies and pretty much all of the activities were manageable with the right amount of challenge.

The K to 1 book was mostly ok. The first of the three sections was so ridiculously easy that my daughter did it all on her own before school was even over (she wanted to!). The 3rd to 4th grade book had the opposite problem. It started off great, but halfway through the second section much of the math was getting overly busy and sometimes too complex. profile.name: Habblie

title: Engaging!
body: My incoming 2nd grade grandson loves this workbook. When I first gave it to him, he worked in it until his folks told him to go outside and swim! He works in it everyday…alongside his incoming 4th grade brother working on his own 3-4 bridge book. Their mother is a teacher, and she thinks the books are doing a good job on refreshing the boys. I recommended the bridge books to a friend of mine for their incoming 3rd grade granddaughter, and he told me she is enjoying her 2-3 workbook (and she is NOT a fan of homework). I would recommend these books for anyone looking to help their littles stay sharp over their summer break. I’ll be getting the on-going series in the years ahead!

profile.name: Ashley Melchor

title: Good at identifying learning gaps
body: This was a good workbook for my post-1st grader. She had in person school for most of the year, but for limited days at first, and after 15 months of disrupted school followed by a household move to a more challenging school, I wanted to make sure she was a little more prepared academically.  Immediately we were able to see where the gaps in her learning vs. the expected 1st grade curriculum were, and the book gave us a tool to start filling those in bit by bit over the summer. I think she still has a challenging year ahead of us, but this workbook helped her from sliding backwards, taught her some new things, and in general let us feel much better about the nearly 4 month summer break that resulted from moving to an area on a different school calendar.  The work was definitely challenging for her, but manageable. It was probably 10-15 minutes of work per day if she focused and did it. There were complaints about summer work, and I found the best thing was to just keep a consistent time and expectation, 7 days/week.
body_html:

The work was definitely challenging for her, but manageable. It was probably 10-15 minutes of work per day if she focused and did it. There were complaints about summer work, and I found the best thing was to just keep a consistent time and expectation, 7 days/week.

profile.name: Shayne Morlan

title: Great resource for kids to keep up on skills for the next year
body: I have been using these the last few years with my kids and have been super impressed. I have used the preschool to kindergarten, 1st to 2nd grade, and 2nd grade to 3rd. My favorite thing about these work books are that they can be fast and simple lessons that usually take about 15 minutes or less to do. The other thing I like is they aren’t just math or reading. Each day they mix in several different concepts. I feel that way the kids don’t get overwhelmed with a subject or concept they might struggle with. It also GRADUALLY gets a little more difficult each day. So by the time summer is over they are being introduced to things that they will learn for the next year. They also come with flash cards that are made of good card stock to work on concepts like: letters, shapes, numbers, telling time, multiplication, divide, and other concepts that are age appropriate. There are small stickers at the back that the kids can put on their page after they are done that are just small stars. There is also a parent key at the back to check if the kid’s work is correct. I’m not going to lie I have used! :) Overall these have been great. The hardest thing I have struggled with is just being consistent and making sure they try and do them each day. When used these are fabulous!

title: Great to have over summer break to keep kids learning
body: It’s easy to forget what is taught throughout the school year over the long summer break. My daughters teacher recommended this book for her students and not only did it keep my little one occupied for an hour every summer day, but she actually enjoyed learning new things as well as brushing up on some of the things she had already been taught the school year before. I will never go another summer without purchasing these books as she gets older. Thank you Summer Bridge!

profile.name: MKB

title: Iron Wing: A Riveting Flight Through Fantasy
body: Rebecca Yarros masterfully crafts a narrative that is as enthralling as it is vivid. With an exceptional talent for describing characters and scenes, the author brings the fantastical world within the pages to life with striking detail and accuracy. Each description is meticulously crafted, painting a picture so clear it feels as though you're standing right in the midst of the action, witnessing the events unfold before your very eyes.  The plot of "Iron Wing" is a labyrinth of twists and turns. It keeps you on the edge of your seat, eagerly turning pages as you are drawn deeper into the intricately woven narrative. The story’s ability to engage and surprise is its strongest suit, making it impossible to put the book down. Just when you think you have figured it out, the story veers into uncharted territory, demonstrating the author's skill in storytelling.  Adding to the allure of "Iron Wing" are the spicy scenes interspersed throughout the book. These moments are penned with a finesse that makes them utterly captivating, ensuring that they are sure to make the reader melt. The chemistry between characters is palpable, written in a way that is both tasteful and electrifying. These scenes add a layer of intensity to the narrative, making the emotional highs and lows of the characters even more profound.  In conclusion, "Iron Wing" is a masterpiece of fantasy literature that offers everything a reader could wish for: a vividly realized world, a gripping plot full of surprises, and moments of intense emotion that are beautifully depicted. The author's ability to describe the characters and scenes with such detail and accuracy, coupled with a storyline that captivates from the first page to the last, and the perfectly placed spicy scenes, makes this book an unforgettable read. Whether you're a fan of fantasy or just looking for your next great read, "Iron Wing" is sure to satisfy.

profile.name: Melissa Deible

title: Rippin' Yarn
body: The 2 Iron Flame volumes are well allotted and move smartly along. The character development is strong for the most part, including peripheral characters.  The weakness in both books is the adolescent sex scenes that seem forced and something of a "poke in the eye" of Dad or Mom's patent all expectations, (not a mature author's necessity.) Some of the plot development seems "stagey"... as in, "please, please option this for a t.v. series"... or... " yes, this is YA, but don't limit my reader options.  Overall this is an entertaining and well-considered series.
body_html:

date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2024
profile.name: Dr. E. McCoy

title: Couldn't live up to the Fourth Wing Hype
body: I had such incredibly high hopes for Iron Flame after Fourth Wing that I stayed up and read all in one night (finished at 5 am!), but while Iron Flame is a good book, it doesn't live up to Fourth Wing. I was able to get an early copy of the book and it still took me 4 days to finish.  So what's done well? The story itself is incredible. There are many intricacies both with the humans, dragons, and other species we are introduced to. Rebecca Yarros knows how to throw in a few really good twists. Violet is a relatable main character who doesn't always believe in herself, but still rises to any challenge. Character development for Violet's mother delves us deeper into who she is as a person and why she does the things she does. Dain has finally redeemed himself mostly.  What's done poorly? Character development for some of the main characters felt either nonexistent (Hi Sawyer, forgot you were here) or is such a drastic change (Xaden is now lovesick and while I felt like it was meant to be a strong, I'll burn this world down for you, I was starting to get Tamlin vibes instead. I felt like he got kind of whiney). Then there's the whole issue of the book feeling like it revolved entirely around Violet and Xaden's relationship (the first 3/4 of the book is Violet just lusting after Xaden while the other 1/4 is them fighting) and everything else (including the Venin, Wyverns, displacement of people and cadets, dragon issues) were all completely secondary. What I had loved about the first book was that it felt the opposite - where Xaden and Violet had a budding romance, but it was a fantasy first novel. This felt like fantasy became the subplot in a way with how much of the focus was on their relationship specifically.  Overall, I'd give it 3.5 stars. It was a good book. Will I reread it? No.
body_html:

So what's done well?
The story itself is incredible. There are many intricacies both with the humans, dragons, and other species we are introduced to. Rebecca Yarros knows how to throw in a few really good twists. Violet is a relatable main character who doesn't always believe in herself, but still rises to any challenge. Character development for Violet's mother delves us deeper into who she is as a person and why she does the things she does. Dain has finally redeemed himself mostly.

What's done poorly?
Character development for some of the main characters felt either nonexistent (Hi Sawyer, forgot you were here) or is such a drastic change (Xaden is now lovesick and while I felt like it was meant to be a strong, I'll burn this world down for you, I was starting to get Tamlin vibes instead. I felt like he got kind of whiney). Then there's the whole issue of the book feeling like it revolved entirely around Violet and Xaden's relationship (the first 3/4 of the book is Violet just lusting after Xaden while the other 1/4 is them fighting) and everything else (including the Venin, Wyverns, displacement of people and cadets, dragon issues) were all completely secondary. What I had loved about the first book was that it felt the opposite - where Xaden and Violet had a budding romance, but it was a fantasy first novel. This felt like fantasy became the subplot in a way with how much of the focus was on their relationship specifically.

Overall, I'd give it 3.5 stars. It was a good book. Will I reread it? No.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2024
profile.name: Mary

title: Highly, highly recommended!!!
body: I am so in awe of both "Fourth Wing" and "Iron Flame" that I thought I would sit here staring at a blank screen for a long time while trying to find words to express my respect for Rebecca Yarros, author of both books. I just spent 3 days reading them and the only reason it took so long is that one still has to bath, eat, water plants, feed pets and sleep though I did not do much of the latter.  What writers call voice in both books is so very perfect that I immediately want to reread both books! The voice is fresh and up-to-date and modern even for the dragons yet fits perfectly into whatever period of time this fantasy took place but clearly when there were dragons! Before proceeding, however, I need to hyperventilate briefly.  First of all, it is totally immature and so unnecessary for anyone to post a critical plot point in a review especially on purpose and without first posting a spoiler alert. This happens not only with these books but others as well. Doing so is just another, although minor, example of how Homo sapiens have free will which they unfortunately can and often do waste on trivialities. So, then, here is how I deal with the review situation.  I do not read them until after I read the book, then I read them to see how others felt about the book. Since one needs to know what the book is about before purchase, then reading the descriptive paragraphs at the listing along with reading the free chapters Amazon thankfully offers at the listing itself will provide that. Thanks Amazon. Reading those chapters and the description plus checking the star/purchase numbers are good steps to take to avoid learning too much in a review prior to reading the book.  The second rant has to do with plot. Let me assure everyone there are NO NEW PLOTS. People have been murdering people since the beginning of time. It is how the author takes a plot(s) and makes it her/his own that matters to the reader. It is doubtful anyone knows how many dragon/people/rider fantasy books are out there so in the end it is a personal opinion as to which book(s) one chooses to like.  Having so many to choose from means some plot points will seem similar. For instance how many ways are there to shove a dagger into someone's ribs, a plot point in a massive number of books? This author knew how to handle the plot she chose and then developed with aplomb. Both books kept my attention fully--page after page after page.  I so love both books. What is so outstanding about both is that we learn most everything we need to know about each well developed character, not by telling, but by showing through their actions and their sharp and sometimes witty dialogue. It is beyond skillful at how on point the conversations are not only between the humans but the humans and their dragons especially Tairn and Violet and with Andarna--such a cutie and definitely my favorite dragon. The growing relationship between Violet and Xaden is razor sharp and on point.  Violet gets wonky with her "having to know all the truth up front demands" regardless of how Xaden has put forth so much effort to show her he cares. Everyone has secrets but a book needs tension to advance so whoa and hold on the tension builds and builds between those two. Xaden is my favorite character out of many favorites. Their arguments are worth "eavesdropping" on and their love scenes are well done (Chapter 48 is mentioned by some reviewers).  In this book Violet, in spite of her fragile bones and smaller size but because of her iron will and cleverness, and all those who made it through First Year at the Basgiath War College (covered in Fourth Wing") are now Second Years. Third years like my favorite character, Xaden, have graduated out and been assigned to outposts outside Basgiath. Thus begins an every other week trip for Violet and Xaden, him with her one weekend, her with him the next weekend. This is so their mated dragons can have time together each weekend.  It is also in this book that Basgiath and all the outposts are put in perspective regarding the coming battle. The 'revolution' becomes a much larger focal point and Violet learns about Xaden's connection to the estate in Aretia. One can already see by this point how hard it is to give this book the 10 star, 100% review it deserves! Just read it and see what I mean. It is one well-done, well written heck of a book and do not forget "Fourth Wing first!!  This book covers in more detail wards, the reason for them and the ins and outs of setting them up and what happens when they do not work (descriptive details I liked BTW). Details regarding the approaching battle then the battle itself are incredible. I am skimming plot points here since others have covered them very well but there is a lot of stuff left hanging at the end of this book and the end itself will floor you. It is like learning to fly on your own and suddenly losing that ability and plopping onto the ground and then fighting to just take a breath. It is shocking, promise.  When an author has done their job, the reader will fantasize about what may happen next but this book leaves so much stuff hanging that there has to be another book. My favorite character deserves a better ending--the last two chapters still has me plopped on the ground breathless. So here's a partial list of the left-hanging questions.  What happens between Violet and Xaden after the battle's aftermath? What happens to Aretia? Will Andarna's newly acquired fire play a role in the future especially in helping to set up wards? What happens to Basgiath after the war? What happens about the new dragon hatchlings? Will Cat's crew of riders play a future role? And, BTW, how did Jack get the way he turned out?  So very many unanswered questions in addition to many, many not covered here. So, then, Rebecca Yarros, listen up: We readers have to have another book--please, please and thank you!!
body_html:
I am so in awe of both "Fourth Wing" and "Iron Flame" that I thought I would sit here staring at a blank screen for a long time while trying to find words to express my respect for Rebecca Yarros, author of both books. One can already see by this point how hard it is to give this book the 10 star, 100% review it deserves! Just read it and see what I mean. It is one well-done, well written heck of a book and do not forget "Fourth Wing first!!

This book covers in more detail wards, the reason for them and the ins and outs of setting them up and what happens when they do not work (descriptive details I liked BTW). Details regarding the approaching battle then the battle itself are incredible. I am skimming plot points here since others have covered them very well but there is a lot of stuff left hanging at the end of this book and the end itself will floor you. It is like learning to fly on your own and suddenly losing that ability and plopping onto the ground and then fighting to just take a breath. It is shocking, promise.

When an author has done their job, the reader will fantasize about what may happen next but this book leaves so much stuff hanging that there has to be another book. My favorite character deserves a better ending--the last two chapters still has me plopped on the ground breathless. So here's a partial list of the left-hanging questions.

What happens between Violet and Xaden after the battle's aftermath? What happens to Aretia? Will Andarna's newly acquired fire play a role in the future especially in helping to set up wards? What happens to Basgiath after the war? What happens about the new dragon hatchlings? Will Cat's crew of riders play a future role? And, BTW, how did Jack get the way he turned out?

So very many unanswered questions in addition to many, many not covered here. So, then, Rebecca Yarros, listen up: We readers have to have another book--please, please and thank you!!
date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2024
profile.name: CrazyAboutBooks

title: Unputdownable
body: I'm most definitely broken-hearted by the ending of this massive book, which I simultaneously want to throw across the room and clutch to my chest in a tight embrace.  I was on the fence with the beginning of Fourth Wing, which came off as super strong, but along the way, I grew to like it. And this book cements that this is a series that I will happily proclaim to be a must-read. It's complicated and drama filled and absolutely unputdownable.  The characters are all keeping secrets and existing along an ever evolving precipice. The danger, the dragons, and the world building are all epic and beautifully layered. With brilliant and intriguing elements, this will keep you glued to its pages.  If you crave an enemies-to-lovers romance with assassination plots and lurking shadows with irriatable dragons in an academy setting, buckle up because you're going to want to strap in for an eyebrow raising adventure.
body_html:
I'm most definitely broken-hearted by the ending of this massive book, which I simultaneously want to throw across the room and clutch to my chest in a tight embrace.

I was on the fence with the beginning of Fourth Wing, which came off as super strong, but along the way, I grew to like it. And this book cements that this is a series that I will happily proclaim to be a must-read. It's complicated and drama filled and absolutely unputdownable.

The characters are all keeping secrets and existing along an ever evolving precipice. The danger, the dragons, and the world building are all epic and beautifully layered. With brilliant and intriguing elements, this will keep you glued to its pages.

If you crave an enemies-to-lovers romance with assassination plots and lurking shadows with irriatable dragons in an academy setting, buckle up because you're going to want to strap in for an eyebrow raising adventure.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on April 21, 2024
profile.name: M. Fritz

title: This book broke me in the best way 🫠🥲
body: ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️💫 - 4.5 stars ****tried to be vague as possible but may be slight spoilers read at your own risk*** What I loved: - Xaden & Violet - Their love confessions - Fighting for one another - All the twists, unexpected plot bombs everywhere - The dragons complete this story, Tairn & Andarna forever 💕 - Iron squad - Found family gets even stronger - Sorrengail siblings - All the action and battles were epic - Felix is a WAYYYY better teacher than Carr - More backstory, more character development history insight  Didn’t enjoy/wanted more: - more healthy relationship building with Xaden & Violet, less sex and more healthy dicussion so the sex was more meaningful instead of avoiding meaningful discussion - More trust for Xaden from Violet (we started getting there) - Violet to not lose her confidence in her intelligence - The freaking ending. Are you kidding me?! The battle was hard enough. Did Rebecca really have to do that???! “You should be scared of me” - More Iron Squad shenanigans, never enough - More of Xaden’s history - More from Violet’s childhood, specifically need more details on dad - LESS OF JFB 😡 - More about Tairn & Sgaeyl’s relationship - Everything about Cat pissed me off, it sorta resolved but also felt a little unnecessary, but I saw why she’s in the story to push Xaden towards more honesty. But still hated just about everything about her character -  I didn’t know I was capable of being so invested in a couple’s story. But here I am praying Xaden & Violet get their HEA somewhere in this long series 🫠 I don’t have all the words for my feelings about this book. But I can say I’ve felt just about every emotion in this book 🙃 plot and storyline is phenomenal. The suspense is next level and kept me devouring the book. I don’t know how to recover from this book 🫣🫠 I had to take a half point away because the ending has left me SHATTERED. There better be a way that this gets fixed and Xaden & Violet get some version of a HEA because if those two don’t make it, I’ll be PISSED. January cannot come fast enough 😭😭  This is an open door book with open scenes. Easy to skip about 4-5 pages each. There are frequent discussions of sex and innuendo. There is a lot of cursing, violence, torture, kidnapping, PTSD, and death.  Songs for the book: “Game of Survival” by Ruelle “Can’t Catch Me Now” by Olivia Rodrigo “Natural” by Imagine Dragons  Songs for Violet & Xaden: “Last night” by Morgan Wallen “War of Hearts” by Ruelle “loml” by Taylor Swift “Fortnight” by Taylor Swift & Post Malone “Home” by Good Neighbors “So it goes” by Taylor Swift “Another Forever” by Ni/Co “After life” by Hailee Steinfield “Haven’t you ever been in love before” by Lewis Capaldi  Xaden to Violet: “Sleeptalking” by Jake Scott *** “Pointless” by Lewis Capaldi “After You” by Meghan Trainer “Don’t make it easy” by Jake Scott “My Home” by The Change “Come close” by Jake Scott “Banks” by NEEDTOBREATHE  Violet: “I Can Do It With a Broken Heart” by Taylor Swift “If this is goodbye” by Britton “I’m Fakin” by Sabrina Carpenter  Dain to Violet: “Vicious” by Sabrina Carpenter “Wish You The Best” by Lewis Capaldi “Happier” by Ed Sheeran
body_html:
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️💫 - 4.5 stars
****tried to be vague as possible but may be slight spoilers read at your own risk***
What I loved:
- Xaden & Violet
- Their love confessions
- Fighting for one another
- All the twists, unexpected plot bombs everywhere
- The dragons complete this story, Tairn & Andarna forever 💕
- Iron squad
- Found family gets even stronger
- Sorrengail siblings
- All the action and battles were epic
- Felix is a WAYYYY better teacher than Carr
- More backstory, more character development history insight

Didn’t enjoy/wanted more:
- more healthy relationship building with Xaden & Violet, less sex and more healthy dicussion so the sex was more meaningful instead of avoiding meaningful discussion
- More trust for Xaden from Violet (we started getting there)
- Violet to not lose her confidence in her intelligence
- The freaking ending. Are you kidding me?! The battle was hard enough. Did Rebecca really have to do that???! “You should be scared of me”
- More Iron Squad shenanigans, never enough
- More of Xaden’s history
- More from Violet’s childhood, specifically need more details on dad
- LESS OF JFB 😡
- More about Tairn & Sgaeyl’s relationship
- Everything about Cat pissed me off, it sorta resolved but also felt a little unnecessary, but I saw why she’s in the story to push Xaden towards more honesty. But still hated just about everything about her character
-

I didn’t know I was capable of being so invested in a couple’s story. But here I am praying Xaden & Violet get their HEA somewhere in this long series 🫠 I don’t have all the words for my feelings about this book. But I can say I’ve felt just about every emotion in this book 🙃 plot and storyline is phenomenal. The suspense is next level and kept me devouring the book. I don’t know how to recover from this book 🫣🫠 I had to take a half point away because the ending has left me SHATTERED. There better be a way that this gets fixed and Xaden & Violet get some version of a HEA because if those two don’t make it, I’ll be PISSED. January cannot come fast enough 😭😭

This is an open door book with open scenes. Easy to skip about 4-5 pages each. There are frequent discussions of sex and innuendo. There is a lot of cursing, violence, torture, kidnapping, PTSD, and death.

Songs for the book:
“Game of Survival” by Ruelle
“Can’t Catch Me Now” by Olivia Rodrigo
“Natural” by Imagine Dragons

Songs for Violet & Xaden:
“Last night” by Morgan Wallen
“War of Hearts” by Ruelle
“loml” by Taylor Swift
“Fortnight” by Taylor Swift & Post Malone
“Home” by Good Neighbors
“So it goes” by Taylor Swift
“Another Forever” by Ni/Co
“After life” by Hailee Steinfield
“Haven’t you ever been in love before” by Lewis Capaldi

Xaden to Violet:
“Sleeptalking” by Jake Scott ***
“Pointless” by Lewis Capaldi
“After You” by Meghan Trainer
“Don’t make it easy” by Jake Scott
“My Home” by The Change
“Come close” by Jake Scott
“Banks” by NEEDTOBREATHE

Violet:
“I Can Do It With a Broken Heart” by Taylor Swift
“If this is goodbye” by Britton
“I’m Fakin” by Sabrina Carpenter

Dain to Violet:
“Vicious” by Sabrina Carpenter
“Wish You The Best” by Lewis Capaldi
“Happier” by Ed Sheeran
date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2024
profile.name: Tatum Sergent

title: So much more to dragons than their wings!
body: Woth more than 5 stars! The worst part of this book is the knowledge that the next one won't be out until late next year. The 2nd most irksome thing is that yes, there are content warnings, but you have to leave the book to read them. Seriously? Without being gratuitous, there is some sex, violence, profanity, and poor decisions. There are other things that triggered me but were essential to the plot.  The book picks up right as The Fourth Wing ends. There are so many secrets between the characters. The way Violet and Xaden deal with secrets sometimes makes me want to grind my teeth. They finally start coming to some adult relationship decisions that I hope they can keep in the next book.  While the humans, all of the humans, deal with their training, battles, relationships, and secrets, the dragons come forward more. Their relationships to their chosen deepen, their own skills are put more on display, and how each is a unique individual not just stereotyped by color, rider, or den. We learn more about the politics of the Empyrean and that the politics of the dragons is not necessarily in line with or shared with the humans.  I hope the next book brings Andarna into play more often. She was where she needed to be, but at one point, when Violet tells Tairn she misses Andarna, I realized I did too. Like Violet, she is so much more than she seems, and I really appreciated her adolescent viewpoint to compare to Tairn's.  There are new relationships forged as we get to meet more gryphons and their fliers. While practical, walking out the idea that the enemy of my enemy is my friend can be challenging. Thankfully, Tairn reminds us, "We do not eat our allies." I really enjoyed the time spent as they get to know each other and learn to appreciate their similarities and differences, and finally come to respect.  The training and battle scenes were amazing! I tend to both listen and read a book I really like, especially when I know I won't have time to sit and read. I found for some of the action scenes I needed to go back and read them. For me, it helps me picture it in my head better. That isn't a critique of the writing or narration, just how my brain processed things. I enjoyed both!  This series is an excellent read for those who love Anne McCaffery's Pern, anyone who likes a little military structure in they fantasy, and anyone who enjoys fantasy and knows pain from the moment the wake up. May our boxes hold as well as Violet's.

I hope the next book brings Andarna into play more often. She was where she needed to be, but at one point, when Violet tells Tairn she misses Andarna, I realized I did too. Like Violet, she is so much more than she seems, and I really appreciated her adolescent viewpoint to compare to Tairn's.

profile.name: Wilting Violet

title: Hold on until part 2…
body: What is it about Rebecca Yarros and writing absolutely lengthy and boring part ones? The first half of Iron Flame just dragged on and on and on. It was unnecessarily long and ultimately, inconsequential for the rest of the story’s development. I almost gave up on Iron Flame about 40% of the way in but something told me to keep reading and I’m glad I did! Part two was spectacular! Action packed and full of information. I wish the first half had been condensed to 100 pages or so and the second half had been made longer. I loved reading Dain’s and Violet’s mom’s redemptions. I also fell more in love with Violet and Xaden as a couple. She knows what he is at the end of the book and still she sleeps next to him. It’s a testament to “through sickness and in health” and I really hope these two are endgame. I can’t wait for the second part of the third book!

profile.name: Flipping Nap Time

title: More focused on story and plot with less redundant teen angst and sex compared to the 1st book
body: Do yourself a huge favor, don’t read any reviews until after you have read the entire series. There is no unseeing something that will tarnish your own feelings. Just look at the stars and how many ratings have been left. Once you have completed the series read and enjoy the reviews. There is nothing to gain from the written reviews. They will only dilute your own experience of the books. So far they are enjoyable and exciting. Currently 4.6 with tons of ratings is a good read. That’s all you need to know.  Yarros has an amazing ability to construct an intricately woven story with twists and payoffs. I appreciated this second book's immediate focus on those qualities after the first book's ending.  Spoiler Alert: This addresses the first book's final chapters. I realize her genre is "Romantasy Fiction" but she could have been more consistent with a less-is-more approach to angst and sex. Sometimes she unnecessarily went on paragraph after paragraph page after page. Even having done it once, all it would take is a hint to get the point across each time thereafter yet she would drop back into every detail and even implausibly while in the midst of battle. Come on! No one would think in such detail and about relationship angst during a battle for your life. That indulgence only comprises 2% of the book and takes place towards the end yet it delved too long and too repetitively to go unmentioned. I am certain some and many readers enjoyed every word of it. This is Romantasy. On the other hand this story would be great even if the "romance" was not so graphic that it was "Fantasy Fiction" instead of "Romantasy Fiction." I appreciated the eloquence and the fine layers of sensitivity of the character's perspective but too much is too much.
