profile.name: M on Amazon

title: « spoiler-free book review »
body: ↳ Iron Flame (The Empyrean, 2)— Rebecca Yarros  Rating— ★★★★★  “𝐿𝑜𝓋𝑒 𝒹𝑜𝑒𝓈𝓃’𝓉 𝑒𝓋𝑒𝓃 𝒽𝒶𝓋𝑒 𝓉𝒽𝑒 𝒹𝑒𝒸𝑒𝓃𝒸𝓎 𝓉𝑜 𝒹𝒾𝑒. 𝐼𝓉 𝒿𝓊𝓈𝓉 𝓉𝓇𝒶𝓃𝓈𝒻𝑜𝓇𝓂𝓈 𝒾𝓃𝓉𝑜 𝒶𝒷𝒿𝑒𝒸𝓉 𝓂𝒾𝓈𝑒𝓇𝓎.”  ⟡ Thoughts— The emotional rollercoaster I endured while reading this book was so intense that I had to take extra time between scenes to stop reading & ponder what just happened. I felt every emotion under the sun, laughing one moment then being pissed off the next. There were hardly any moments where I felt I could take a mental rest because of how action-centered this book was. I’m still in awe that this is only book 2 out of a 5 book series given all that happened.  It’s no secret that I absolutely adore the main characters & their dragons, but what took me by surprise was my fixation for the supporting characters. I’m usually indifferent when it comes to side characters, but Yarros made it utterly impossible for me NOT to care. I thought Liam was the exception but after finishing Iron Flame, I realized I’m completely attached to the entire squad—new members included.  This book just about alleviated most of the queries I harbored from Fourth Wing, while also sparking up so many more. My advice before going into this book is to re-read Fourth Wing right before jumping into Iron Flame. I personally followed this route, and it was definitely worth taking the extra time. Most of the theories I pondered in the first book were set to rest and I’m glad for it.  With all that being said, I can admit that this was by no means a perfect book. There were things I found unnecessary and some scenes I thought were anticlimactic. However, for being only the second book of a series, I think Yarros did a fantastic job— hence, there’s still plenty of time to iron out the bumps in the story. I speculated that this book was going to be solely transitional, but I found it to be that & so much more.
body_html:
↳ Iron Flame (The Empyrean, 2)— Rebecca Yarros

Rating— ★★★★★

“𝐿𝑜𝓋𝑒 𝒹𝑜𝑒𝓈𝓃’𝓉 𝑒𝓋𝑒𝓃 𝒽𝒶𝓋𝑒 𝓉𝒽𝑒 𝒹𝑒𝒸𝑒𝓃𝒸𝓎 𝓉𝑜 𝒹𝒾𝑒. 𝐼𝓉 𝒿𝓊𝓈𝓉 𝓉𝓇𝒶𝓃𝓈𝒻𝑜𝓇𝓂𝓈 𝒾𝓃𝓉𝑜 𝒶𝒷𝒿𝑒𝒸𝓉 𝓂𝒾𝓈𝑒𝓇𝓎.”
 
⟡ Thoughts—
The emotional rollercoaster I endured while reading this book was so intense that I had to take extra time between scenes to stop reading & ponder what just happened. I felt every emotion under the sun, laughing one moment then being pissed off the next. There were hardly any moments where I felt I could take a mental rest because of how action-centered this book was. I’m still in awe that this is only book 2 out of a 5 book series given all that happened.
 
It’s no secret that I absolutely adore the main characters & their dragons, but what took me by surprise was my fixation for the supporting characters. I’m usually indifferent when it comes to side characters, but Yarros made it utterly impossible for me NOT to care. I thought Liam was the exception but after finishing Iron Flame, I realized I’m completely attached to the entire squad—new members included.
 
This book just about alleviated most of the queries I harbored from Fourth Wing, while also sparking up so many more. My advice before going into this book is to re-read Fourth Wing right before jumping into Iron Flame. I personally followed this route, and it was definitely worth taking the extra time. Most of the theories I pondered in the first book were set to rest and I’m glad for it.

With all that being said, I can admit that this was by no means a perfect book. There were things I found unnecessary and some scenes I thought were anticlimactic. However, for being only the second book of a series, I think Yarros did a fantastic job— hence, there’s still plenty of time to iron out the bumps in the story. I speculated that this book was going to be solely transitional, but I found it to be that & so much more.

profile.name: Cher

title: second year brings Violet more torture
body: We're picking up right where the other book left off-- a good friend is dead, Violet and the rest of her squad are still together about to enter Second Year at Basgiath war college, and Xaden is being sent to the front lines as a graduated Lieutenant.  Added to the mix is a new war college vice commander who has it in for Violet, mysterious healer goings-on, and the oncoming war with Wyverns and Venin ramping up.  Plus the dead friend's little sister who blames Violet for the friend's death entering as a first year.  There's alot of fluffing around with Violet making a big deal about not trusting Xaden, a big reveal of a baddie we thought gone, backstory about how wardstones are made, and a lot of steamy times between Xaden and Violet that read more like an adult paranormal than YA, and alot of pompous announcements from Tairn whilst Violet gets caught up in severe danger and he's always 5 minutes away from saving her.  Gotta hand it to Yarros, there's alot of action scenes here, especially in the last third of the book, that made my heart race a bit because this author has already proved she'll put characters through major damage.  There was a second year secret trial that-- yikes-- made me blanch. There's severe damage, and then there's SEVERE damage. When Violet has a conversation with the Grphyon riders about how failing to bond with a Gryphon doesn't end in death and she's like "huh, imagine that" I wanted to smack her and Yarros over the head.  This is major character abuse. Yikes.  But we must all like it because we keep reading. And now with the wardstone, Xaden, and dragon developments at the end of this book-- gotta keep going to find out what happens
body_html:

Added to the mix is a new war college vice commander who has it in for Violet, mysterious healer goings-on, and the oncoming war with Wyverns and Venin ramping up.

Plus the dead friend's little sister who blames Violet for the friend's death entering as a first year.

There's alot of fluffing around with Violet making a big deal about not trusting Xaden, a big reveal of a baddie we thought gone, backstory about how wardstones are made, and a lot of steamy times between Xaden and Violet that read more like an adult paranormal than YA, and alot of pompous announcements from Tairn whilst Violet gets caught up in severe danger and he's always 5 minutes away from saving her.

Gotta hand it to Yarros, there's alot of action scenes here, especially in the last third of the book, that made my heart race a bit because this author has already proved she'll put characters through major damage.

There was a second year secret trial that-- yikes-- made me blanch. There's severe damage, and then there's SEVERE damage. When Violet has a conversation with the Grphyon riders about how failing to bond with a Gryphon doesn't end in death and she's like "huh, imagine that" I wanted to smack her and Yarros over the head.

This is major character abuse. Yikes.

But we must all like it because we keep reading. And now with the wardstone, Xaden, and dragon developments at the end of this book-- gotta keep going to find out what happens

profile.name: K. Bird Lincoln

title: Intense Second Installment
body: I am going to do my best to make this a non-spoiler review. There is just so much in this book that I can’t talk about due to it spoiling one thing or another, especially that ending. I mean, where did that come from, how do we move on from here. I am not okay.  This is the second book in The Empyrean Series. This book picks up right where the first one ends. I just need to say I get that it’s a war college, but oh my god what these people endure. I want to note that there is torture in the book, however it is actually handled well, you will cringe but its not overly graphic. There was so much action going on in this one that I had a hard time putting it down. I can only imagine how the next book is going to go.  Of course after the ending of Fourth Wing there are a lot of issues between Violet and Xaden and even though they are stubborn and well young there is a lot of talk about why communication is so important for their relationship to work. Communication is discussed a lot in the book, so I am wondering if it’s a set-up for what is to come or the author really wanted to push it home. I mean, even Tarin and Sgaeyl have a moment and OMG the secret Andarna has. I am not well.  Vi is pissed for a good bit of the book, mostly justified, but they pull though when she thinks Xaden is possibly on his deathbed. And there the romance picks up. Oh, and assassins are being sent to kill anyone that survived the ending of book one so that they can’t tell the truth about what’s out there. And then the whole let’s bring back person X. I am still confused about a few things. Let’s just say the stakes start high in this book and just keep climbing.  The family that Vi created in book one just gets stronger and every time Rhi, Ridoc, and Sawyer were in trouble I had so much anxiety because we just can’t lose them. I know that thinking like that means that someone isn’t going to make it, but I am way too attached. And I will root for them all to make it to the end every time. The problem is now that alliances have been forged this found family has grown and now all these characters need to stay safe too.  Tarin may still be one of my absolute favorite characters in these books. I love this dialog and the fact that every time Vi doubts herself, he reminds her that he picked her because of XYZ. He may be one of the absolute toughest dragons, but he has a big heart. Sgaeyl didn’t seem to be as present in this book, and I think that was because she was off the page a lot. I hope it doesn’t mean anything. Then we have our precious Andarna who might just be hiding the biggest secret of them all. She is still a witty young dragon who apparently knows her worth, even if she isn’t telling anyone, including Tarin. Poor Tarin everyone was keeping secrets from him.  If you read Fourth Wing and liked it them pick up this one!

date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2024
profile.name: Mary

title: Magic School? Fighting the Dark Forces of evil? balance of power?
body: I’ve got to be honest. I’ve grown weary of Dystopian trilogies where the heroine is the all too unlikely candidate with powers to conquer the evil with in the society. Love triangles where she must choose who is good and who is not so good are losing their favor with me. There has to be more to Young Adult dystopia than this time tested framework for best selling works of art.  Yet I’m hooked. Just like when I finally finished a JK Rowling masterpiece, I know I’m going to be first in lime to grab the third installment in this series in January. Not sine I read “Project Hail Mary” have I felt this rush like I did for “The Goblet of Fire.” I simply couldnt put the Empyrean series down.  It follows the classic framework for protagonist, antagonist, and love triangle you could see. The boundaries for the battle between good vs evil are gray as there are three sides fighting for good, or are there four? You must choose a side.  The magic the riders use and the energy that flows from the words embed your reading, like a distraction rune is woven into the pages. Im not sure that this book isnt more adult than it is you g adult as Violet and Zaden flare up the pages with steamy enticing details. The passion and faults of young love are all present, seemingly balanced out by the much more mature and aged love that is Tarin and Sgael.  Like Zaden for Violet (or vise versa) I must have the next book.

profile.name: WyomingTeacher

title: That Ending Though!!
body: I put off reading this book because I knew that there was no set date on when book 3 would be out and I wanted to prolong this experience as long as possible. It was worth it but not because I found out some of the twists before reading them. This book and series have been epic to me. It's like a mix of Harry Potter, with ACOTAR feels and dragons and ruthlessness. There were a few things that I wish there were more of BUT I will address in a sec.  This book picks up right where we left off from book 1. Violet is back at Basgiath and is supposed to act like nothing that happened as happened. Oh and Xaden is graduating. They aren't together even though he clearly wants to be and with him graduating they will only get to see each other every week MAYBE. The crew that shows up after they disappeared will all be almost interrogated to see if they will crack on where they actually were. The biggest struggle I had with this book was the lack of time with Xaden and Violet and then with that "time" that they got Violet used it terribly. They would either be arguing or she would ignore him even though she clearly missed him. The lack of spice in this one was disappointing as well. Violet was just a BIT too whiny for me :/ She was a little all over the place.  Anywho back to the plot- Violet's friends are starting to put together that she isn't telling them something. Violet is on the hunt to find out more history from the original 6. She is looking into wards. Things happen. She makes decisions that end up with majority of the college now in Aretia where a temporary college is setup for the "rebels" if you will. Everyone knows there is an epic showdown on the horizon with the venin, but they don't know how to stop them. Will everyone make it? Will they learn how to do the wards? Do we learn more about the venin and their history?  AHHHH the ending of this book was just epic!! I am so scared and excited to see where this goes. I don't think I have read a book yet where this happens and can't wait to see what Rebecca has in store for us. I loved how she throws in tidbits of history at the beginning of each chapter that come into fruition later in the book. I should probably pay more attention to those because they indicate where things are headed LOL. I would ask one small thing for book 3- pretty please don't make us wait forever??

Everyone knows there is an epic showdown on the horizon with the venin, but they don't know how to stop them. Will everyone make it? Will they learn how to do the wards? Do we learn more about the venin and their history?

AHHHH the ending of this book was just epic!! I am so scared and excited to see where this goes. I don't think I have read a book yet where this happens and can't wait to see what Rebecca has in store for us. I loved how she throws in tidbits of history at the beginning of each chapter that come into fruition later in the book. I should probably pay more attention to those because they indicate where things are headed LOL. I would ask one small thing for book 3- pretty please don't make us wait forever??
date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2024
profile.name: Katie Beasley

title: Excellent Story and Writing, but…
body: Both Iron Flame and Fourth Wing are fantastic stories that draw you in to where you can’t put the book down. The characters are well developed, and the story is well told. As I was reading the books, I was thinking what great books they would be for a young reader until I got to the chapters about the romantic interests of two of the characters. The chapters read like a cross between a Harlequin romance and Penthouse Forum. These chapters made the books inappropriate for anyone under 18, and as an adult, I thought it was too much, and thumbed through it until it was over (if it was a movie I would have fast forwarded). It was only disappointing because the writing was so good, I’m sure the author could have told the story without being so graphic, really limiting the audience for this book. Other than that, well done and I’m looking forward to the next book.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2024
profile.name: Dave

title: The Pain. The Laughs. The Tears.
body: How am I supposed to live, laugh, love in these conditions?  I have so many thoughts that my mind is SPINNING. My brain literally hurts. Last 100 or so pages? Chill bumps. This book had, and still has, me in a chokehold. It was tense, mysterious, stressful, HOT, and so much fun (at first at least).  Was it long? Absolutely. Was I scared to start it? Yes. Mainly because I’d seen so many mixed reviews! I was worried it wouldn’t live up to the hype. Safe to say, I was wrong. It was perfection and then some.  I enjoyed the first part’s world building, banter, and “filler” (some may call it). I had fun reading it and it kept me flipping page after page. Getting to see more of Violet’s squad was ideal IMO. My appreciation for Rhiannon, Ridoc, Sawyer, etc all grew. The ‘found family’ trope was evident in this book. I also found it necessary for the later parts of the book. I understood more of what each member brought to the table and how important they were to each other.  I was worried we wouldn’t get much Violet/Xaden time since they were separated, but I was mistaken. Their reunions each week were exciting and left me anticipating the next. Across the whole book, watching their relationship grow was awesome. I think the whole “separation makes the heart grow fonder” thing was apparent…and lead to great smut too.  I think one of my favorite aspects was Xaden and his outward affection for Violet. Whether it just be small touches here, or whispered reminders, it was the best. Up front, he’s this tough, moody guy that seems like he’d be annoying as hell. But, as you realize what his weakness is and who is soft spot is for, you can’t help but love him safe to say, he’s one of my top MMCs.  I can’t not talk about the dragons of course. The sass on all fronts was top tier. I have no qualms. I loved Tairn even more than before, and moody Andarna can’t be topped. As the books progress, I am VERY interested to see what happens relating to the dragons.  The build up to the end of the book had me on the edge of my seat. As a reader, knowing a plot is going to span multiple books, you know something is gonna happen. Something frustrating, mind blowing, sad - it’s gonna happen. And it did. The ending left me angry, in fact, I hate it here 🚩  But heck if I’m not ready to devour the next book.  It’s hard to say much without spoiling it, but wow. “WOW” (read in Owen Wilson’s voice)  I hate that I put reading it off for so long, but I’m mad that I didn’t put it off for longer. Because now, I have to wait for the next one

How am I supposed to live, laugh, love in these conditions?

I have so many thoughts that my mind is SPINNING. My brain literally hurts. Last 100 or so pages? Chill bumps. This book had, and still has, me in a chokehold. It was tense, mysterious, stressful, HOT, and so much fun (at first at least).

Was it long?

Yes. Mainly because I’d seen so many mixed reviews! I was worried it wouldn’t live up to the hype. Safe to say, I was wrong. It was perfection and then some.

I was worried we wouldn’t get much Violet/Xaden time since they were separated, but I was mistaken. Their reunions each week were exciting and left me anticipating the next. Across the whole book, watching their relationship grow was awesome. I think the whole “separation makes the heart grow fonder” thing was apparent…and lead to great smut too.

I think one of my favorite aspects was Xaden and his outward affection for Violet. Whether it just be small touches here, or whispered reminders, it was the best. But, as you realize what his weakness is and who is soft spot is for, you can’t help but love him safe to say, he’s one of my top MMCs.

I can’t not talk about the dragons of course. The sass on all fronts was top tier. I have no qualms. I loved Tairn even more than before, and moody Andarna can’t be topped. As the books progress, I am VERY interested to see what happens relating to the dragons.

I hate that I put reading it off for so long, but I’m mad that I didn’t put it off for longer. Because now, I have to wait for the next one
date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2024
profile.name: Mary Allison

title: Great sequel!
body: 11/13 FULL REVIEW: I don't even know where to begin. That ending has left me reeling. And I thought I knew what was coming because some *lovely* person on Goodreads thought to retaliate against the author by dropping a major spoiler with no warning to people like me, who were aimlessly scrolling, so for me to still be shocked and surprised is saying something. And just word to the wise: Be careful out there, folks! There are spoilers everywhere. 😒  Anywhoo...that's my rant. Now back to my review!  Look, there's no surprise Fourth Wing and Rebecca Yarros has taking the book world by storm these past few months and I am LOVING it, okay? This love/ obsession/ hype is giving me all the nostaglia and throwing me back to my Harry Potter days twenty-six (🤯‼️) years ago. With me trying to get my hands on the physical books, the fandom going crazy over the series, the midnight release parties, and all the conversations spurred between readers and friends, it has been amazing to watch and to be apart of, and I am in love with the Fourth Wing Era we are in right now.  There was something ✨️magical✨️ about my reading experience with Fourth Wing earlier this year. It was a combination of right book at the right time and it had me hooked. I was excited to get my hands on the sequel, but went into the book nervous it wouldn't hold a candle to the first one and I would be left disappointed because of my high expectations.  Sadly, this book didn't give me that all consuming, unputdownable feeling I had with FW for the first 25% of the book and that is where my 4 star rating comes into play. I was easily able to read it, because I just think Yarros has this easy, flowing type of writing that even though not alot might be happening on the pages, I am still able to continue on without many delays in my reading time and I was reading this section of the book like I do a normal book. It just wasn't making me abandon all of my responsibilities and make it a top priority to read like FW did, if that makes sense. I think we could have shortened the first 200 pages to make the pacing of the book better overall.  However, let me tell you! Once you get about a fourth of the way through, we get that spark and the twists start dropping and then I became hooked til the final page. And whew, that ending! I was on an emotional rollercoaster for the last 50 pages or so. I'm so paranoid about spoilers with this series, especially after my horrible experience,so I don't even want to say anything else about how I feel or what I am expecting from this series as we continue on this journey for fear of spoiling anything. Let's just say there are lots of theories and it has been fun being able to safely navigate through Instagram, Goodreads, and TikTok without fear of the book being ruined now, and I'd recommend if you want to read book 2, you better do it asap before something gets spoiled for you!  P.S. Still loving the dragons. They are seriously one of the best parts of these books and world. I love their sass, their snark, and just overall, what they bring to the table. 🐉  I love Ridoc's sarcasm and it helped bring levity to the book in general. I really enjoy the side characters in this series and you get really attached to everyone making it enjoyable, but also nerve-racking. 😅  I can't wait for news of book three's release and I've seen articles stating she would let us know 2 weeks after Iron Flames release date, so one more week hopefully and we will know how long we will have to wait for it. Here's hoping it'll only be another 6 months or so and we can have book 3 in our hands by spring. 🤞 I know I'll be pre-ordering multiples this time around and not from just one site, because I don't want the stress of what I went through waiting on Iron Flame to arrive on my doorstep. 🤣  ******************  11/12 : 🤯🤯🤯 I need some time to gather my thoughts. I did NOT see that coming.
body_html:
11/13 FULL REVIEW:
I don't even know where to begin. That ending has left me reeling. And I thought I knew what was coming because some *lovely* person on Goodreads thought to retaliate against the author by dropping a major spoiler with no warning to people like me, who were aimlessly scrolling, so for me to still be shocked and surprised is saying something. And just word to the wise: Be careful out there, folks! There are spoilers everywhere. 😒

Anywhoo...that's my rant. Now back to my review!

Look, there's no surprise Fourth Wing and Rebecca Yarros has taking the book world by storm these past few months and I am LOVING it, okay? This love/ obsession/ hype is giving me all the nostaglia and throwing me back to my Harry Potter days twenty-six (🤯‼️) years ago. With me trying to get my hands on the physical books, the fandom going crazy over the series, the midnight release parties, and all the conversations spurred between readers and friends, it has been amazing to watch and to be apart of, and I am in love with the Fourth Wing Era we are in right now.

There was something ✨️magical✨️ about my reading experience with Fourth Wing earlier this year. It was a combination of right book at the right time and it had me hooked. I was excited to get my hands on the sequel, but went into the book nervous it wouldn't hold a candle to the first one and I would be left disappointed because of my high expectations.

Sadly, this book didn't give me that all consuming, unputdownable feeling I had with FW for the first 25% of the book and that is where my 4 star rating comes into play. I was easily able to read it, because I just think Yarros has this easy, flowing type of writing that even though not alot might be happening on the pages, I am still able to continue on without many delays in my reading time and I was reading this section of the book like I do a normal book. It just wasn't making me abandon all of my responsibilities and make it a top priority to read like FW did, if that makes sense. I think we could have shortened the first 200 pages to make the pacing of the book better overall.

However, let me tell you! Once you get about a fourth of the way through, we get that spark and the twists start dropping and then I became hooked til the final page. And whew, that ending! I was on an emotional rollercoaster for the last 50 pages or so. I'm so paranoid about spoilers with this series, especially after my horrible experience,so I don't even want to say anything else about how I feel or what I am expecting from this series as we continue on this journey for fear of spoiling anything. Let's just say there are lots of theories and it has been fun being able to safely navigate through Instagram, Goodreads, and TikTok without fear of the book being ruined now, and I'd recommend if you want to read book 2, you better do it asap before something gets spoiled for you!

P.S. Still loving the dragons. They are seriously one of the best parts of these books and world. I love their sass, their snark, and just overall, what they bring to the table. 🐉

I love Ridoc's sarcasm and it helped bring levity to the book in general. I really enjoy the side characters in this series and you get really attached to everyone making it enjoyable, but also nerve-racking. 😅

I can't wait for news of book three's release and I've seen articles stating she would let us know 2 weeks after Iron Flames release date, so one more week hopefully and we will know how long we will have to wait for it. Here's hoping it'll only be another 6 months or so and we can have book 3 in our hands by spring. 🤞 I know I'll be pre-ordering multiples this time around and not from just one site, because I don't want the stress of what I went through waiting on Iron Flame to arrive on my doorstep. 🤣

******************

11/12 : 🤯🤯🤯 I need some time to gather my thoughts. I did NOT see that coming.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2023
profile.name: Celene

title: Despite my review, I still recommend this.
body: The mind wrestling I've been doing internally since finishing the book last night as been UNREAL. What star do I give this? Has this exceeded or fell short of my expectation? Am I being swayed by opinions I've seen on this book? Was it really that bad or am I trying to convince myself it was good. These are all of the questions I've been asking myself leading in to this morning. This book has rattled me so much and right now I am so conflicted.  I fought trying to love this book as much as I had hoped I would. And here I am, even now, trying to convince myself. There are parts, so few parts where I was completely immersed and felt the similarity and connection to the Fourth Wing, so let me explain...  Violet; Who is she in this book?? I'm not sure when or if I missed something but I felt the author genuinely failed out FMC. The entire book, we get this insecure, can't make any right decisions...absolutely no character development. I hardly felt like Violet was a second year (Compared to the first book where the older kids seemed "way cool and badass and I couldn't wait for our character to be like that) instead we got this horny and whiny thing. I did like how the author interpreted the responsibility that Violet had to take on like needing to keep secrets and what really happened at War Games to herself in order to protect those around her. It was well written how it took its toll on her and her friendships. Of the badassery in the torture chamber and summoning Liam (theory) to be her guardian angel. Then the entire book, she still cannot hit a target with her lightning. Like, give me a break.  The romance also fell short. Some moments were tender and alluring, but not enough in this developing relationship. In Fourth Wing there was more tension and I'm sure I can speak for everyone....we all FELT it thought the text. The throne scene was amazing, but again ended on a bad note. Instead we got this Jealous X trope creating negative tension and unnecessary drama for our characters. The time spent on that could have been spent on writing other more important things. And speaking of drama, the trust dance we had to endure throughout the book was irritating. The hiding things and keeping secrets from each other only because the other didn't simply ask? Ugh. The author then explains how Xaden is trying to earn back Violet's trust...by doing what exactly? Making violet give him the "three little words". Stop. There is absolutely no detail or explanation when and how Xaden actually WORKS to earn her trust back...oh by simply telling her that there's been an attack on Samara so she didn't have to hear it in Battle Brief? Please. Oh and the letters...we could have been included in those a little more. Maybe I would have stayed in love with him. Again, very one dimensional and a complete downgrade. Just like any other relationship...like "Ope, we are together now. I don't need to try anymore."  This book should have been the next step up. The upgrade. Fourth Wing should have been inferior to this...but I feel it to be completely opposite. The writing....don't even get me started on the writing. So CHOPPY. And rushed. I cannot stand when authors fast forward days, weeks and months and Rebecca did that numerous times throughout. Those could have been precious moments where she could have colorfully grown our characters. But, everything was so...shallow. Lazy. Hardly any world building, and again no character development. Then the information dump that seemed to continuously make my head spin. But then lack of information, especially for our Gryphon squads. We barely even know what's the story about them. Except that Cat is Xadens bitchy X. Yeah, because that's what we want to read about.  But he most disappointing part....the dragons. I really wished for MORE. There should have been so much more as the characters develop a deeper bond with them. Tairn used to be this grumpy dad-like character, full of sarcasm and wisdom. In Iron Flame, he was so....boring. And Andarna, my favorite. Rebecca let me down so much with that done. She slept more than half of the book and was written so dully. All I got was this arrogant and annoying "adolescent" character who lacked depth and absolutely no connection to Violet what so ever. But then swoops in and saves the day at the end of the book...  To conclude, the only reason I even finished it was because my attachment to the first book. Hope. Iron Flame was entirely too long, and I wondered why it took me a week to finish it. It was a drag and painful. Overall I am disappointed and this did not meet my expectations. I really hope for Rebecca to turn this around when she plans to continue writing this story. I will give her that the cliffhanger was insane and shocking. But again, no depth. I think this could be really amazing, but the writing needs A LOT of work. If you've made it this far and wondering if I'd recommend it? Yes, of course. It's a good story, but I am glad I finished it and can now move on.

But then swoops in and saves the day at the end of the book...

To conclude, the only reason I even finished it was because my attachment to the first book. Hope. Iron Flame was entirely too long, and I wondered why it took me a week to finish it. It was a drag and painful. Overall I am disappointed and this did not meet my expectations. I really hope for Rebecca to turn this around when she plans to continue writing this story. I will give her that the cliffhanger was insane and shocking. But again, no depth. I think this could be really amazing, but the writing needs A LOT of work. If you've made it this far and wondering if I'd recommend it? Yes, of course. It's a good story, but I am glad I finished it and can now move on.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2023
profile.name: Aleksandra L.

title: Warning: Some Spoilers
body: I feel like FBAA, Zodiac Academy and ACOTAR have me prepared to expect all kinds of twists and turns which I think helped soften some of them.  Overall, I loved Iron Flame. It reminded me of the second From Blood and Ash book - there was a lot of world-building and major conflict set up. However, (and trust me I'm usually advocating for less books) I think the first and second half could have been different books. I felt like Varrish (aka Umbridge 2.0) went away way to fast for the kind of villain he was. I was always waiting for him to pop off and he had me on edge. I think we could have been given more Basgiath second-year moments beforehand - like the Interrogation scene should have happened closer to the end of the second year (not the exact day it was supposed to but closer).  The interrogation scene gutted me though - Liam - I sobbed. I was not prepared.  As always, Tarin is my favorite character, but Andarna grows on me more and more. The ended was a semi-throw out of left field, but I'm not mad about it. However, after having read two books where the H and h were separated for the entire book...it feels like that might be how book 3 is, but I hope I'm wrong.
body_html:
I feel like FBAA, Zodiac Academy and ACOTAR have me prepared to expect all kinds of twists and turns which I think helped soften some of them.

Overall, I loved Iron Flame. It reminded me of the second From Blood and Ash book - there was a lot of world-building and major conflict set up. However, (and trust me I'm usually advocating for less books) I think the first and second half could have been different books. I felt like Varrish (aka Umbridge 2.0) went away way to fast for the kind of villain he was. I was always waiting for him to pop off and he had me on edge. I think we could have been given more Basgiath second-year moments beforehand - like the Interrogation scene should have happened closer to the end of the second year (not the exact day it was supposed to but closer).

The interrogation scene gutted me though - Liam - I sobbed. I was not prepared.

As always, Tarin is my favorite character, but Andarna grows on me more and more. The ended was a semi-throw out of left field, but I'm not mad about it. However, after having read two books where the H and h were separated for the entire book...it feels like that might be how book 3 is, but I hope I'm wrong.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2024
profile.name: Erin Larrivee

title: Very Enjoyable
body: Fourth wing was my favorite read last year, and thus my expectations were sky high. Even though I did not think Iron Flame truly lived up to those expectations it was still a very enjoyable book and worth every penny. I found Iron Flame to be a bit messy at times, and that the structure of the story, that I personally felt had been very present in Fourth Wing, was not really there. I also felt that one specific storyline was not necessary at all - the storyline regarding Xaden`s ex, Kat. I don`t usually have a big issue with exes getting introduced to the story, but when they behave the way Kat did I find that i very much do have an issue. While I think that she redeemed herself towards the end of the book I still found the conflict between her and Violet to be very unecessary. However, this was more or less my only gripe with the story. I adored the sibling relationship between Brennan, Mira and Violet, and the friendship between Rhiannon and Violet as well. The underlying plot of this series is something i wholeheartedly enjoy, I find the dragon politics to be very interesting, and as I learn about the venin and the history of this world, I yearn to learn even more. The author has a way of writing that completely pulls you into the story, and even though reading Iron Flame took me longer than reading the first one (3 days), I truly enjoyed every moment. As I said, Fourth Wing was my favorite read from last year and it completely consumed me during the 24 hours i spent reading it. Considering this, I think my expectations would have been too high no matter what Iron Flame was like. It also does help how utterly gorgeous the book is;).The twist towards the end left me reeling and I truly cannot wait for the next book in this series.

profile.name: Selma

title: Twists, Turns, Ex-Girlfriends, Great Sex! It's all here!
body: Edge of your seat action in the end that leaves you pinned you won't be able to reach for the ejection handle! They'd die for each other... They'd kill for each other. Who makes the ultimate sacrifice... I didn't see it coming, hopefully you don't either. While I don't think I'd make the cut as a Rider by God do I want one of their patches! Can't wait for the next book.  ***Spoiler*** Oh and Jack-Fucking-Barlowe!!! Never hated a character so much (in a good way you'll feel the anger too and wish you could could punch his smug face in also) I had a feeling he was working with someone but it was not who I thought... What a twist! ***End Spoiler***
body_html:
Edge of your seat action in the end that leaves you pinned you won't be able to reach for the ejection handle! They'd die for each other... They'd kill for each other. Who makes the ultimate sacrifice... I didn't see it coming, hopefully you don't either. While I don't think I'd make the cut as a Rider by God do I want one of their patches!
Can't wait for the next book.

***Spoiler***
Oh and Jack-Fucking-Barlowe!!! Never hated a character so much (in a good way you'll feel the anger too and wish you could could punch his smug face in also) I had a feeling he was working with someone but it was not who I thought... What a twist!
***End Spoiler***
date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2024
profile.name: Ted R.

title: Still recovering from reading this a second time!
body: I'll start by saying I cannot wait for book 3. I have read this book twice now just because I enjoyed both books so much. Now that the 3rd book has been announced, I may have to read again, a few more times. I loved this addition to the series. Again, the author went above and beyond when creating this wonderfully written book that flowed so well. I did not want to put the book down. I continue to think that Violet is seriously a bad ass lead character and she really seems to be coming into her own and owning the fact that she can do anything and everything all on her own if she chose to do so. This complex story finds V and Xaden putting their lives on the line for what they believe in, and who can fault them for that. Violet is thinking for herself, dealing with drama and trauma from all ends and learning more about how her world really works. The character building, world building and overall plot is thickening so book three cannot come at a better time. The romance scenes are again quite graphic so for those who enjoy that type of reading material, you will not be disappointed. I still say the author could do without all the details of the romance scenes and still have a magnificent and successful series. To each their own. Overall I enjoyed this book just as I did the first. I give this book 5 out of 5 stairs.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2024
profile.name: Darla Yocom

title: WOW
body: I just finished this book and My heart is pounding. I loved the first book, Fourth Wing. Didn't think I'd love this one as much but I do. It started out slow but wow when it picked up I couldn't put the book down. This is the first series about Dragon Riders I've ever read and it is glorious. Imaginative and exciting. Thanks to Rebecca Yarros for the wonderful adventure she has provided to her readers with this series. To those considering the books if you like a strong willed heroine who has her faults like all of us, and an even stronger anti hero - strong in body will and mind who's hopelessly in love with the heroine and if you love arrogant witty dragons then Fourth Wing and Iron Flame are the books for you. I'm on pins and needles as I await the next in the series.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2024
profile.name: Lunatta

title: Incredible, 7/5 Stars!
body: This book was incredible! It is exactly what I look for in a fantasy/romance/war series. The fact that this author takes her time in laying the groundwork and developing her characters in a way that doesn't feel dragged out or unneeded while also completely submersing you in the romance and battle scenes with so much anxiety and tension is truly a work of art. There were times I didn't think I could read fast enough because the scene was so explosive and imaginative. It truly was a rollercoaster of emotions; laughter, heartbreak, comradery, confusion, love, epiphanies, sorrow, hate. The list goes on. Safe to say I was never bored. The integrity Rebecca maintains in this world is extremely notable. This may be a fantasy/romance series, but it's also war and it's cruel. That makes the stakes so much higher and the way she makes her readers feel that emotion says everything about her writing and storytelling. I've seen several people say they hated the ending and that upsets me. The ending was SUBLIME! I want to be shocked. I want to be floored. I want to have never guessed that's how it could have gone and that is what Rebecca delivers. Kudos to you, Rebecca Yarros. I will be spending the next 9 months theorizing what happens all for her to probably shock me to my core again. I'm truly on the edge of my seat for what happens next in this amazing world she's created.

profile.name: Liddy

title: My heart is racing
body: I just finished this and my heart is still racing from the battle at the end of the text, at the cliffhanger, at the change in Fate.  While I I felt the beginning dragged a little, perhaps because of the back and forth between Violet and Xaden, once things got moving. It was a constant rush. A few highlights include an old girlfriend who really makes things tough, much deadlier enemies, the return of the most horrible foe, A family reunion, and some really steamy love scenes. If you like the first book, you will not be disappointed with this one.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2024
profile.name: Siobhan Jurczyk

title: Everything hurts & I need book 3
body: It has been almost two weeks since I finished and my gosh I still can't stop thinking about this book. I have many thoughts so I'm going to try and narrow it down to the most important things but I feel like this is still going to be all over the place.  The pacing of this story was immaculate! There was not a moment where I was bored and waiting for the story to pick up or there were any scenes that didn't pertain to the overall plot. Everything was happening so fast throughout the story and yet it still felt like it was showing the information that was needed to keep the story rolling. I was unable to put this book down, while I was at work I had to force myself to stop reading to answer calls when they came in and I hardly ever have this issue. I went on a trip with some friends and I was so excited to have a few hours of reading time on the plane and then my silly little self was in too much of a hurry to get out of the car at the airport that I left my book in the car *cue the beginning of a mental breakdown in the TSA line* I kid you not I was racing through the airport to find a store that had a copy because there was no way I was going to be able to wait 3 days before picking it back up. It has been so long since I have felt that compelled by a book to go out of my way and buy a second copy and paying double what I paid for my preorder.  So much happens and every chapter I was going "what the heck?!" So many twists and turns that I did not see coming, some came no where close to crossing my mind of being a possibility. There was so much mental screaming going on I thought my head would explode. I'm normally a very quite reader, I make faces while reading things but very rarely do I make any audible noises and let me tell you this book got me. I was laughing out loud, gasping, and voicing my thoughts in the moment. At one point I apologized to my coworker at the beginning of her shift because I was going to be annoying.  I do have one issue with this installment and it is Violet being really annoying about her relationship/ not relationship with Xaden. She was constantly going back and forth and I'm just like.... girl please get it together. Like I get it but also there are more important things that need attention other than your relationship crisis. I'm hoping with this ending of this book that that issue has been solved because there is nothing else Xaden can do to prove to Violet that he is hers and trusts her completely.  I love the Sorrengail siblings, their relationship reminded me a lot of my sibling and I... you know minus the one of use pretending to be dead for 6 years. Also Mira decking Brennen in the nose upon first seeing him killed me cause that is 100% something I would do in that situation lmao.  The theories I have seen since finishing have been wild man, like I cannot wait to see what ends up being true and how it all connects. In the meantime I will be screaming and crying over this ending and then foaming at the mouth for book 3.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2023
profile.name: Rich

title: I’m invested in this story
body: I love this story and can’t wait for the next book. I did struggle to finish this one though which after FW was a let down.  My critiques for this book is that it was too long and yet somehow not long enough. I feel like 200 pages could have been cut out by taking out somewhat pointless scenes. There was a lot of time spent on needless angst. Yet somehow with 800+pages there wasn’t a ton of character development on anyone who wasn’t Violet or Xaden. Would love to have loved a supporting character as much as I loved Liam in FW….also Sloane was a huge game changer in this story but she was barely mentioned beyond her crossing the parapet.  Xaden is still book boyfriend goals. I’ll be waiting patiently for the Onyx Storm!

date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2024
profile.name: Whitney

title: A bit predictable but surprised me in ways as well
body: Held off reading this since last year and finally had the time to actually pick it up and read it. I don’t know if that’s the best thing I did or the worst cause I knew I was getting a cliffhanger at the end of this book (series always do cliffhangers 😭) or the one of my great ones cause at least now I can satiate my curiosity about what happens on this book. I should have held myself back and waited for the third book to at least come out cause that ending, while I knew was gonna be a cliffhanger, was not it. I need answers and a continuation now please, thank you very much 😩😂  Putting aside that one, the read was enjoyable and although this book frustrated me so much that is had me hitting my pillow so much that I think that if there was a pillow justice system, my pillow would have cold the pillow cops on me to get me arrested for hitting them so much. That’s how frustrated I became when reading this book.  I mean, I get where Violet and Xaden was coming from (kinda) but the “You need to ask me, Violet” Xaden was REALLY NOT IT for this book. I love the man but I found that there was a lot of the time I wanted to jumped into the book and pull the man’s hair to release the annoyance I felt during those moments. Don’t even get me started on Violet. I love the girl (I really do) but she needs to get a grip—I’m done (zipping up my mouth or stopping my fingers from typing, whichever is fine) I’m not ranting anymore cause my heart is pumping so much for some reason (I think it might have to do with the cliffhanger but I’m not diving into that again 😂) and I am so glad that I don’t have to do anything tomorrow cause now I’ll be up all night thinking about what could possibly happen on the next book 😂  Anyways, I give it a 3 stars cause I did enjoy it but I felt like this could have been better.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2024
profile.name: Allyson Armado

title: Obviously amazing!
body: Ok, first off, Xedon is a dreamboat and I’m not really sure if real men like him exist but all men need to take notes. If you’re not like Xedon, we don’t want you. :)  Second, I’ll admit that the first part of the book was rough to get through. Even some of the second part of the book was a struggle. There is A LOT of info dumping. I do think some of what was in this book wasn’t needed. It was hard to keep going so I took a break.  Thankfully, I pressed on. The ending— omg.  I did feel like Xedon wasn’t himself for some of the book but then he came back near the end. I wanted to cry because he’s such a well written character.  Violet goes through a lot and I really loved the struggle with her. Her feeling like a failure made her realistic and I really appreciated that. I also love her motivation for everything she is doing. Violet is a beautiful female character.  I can’t wait for the next book! And I also want to state that I’m very intrigued by Aaric. I need more of him. :) The dragons are also one of my favorite parts of the book! I adoreeee them.  All in all it gets a 4, whereas the first book gets a 5 because I was on the edge of my seat the entire time with book one. This book was a little bit of a struggle throughout until the end when things finally felt like they were moving. I also struggled not getting as much Xedon in this book. I can’t say it enough, he’s just one of the best book characters out there. I also love reading his point of view. And have I said how much I love Xedon?! 😂

All in all it gets a 4, whereas the first book gets a 5 because I was on the edge of my seat the entire time with book one. date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2024
profile.name: Kindle Customer

title: Good but not as good as the first one
body: 1. The whole premise of the conflict that led to the rebellion was faulty for me. Because to be honest, I totally can understand why a country would choose to protect its citizens. NO country would open up its people to an undefeatable danger for the sake of saving another country. Its silly. 2. That being said. It was still ridiculous that Navarra would choose to keep their people ignorant. The realistic thing would be to use the outside danger as a rallying point for the people and justification for the rulers’ positions. That the author chose to have the leaders keep people ignorant didn’t make sense to me. It wasn’t even a strategic decision. Maybe it will become clearer in later books I don’t know. But I doubt I will still remember the series well enough to be interested in picking up a continuation in a year or so. This is why I generally don’t pick incomplete series and when I do so it is a mistake—one which I sorely regret for this book. 3. I love love in my books so I am always happy to have a serious against all odds romance like Xaden and Violet’s but the juvenile angst in the Xaden-Violet relationship just got too silly for me in this book. And the cliché of Violet being the silly one wanst lost on me.it always surprises me how authors write badass female characters sho somehow should go against the gender styreotypes. But they always make them play into the styreotypes on the character front. They are always the irrational ones, constantly making unrealistic demands – how do you give a leader of a movement an ultimatum in your relationship because you insist he gives you all his secrets EVEN if they endanger other people’s lives. She was unable to shield but still wanted to be trusted with the rebellion and Xaden’s full secrets. I mean COME ON! This all felt out of place in a clearly adult age group book. It’s the sort of thing I expect in young adult. How do you get angry with someone for keeping a secret that could get them killed?? That being said, I still deemed it a 3.5 for the creative world and magic system. It really is promising if she can give us a more mature, more strategic and less whiney female lead next time. I just hope I will still remember the first two books by then.
body_html:
1. The whole premise of the conflict that led to the rebellion was faulty for me. Because to be honest, I totally can understand why a country would choose to protect its citizens. NO country would open up its people to an undefeatable danger for the sake of saving another country. Its silly.
2. That being said. It was still ridiculous that Navarra would choose to keep their people ignorant. The realistic thing would be to use the outside danger as a rallying point for the people and justification for the rulers’ positions. That the author chose to have the leaders keep people ignorant didn’t make sense to me. It wasn’t even a strategic decision. Maybe it will become clearer in later books I don’t know. But I doubt I will still remember the series well enough to be interested in picking up a continuation in a year or so. This is why I generally don’t pick incomplete series and when I do so it is a mistake—one which I sorely regret for this book.
3. I love love in my books so I am always happy to have a serious against all odds romance like Xaden and Violet’s but the juvenile angst in the Xaden-Violet relationship just got too silly for me in this book. And the cliché of Violet being the silly one wanst lost on me.it always surprises me how authors write badass female characters sho somehow should go against the gender styreotypes. But they always make them play into the styreotypes on the character front. They are always the irrational ones, constantly making unrealistic demands – how do you give a leader of a movement an ultimatum in your relationship because you insist he gives you all his secrets EVEN if they endanger other people’s lives. She was unable to shield but still wanted to be trusted with the rebellion and Xaden’s full secrets. I mean COME ON! This all felt out of place in a clearly adult age group book. It’s the sort of thing I expect in young adult. How do you get angry with someone for keeping a secret that could get them killed??
That being said, I still deemed it a 3.5 for the creative world and magic system. It really is promising if she can give us a more mature, more strategic and less whiney female lead next time. I just hope I will still remember the first two books by then.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2024
profile.name: Avid reader

title: Excellent storytelling
body: This author has the gift of being able to effectively craft an engaging plot and to develop characters. She creates an underlying romance that doesn't overpower the story, and a heroine who isn't waiting to be saved. I would call it YA due to the ages of the characters, but it doesn't feel shallow or awkward.
body_html: This author has the gift of being able to effectively craft an engaging plot and to develop characters. She creates an underlying romance that doesn't overpower the story, and a heroine who isn't waiting to be saved. I would call it YA due to the ages of the characters, but it doesn't feel shallow or awkward.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2024
profile.name: Ishtar81

title: Intense
body: My mind was reeling when I finished Iron Flame. I loved every minute of it. To see how much stronger and cleverer Violet gets is exciting. I love how she uses her brains when her body won’t cooperate. And those dragons! I love the dragons!  Some people have really criticized this book and compared it directly to the first, Fourth Wing. That is a huge mistake in my opinion. This series is going to be at least 4, maybe 5 books in all. The end of Iron Flame is nowhere near the end of the whole story. I think it was great as a bridge to the next. And after that shocker of an ending I can’t wait to see what happens. Others complained about the constant back and forth of trust issues with Violet and Xayden. Remember - they are very young adults, especially Violet. She is reacting true to her age. I loved the book and give it 5/5 ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️  “Everyone expected Violet Sorrengail to die during her first year at Basgiath War College—Violet included. But Threshing was only the first impossible test meant to weed out the weak-willed, the unworthy, and the unlucky. Now the real training begins, and Violet’s already wondering how she’ll get through. It’s not just that it’s grueling and maliciously brutal, or even that it’s designed to stretch the riders’ capacity for pain beyond endurance. It’s the new vice commandant, who’s made it his personal mission to teach Violet exactly how powerless she is–unless she betrays the man she loves. Although Violet’s body might be weaker and frailer than everyone else’s, she still has her wits—and a will of iron. And leadership is forgetting the most important lesson Basgiath has taught her: Dragon riders make their own rules. But a determination to survive won’t be enough this year. Because Violet knows the real secret hidden for centuries at Basgiath War College—and nothing, not even dragon fire, may be enough to save them in the end.”
body_html:

Others complained about the constant back and forth of trust issues with Violet and Xayden. Remember - they are very young adults, especially Violet. She is reacting true to her age. I loved the book and give it 5/5 ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

But Threshing was only the first impossible test meant to weed out the weak-willed, the unworthy, and the unlucky.  Now the real training begins, and Violet’s already wondering how she’ll get through. It’s not just that it’s grueling and maliciously brutal, or even that it’s designed to stretch the riders’ capacity for pain beyond endurance. It’s the new vice commandant, who’s made it his personal mission to teach Violet exactly how powerless she is–unless she betrays the man she loves.  Although Violet’s body might be weaker and frailer than everyone else’s, she still has her wits—and a will of iron. And leadership is forgetting the most important lesson Basgiath has taught her: Dragon riders make their own rules.  But a determination to survive won’t be enough this year.  Because Violet knows the real secret hidden for centuries at Basgiath War College—and nothing, not even dragon fire, may be enough to save them in the end.”

title: Great sequel!
body: The plot starts out a little slow but picks up fairly quickly. By the time I was halfway through the book, I had a hard time putting it down. I never saw that ending coming! That said, I can’t wait to read the next book in the series!

profile.name: Candice

title: I don’t want to give this 5 stars…but it’s like a 4.75
body: Holy flaming hot chetos, what did I just read? -spoilers ahead-  This entire book was so stressful!! I spent most of it wondering who was going to die next.  Rebecca really went for “how can I stress out my readers the most?”  Oh Violet. Seeing her struggles throughout this book had me wanting to cry. Part one struggling at Basgiath. Then struggling outside it.  Xaden. Omg Xaden just went full on commitment mode this book. When he goes all in he goes ALL in …..literally 😭 I’m broken. I’m broken beyond repair and idk  Tairn. Yo Tairn really upped his sass game this book. The dragon arrogance was on POINT. Watching him defend Violet made my heart swell  Fourth Wing: Rhi, Ridoc, and Sawyer. I spent way too much time expecting one of these people to die. I love them too much. I don’t want to lose them. Please don’t take them away from me.  The first years were interesting this year. I will admit the two we got to know were veeeerrrryyy conveniently placed in the story. I’m interested to see how they will continue. I especially want to see Aaric’s signet manifest and what that will be.  Andarna: girl I knew it!! I knew this girl was special. The thing with the scales right away said she was different. Omg tho, was not expecting that outcome with the whole waiting for Violet thing. Really made Violent into that typical YA-fantasy chosen-one trope there. Idk how I feel about that.  This book was way too fast paced. I don’t want to say it was too long…but it felt long. And I read this in like 3 days. This was a lot. I mean I’ll likely continue the series but I won’t lie, with everything going on around Rebecca Yarros, I’ll keep getting my content from the library.

profile.name: Amber Daugherty

title: Regrets. Dislike Xaden no matter what his reasons
body: I regret starting this series. I did not realize, of course, the outcome of this plot. The type of angst throughout the whole series between Violet & Xaden. I loved Violet's character, who was considered a weakling but who proved everyone wrong, especially Xaden. But why then did the author have Violet become such spineless, cringey fool over Xaden? She actually begged him to love her over & over! I felt nauseated by the way she obsessed over his beautiful face & body. I equally hated his smirkyness, his manipulation of her feelings even after he started caring for her in his twisted limited way. And the ending of this 2nd book! Angst to the very end, which I said before I dislike this type of plot that will cause more hurt & suffering for Violet. 4 stars because I have to admit the author writes an intense story filled with fascinating characters & fierce dragons.

profile.name: Orchid

title: Not as good as the first one
body: Violet was a very likable and charming character in the first book. In this book she displays immaturity and becomes non likable. During life and death situations she either wants to fight with her boyfriend or jump his bones. This boyfriend apparently has a lot going for him. What he sees in her is beyond me. Violet continually tells us how hot her boyfriend is and is constantly jealous and picking fights with him based on irrationality. The author has above average skill but the book get bogged down in meaningless description and trivial detail.

profile.name: Kindle Customer

title: You cannot convince me that she didn't write this with AI
body: SPOILERS ** SPOILERS ** SPOILERS - Still actively reading, but I need to rant.  I am about halfway through this book but wanted to start writing a review now so I don't forget anything.  First off, I think it is a little funny that when the group of cadets is discussing the unity of Navarre they're discussing how a language was lost among groups of people. That the unification only benefited three particular provinces. It has been irking me since I first read Fourth Wing that Yarros was using Gaelic incorrectly...and of course by now, I'm sure you've seen all the videos of true Gaelic speakers bringing awareness to this. Yet, she actively chooses to be ignorant by mispronouncing not only the language entirely, but the dialect. And she literally put it in her book. So, she knows what she is doing.  Second, Violet has got to be the most obnoxious character I have ever read. The way she is so mad about Xaden keeping things from her is outrageous. If we look at the big picture, the two hardly know anything about each other. Why she thinks she has earned the right to know all of his secrets is beyond me. And same, that he doesn't deserve to know any of hers outright. But she is behaving like a spoiled brat. Thousands of lives are at stake and she's pissy that he won't tell her this info, knowing she can slip. (Which she does. She spills the beans to all of her friends. It is a good thing he didn't trust her to keep her mouth shut, because she can't. I don't care the intentions.) And when she does spill the beans, she gets irritated that her friends aren't blowing up and furious at her the way she is at Xaden. (You'd think she would realize that makes her the problem, but no.)  Third, this book is absolutely filler. I'm at page 274 currently and at least 100 pages could have been cut out. The whole back and forth of Violet and Xaden arguing, but not really making any progress is redundant. Why this wasn't condensed is beyond me.  Fourth, ward keys? Really? She couldn't come up with any thing else? Couldn't try to call them something even a little different? Previously a lot of readers mentioned there were parallels to SJMaas's ACOTAR books. I didn't catch it in Fourth Wing (and maybe that's because I was listening to the audiobook on double the speed so I wouldn't have to hear how stuffy the narrator was) but there are significant elements that stand out to me now in Iron Flames. I can see several from ACOTAR and TOG.  As of right now this book is getting two stars and that is being generous.  UPDATE:  Wow, now Violet has siphons just like the bat boys. And listen, I know in some books there will be similarities. It happens. The Fourth Wing story is an easy read. It doesn't deep dive into fantasy the way most books do within its genre so maybe I should have expected this. But there are too many similarities from Maas's work that are blatant. Again I'm wondering where a proper editor was so something like this could have been avoided.  So far, I have not read anything unique in either of these books. So far, there is nothing original. Nothing has wowed me. I do like Xaden. I think he is a fun and strong character. It is really hard to root for Violet. At this point, I would be happy if she was written off (and somehow the dragons and Xaden live) and someone else take the spotlight.  Ok, we are around page 500 and things have started to pick up. This book is all drama. As if we didn't have enough of it already, insert Cat who is a b*tch just because she can be. Just goes back to that I don't feel this is a true rep of fantasy. Fantasy is an element, of course, but sometimes I feel like I'm reading some cheap reality show. And Violet....Lord have mercy. Violet is still a loose cannon and not in a Rin type of way from The Poppy War. She's a loose cannon because she continues to act like she is thirteen years old and can't take accountability for her own actions. And the rare occasions that she does, she just throws a pity party.  FINAL UPDATE: Ok I finished it and my gosh....it did not get better. I'm leaving this at a two star review and that is being VERY generous.  Now that we know Xaden turns venin...did anyone else catch this is exactly what happens to Dmitri in Vampire Academy? Where he is reluctantly turned strigoi and in Blood Promise Rose has to off him? I would not be surprised if in the third or fourth book that Xaden is written off. At the very least, this is another blatant similarity to another well established book and author.  If this comes out that any sort of AI was used to write this book, I will not be surprised. Disappointed, but not surprised. WHERE WERE THE EDITORS???? Scenes should have been cut entirely, these similarities could have been handled better (if they truly were not stolen) and rewritten, dialogue was cringe. I saw someone else mention that she wondered about the AI, if not a ghost writer. Something is up with this book and not in a good way. I believe Red Tower is pushing so hard for a money grab that quantity became more important than quality.  Violet's character development continues to go downhill. (And again, this isn't the masterpiece chaotic development that Kuang used for Rin. This is just...awful and embarrassing.) Cat is still an unnecessary character that I believe was thrown in for the reality TV lovers, the readers that crave drama. Xaden is the glue holding this story together and if she does go the same route that Richelle Meade took, then the series is in trouble. (As if it isn't already.) This was a filler book that deserved more time and effort.  Worst book I've read in a long while.
body_html:
SPOILERS ** SPOILERS ** SPOILERS - Still actively reading, but I need to rant.

I am about halfway through this book but wanted to start writing a review now so I don't forget anything.

First off, I think it is a little funny that when the group of cadets is discussing the unity of Navarre they're discussing how a language was lost among groups of people. That the unification only benefited three particular provinces. It has been irking me since I first read Fourth Wing that Yarros was using Gaelic incorrectly...and of course by now, I'm sure you've seen all the videos of true Gaelic speakers bringing awareness to this. Yet, she actively chooses to be ignorant by mispronouncing not only the language entirely, but the dialect. And she literally put it in her book. So, she knows what she is doing.

Second, Violet has got to be the most obnoxious character I have ever read. The way she is so mad about Xaden keeping things from her is outrageous. If we look at the big picture, the two hardly know anything about each other. Why she thinks she has earned the right to know all of his secrets is beyond me. And same, that he doesn't deserve to know any of hers outright. But she is behaving like a spoiled brat. Thousands of lives are at stake and she's pissy that he won't tell her this info, knowing she can slip. (Which she does. She spills the beans to all of her friends. It is a good thing he didn't trust her to keep her mouth shut, because she can't. I don't care the intentions.) And when she does spill the beans, she gets irritated that her friends aren't blowing up and furious at her the way she is at Xaden. (You'd think she would realize that makes her the problem, but no.)

Third, this book is absolutely filler. I'm at page 274 currently and at least 100 pages could have been cut out. The whole back and forth of Violet and Xaden arguing, but not really making any progress is redundant. Why this wasn't condensed is beyond me.

Fourth, ward keys? Really? She couldn't come up with any thing else? Couldn't try to call them something even a little different? Previously a lot of readers mentioned there were parallels to SJMaas's ACOTAR books. I didn't catch it in Fourth Wing (and maybe that's because I was listening to the audiobook on double the speed so I wouldn't have to hear how stuffy the narrator was) but there are significant elements that stand out to me now in Iron Flames. I can see several from ACOTAR and TOG.

As of right now this book is getting two stars and that is being generous.

UPDATE:

Wow, now Violet has siphons just like the bat boys. And listen, I know in some books there will be similarities. It happens. The Fourth Wing story is an easy read. It doesn't deep dive into fantasy the way most books do within its genre so maybe I should have expected this. But there are too many similarities from Maas's work that are blatant. Again I'm wondering where a proper editor was so something like this could have been avoided.

So far, I have not read anything unique in either of these books. So far, there is nothing original. Nothing has wowed me. I do like Xaden. I think he is a fun and strong character. It is really hard to root for Violet. At this point, I would be happy if she was written off (and somehow the dragons and Xaden live) and someone else take the spotlight.

Ok, we are around page 500 and things have started to pick up. This book is all drama. As if we didn't have enough of it already, insert Cat who is a b*tch just because she can be. Just goes back to that I don't feel this is a true rep of fantasy. Fantasy is an element, of course, but sometimes I feel like I'm reading some cheap reality show. And Violet....Lord have mercy. Violet is still a loose cannon and not in a Rin type of way from The Poppy War. She's a loose cannon because she continues to act like she is thirteen years old and can't take accountability for her own actions. And the rare occasions that she does, she just throws a pity party.

FINAL UPDATE:
Ok I finished it and my gosh....it did not get better. I'm leaving this at a two star review and that is being VERY generous.

Now that we know Xaden turns venin...did anyone else catch this is exactly what happens to Dmitri in Vampire Academy? Where he is reluctantly turned strigoi and in Blood Promise Rose has to off him? I would not be surprised if in the third or fourth book that Xaden is written off. At the very least, this is another blatant similarity to another well established book and author.

If this comes out that any sort of AI was used to write this book, I will not be surprised. Disappointed, but not surprised. WHERE WERE THE EDITORS???? Scenes should have been cut entirely, these similarities could have been handled better (if they truly were not stolen) and rewritten, dialogue was cringe. I saw someone else mention that she wondered about the AI, if not a ghost writer. Something is up with this book and not in a good way. I believe Red Tower is pushing so hard for a money grab that quantity became more important than quality.

Violet's character development continues to go downhill. (And again, this isn't the masterpiece chaotic development that Kuang used for Rin. This is just...awful and embarrassing.) Cat is still an unnecessary character that I believe was thrown in for the reality TV lovers, the readers that crave drama. Xaden is the glue holding this story together and if she does go the same route that Richelle Meade took, then the series is in trouble. (As if it isn't already.) This was a filler book that deserved more time and effort.

Worst book I've read in a long while.

title: Iron Flame
body: In my opinion I thought that this book was a solid well written novel. My only problem with it was that certain aspects of the book dragged on way too long and that there was a lack of new atmosphere. The plot twists were easy to easy except the end. The first book opened this up to a lot more then I thought that it produced.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2024
profile.name: Emily

title: Great Follow Up for the Dragon Lovers!
body: After Fourth Wing I immediately had to pick up Iron Flame! There was no question, there was no processing, I had to keep going.  The tension between Violet & Xaden is still there as they’re navigating how to really be in a relationship & if they can trust each other. Violet’s world has basically been turned upside down & now she has to pretend as if things are ok. Xaden is determined to prove to her that while there may have been some very big lies in her world, his love for her has been nothing but true. Their push & pull was just so fun to read… ugh I have heart eyes as I’m typing this.  We get to meet new adversaries who put Violet through some real crap…. Oh my god I can’t begin to explain how much rage I felt b/c of some of these characters. For the record, these Aetos men are mediocre as hell & I hate them. Violet is pushed to her limits & I really enjoyed reading about her containing control in her power. I also liked how much more of the political side we saw our fave characters have to navigate.  Just like book one, I couldn’t put this book down. I needed to know what was happening next! There are a boatload of twists, & even if I saw some of them coming I was still enthralled to keep going. That cliffhanger was such a doozie, I definitely can’t wait to see what comes next in the Empyrean series!

profile.name: wildforbooks

title: I cannot get enough of this series!!!
body: Epic fantasy Romantasy War college Dragons Dragon riders Magic Cutthroat Battles Secrets Touch her and die Smart FMC Gryphons FMC living with physical disorder High stakes Found family Corruption Betrayal Torture Morally gray MMC Shadow Daddy Cliffhanger Second book in a series Spice: 2.75/5  FMC: Violet Sorrengail MMC: Xaden Riorson  Did I enjoy the book? Yes Would I read this book again? Yes Will I continue the series? Yes, can’t wait Will I read from this author again? Yes  I am all about escapism and this story does just that. For a little while, I can escape to this beautifully crafted world full of action packed adventure, love, and fantasy. I don’t care what anyone else says, this story checks all my boxes. That being said, I loved the whole cast of characters. The deaths of some characters were shocking and some others were surprising. It felt very GOT in the fact that I didn’t want to love a character too much because I wasn’t sure if they were going to survive. Violet kind of started to annoy me with the whole tell me all your secrets and do it right now to Xaden. They just started a relationship. No one tells all their secrets right away in a new relationship. They come out gradually and over time. That’s a natural progression. Other than that, loved Vi. Xaden was amazing as always. Just loving Violet and doing everything he can to protect her and tell her what secrets he could. The letter passing back and forth was so romantic. He became overprotective at one point, but Violet put him in his place. Loved that scene. I love that she never backs down when she feels she is right and is passionate about something. I missed that he didn’t call her Violence much at all. This book had its spicy moments but wasn’t all that spicy which was fine with me. They were in the middle of so much war and action that who would have the time. When they did find the time is was Hawt. Honestly, this book is so good I could have gone spice free and still been 5 stars. The plot was action packed, constantly changing and new revelations being made. So much happened I’m still wrapping my mind around it. One plot hole that bugged me and it may be *spoiler* so stop reading here if you don’t want to know. The wards were failing in Aretia and they fell in Basgiath and Vi said she could only save one of them. Why? Why couldn’t Andarna do both with her fire? Basgiath was chosen. So what happens to Aretia? Since some dragon hatchlings chose to hatch there it has restored the magic there. What is going to happen to the hatching grounds at Aretia now that the wards will fail? This is just a huge plot hole to me and I will definitely be disappointed if it isn’t covered in the next book.
