Spice: 2.75/5

FMC: Violet Sorrengail
MMC: Xaden Riorson

Did I enjoy the book? Yes
Would I read this book again? Yes
Will I continue the series? Yes, can’t wait
Will I read from this author again? Yes

I am all about escapism and this story does just that. For a little while, I can escape to this beautifully crafted world full of action packed adventure, love, and fantasy. I don’t care what anyone else says, this story checks all my boxes.
That being said, I loved the whole cast of characters. The deaths of some characters were shocking and some others were surprising. It felt very GOT in the fact that I didn’t want to love a character too much because I wasn’t sure if they were going to survive.
Violet kind of started to annoy me with the whole tell me all your secrets and do it right now to Xaden. They just started a relationship. No one tells all their secrets right away in a new relationship. They come out gradually and over time. That’s a natural progression. Other than that, loved Vi.
Xaden was amazing as always. Just loving Violet and doing everything he can to protect her and tell her what secrets he could. The letter passing back and forth was so romantic. He became overprotective at one point, but Violet put him in his place. Loved that scene. I love that she never backs down when she feels she is right and is passionate about something. I missed that he didn’t call her Violence much at all.
This book had its spicy moments but wasn’t all that spicy which was fine with me. They were in the middle of so much war and action that who would have the time. When they did find the time is was Hawt. Honestly, this book is so good I could have gone spice free and still been 5 stars.
The plot was action packed, constantly changing and new revelations being made. So much happened I’m still wrapping my mind around it.
One plot hole that bugged me and it may be *spoiler* so stop reading here if you don’t want to know.
The wards were failing in Aretia and they fell in Basgiath and Vi said she could only save one of them. Why? Why couldn’t Andarna do both with her fire? Basgiath was chosen. So what happens to Aretia? Since some dragon hatchlings chose to hatch there it has restored the magic there. What is going to happen to the hatching grounds at Aretia now that the wards will fail? This is just a huge plot hole to me and I will definitely be disappointed if it isn’t covered in the next book.

profile.name: *erin*

title: Just as good as #1
body: If you liked Fourth Wing, you will enjoy Iron Flame. I loved both!!  What I will say is that I missed A LOT when I read it. Because it’s such an easy read, the story is deceptively dense…especially the first 13ish chapters. I did quite a bit of Googling and texting with fellow Empyrean Series nerds to find info I missed. My rec is to read Iron Flame as close to finishing Fourth Wind as possible so you don’t forget details. But, if that window is already passed for you, still read it but be ready to Google a few times (or message me 😜). Never fear, the interwebs LOVE this series and all the info you may have forgotten is very readily available with a quick search.  If you’d prefer to join me deeeeeeep down the Fourth Wind/Iron Flame rabbit hole, I recommend the Fantasy Fangirls podcast where they review each section of the book in detail. I didn’t realize how many details I’d missed in my initial read of both Fourth Wing or Iron Flame until I listened to these deep dives. Also…conspiracy theories abound (and I love it)! 🤓

profile.name: Tammy Nates

title: A well organized trove of Bill's sensible, fact based humor.
body: I don't always agree with Bill Maher, but I am a fan. The thing I do whole heartedly agree with him is that open dialogue in this country is greatly needed. We all need to get out of our echo chambers and try to empathize with "the other side". The majority of Americans are not binary when it comes to politics.  This book is a reflection of his humor, wit, and often his frustration with the lack of common sense in this country. There is enough in this book to both entertain and piss off those one the left and the right. Yes, it leans left in a "classical liberal" sense, but Bill will just as soon call out the left which seems to have lost all common sense over the past 8 years. For sensible people, this book great comedic entertainment based in reality.  It's very well organized and an easy read. Something you can pick up and flip through for a few laughs, or read cover to cover. Bill seems to be very meticulous with his work (Club Random aside) and it shows in this book. Highly entertaining and humorous, while thoughtful and critical when called for.

profile.name: Mak

title: What This Comedian Said Will Make You Laugh Hysterically
body: In this book Bill Maher skewers both the Cult of Trump and the Church of the Woke. He addresses what he calls Zombie Lies, nonsense that refuses to die no matter how often it is debunked. He addresses the urgency to address climate change and our failure to do so. He makes fun of the sanctimonious hypocrisy in show business, media and society, the racket our universities have turned into, cancel culture, the new attacks on free speech, and he addresses the problems with the Republican party as well as the Democratic party. He brings up a lot of important points that we typically avoid talking about, or can’t even talk honestly about without being shamed, all while adding compelling insights. In the last chapter he has an important message for all of us.  In the past I did not always agree with Bill Maher, especially the period when I was a staunch Republican (centrist now), and I also don’t agree with a lot of aspects of his lifestyle, but I’ve always found him to be funny and smart. I laughed out loud on every page. In fact, I do not recommend that you read this book in public places. People may think you are crazy for sitting somewhere and continuously chuckling to yourself, or mistake you for a Hyena, depending on how your laughter sounds like. I also found that I agreed with almost everything he said. There were a few things I did not agree with him on, but I forgive him for being wrong a few times. He made me laugh more than I have laughed in a long time, while also making me think. This book will anger some people, but before you get too upset about something, read the whole book and try to enjoy the parts that entertain you. I think they exist almost regardless of who you are.  I highly recommend this book to everyone with a sense of humor.
body_html:
In this book Bill Maher skewers both the Cult of Trump and the Church of the Woke. He addresses what he calls Zombie Lies, nonsense that refuses to die no matter how often it is debunked. He addresses the urgency to address climate change and our failure to do so. He makes fun of the sanctimonious hypocrisy in show business, media and society, the racket our universities have turned into, cancel culture, the new attacks on free speech, and he addresses the problems with the Republican party as well as the Democratic party. He brings up a lot of important points that we typically avoid talking about, or can’t even talk honestly about without being shamed, all while adding compelling insights. In the last chapter he has an important message for all of us.

In the past I did not always agree with Bill Maher, especially the period when I was a staunch Republican (centrist now), and I also don’t agree with a lot of aspects of his lifestyle, but I’ve always found him to be funny and smart. I laughed out loud on every page. In fact, I do not recommend that you read this book in public places. People may think you are crazy for sitting somewhere and continuously chuckling to yourself, or mistake you for a Hyena, depending on how your laughter sounds like. I also found that I agreed with almost everything he said. There were a few things I did not agree with him on, but I forgive him for being wrong a few times. He made me laugh more than I have laughed in a long time, while also making me think. This book will anger some people, but before you get too upset about something, read the whole book and try to enjoy the parts that entertain you. I think they exist almost regardless of who you are.

I highly recommend this book to everyone with a sense of humor.

profile.name: Thomas Wikman

title: A book that’s hard to put down
body: I’ve loved Bill’s show Real Time for years and always look forward to watching it Friday night for the great conversations with smart people and Bill’s very funny commentary. He’s done a wonderful job putting this book together and it’s hard to put down with so many deep and funny insights into human idiocy. I think when I’m done, I’ll start again at the beginning. Here’s one gem I just read:  “Did you ever wonder, for example, why shaving needs to keep reinventing itself? Men used to shave with a sharp rock. Then there was the straight razor. The single-blade razor, the double-blade razor, the three-blade razor and now the Quattro. Let me tell you something—if you’ve got something on your face that doesn’t come off after three blades, that’s not a whisker, that’s a tumor.”  We love you, Bill.

“Did you ever wonder, for example, why shaving needs to keep reinventing itself? Men used to shave with a sharp rock. Then there was the straight razor. The single-blade razor, the double-blade razor, the three-blade razor and now the Quattro. Let me tell you something—if you’ve got something on your face that doesn’t come off after three blades, that’s not a whisker, that’s a tumor.”

We love you, Bill.

title: I wish I could get my money back!
body: I watch Maher's program each Friday it's on. This book exposes Bill for who he is: a guy who looks at the Democrats through rose colored glasses while seeing Republicans through opaque cataract lenses. Frankly, he has his head so far up his ass that he apparently has eaten the part of his brain that is responsible for rational thinking. If Democrats haven't paid Bill for this propaganda, well, Mr Maher, they owe you money! Please do yourself a favor and read something interesting, and don't waste your precious time and money on this book.

profile.name: Doug Crump

title: Resubmission
body: I gave a carefully nuanced review of Maher's book with the above number of stars, and it was rejected because of some violation of the submission rules. I cannot find anything in that review which does not adhere to the list of prohibitions I was provided. In fact, his book seems to violate many of them. So, I will be as bland as possible and state that readers who may have a Maga cap or a Hamas flag in their closets should avoid this book to prevent unnecessary blood pressure elevations, since Maher throws bricks at both extremes of the political spectrum. Many of his commonsense observations strike home and a few laughs will be discovered along the way.

title: What we need right now
body: You ever look around and think to yourself… what happened to the US in USA? Half the cars with an American flag on them are no longer red white and blue.. they have some type of symbolism.. a thin blue line… all black out.. covered in skulls… there’s not a great time to go back to or to go make great again… most of US just want decent food, fair wages, affordable housing and not to be lied to. This book is so comforting.. bill isn’t saying the quiet parts out loud he shouting them.. reminding everyone that between the left and the right there’s a center and we just want common sense to be common.

title: A perfect beach read.
body: I love reading Elins books. They're something I always look forward to in the summer. This one is the final book in the Nantucket series and her final beach read (for now), after a fantastic run of amazing, beachy novels. I haven't read all her books but have read a lot of them. They always give me such a summery feeling. I really liked this one, just as I have her others.  A new rich couple, the Richardson's, has moved to Nantucket with their concierge Coco. They have lavish patties and all the locals are present. The local chief of police is getting ready to retire at the end of summer, but when the Richardson's mansion goes up in flames AND their concierge goes missing, he delays his retirement to handle this one last case.  If you haven't read one of her books yet, and love reading beachy reads with all the summer vibes, what are you waiting for? I still have some to get to, and hope to eventually read them all. Love her books!

profile.name: B Burke

title: Excellent insight into an underappreciated essential to America
body: The Situation Room, which covers how the White House is set up to gather and disseminate information to the President and his advisors, particularly in times of crisis, is an excellent, fast-paced, entertaining, and informative book. Starting with the Kennedy Administration, the book captures several well-known scenes -- e.g., Johnson becoming obsessed about Vietnam, the elimination of Osama bin Laden, the 9/11 attack on America, among others -- and how the people assigned to this particular position in the White House answered their Country's call, even if it potentially required them to sacrifice their lives. While author Stephanopolous does an excellent job of capturing the context, without bogging down in details, the book clearly shows how America has dealt with the ones of information that increases all the time. The epilogue, and the concern as to whether AI will mandate changes in the limited time available for the consideration of issues, is also telling and, to some extent, disconcerting. To be sure, introductions to various Presidents is helpful, but it is not as in depth as desired for those needing a moment-by-moment analysis of everything that went into every decision. But, the book points out why that is not possible, why some information is still classified after years, and why it is appropriate to trust the dedicated servants assigned to staff this location. An excellent read for anyone who wants to be informed on how decisions are made.

An excellent read for anyone who wants to be informed on how decisions are made.

profile.name: James S Carter

title: An Insiders Look At One Of The Most Important Rooms In The US
body: Many people only know George Stephanopoulos from hosting a morning TV show, but he previously served as a senior adviser to President Bill Clinton. Now drawing on his experience and insider knowledge plus information from many interviews, his book The Situation Room: The Inside Story of Presidents in Crisis provides an in-depth exploration of the White House Situation Room, detailing its evolution and pivotal role in American crises. From its inception after the Bay of Pigs fiasco to its digital transformation in 2023, the book examines how presidents and their advisers have used this critical space for decision-making during significant historical events. Through personal anecdotes and interviews, Stephanopoulos reveals both the technological advancements and the human elements that have shaped the Sit Room’s function in handling nuclear scares, terrorist attacks, wars, and political scandals.  Initially resembling a mundane corporate meeting room, it gradually evolved into a high-tech command center. The book tracks its role from the Vietnam War and the collapse of the Soviet Union to the 9/11 terrorist attacks and the operation to kill Osama bin Laden. The book also touches on notable moments such as the near-nuclear confrontation during the Yom Kippur War in 1973, the hostage crisis on the day of Reagan’s inauguration, and the immediate chaos following the 9/11 attacks.  The Sit Room's transformation over the decades reflects advances in technology and the increasing complexity of global threats. By 2023, it had become a digitally advanced, ergonomically designed complex known as the WHSR. Despite these advancements, Stephanopoulos feels nostalgic for the earlier, less sophisticated days. Through his detailed account, the book captures the essence of the Sit Room as both a symbol of presidential power and a crucial element in safeguarding national security.  Five Highlights  1. Creation and Evolution: The Sit Room was created after the Bay of Pigs fiasco to centralize information and improve presidential decision-making. Initially a plain meeting room, it has evolved into a sophisticated command center.  2. Technological Advances: From handwritten notes and typewriters to computers and video teleconferencing, the Sit Room's technology has significantly advanced, culminating in its 2023 transformation into the WHSR.  3. Crisis Management: The book covers major historical events managed from the Sit Room, such as the Vietnam War, the collapse of the Soviet Union, the 9/11 terrorist attacks, and the operation to kill Osama bin Laden.  4. Presidential Styles: Stephanopoulos provides insights into the different management styles of presidents, from Nixon’s incapacitation during the Yom Kippur War to Obama’s handling of communication with Vladimir Putin.  5. Human Element: Despite technological advancements, the human element remains crucial. The book highlights moments of tension, humor, and camaraderie among Sit Room staff and presidents, illustrating the room's role in American governance.  The most important lesson from Stephanopoulos’ The Situation Room is the critical importance of effective communication and centralized information in crisis management. The evolution of the Sit Room underscores how technological advancements have enhanced decision-making capabilities, but it also highlights that the human elements of leadership, judgment, and collaboration are irreplaceable in navigating complex global crises.
body_html:
Many people only know George Stephanopoulos from hosting a morning TV show, but he previously served as a senior adviser to President Bill Clinton. Now drawing on his experience and insider knowledge plus information from many interviews, his book The Situation Room: The Inside Story of Presidents in Crisis provides an in-depth exploration of the White House Situation Room, detailing its evolution and pivotal role in American crises. From its inception after the Bay of Pigs fiasco to its digital transformation in 2023, the book examines how presidents and their advisers have used this critical space for decision-making during significant historical events. Through personal anecdotes and interviews, Stephanopoulos reveals both the technological advancements and the human elements that have shaped the Sit Room’s function in handling nuclear scares, terrorist attacks, wars, and political scandals.

Initially resembling a mundane corporate meeting room, it gradually evolved into a high-tech command center. The book tracks its role from the Vietnam War and the collapse of the Soviet Union to the 9/11 terrorist attacks and the operation to kill Osama bin Laden. The book also touches on notable moments such as the near-nuclear confrontation during the Yom Kippur War in 1973, the hostage crisis on the day of Reagan’s inauguration, and the immediate chaos following the 9/11 attacks.

The Sit Room's transformation over the decades reflects advances in technology and the increasing complexity of global threats. By 2023, it had become a digitally advanced, ergonomically designed complex known as the WHSR. Despite these advancements, Stephanopoulos feels nostalgic for the earlier, less sophisticated days. Through his detailed account, the book captures the essence of the Sit Room as both a symbol of presidential power and a crucial element in safeguarding national security.

Five Highlights

1. Creation and Evolution: The Sit Room was created after the Bay of Pigs fiasco to centralize information and improve presidential decision-making. Initially a plain meeting room, it has evolved into a sophisticated command center.

2. Technological Advances: From handwritten notes and typewriters to computers and video teleconferencing, the Sit Room's technology has significantly advanced, culminating in its 2023 transformation into the WHSR.

3. Crisis Management: The book covers major historical events managed from the Sit Room, such as the Vietnam War, the collapse of the Soviet Union, the 9/11 terrorist attacks, and the operation to kill Osama bin Laden.

4. Presidential Styles: Stephanopoulos provides insights into the different management styles of presidents, from Nixon’s incapacitation during the Yom Kippur War to Obama’s handling of communication with Vladimir Putin.

5. Human Element: Despite technological advancements, the human element remains crucial. The book highlights moments of tension, humor, and camaraderie among Sit Room staff and presidents, illustrating the room's role in American governance.

The most important lesson from Stephanopoulos’ The Situation Room is the critical importance of effective communication and centralized information in crisis management. The evolution of the Sit Room underscores how technological advancements have enhanced decision-making capabilities, but it also highlights that the human elements of leadership, judgment, and collaboration are irreplaceable in navigating complex global crises.

profile.name: DES

title: fascinating read about possibly the most important room in the nation
body: George Stephanopoulos, with leaders from so many administrations willing to talk to him, has written an incomparable account of the evolution of the Situation Room and the vital role it played in each generation of its existence, up to today. In the process, it retraces what administrations, both Republican and Democrat. Have done some of the most fraught times in our nations history. It highlights some of the unsung, a political heroes who have all the work behind the scenes to distill information for our leaders. Unique in this entire 70-year history is the lack of respect of Donald J Trump for the role of this vital institution and the valuable information provides in a dangerous world.

title: Inside Story of Presidents in Crisis
body: This book should be a must read in high school and college history classes, and should be read by those of us my age (70) who need reminders of the grave issues that have faced our nation over the years. It starts with the Kennedy administration and goes up to the current years including what happened in the situation room during the 9/11 attacks and the January 6th attack. It's intriguing and informative.

title: The History of the Situation Room
body: My thanks to author George Stephanopoulos, Grand Central Publishing, and NetGalley for the opportunity to review an ARC of this new book. I attest this review is my own unbiased and objective work.  We've all heard of the White House Situation Room. What we lacked was an understanding of when and how the Situation Room evolved over the course of time. The research behind this book consisted of numerous documents and interviews with the actual participants and people who worked in the Situation Room. Author and broadcaster George Stephanopoulos guides the reader through the development and history of the Situation Room (hereafter abbreviated as SR) through the past eleven Presidencies in this highly readable and interesting new book.  Starting with the Kennedy administration, we learn how the SR operated in a very crude manner in the time it took to relay information primarily through a system of telephone lines, which may have helped contribute to the Bay of Pigs debacle early in JFK's presidency. This was inferred from reading the text, not explicitly stated by the author. From there the SR is examined from the Johnson to the current Biden presidencies.  There are many remarkable moments in the book depending on your own perspective of history. For me the most interesting chapters were those devoted to the two Bush presidencies (for GHW Bush the fall of the Berlin Wall, collapse of the USSR; for GW Bush the story of 9/11 and its aftermath). However, there are many other interesting stories such as LBJ's obsession with the Vietnam War; the Mayaguez Incident in the Ford years; and the rogue actions by Oliver North that took place during the Reagan White House.  There is also a very interesting juxtaposition of the parallel events involving Operation Eagle Claw in the Carter administration to try and rescue hostages in Iran, and Operation Neptune Spear which resulted in the assassination of Osama Bin Laden in Pakistan. A central character in these chapters is Robert Gates, former US Defense Secretary who was a witness to both the failed and successful raids.  I am a big fan of Presidential History and was excited to have the chance to read the book. I found it very well written and engaging, and highly recommend it if interested in the subject.  @GrandCentralpub
body_html:
My thanks to author George Stephanopoulos, Grand Central Publishing, and NetGalley for the opportunity to review an ARC of this new book. I attest this review is my own unbiased and objective work.

We've all heard of the White House Situation Room. What we lacked was an understanding of when and how the Situation Room evolved over the course of time. The research behind this book consisted of numerous documents and interviews with the actual participants and people who worked in the Situation Room. Author and broadcaster George Stephanopoulos guides the reader through the development and history of the Situation Room (hereafter abbreviated as SR) through the past eleven Presidencies in this highly readable and interesting new book.

Starting with the Kennedy administration, we learn how the SR operated in a very crude manner in the time it took to relay information primarily through a system of telephone lines, which may have helped contribute to the Bay of Pigs debacle early in JFK's presidency. This was inferred from reading the text, not explicitly stated by the author. From there the SR is examined from the Johnson to the current Biden presidencies.

There are many remarkable moments in the book depending on your own perspective of history. For me the most interesting chapters were those devoted to the two Bush presidencies (for GHW Bush the fall of the Berlin Wall, collapse of the USSR; for GW Bush the story of 9/11 and its aftermath). However, there are many other interesting stories such as LBJ's obsession with the Vietnam War; the Mayaguez Incident in the Ford years; and the rogue actions by Oliver North that took place during the Reagan White House.

There is also a very interesting juxtaposition of the parallel events involving Operation Eagle Claw in the Carter administration to try and rescue hostages in Iran, and Operation Neptune Spear which resulted in the assassination of Osama Bin Laden in Pakistan. A central character in these chapters is Robert Gates, former US Defense Secretary who was a witness to both the failed and successful raids.

I am a big fan of Presidential History and was excited to have the chance to read the book. I found it very well written and engaging, and highly recommend it if interested in the subject.

@GrandCentralpub

profile.name: Emma

title: Must buy for your Dad!!
body: Must buy these books for your parents! I have been on my own since age 16 when my parents left for the Middle East and lived overseas 19 years. And I honestly don't know a whole lot about my parents or their history. My dad is now 86 (this is my stepdad) and my mom is 84. I bought one book for each and my dad has told me he has already started completing it. They live in the Northwest and I'm in Washington, DC and they won't let the kids come home to visit because of the Coronavirus so I can't be there to fill this book out asking him questions and really didn't expect him to complete it but apparently he is and I am so thrilled! I can't wait to get it back from him and my mom. For $9, This book is fun for my dad to fill out with my mom as they reminisce over the questions and it will be something I will treasure for the rest of my days. When I receive it I'm going to print photocopy every page to send a set to my brothers and sister. On Facebook they are promoting something called my story for about a $100. This is fabulous and I highly recommend you buy it as well and perhaps if you are a new dad or a new mom, buy the books yourself so that you can pass this information on to your own children as they grow up, because we never know what tomorrow will bring.

profile.name: Jamie

title: Great purchase!
body: Great purchase! I’m so happy with this. I call my 92 year old dad every night and he after talking about the weather, what he had for dinner, what he did during the day, and what are you watched on TV we are out of things to talk about. Now most nights I will say “do you want to do the book?” And he will say “yes” or” a short one.” This really gets him thinking and remembering stories to share from the past. Instead of sending it to him to fill out, which I knew he would probably never do, it works out perfectly for me to keep the book and ask him questions over the phone. I bring it with me when I go to visit him and we will sometimes do a question after dinner. Just about the only reason why I can get him to turn off the TV for a few minutes!

profile.name: Paulette Zak

title: Great way to bond
body: This was so cool. I got one for my Dad, and I got the Mom version for my Mom. Knowing my Mom way better, it was a fun way to get some more details in writing. But for my Dad, it was totally different. Without divulging too much information, my parents divorced over twenty years ago, and my Dad and I have stayed close, and he's always been there for me, but a lot of times in a way that I felt was superficial, having a few meaningful conversations in my adult life, but not many. This book opened the door for him to share much more personal information about his life, his feelings, and his experiences growing up. It made me feel a lot closer to him, and started some new dialogue on similarities I had no idea existed between us. It made who I am make more sense, and cast my Dad in a new light. Don't hesitate to purchase this book, regardless of your relationship with your parent. The worst it can do is expose your political differences, the best, is open up dialogue that brings you closer than ever before, or at least give you a better understanding of who your parent is outside of being your parent.

profile.name: Craft1

title: Goes Too Far Back
body: I truly want to learn more about my dad, but this journal was not the way to go for me. The first few questions ask things like, "What was your length and weight at birth? What were your first words? ......What were you like as a toddler?". Not only do these questions lack substance, but they also require Dad to have second hand information from his parents. The assumption there is that he had involved, caring parents. That is a pretty huge assumption, especially for a person of his generation. I'm afraid giving him this journal would just make him sad.

profile.name: Cory Armstrong

title: Informative & transformative
body: I have long been a fan of Dr Michael Mosley. From his TV documentaries and the development of the 5:2 intermittent fasting approach to weight loss, his books are written with clarity, easy to understand ideas, backed with comprehensive research and scientific/medical information. Mosley is a try before you buy person...what he writes and recommends is based on personal experience. He advocates based on his experience, in this case, gaining 14lbs in weight to test the efficacy and practicality of an 800 calorie per day fasting diet. Common sense ideas for weight loss: obesity and overweight being the medical issue that afflicts many in our society. Highly recommended.

profile.name: Tony Frobisher

title: Will change your health chances for the better if you follow what it says, more than a diet book.
body: You can read cover-to-cover or open anywhere and pick bits out. This book is written in a style that keeps your interest and keeps offering nuggets of information or ideas. It explains things so that anyone could understand. It cites the sources for all data so you can either trust the author or check up on it by looking up what the researchers found. There are recipe plans using normal ingredients, calorie and carbohydrate info, health benefits are discussed beyond weight loss. The author likes to experiment on himself and report back. He is a doctor and his wife is a nutritionist and both contribute to the book and to his experiments. I lent the book to a neighbour who returned it, saying that she had gone out and bought her own copy. The author has a business selling food replacement shakes and he earns money by going round on tour speaking about the low carb diet but you do not have to pay any more money than the price of the paperback. Did we lose weight? Yes, one of us from Overweight to Normal and one from Obese to Normal. Have we stayed at the weight? Yes, apart from a couple of kilos gained over Christmas. At one point husband started noticing some hair loss. Googled “Keto Hair Loss”, it said not enough protein. Upped the protein and all well again. If you stick to what the book says, including when to eat, not just what to eat, you will lose weight dramatically. Did this book change our lives? I can honestly say yes. It has kept diabetes, heart problems, obesity-related cancer etc a step further away.

profile.name: Amazon Customer

title: Genius
body: I have been determined for years to find a diet that works and works naturally  I am only 4 days into it and have a gut feeling that this is it, after at least 20 years of trying unsuccessfully to lose weight. Like much modern medicine most diet plans treat just the symptoms. This diet treats the cause. I am nearly 60 and was at the cusp of resigning myself to being fat until I die. I have tried more diet regimes than you have fingers to count them on, plus a few I made up myself. So I can confidently say that this time I have feelings of relief (finally) and confidence that my obesity sickness is being cured. If the diet sounds harsh, it is but it is also surprisingly easy! I am now enjoying every bite of my delicious food with no desire to keep on eating all day, no more fear of feeling hungry, and no more carrying snacks in my handbag "just in case"  Thank you Dr Mosley  Addendum: I lost a stone in three weeks going from 14.5 stone to 13.5 Then I lost the plot a bit over a couple of birthday celebrations and put 3lb back on. However it's been easy to get back on track. And I've started losing weight again.

I lost a stone in three weeks going from 14.5 stone to 13.5
Then I lost the plot a bit over a couple of birthday celebrations and put 3lb back on. However it's been easy to get back on track. And I've started losing weight again.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 6 January 2019
profile.name: Wild Flower

title: An amazing book to keep you well and healthy
body: I brought this book to help keep me on the right track to be more healthy and to lose weight that had crept back on over the 2020 lockdown.  After watching Michael Moseley's programme recently aired in July/Aug, I knew this would be the right thing to help me.  Through the entire month of May 2020, I exercised everyday - be it walking, running, trail running, cycling and Hiit workouts and I felt so deflated at the end of May when I felt I had put more weight on than off. (I don't own scales, I go on my clothes and I struggled to fit in anything, which is depressing).  After watching Michael's program, I realised that it's what I am or not eating, so I ordered his new book.  The book is full of facts and credible evidence as why rapid weight loss is best, getting active, the diet in practice recipe's and meal planners. Michael explains the process and flexibility to it, for those who may not be able to do the fast 800. You can do TRE (time restricted Eating) where you eat during a time period so your body fasts over the rest, and when you are sleeping, so eating breakfast a little later or dinner a little earlier. The 5:2, 2:5, 6:1 ect where your fast days are just healthy low carb Mediterranean 800 cal meals.  There's plenty of meal ideas at the back to keep you going and of course you can look at other recipes on the fast 800 website and in other cookbooks.  It's suggested to write down what you consume during the fast 800, which is what I am doing and Calorie counting, until I get to my idea weight and the I'll maintain the diet with a 5:2 or 6:1 and continue to eat healthy. I weigh-in with a family member who is also doing this diet, to keep us both motivated.  A very good read for anyone who wants to be well, healthy and maintain wellbeing.

profile.name: Reader

title: Good on science, sensible programme that works, dull recipes, more needed on behaviour modification.
body: If you are sceptical of diet lore, so-called 'clean' eating and every other fad that's out there, then this book, an update on previous work by Dr Moseley, will be reassuring. The author has revised his original 5:2 programme, based on what he's learned from current research. You don't have to be a science nerd to realise that Moseley is making a genuine attempt to inform readers on how proper scientific research is conducted. There's a helpful section at the back on clinical trials. Issues such as sample size, replication and peer-review of research are important in verifying claims on particular methods of food restriction.  Publishers, of course, want books to make money, so the latest from Dr Moseley, after 5:2, Blood Sugar Diet and Clever Guts, revises earlier assumptions and tailors a diet based on Mediterranean eating that is restricted to 800 calories a day, eaten within a short window of 12 hours or fewer. It's heavy on ketosis, so if you have had your fill of the Keto diet, perhaps this is not for you. It advises on cutting down on 'white carbs' and sugar. It follows the dictum of a famous neurologist who was asked the key to a long and healthy life: "eat lots of plants; move more". The book has a lot of advice on exercise which is a little limited. I think more options could have been briefly outlined so adherents don't feel that they have to do spin classes. Although walking is advocated, I think there could have been more on this. Not everyone will be motivated by HIIT - although it really does work - and will want options.  The diet is flexible: one can stay on 800 per day for as little as two weeks or as much as 8 weeks, then head to 5:2 fasting. The author provides options to be tailored to personal needs.  The range of food available on the diet is wide. You don't have to eat ghastly brown rice or wholemeal pasta, even though the author is a fan. There are other ways of getting slow-release carbs that are less 'diet-dreary'. There are some interesting recipes (the pistachio chocolate and chilli snack is lovely) but many of the options are unimaginative. A diet of this sort could be full of great options. The ones in '800' are an improvement on the 'Clever Guts' recipes which were uninspiring, to say the least. One can still restrict calories, carbs and sugar without having a repetitive and dull diet full of wholegrain pasta and brown rice.  What's a little scant is how behaviour modification works. Dr Moseley is reassuring on willpower. There could, however, be more on eating behaviours and how to modify them. This is where the Beck Diet is effective. The Beck Diet Workbook is a great option on eating behaviour.  My suggestion is: embrace the diet, pay attention to the science, look at other, similar (low carb, protein-rich, calorie-controlled) more imaginative recipes/plans than the ones in the book. If you are a good cook, you can probably work it out yourself without compromising on calories by using spices more effectively. Have a look at The Healthy Food Guide Magazine for ideas if you are not a confident cook. You don't HAVE to have chia seeds and turmeric and take out a mortgage for the avocados.  No doubt next year's offering will bring more revelations about 'diet-science' and a slightly different direction. Remember, however committed works like these are to promoting sensible eating guided by sound science, they are still commercial products designed to make money. If you're unsure about committing to buying this book, borrow it from the library or wait until about April when the January dieters donate their books to charity shops. The book is worth a read and helpful. The diet will work, as will all restrictive eating plans but this provides a balanced nutritional plan, if unimaginative in execution. Eat more plants; move more.
body_html:
If you are sceptical of diet lore, so-called 'clean' eating and every other fad that's out there, then this book, an update on previous work by Dr Moseley, will be reassuring. The author has revised his original 5:2 programme, based on what he's learned from current research. You don't have to be a science nerd to realise that Moseley is making a genuine attempt to inform readers on how proper scientific research is conducted. There's a helpful section at the back on clinical trials. Issues such as sample size, replication and peer-review of research are important in verifying claims on particular methods of food restriction.

Publishers, of course, want books to make money, so the latest from Dr Moseley, after 5:2, Blood Sugar Diet and Clever Guts, revises earlier assumptions and tailors a diet based on Mediterranean eating that is restricted to 800 calories a day, eaten within a short window of 12 hours or fewer. It's heavy on ketosis, so if you have had your fill of the Keto diet, perhaps this is not for you. It advises on cutting down on 'white carbs' and sugar. It follows the dictum of a famous neurologist who was asked the key to a long and healthy life: "eat lots of plants; move more". The book has a lot of advice on exercise which is a little limited. I think more options could have been briefly outlined so adherents don't feel that they have to do spin classes. Although walking is advocated, I think there could have been more on this. Not everyone will be motivated by HIIT - although it really does work - and will want options.

The diet is flexible: one can stay on 800 per day for as little as two weeks or as much as 8 weeks, then head to 5:2 fasting. The author provides options to be tailored to personal needs.

The range of food available on the diet is wide. You don't have to eat ghastly brown rice or wholemeal pasta, even though the author is a fan. There are other ways of getting slow-release carbs that are less 'diet-dreary'. There are some interesting recipes (the pistachio chocolate and chilli snack is lovely) but many of the options are unimaginative. A diet of this sort could be full of great options. The ones in '800' are an improvement on the 'Clever Guts' recipes which were uninspiring, to say the least. One can still restrict calories, carbs and sugar without having a repetitive and dull diet full of wholegrain pasta and brown rice.

What's a little scant is how behaviour modification works. Dr Moseley is reassuring on willpower. There could, however, be more on eating behaviours and how to modify them. This is where the Beck Diet is effective. The Beck Diet Workbook is a great option on eating behaviour.

My suggestion is: embrace the diet, pay attention to the science, look at other, similar (low carb, protein-rich, calorie-controlled) more imaginative recipes/plans than the ones in the book. If you are a good cook, you can probably work it out yourself without compromising on calories by using spices more effectively. Have a look at The Healthy Food Guide Magazine for ideas if you are not a confident cook. You don't HAVE to have chia seeds and turmeric and take out a mortgage for the avocados.

No doubt next year's offering will bring more revelations about 'diet-science' and a slightly different direction. Remember, however committed works like these are to promoting sensible eating guided by sound science, they are still commercial products designed to make money. If you're unsure about committing to buying this book, borrow it from the library or wait until about April when the January dieters donate their books to charity shops. The book is worth a read and helpful. The diet will work, as will all restrictive eating plans but this provides a balanced nutritional plan, if unimaginative in execution. Eat more plants; move more.

profile.name: bookwoman

title: Brilliant book and knowledgable author
body: I usually struggle to stay interested in books that are medical or non-fiction as most are written in a manner which is very much textbook style, but I must admit this one had me captivated from the word go & I read it all in an afternoon. I found the info interesting and relevant and felt so inspired by his writing that I actually started the diet the next day. I feel more educated and knowledgeable on this lifestyle and how and why it works, which I like as I am the type of person that doesn’t like the concept of “because it just does” - I want to understand the how and whys of things. Dr Mosley’s writing style grabbed my attention and made this an enjoyable read and not just another text book. I happily paid for the book over some of the free titles, after reading the first few chapters as a kindle sample because I found it interesting and fact based. There’s another book I tried reading where the author (not a Doctor either) admits they tried the diet but couldn’t stick to it, but then carried on writing diet recipes. That to me is not a good example - with Dr Mosley’s work however, he has tried all the things he has written about so he not only knows the science behind them but also how it feels to actually do them. That I can get behind and totally respect. He’s not a “do as I say, not as I do” author but has really been there and tried it before sitting claiming to be an expert (not that he makes that claim) as such I already have his other books on my wish list. I told my partner about this book and gave him the summary of it and he also decided to join me in becoming a 5:2er. I’m impressed how dedicated he is to it, so now we have changed our eating times to between 12:00 and 20:00 and also have 2 days a week where we fast, and both are seeing improvements in many areas. Now others at work have expressed and interest in our new eating habits and want to know more, so I am recommending this book to them to also try. Good book and reasonably priced.  UPDATE: 3 weeks in on this diet come new lifestyle, and my partner has lost a stone and I have lost half a stone (which is about right given he is heavier than me and Male and we are both eating approx the same amount of calories). By simply reducing what we eat twice a week and watching the times we eat within, has done us wonders. Granted we both miss our late night dinners (due to shifts we were eating at 21:30 in the evenings most nights) so we feel cheated out of a meal, purely because we haven’t adjusted mentally to the fact we are now just eating it earlier in the day. We aim to have our first meal around 12:30/13:00 and the last one by 19:30 and that seems to be working. We’ve also noticed that even though 5 days are pretty much eating what we want, we are more conscious of what we are eating, selecting healthier meals & ditching the junk. It’s made us more aware of what crap we were eating and now we have cut a lot of rubbish out completely without really much thought. This book has changed our lives for the better in such a short space of time. Thank you Dr Mosley.

profile.name: KD

title: Updated advice
body: I've read most of Dr Michael Mosley's previous books and found this to be a good update. It provides a mixture of Michael's experience, the latest research and some real-life case studies as well as a recommended (but non-prescriptive) programme. Some of it is familiar and some advice has changed (e.g. up the calories on 5:2 to make it more achievable and to get more nutrients). It's quite a quick read as well (and half is made up of recipes but they sound tasty).  Michael Mosley has used the experience and knowledge gained over the last few years since The Fast Diet (5:2) plus I finished the book feeling quite motivated to get started.  In summary, if you've got a lot of weight to lose, try: - 800 calories a day of a Mediterranean-style diet. Review your progress and goals after two weeks and either continue for up to twelve weeks or move to New 5:2. - 5:2 until you reach your goals. - Med-style eating in the main for maintenance (maybe with one fast day for health reasons and easier maintenance).  Other recommendations are included, such as time-restricted eating and exercise suggestions.  A lot of it will be familiar if you've read previous books, but it does provide updated research and is definitely worth a read if you want a boost and a little convincing to get started.  As another reviewer has said, there is some encouragement to go to their website. This was the same in previous books but unlike e.g. the blood sugar diet website you can't get to forums and some info unless you pay to go on their 12 week programme.
body_html:
I've read most of Dr Michael Mosley's previous books and found this to be a good update. It provides a mixture of Michael's experience, the latest research and some real-life case studies as well as a recommended (but non-prescriptive) programme. Some of it is familiar and some advice has changed (e.g. up the calories on 5:2 to make it more achievable and to get more nutrients). It's quite a quick read as well (and half is made up of recipes but they sound tasty).

Michael Mosley has used the experience and knowledge gained over the last few years since The Fast Diet (5:2) plus I finished the book feeling quite motivated to get started.

In summary, if you've got a lot of weight to lose, try:
- 800 calories a day of a Mediterranean-style diet. Review your progress and goals after two weeks and either continue for up to twelve weeks or move to New 5:2.
- 5:2 until you reach your goals.
- Med-style eating in the main for maintenance (maybe with one fast day for health reasons and easier maintenance).

Other recommendations are included, such as time-restricted eating and exercise suggestions.

A lot of it will be familiar if you've read previous books, but it does provide updated research and is definitely worth a read if you want a boost and a little convincing to get started.

As another reviewer has said, there is some encouragement to go to their website. This was the same in previous books but unlike e.g. the blood sugar diet website you can't get to forums and some info unless you pay to go on their 12 week programme.

profile.name: Mrs S

title: Excellent book; let down somewhat by sloppy editing
body: Just how good a communicator Mosley is will become clear very quickly if you try to listen to some of the scientists doing the research on fasting (who talk about RAS, IGF-1, and pathways, etc., as if those meant anything to a layperson). He really is very good, and this is definitely a book worth getting and using.  But there are areas where Mosley has been let down by sloppy editing. To start with, the term 'fast' is used in two quite different ways at different points in the book. It can mean going without any food at all, as in the 3-day 'fast' undertaken by Jenni Russell to cure her autoimmune disorder (let's call that a 'total fast') or the nightly total fast with time restricted eating. But it can also mean what Webster’s dictionary gives as a second definition, which is ‘to eat sparingly or abstain from some foods’--in other words, a 'fast' is a low-calorie diet for a period of time (call that a 'partial fast'; obviously that wouldn't work in the book's title, but a good editor might have suggested that in the text of the book the distinction would have helped to avoid confusion).  Other bad editing shows in the Endnotes: For example, the Jenni Russell story is fascinating to anyone who suffers from an autoimmune condition. But if you go to the reference cited, you find a subscription-only article on The Times website by Helena de Bertodano. If instead you google ‘Jenni Russell fast’, you can find Russell's own article on the Prolon website, which was written 2 months before the one in The Times. This is the sort of thing an editor is supposed to check.  Another confusion (took me awhile to get this straight in my head): --for intermittent fasting, 5:2 means eat on 5 days and observe a partial fast on 2 days (the subject of one of his earlier books, and developed further in this one); --for time restricted eating, 14:10 means the reverse: total fast for 14 hours (overnight), eat for 10 hours. Again, a good editor would have, for the purposes of this book, suggested that that pattern should be consistent: either eat:fast or fast:eat but not switching between the two.  Finally, to save you searching the website and then doing the maths: for the meal replacement shake on his website the800fast, it says that a small meal = ‘200kcal = 5 scoops (50g)'. That means a 400kcal portion = 100g. With 500g in a packet, that gives five 400kcal portions in each packet (which is not mentioned anywhere). That’s a bit expensive compared with what you can find on Amazon. Of course, it could be argued that the quality is better, but that would need to be spelled out, because a look at the ingredients for the different products available shows them to be much the same at less cost.  Timothy Corwen (The Worth of a Person; https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/1790698391/)

Just how good a communicator Mosley is will become clear very quickly if you try to listen to some of the scientists doing the research on fasting (who talk about RAS, IGF-1, and pathways, etc., as if those meant anything to a layperson). He really is very good, and this is definitely a book worth getting and using.

But there are areas where Mosley has been let down by sloppy editing. To start with, the term 'fast' is used in two quite different ways at different points in the book. It can mean going without any food at all, as in the 3-day 'fast' undertaken by Jenni Russell to cure her autoimmune disorder (let's call that a 'total fast') or the nightly total fast with time restricted eating. But it can also mean what Webster’s dictionary gives as a second definition, which is ‘to eat sparingly or abstain from some foods’--in other words, a 'fast' is a low-calorie diet for a period of time (call that a 'partial fast'; obviously that wouldn't work in the book's title, but a good editor might have suggested that in the text of the book the distinction would have helped to avoid confusion).

Other bad editing shows in the Endnotes: For example, the Jenni Russell story is fascinating to anyone who suffers from an autoimmune condition. But if you go to the reference cited, you find a subscription-only article on The Times website by Helena de Bertodano. If instead you google ‘Jenni Russell fast’, you can find Russell's own article on the Prolon website, which was written 2 months before the one in The Times. This is the sort of thing an editor is supposed to check.

Another confusion (took me awhile to get this straight in my head):
--for intermittent fasting, 5:2 means eat on 5 days and observe a partial fast on 2 days (the subject of one of his earlier books, and developed further in this one);
--for time restricted eating, 14:10 means the reverse: total fast for 14 hours (overnight), eat for 10 hours.
Again, a good editor would have, for the purposes of this book, suggested that that pattern should be consistent: either eat:fast or fast:eat but not switching between the two.

Finally, to save you searching the website and then doing the maths: for the meal replacement shake on his website the800fast, it says that a small meal = ‘200kcal = 5 scoops (50g)'. That means a 400kcal portion = 100g. With 500g in a packet, that gives five 400kcal portions in each packet (which is not mentioned anywhere). That’s a bit expensive compared with what you can find on Amazon. Of course, it could be argued that the quality is better, but that would need to be spelled out, because a look at the ingredients for the different products available shows them to be much the same at less cost.

Timothy Corwen (The Worth of a Person; https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/1790698391/)

profile.name: Pimlico reader

title: Life Changing
body: As a woman who has never struggled with weight until I reached that 'certain age', I have finally unlocked the secret to the slowing metabolism of the older woman. All thanks to this book. Previously I had purchased apps which measured macros, calorie counts, steps and all the rest and nothing worked. This book had one chapter in particular that literally 'flipped my metabolic switch', I lost 10kg in as many weeks, the weight has stayed off, and all with little to no additional exercise, no great change to my diet (I cook mediteranean style from scratch every day anyway), minimal calorie counting - a simple awareness is key, and absolutely no step counting whatsoever. I'm plant based which means its a bit harder with no meat, but like giving up smoking, when you've done around 3 weeks on this 'diet', the cravings for 'bad' food, go away, and you can proceed with ease for the rest of your life! Infact, it isn't really a diet, it's a different perspective on food which raises awareness to the effects that certain food groups have on your body. An absolute must, this book should be given free on the NHS.

profile.name: Kindle Customer

title: 6.8lb lost in a week- and still going down.
body: I am really pleased I bought this book. I’ve tried most diets out there and end up giving up, either because it’s too complicated or because I don’t see results fast enough and I lose motivation. I found the case studies and research into rapid weight loss really interesting.  I’ve just reached the end of my first week of 800 cals a day. This is nowhere near as difficult as I thought. I haven’t been as strict on extra low carb count but I have cut out bread, pasta and rice. I had 2 small cheeky potatoes yesterday. Using MyFitnessPal to track my calories I’ve had no problem sticking to the 800 calories and have included a small glass of dry white wine in my allowance most days. I’m not going to lie there are a few days when I’ve felt really hungry and some where I’ve been tempted to scoff the contents of the waitrose cake aisle right there in the shop but it is getting easier and I’m getting to have an idea of the sorts of foods that fill me up better (quark is a lifesaver). I am also trying to do the time restricted eating and generally have a 16 hour fasting window. In my first week I’ve lost 6.8lb and guess I could’ve lost more if I’d reduced my carbs better and not had wine. I’m more than happy though and will continue this for a few more weeks before I switch to the ‘New 5:2’. If you’re looking for quick results that you can then make sustainable over time then this is for you. It doesn’t feel like a crash diet because it talks you through your maintenance plan and how to sustain it. I also bought the recipe book which has some nice ideas. I’ll update when I have more progress.  Edit : after 5 weeks I’ve lost almost a stone and have switched to the new 5:2. I’m still losing roughly 1lb per week this way. My weight loss isn’t spectacular but I don’t have much to lose and I lose weight very slowly so if it’s this fast for me, anyone else I’m sure will have really good results.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 22 March 2024
profile.name: Freckle-buddies

title: A bit disappointing
body: I read the original Fast Diet book years ago and thought it was great. Even though a lot of the theories hadn't reached human trials at that time there was enough there that I gave it a go and successfully lost several stone.  A bad few years and lockdown has seen me gain a lot again so thought I'd give this new version a try.  There's more in here about observed effects of fasting in trials but it wasnt as satisfying a read. The first book really captured his enthusiasm for the subject, but this one felt more like an advert for his website and you could really tell his priorities had shifted. I lost count of the number of times I read something along the lines of "if you want to know more you can find out on my website." It doesn't mention that you can't actually access the site unless you pay a subscription though. I found it galling to have paid for a book, only for it to leave out significant information and tell me I have to pay even more to access it.  Even half of the experts were people selling their own versions of intermittent fasting too, which made it hard to take seriously.  Despite it feeling so much like a sales pitch (and therefore automatically untrustworthy!) there was enough in there that I have been incorporating ideas from it into my diet, like restricting my eating to 8 hours a day. I rarely eat breakfast anyway and I'm not a big snacker so it fits quite well with my lifestyle and it's worth trying and seeing if it makes a difference. I *am* losing weight but not noticably more than I was before I started, so it remains to be seen if it'll be worth keeping up long term.

There's more in here about observed effects of fasting in trials but it wasnt as satisfying a read. The first book really captured his enthusiasm for the subject, but this one felt more like an advert for his website and you could really tell his priorities had shifted. I lost count of the number of times I read something along the lines of "if you want to know more you can find out on my website." It doesn't mention that you can't actually access the site unless you pay a subscription though. Even half of the experts were people selling their own versions of intermittent fasting too, which made it hard to take seriously.

Despite it feeling so much like a sales pitch (and therefore automatically untrustworthy!) there was enough in there that I have been incorporating ideas from it into my diet, like restricting my eating to 8 hours a day. I rarely eat breakfast anyway and I'm not a big snacker so it fits quite well with my lifestyle and it's worth trying and seeing if it makes a difference. title: Best buy!
body: This book is a gem. Everything Michael Moseley says makes sense. Decided to give it a try and am so glad I did. It might not be for everyone but it works perfectly for me. I have a busy life and I struggled to find time to eat and when I did I was eating the wrong things. With time restricted eating (which I was practically doing before) and changing the things I eat I’ve lost 22lbs in a few weeks and now back in the normal BMI range. Can’t believe how easy it is and how good the food is. Well worth a try!

date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 31 October 2023
profile.name: Elaine

title: A Fascinating Look at the Science of Longevity — and How to Apply It
body: Having been interested in longevity studies for over a decade, I was super excited to check out this book and learn more about intermittent fasting on a more basic level. Though a practitioner of intermittent fasting since 2014, I still had a lot to learn!  This book is well laid-out, easy to read, and well researched. I definitely wouldn’t recommend it for those with eating disorders (or those who have recently recovered), since calorie restriction, though without a pure weight loss focus, is a major theme throughout the book.  I found the emphasis on being realistically healthy and happy (without toxic positivity) refreshing for a health book. With other books in the genre, you often find a kind of “Put your mind to it,” approach, but Michael Mosley writes as someone in your corner — on your side.  Definitely recommend! :)
body_html:

I found the emphasis on being realistically healthy and happy (without toxic positivity) refreshing for a health book. With other books in the genre, you often find a kind of “Put your mind to it,” approach, but Michael Mosley writes as someone in your corner — on your side.

Definitely recommend! :)
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 14 June 2023
profile.name: Esme 🌧

title: It works - that's all you need to know.
body: This book was a revelation to me. The first part of the book lays out the 'science' of following a ketogenic-style diet, and suggests different approaches you might adopt - some being easier than others. The second part is recipes, most of which I have not bothered with, though the portobello pizza is a winner.  I'm writing this review 41 days after following the fast800 diet, and can confirm this works superbly. I've now lost 22 pounds, but I did combine this with rigorous daily exercise so this speeded up the effect! Like all diets the Fast800 requires discipline and commitment, but this was so easy to follow largely because the rules are very simple. In my case, I skipped breakfast and only ate between 1pm and 7pm. Two main meals a day, no snacking, and daily exercise.  Why is this better than anything else I've tried? Firstly, because losing weight relatively quickly is extremely motivating and helps you keep going. Secondly, reducing calorie intake and dropping the carbs had an effect I wasn't anticipating - reduced hunger pangs and more energy! I think this is probably why low carb diets are becoming all the rage. I just didn't get the cravings I've experienced on other diets. Don't get me wrong - it's still tough to do this and will require consistent focus, but this is an eating program that presents you with rational choices and puts you firmly in control of your weight loss. Even better, it sets you up with a good strategy (5:2) to help you maintain the weight loss after the "intense" period is over. Good luck!

profile.name: Egxrx

title: Incredible results!
body: Bought this book with the Blood Sugar Diet, both by Dr Michael Mosley, to help me to get back on track after this lockdown year of little exercise/ not watching my diet. Had piled on 2 st 4lbs, but could not work out why. I had kept to low calorie/low fat foods, not realising the amount of carbs I was taking in. I read both books carefully, did all the planning ready to start, ie : getting rid of any foods I hoped not to eat, and taking stock. Followed the Fast 800 diet to the letter! As told, the gnawing hunger went after 48 hours, and I kept all meals within a 12 hour period. Started a week ago at 10.4 st, BMI : 30.30. Today, just 7 days later, the scales said 9.4st, and BMI down to 26.2. Whist I am not diabetic, my blood sugar levels were initially very high, now in a normal range. Still have a long way to go as I should weigh just under 8 stones, but this rapid weight loss (yes, I know, a lot of that is fluid) has given me the impetus to keep going. I used a combination of real protein and low carb veg, and very low carb protein drinks with added soluble fibre. My whole weeks shopping bill was only half what I'd normally spend on what I'd thought to be a sensible diet. Thank you Dr Mosley for showing me the correct/safe way to diet.

My whole weeks shopping bill was only half what I'd normally spend on what I'd thought to be a sensible diet. Thank you Dr Mosley for showing me the correct/safe way to diet.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 26 January 2021
profile.name: Mary W.

title: This Works!
body: This is the easiest and by far the most successful diet I have used to date. Supported and sited by research and a section with recipes to get you started it was an undemanding read that was simple and to the point. Relatively strict in it's purest form, I followed the recommended 800 calorie low carbohydrate phase with a sixteen hour fast window from the last meal, until the break of fast late morning and within a day, found that I did not go hungry. It took a good few weeks however, to finally break through the symptoms of what I presume are a kind of withdrawal of the sugar cravings/effects that left me with with itchy feet {of all things,} and cramping in my calves as well as headaches and a general feeling of fatigue and as if I was starting a bad cold without the snotty nose! I also stopped my major sugar craving within two days and after two months {9 weeks,} lost 1.5 stone! I have to say I have been very good on this regime with no lapses but then I did not find it hard and a vitamin/mineral replacement and a little extra salt seemed to help with the aches. You do need lots of water and must maintain a good fluid intake and I have kept to three brisk half hour walks every week. After trying to lose really stubborn mid life fat for over 10 years, I have never been able to get beyond a stone until now and I'm still losing and will be finishing the first phase by the twelve week mark. Blood sugars back to normal from pre diabetic markers, lipids back to normal, blood pressure the best it's been since my twenties {twas creeping up!} and more energy and fizz, I am very impressed.....one more stone to go and I will be one, very happy bunny! Highly recommended.

profile.name: jennifer williams

title: This plan really works!
body: I tried Michael Mosely's 8 week Blood Sugar Diet a couple of years ago, to tackle my obesity. It worked very well ,although - like any healthy eating plan - I regained weight when I went back to my old unhealthy habits. So I was keen to try this new, revamped combination of the blood sugar diet and 5:2 diet, incorporating intermittent fasting (time-restricted eating) that is the Fast 800 plan. I am delighted to report that the plan works very effectively, and the rapid weight loss that comes as a result of sticking to the 800 calories is very motivating - I have lost 18 pounds in less than 6 weeks (I have a further 4 stone I would like to lose). I have gone off plan a couple of times, due to indulging at social events, but the weight happily flies off again once I return to plan. I would highly recommend the book, as it feels sustainable for a few months at least (it is recommended you do the 800 calories per day for up to 12 weeks, then switch to the 5:2). As a person who has struggled with overeating and weight gain for many years, this plan helps control my appetite on a daily basis, and has given me hope that I will be able to get to my goal. It contains the most recent scientific research to support it, and the book is an interesting and straightforward read. I've also gone on to buy the Fast 800 recipe book and the Fast Exercise book. Would highly recommend.

profile.name: Bob

title: It worked for me.
body: Although I prefer the original book I do recommend this one as a guide to winning the battle with diabetes. I was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes in 2016 and tried every diet going with limited or no success even though my wife was losing weight I had severe problems doing the same. That was until I went on Michael Mosley ‘s diet of 800 calories a day for 12 weeks and lost 2 and 1/2 stone ( it’s surprising how much you can eat when you choose wisely). The hospital have now said my blood sugar test for 3 months is down in the normal range of 36 with the previous one at 38 which is a vast improvement from the normal 48 I usually got. I now manage to keep my diet at low carbs and high protein and use one or two days a week of Michael Mosley advice to maintain my weight if necessary. My bmi according to the hospital recently has dropped to 27, although they would like to see just 5 pounds more off. A big thank you to Dr Mosley for the wonderful books and tv programmes and hopefully i have managed to get rid of diabetes for good. I also found the period of time restriction for eating useful as well.

profile.name: J. Don

title: More to learn, reinforce and retain
body: Negative reviews on this being a rehash adding little extra, is harsh. I have read some of the earlier books and this adds to the knowledge. Frankly I would be dubious if everything was new. This builds on previous knowledge and is a useful re-read reminding the basic principles and adding the latest findings. I am also reading it in tandem with the Clever Guts Diet which has more focus on the guts vs this which focus is on intermittent fasting, TRE etc  I was not successful with the 5:2 in that I did not fundamentally change my diet, i just tried to fast 2 days a week on 500cal. and then i would switch my days because of some social activity and fail. Some friends have been very successful on 5:2 but not me.  Reading the Fast800 I decided to get fully committed so signed up to the 12 week program. I have to say except for the first couple of days it has been surprisingly easy. The program is very well structured, the website and the options to adjust to your particular circumstances well thought out e.g you can adjust the menus/shopping list to account cooking for 1 or 2 people. My diet is now much more varied; the planning on what to cook is made easy, with the meal planners for each week laid out for you (and customisable). The way it gives you options to do either the Fast800, 5:2 or Mediterranean diet depending on your weight loss/healthy eating needs. It also feels like a re-education for the long term. Alongside the weekly meal planners/recipes there are also weekly exercise programs and 'learnings', again reinforcing what can be found in the books but always fresh as if it were a conversation.

profile.name: fiona

title: It works
body: I don't tend to write many reviews. I have bought this book after finding it on my google search. I have been trying to lose weight for a year. I did not lose much, so was very keen to find something that works. I am healthy BMI and don't need to lose much, but I want to be healthy and fit into my favourite pair of jeans. I took a chance with this book. I read a lot of it the same day I have received. Next day I went to stock up on the food suggested in the book. Today is my forth day on the two weeks 800. I am not going to pretend that it is easy. It is hard not to give up. I managed to lose over 2 pounds in just few days. The recipes are tasty and it can make you satisfied. You do need to drink a lot and keep yourself busy as it is hard not to think of other food to have. I am not sure I can last whole two weeks, but I will definitely do 5-2. I have been doing it anyway, but just didn't know what food to eat to keep the calories low. I feel very motivated and good about myself already.

profile.name: Carol Parry

title: Re-write of previous books
body: If you have never read any of the previous books, then it is a very good book. Practical advice that you can follow and the diet definetly works. However, if you have bought previous books then honestly dont bother. Its updated with some new research and basically saying have large gaps ie 8 or 12 hours between your first and last meal. Not worth purchasing the book for. Its is also fairly repetitive in that the same message is continuously repeated, you can skip pages as you have just read the same message again and again. You get the feeling this is done to bulk the book out. The recipes would have benefited from pictures. A shame, I really like Dr Mosley but feel this is just a cash cow project especially considering to join the website fast800 costs £99 ,! Maybe he had an expensive Christmas

profile.name: kylie parker

title: Contributed to a 15kg weight loss...
body: ..without really trying too hard.  Also saw off my type 2 diabetes. I work in an office where two colleagues are weight induced type 2 diabetics and a third a genetically disposed type 1.  I am the only only of three to have reversed their diabetes.  What's not to like?  The diet plans menus even if not rigidly adhered to will cut your weight if combined with a little exercise.  The portions some recipes illustrate are huge offerings when served at the proportions listed.  I've not read the text just prepared the recipes.  If I was more zealous no doubt my weight loss would have been greater but for the average couch spud this book has been worth the cover price.  Want to loose weight?  Remove Potatoes, bread and most grains from your diet, eat a good salad at lunchtime and don't snack between meals. This book just gives you breakfast and evening meals that will help you feel full as you re-educate your eating habit.
body_html:
..without really trying too hard.

Also saw off my type 2 diabetes. I work in an office where two colleagues are weight induced type 2 diabetics and a third a genetically disposed type 1.

What's not to like?

If I was more zealous no doubt my weight loss would have been greater but for the average couch spud this book has been worth the cover price.

Want to loose weight?

Remove Potatoes, bread and most grains from your diet, eat a good salad at lunchtime and don't snack between meals. This book just gives you breakfast and evening meals that will help you feel full as you re-educate your eating habit.

profile.name: Pow67

title: It certainly working for me
body: A friend recommended this book after she lost over stone and a half. I have a short attention span when it comes to dieting and exercise in that if I don't see quick results I lose faith and interest. Not the case here, the recipes are delicious, quick and easy to make and in the short time I've been doing this (2 weeks) I've lost 5lbs, May not sound a lot but for me it's marvellous, keeps my interest and momentum going until I hopefully achieve my ideal weight. I'll definitely stick with it. I've adapted the recipes and added my own foodstuff but kept the same format. I've not felt hungry once although on occasion I have felt a little tired but I follow the guidance in the book about healthy snacking and soon my energy levels are back. You do need to keep an eye on your calorie count but for the results I've had it's absolutely worth it.

profile.name: Amazon Customer

title: It works!
body: I'm not overweight but I'm a great believer in prevention and I had been trying to lose the same half a stone for God knows how long. I heard about the book and was intrigued about the science. As other reviewers have said it's true that nothing in the book is original in so far that Dr Mosley has already written books and made TV programmes about fasting and TRE but if you're new to the subject then the book is informative. I don't really know how safe it is to be on only 800 calories for an extended period of time but the concept of doing continually until you've lost at least 10% of your weight seems sound enough. Eating 800 calories and doing TRE I've lost 3.7 pounds in 5 days and I can't say that I have found it horrendous. It's fair to say that I don't have quite enough energy to run as when I eat normally, a low calorie and low carb diet will impact on this without a doubt, so instead of doing 5 miles I did 3 miles and part jogged part walked. The book is also quite repetitive and you get the feeling that Dr Mosley is trying the peddle his website for £99 and his shakes get quite a lots of mention. Some of the recipes at the end of the book look quite good but some are ridiculous. Mushroom omelette with 2 mushrooms? A punnet of 250g of mushrooms is 55 calories so for 250 calories you could have a mushroom omelette that's actually worth making. Same thing with the Spanish omelette with 3 cherry tomatoes. Use your common sense and keep it simple but if you need to lose weight give it a go.
