Some of the recipes at the end of the book look quite good but some are ridiculous. Mushroom omelette with 2 mushrooms? A punnet of 250g of mushrooms is 55 calories so for 250 calories you could have a mushroom omelette that's actually worth making. Same thing with the Spanish omelette with 3 cherry tomatoes. Use your common sense and keep it simple but if you need to lose weight give it a go.

profile.name: utopia139

title: Fast, easy, safe, effective
body: I'm now 6kg down in 3 weeks after following the 800kcal per day diet with Intermittent Fasting. I've failed on many diets through boredom at the slow progress but this is surprisingly easy. It takes a bit of getting used to but even if you've never done IF before, provided you have a clear plan it's easy. I find 2 meals per day works better for me than 3. I finish eating by about 7 pm then fast till at least 10 am or later. Some days I have a late breakfast and an early dinner; other days lunch and dinner, depending on my schedule. The recipes are easy and absolutely delicious as well as perfectly balanced and I haven't been tempted to cheat once ! Not only has the weight been coming down but my blood pressure has also dropped and I look and feel great! I thoroughly recommend this book - it does everything it says and the science behind it is clear and very well explained and supported. This is a winner!

date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 21 September 2021
profile.name: Justine

title: Interesting points but some big niggles
body: I did take quite a bit from this, mainly broad encouragement that dieting can work, because frankly for me it hasn’t, not very well (and yes I can count calories thanks). Dr Moseley’s approach will influence what I do from now on. As for the niggles. Well Dr M had a blood sugar problem, so the effect of this approach on blood sugar problems gets a lot of emphasis. Blood pressure barely warrants a mention, though it’s just as big a problem for overweight people. He advocates rapid weight loss but almost in passing tells us of the Matador experiment and the success therein of an on/off approach to dieting. Is this not contradictory? He describes his own experiment with the diet, giving his starting weight and waist measurement but not his height, so no real point of reference for the reader. That’s pedantic, yes, but dieting requires attention to detail. The big irritant though is the recipe section. All the recipes are overly fussy and time-consuming, And you are not going to find those ingredients in a local version of your supermarket. Why not tell us the stuff we can all put our hands on rather than miso, turmeric, cumin and all that middle-class fluff? I have canned, yes, don’t gasp with horror, canned, salmon and mackerel, eggs, loads of normal salad stuff and fruit, low-sugar baked beans, almonds, olive oil. What I can I get off the shelf? I need to ‘open’ rather than cook.

I did take quite a bit from this, mainly broad encouragement that dieting can work, because frankly for me it hasn’t, not very well (and yes I can count calories thanks). Dr Moseley’s approach will influence what I do from now on.
As for the niggles. Well Dr M had a blood sugar problem, so the effect of this approach on blood sugar problems gets a lot of emphasis. Blood pressure barely warrants a mention, though it’s just as big a problem for overweight people.
He advocates rapid weight loss but almost in passing tells us of the Matador experiment and the success therein of an on/off approach to dieting. Is this not contradictory?
He describes his own experiment with the diet, giving his starting weight and waist measurement but not his height, so no real point of reference for the reader. That’s pedantic, yes, but dieting requires attention to detail.
The big irritant though is the recipe section. All the recipes are overly fussy and time-consuming, And you are not going to find those ingredients in a local version of your supermarket. Why not tell us the stuff we can all put our hands on rather than miso, turmeric, cumin and all that middle-class fluff? I have canned, yes, don’t gasp with horror, canned, salmon and mackerel, eggs, loads of normal salad stuff and fruit, low-sugar baked beans, almonds, olive oil. What I can I get off the shelf? I need to ‘open’ rather than cook.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 29 October 2019
profile.name: mhow1862

title: Brilliant
body: Saw the author on This Morning and thought wow this sounds like it’s worth a try. Glad I bought this. Basically the whole book is about limiting your calories to just 800 a day and eating during a limited time window of say six hours a day and not eating during the other eighteen. So is there a need for a whole book about it? Well some may say no and it’s right when people are talking about all the scientific facts and case studies that appear throughout the book. But this information is important. It’s important to know who’s done this before and how did the diet affect them. It’s essential reading but not for those who can’t absorb facts n figures. I’ve done really well so far and lost half a stone in the first two weeks. It’s hard and my stomach is rumbling like thunder. I had a few headaches in week 1 but I’m over it now. This is definitely a good read and I’m glad I bought it

profile.name: chrismichaeluk

title: Get the recipe book too
body: It's a good book recommended by friends who have lost the projected 14lb in 21 days - I've lost 11lb in 5 weeks as I have the odd pub visit (once a week generally, or one glass of Red at home per week ish). I've only eaten from this plan from morning to evening - no snacking, 800 cal every day (I don't add it up but follow the book mostly). I also only eat between 10:30 and 19:00 - TRE eating (explained in this book). There are limited photos in this book and a good few recipes in the back in B&W, good nutritional info and tips, suggested meal plans also. I dip in and out of this book as a reference point and use the large, nicer recipe book to actually cook from.

profile.name: Maker/Creator

title: Life Changing!
body: I’ve been struggling with my weight creeping up over a number of years and then lockdown tipped me over the edge. I was bloated, exhausted experiencing low mood and hated how I looked. I bought this as the idea of fasting appealed to me and all my previous diets had failed or I’d only lost 1 or 2 pounds and gave up.  All I can say is WOW the recipes were easy and delicious and once your body adjusts after a few days I felt mentally clear and full of energy. I’ve lost 5lbs in under 2 weeks and my partner who got dragged along for the ride has lost 8lb! I’d suggest getting the ketone sticks as it’s really motivating to see yourself transition and stay in ketosis. Stick through the “Keto Flu” and eventually the carb cravings subside, that was the toughest part. Drinking lots of water and herbal tea helped.  We’re both feeling great and can see this as being a lifestyle change. Have bought the recipe book today and that is also excellent.

body: Bought as a gift for a curious teen. I had a look through it before wrapping it to be sure it was appropriate and out of my own curiosity. I was honestly expecting a bit more in terms of the presentation.  The facts are presented in small paragraphs one after another with no styling, difference in formatting or any real flair. Theres a handful of images in the book (literally a handful). The facts are there but the presentation is a real let down.  Fun book and the facts are interesting but for a book touting itself as for children I'd expected a bit more oh an effort into making it friendly and engaging visually.

Really boring and uninspiring layout - could do so much more with that.  I’m sure facts are interesting for some adults, but definitely not children. profile.name: Sumo

title: Great recipes for all the family!  Don't hesitate buying this.
body: My wife bought this book as she wanted us as a family to cut down (not out) on our sugar intake and she wanted a recipe book that provided some inspiration and a varied menu to achieve this. It's no secret we were consuming far too much sugar so we decided to get proactive before our health began to seriously suffer. The recipes in this book are delicious and even better, they're simple with a minimal number of ingredients required across most of the recipes. As full time working parents anything we can cook that is quick, simple, tasty and healthy every night is a total bonus. Unlike competitors to this book where the ingredients are a-plenty and somewhat pricey, these ingredients are your day to day stuff combined to make delicious flavours and simple meals that the whole family (not just adults) can enjoy. The Pork in Mustard is an absolute fave! The food is filling and if you do your best to stick to the plan you won't be hungry however as our goal was to significantly reduce not remove sugar from our diet we do allow ourselves some sugar free jelly with chopped fresh fruit and a dollop of reduced fat creme fraiche for dessert each night because we found we did want something a little sweet just once a day. Adding this pudding hasn't hindered our progress in any major way and we're finding we can pinch a bit less belly fat already. Really worth having this book open and ready to use and not gathering dust on your shelf. There are loads of recipes to choose from that are inexpensive and simple to make. Tonight we're making meatballs from it and our 8 year old will get involved in the prep of it too so we can educate her on the importance of cooking simple healthy meals. I wished we'd known about the pitfalls of sugar decades ago before we got hooked on it! Nonetheless this is a great recipe book for weaning yourself off sugar without feeling deprived. Highly recommend and for the price it's excellent value for money.

profile.name: janetclipston

title: Honestly the best Recipe Book I ever bought.
body: I am a hoarder of recipe books and I can honestly say this is the best recipe book I have ever bought simply because I've tried a whole host of it's recipes and all have been delicious, not one duff one! I am a bit fussy when it comes to meals I like them to be dead tasty, I don't do bland, so I've often been disappointed with previous recipe books when they promise a delicious recipes which turn out to be bland. Not so with this book, Michael and his GP wife must have my love for tasty food that's easy to prepare and requires no special cookery skills.  I don't have blood sugar problems, I'm not diabetic, but I am over weight and have a hard time trying to lose weight. Although my diet was relatively healthy I was addicted to starchy carbs and I'm sure that was where my weight loss problem was. I bought this together with the Blood Sugar Diet paperback and Micheal Mosley's other wonderful book the Clever Guts Diet and have not looked back. I'm following recipes from both books as they are both based on the same style low carb Mediterranean style diet, I'm not following the 800 calorie a day diet as that's too hard for me but instead I'm just using the recipes in both books for all my meals.  I've lost half a stone in 3 weeks which is a great weight for me, considering I'm not following the 800 calorie rule, I'm not counting calories at all, on previous diets like WW and SW I only used to lose half a pound to a pound a week if I was lucky. Amazingly I don't miss the starchy carbs at all probably because the recipes in the book are so delicious and satisfying. I love how I haven't had to cut out all fat as in previous diets but instead can have plenty of good fats, like olive oil, nuts, seeds, full fat yogurt and cheese.....yum. Like the book warns I did feel a bit hungry in the first few days while my body adapted to burning fats for fuel rather than sugary carbs but that soon passed. I never thought I'd be able to give up bread for lunch, but the alternatives lunches in this book are so much nicer, I wasn't much of a fish eater but this book has converted me.  Recipes tried so far include: Main Meals: Chicken Korma - best homemade curry I've made and already a family favourite, delicious with the Cauliflower Rice recipe in the Clever Guts Book. No Pasta Beef Lasagne - delicious, never thought I'd say it but better than lasagne with pasta and I was a pasta lover. another Family favourite. Creamy Fish Bake - Yummy, didn't like Celeriac before but it's great with this, another family favourite. Lamb Tagine - Lovely, especially if made the day before so flavours develop even more, nice with Quinoa. Pancetta, Broccoli and Tomato Gratin - so simple yet so tasty and surprisingly filling. Seedy Flapjacks - Lovely and perfect if you're in need of a quick snack. StirF-Fried Cabbage and Peppered Mackerel - I could live on this and I never used to liked smoked fish, so simple to make, especially if like me you're lazy and use just cabbage and fish, finely sliced a cabbage (I used a whole pointed cabbage for 2 people), fry in a little olive oil for a few minutes, break up a couple of smoked mackerel fillets and chuck 'em in to heat through, viola tasty filling lunch.  If you like tasty grub and need to lose some weight you can't fail with this book.

profile.name: Debs Hyland

title: Could be much better but it has worked
body: Bought the print version originally but found the text too small so I then purchased the Kindle edition which is much better. The meal plans in the back of either book have no reference to the page number of the actually recipes and it is often difficult to find the recipes in the index as they often come under different names. The Kindle version wins on this as it is possible to search the text and then bookmark the location or highlight the name of the recipe.  The recipes themselves are quite expensive and. if one follows the meal plans, there will be some wasted food at the end of the week. Be prepared to freeze what you can. Unfortunately, my freezer space is limited so this is not always possible.  Some of the evening meals have been quite tasty such as the Salmon with lemon and dill nut crust with roasted veg, Easy Bolognese, Michael's Thai Fish Cakes, Pork Steaks in Mustard Sauce, Thai Red Curry, Moroccan Meatballs, Baked Fish and Chorizo Parcels and Turkey Burgers etc. but many of the recipes contain quite a lot of chilli which over powers them such as the Chicken Korma (which is supposed to be a milder curry) and Spicy Spinach and Lentil Dahl and, whilst I do like chilli, I do not enjoy every meal just tasting of chilli. I also found the courgetti (spaghetti type) recipes to be unimaginative as are the lunch recipes which are mostly lunch box type of meals such as tuna in lettuce, dips with vegetable sticks, tiny kebabs with a whopping 430 calories (out of the 800 calorie allowance for the day) and just left me hungry. The soups sound better but one is a Tomato, ham and lentil soup which has 440 calories and 40g of carbs. It also contains chilli flakes and I am guessing, as I have not made it, that it will mask all the other flavours. Maybe I just have over developed taste buds.  Edited as now almost at end of the 8 week plan.  I learned to adapt the recipes over the weeks and cut down on some of the spices in some recipes. This made the meals more appropriate for my tastes. The breakfasts and evening meals are, on the whole, very good and I will continue to make some of these once the 8 weeks are up. Blood glucose levels have responded very well in a short time so very happy about this.

profile.name: Norman Pelling

title: Confusing but OK
body: Good news: YES it has helped me lose a lot of weight - I was dieting and losing weight but this has made the process faster - did 6 weeks, with a cheat day each week. Then a 4 week gap - life got in the way - then back on it now week two. Am the lightest I have been in 12 years !!!! (Have also been exercising A LOT).  Bad News: 1) The book is diabolically edited - the contents (which you need to refer to all the time as the day planner is not cross referenced to recipe pages) is terrible and confusing. 2) The recipes are very odd - some for 2 people, some 4 and ocassionally 6 - so you end up having to eat half or a third or whatever of something and sometimes the remaining bit will probably go off before you get to another recipe that uses it.

profile.name: Kindle Customer

title: LIFE LESSON ! IT REDUCED MY BLOOD SUGARS! BRILLIANT!
body: I am fairly fit, not overweight and play sport - so was surprised when in Feb ‘22 I went for an ‘over 60’s’ full blood test to find I had crept into the “pre-diabetic” zone!! My mother and grandmother both had diabetes so decided I needed to take action!! I bought the ‘8-week blood sugar diet’ book and the recipe book - then followed all the Mediterranean Diet principles religiously, incl the glass of red wine! I didn’t want to reduce down to 800 calories but used a calorie book just for the first month to log calories in my regular meals. I cut out snacks (having the suggested handful of nuts instead) and saved having a piece of cake/pudding just to a weekend treat - which made it more special! … I had another test after 3 months and it had reduced my blood sugars back into the safe zone, and reduced my cholesterol … and I also lost 6Kg! 7 mths later I still follow the same principles - and weight has stayed off - it’s changed attitude to food and we loved the fresh recipes so much that I’ve subsequently bought and regularly cook from both the recipe books - fab moist chocolate cake with no sugar or flour! (Secret kidney bean ingredient!) … thank you Michael, truly life changing and I’d genuinely recommend the healthy Med diet to anyone - eating good carbs not bad ones!  The 8-Week Blood Sugar Diet & The 8-Week Blood Sugar Diet Recipe Book
body_html:
I am fairly fit, not overweight and play sport - so was surprised when in Feb ‘22 I went for an ‘over 60’s’ full blood test to find I had crept into the “pre-diabetic” zone!! My mother and grandmother both had diabetes so decided I needed to take action!! I bought the ‘8-week blood sugar diet’ book and the recipe book - then followed all the Mediterranean Diet principles religiously, incl the glass of red wine! I didn’t want to reduce down to 800 calories but used a calorie book just for the first month to log calories in my regular meals. I cut out snacks (having the suggested handful of nuts instead) and saved having a piece of cake/pudding just to a weekend treat - which made it more special!
… I had another test after 3 months and it had reduced my blood sugars back into the safe zone, and reduced my cholesterol … and I also lost 6Kg!
7 mths later I still follow the same principles - and weight has stayed off - it’s changed attitude to food and we loved the fresh recipes so much that I’ve subsequently bought and regularly cook from both the recipe books - fab moist chocolate cake with no sugar or flour! (Secret kidney bean ingredient!) … thank you Michael, truly life changing and I’d genuinely recommend the healthy Med diet to anyone - eating good carbs not bad ones!

The 8-Week Blood Sugar Diet & The 8-Week Blood Sugar Diet Recipe Book
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 10 August 2022
profile.name: Sara Baxter

title: I still highly recommend this book, read on
body: In a way I should give this book 5 stars. I do highly recommend it. However the niggles are such a pain, I'm only giving it 1.  The recipes are excellent, I'm following the plan at the back of the book to the letter and there have been some really really yummy recipes  The weight is also falling off, so why am I not giving it 5 stars?  Three main reasons.  1) The 8 week meal plan has no recipe page numbers on it and often calls the names of the recipes something slightly different to the index.  2) While often only by 10 or so calories, sometimes the meal plan and the recipe disagrees about how many calories are in a recipe  3) The index isn't always consistent, making things very hard to find  This might seem trivial, but when I'm trying to follow their meal plan and watch my calorie intake and it's taking forever to find recipes, and when I do, sometimes the calories are different, it kind of makes me wonder what else is wrong.  It's taken me over 3 hours to write the page numbers into the plan. This should have been done before publishing. It also would have taken me about 30 mins if everything was clear in the index etc.  Some examples. The plan says "No-Pasta Lasagna" so I look under "L" and "N". It's actually a sub section of "Beef"  Plan says "Kipper and Tomatoes" This is correctly indexed under both "K" and under the subsection of "Fish". So when a fish recipe comes up, I simply go to the fish heading and quickly find it. That's unless I want the recipe for "Tuna Patties", that's only under "T" and not under "Fish"  The plan says "Avocado and Feta Wrap". The index has it as "Avocado and Feta Bash". Sure when you go to the page it makes sense that it is a wrap, and on it's own this may be trivial, but it's been a real headache finding some of the recipes.  The plan says "Tzatziki with 2 seeded thin crackers = 200 calories" The recipe for "Tzatziki" is 140 calories, the recipe for the "seeded crackers" are 50 calories EACH, meaning it equals 250 calories not 200.  The plan says "Spanish chicken with chorizo = 540 calories", the recipe says it's only 495 calories  There are a fair few where there's 10 calories different.  This all might sound a little trivial, but when I'm trying to count calories, it kind of dents my faith a little  They list salads such as "Greek Salad = 250 calories", "Rainbow salad = 120 calories", "Broccoli and Asparagus salad = 60 calories"  The Plan says "Chili salad = 160 calories", with "Rocket and tomato salad = 60 calories"  There's no rocket salad in the book. OK some might argue, use your common sense, get a few rocket leaves, chop up a tomato and there you go, but that's not the point, I'm trying to follow this diet to the letter, I want to know my salad is only 60 calories and not say 120.  I still very very very highly recommend this book, the meals are fabulous and it works, but such a great book is tarnished by the above, especially the lack of recipe page numbers on the meal plan.  If the above was fixed I'd have given it five stars, but it's such a pain, it only warrants one
body_html:
In a way I should give this book 5 stars. I do highly recommend it. However the niggles are such a pain, I'm only giving it 1.

The recipes are excellent, I'm following the plan at the back of the book to the letter and there have been some really really yummy recipes

The weight is also falling off, so why am I not giving it 5 stars?

Three main reasons.

1) The 8 week meal plan has no recipe page numbers on it and often calls the names of the recipes something slightly different to the index.

2) While often only by 10 or so calories, sometimes the meal plan and the recipe disagrees about how many calories are in a recipe

3) The index isn't always consistent, making things very hard to find

This might seem trivial, but when I'm trying to follow their meal plan and watch my calorie intake and it's taking forever to find recipes, and when I do, sometimes the calories are different, it kind of makes me wonder what else is wrong.

It's taken me over 3 hours to write the page numbers into the plan. This should have been done before publishing. It also would have taken me about 30 mins if everything was clear in the index etc.

Some examples.
The plan says "No-Pasta Lasagna" so I look under "L" and "N". It's actually a sub section of "Beef"

Plan says "Kipper and Tomatoes" This is correctly indexed under both "K" and under the subsection of "Fish".
So when a fish recipe comes up, I simply go to the fish heading and quickly find it.
That's unless I want the recipe for "Tuna Patties", that's only under "T" and not under "Fish"

The plan says "Avocado and Feta Wrap". The index has it as "Avocado and Feta Bash". Sure when you go to the page it makes sense that it is a wrap, and on it's own this may be trivial, but it's been a real headache finding some of the recipes.

The plan says "Tzatziki with 2 seeded thin crackers = 200 calories"
The recipe for "Tzatziki" is 140 calories, the recipe for the "seeded crackers" are 50 calories EACH, meaning it equals 250 calories not 200.

The plan says "Spanish chicken with chorizo = 540 calories", the recipe says it's only 495 calories

There are a fair few where there's 10 calories different.

This all might sound a little trivial, but when I'm trying to count calories, it kind of dents my faith a little

They list salads such as "Greek Salad = 250 calories", "Rainbow salad = 120 calories", "Broccoli and Asparagus salad = 60 calories"

The Plan says "Chili salad = 160 calories", with "Rocket and tomato salad = 60 calories"

There's no rocket salad in the book. OK some might argue, use your common sense, get a few rocket leaves, chop up a tomato and there you go, but that's not the point, I'm trying to follow this diet to the letter, I want to know my salad is only 60 calories and not say 120.

I still very very very highly recommend this book, the meals are fabulous and it works, but such a great book is tarnished by the above, especially the lack of recipe page numbers on the meal plan.

If the above was fixed I'd have given it five stars, but it's such a pain, it only warrants one
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 2 July 2021
profile.name: Amazon Customer

title: My constant companion!
body: I bought this book after my husband found that his blood sugar was in the diabetic range. He decided that he didn't want to end up on medication so we have changed the way we eat using this book and another book which explains how to lower your blood sugar and still eat great meals. We have both lost weight, we have much more energy and will keep going with this. My husband's blood sugar is now back in the normal range and he is not on medication. Give this a go whether you have high blood sugar or not as it is a great way to stay healthy. There are a number of books by this same author including his 8 week diet to reduce your blood sugar. This book is the recipe book that goes with the diet. Do it! You can't loose.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 6 June 2023
profile.name: Hanni

title: It could be so much better
body: It is not that it is a bad book but it really, really could be so much better with only a little effort.  My wife and I are using it in conjunction with "The 8 week Blood Sugar Diet" book by Dr Michael Mosley, to which this is a companion, and we are trying to work steadily through the laid out 4 week plan in the latter. It does not take long to find that there are recipes that we do not like. No surprise that, given that for us, and many other people I imagine, it is a fairly radical change in eating habits. This is where it lets you down. My pet hate is the monster mushrooms that it uses as the base (like a slab of toast) for several of its recipes. No problem I thought, lets substitute something else, like a slab of beef tomato as a base. Is there a table whereby I can look up the calories for tomato, compared to mushrooms ? NOPE. No matter maybe I can substitute a completely different recipe with more or less the same total calories. Is there an index of recipes by total calories ? NOPE. OK so I will just have to flog through the recipe book and find one the hard way. OK I did not expect it to be that HARD. Remember this whole exercise is about CALORIES and sure enough they are given for each recipe BUT in minutely small print (4 point ? Whatever it is it makes the small print in a legal contract look large.) And if that is not enough to make it illegible, just to make sure that it is, it is printed in light grey type on a white background.  So provided your happy with the recipes and don't want to change anything, or you have a large magnifying glass and plenty of time, you will be fine. And I am pleased to say that they do actually work: I am losing weight fairly rapidly, unlike any previous diet I have tried, and next week I will know how I am doing on the blood sugar level, having been to have a blood test this morning.  THE PUBLSHERS "SHORT BOOKS" have, true to name, fallen SHORT, IMHO.

It is not that it is a bad book but it really, really could be so much better with only a little effort.

My wife and I are using it in conjunction with "The 8 week Blood Sugar Diet" book by Dr Michael Mosley, to which this is a companion, and we are trying to work steadily through the laid out 4 week plan in the latter. It does not take long to find that there are recipes that we do not like. No surprise that, given that for us, and many other people I imagine, it is a fairly radical change in eating habits. This is where it lets you down. My pet hate is the monster mushrooms that it uses as the base (like a slab of toast) for several of its recipes. No problem I thought, lets substitute something else, like a slab of beef tomato as a base. Is there a table whereby I can look up the calories for tomato, compared to mushrooms ? NOPE. No matter maybe I can substitute a completely different recipe with more or less the same total calories. Is there an index of recipes by total calories ? NOPE. OK so I will just have to flog through the recipe book and find one the hard way. OK I did not expect it to be that HARD. Remember this whole exercise is about CALORIES and sure enough they are given for each recipe BUT in minutely small print (4 point ? Whatever it is it makes the small print in a legal contract look large.) And if that is not enough to make it illegible, just to make sure that it is, it is printed in light grey type on a white background.

So provided your happy with the recipes and don't want to change anything, or you have a large magnifying glass and plenty of time, you will be fine. And I am pleased to say that they do actually work: I am losing weight fairly rapidly, unlike any previous diet I have tried, and next week I will know how I am doing on the blood sugar level, having been to have a blood test this morning.

THE PUBLSHERS "SHORT BOOKS" have, true to name, fallen SHORT, IMHO.

title: Excellent 10/10
body: I cannot rate this lady high enough I am 60 and have dieted for years but never have I used a recipe book so extensively, night after night trying a different healthy recipe just to discover a wealth of different flavours. Not only is the book well written and easy to use but the creativity with which she uses flavours in the recipes is amazing. I started by cooking the ones with pictures but each night I am excited to try a new recipe and am now on the ones without pictures - never have I done this before but I am finding the variety of recipes and flavours mouth watering. Even my partner loves it.  I bought this book along with the fast 800 recipe book (which I haven't started yet) because I follow the 5/2 diet to keep my weight down and having researched all the books wanted the ones written by his wife. This really does not disappoint at all. I am not aware I if I have a blood sugar problem but just wanted to eat healthily and retrain my cooking habits. I love vegetarian food aswell and there is plenty of variety of that in this book too. I highly recommend this book to ANYONE - either to lose weight, add variety to your cooking, eat healthily or simply reduce sugar intake. A total inspiration. LOVE IT !!! (Cant wait to start on the fast 800 recipe book)

title: How do I read the print
body: I have just bought this book for my daughter so far the recipes are untried but usually they're good, my disappointment lies in the print, a recipe book is supposed to be informative, why then are they printed in grey lettering, I am slightly visually impaired and I would like to be able to read the recipe.....Black on white please, my daughter it shows you the food values, I asked where, and there at the side written in grey microdots was cares etc, I did manage to see it with the help of glasses and a magnifying glass which is a but ridiculous when trying to read a recipe......please don't go all arty when it comes to print and size of font...very disappointed with that aspect

body: Just about to start the actual eating plan but it took me a while to go through the book and sort my menus and shopping lists etc. At the back of the book there are 8 different suggested weekly eating plans. I will come back and update as to how I get on with the eating plan after a few weeks.........

profile.name: Loraine Bell

title: Not a cheap way to diet
body: I’ve also written a review of the diet book. If you’re not really interested in the background to the diet you could just buy this book as it has a summary and lots more recipes than the other book. There are some really good recipes in here, practical advice and particularly liked the quick supper choices. It is not cheap to follow this as it’s so heavy on meat/fish so we are spending £20-30 a week extra on food at the moment. 6% body weight loss (5&7kg) after seven weeks, so not as dramatic as the weight loss by using diet ‘shakes’ but better for you as it’s more sustainable to learn new low carb recipes. Some recipes seem a bit light on the herbs/spices and if you’re not a fairly decent cook it might be difficult to follow. Food waste was a challenge in the first couple of weeks as a lot of recipes get you to use half a pack/jar of something and then the ingredient doesn’t appear in anything else in the book. If you follow the weekly planner in the diet book this happens a lot so you will need to mix it up a bit.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 13 October 2023
profile.name: Jo Hallam

title: Great book, lovely recipes
body: I love this book, it focuses on flavours, and easy to follow recipes, all but one I have enjoyed. It teaches you that not having a diet high in carbs can control your weight and used as a weight loss aid, can actually reverse type 2 diabetes.  2 things that really annoy me. 1 the actual 8 week diet is at the end. For every meal you need to a) look up the recipe, then 2 write down all the ingredients that you will need.  This is a bit of a time consuming exercise for weeks one and two, when you haven't got half the ingredients in your store cupboard, but by the time you are at week three, you are able to write down what you require quickly and easily.  I am on week 5, I lost 6 pounds in the first week, 2 in week 2 and 1.5 pound per week for weeks 3 and 4. Total weight-loss going in to week 5 is 11 pounds.  This book works, if you stick to the rules. (there are "healthy" snacks in there which you can have, I particularly love the flapjacks).  The recipes are well structured, and easy to follow. I needed to buy a spiraliser, but most supermarkets now sell spiralised vegetables.  There is some wastage of food however (perhaps an improvement for next version!), and the recipes go from serves 6 to serves 2, which can be annoying, but overall I am pleased that it has delivered what it said it would.
body_html:
I love this book, it focuses on flavours, and easy to follow recipes, all but one I have enjoyed. It teaches you that not having a diet high in carbs can control your weight and used as a weight loss aid, can actually reverse type 2 diabetes.

2 things that really annoy me.
1 the actual 8 week diet is at the end. For every meal you need to a) look up the recipe, then
2 write down all the ingredients that you will need.

This is a bit of a time consuming exercise for weeks one and two, when you haven't got half the ingredients in your store cupboard, but by the time you are at week three, you are able to write down what you require quickly and easily.

I am on week 5, I lost 6 pounds in the first week, 2 in week 2 and 1.5 pound per week for weeks 3 and 4. Total weight-loss going in to week 5 is 11 pounds.

This book works, if you stick to the rules. (there are "healthy" snacks in there which you can have, I particularly love the flapjacks).

The recipes are well structured, and easy to follow. I needed to buy a spiraliser, but most supermarkets now sell spiralised vegetables.

There is some wastage of food however (perhaps an improvement for next version!), and the recipes go from serves 6 to serves 2, which can be annoying, but overall I am pleased that it has delivered what it said it would.

profile.name: S. D. Hurst

title: Absolutely life changing
body: Fantastic book, I bought this after being so frustrated with eating low fat for the past 5 years, exercising about 4 to 5 times a week, eating clean, counting calories and still getting fatter and fatter. I used to wake up at 2 am every night starving, I was so upset and just couldn't figure out why. Decided to try the one thing I hadn't tried yet, low carb. Well what a surprise, I'm full, more energy, lost a dress size and over half a stone already. That was in less than 2 months as well! I didn't quite do 800 calories but I stuck to the low carb principles and it's nothing short of a miracle! I haven't counted calories at all but because I used to for so many years I can tell I do eat less than I was, however because my blood sugar is stable I don't get hungry like I used to. I now feel proper hunger, not just blood sugar crash hunger which feels really different. I'm amazed, just wish I wasn't silly a few years ago and dismissed anyone who suggested low carb...

profile.name: PinkMilk

title: Very Happy
body: This is a great varied recipe book to accompany the original book and there are many recipes which are appealing and fairly simple to make. The only reason i havent given it 5 stars is because i find quantities in several of the recipes a bit vague, such "2 pork steaks" or "a gammon steak". There are such huge variations in size of these things when shopping and so im not sure how accurate the calorie counts can be. And as this is so important on this diet i feel it could throw you off track of the 800 cals a day if your own version of a gammon steak is the size of a dinner plate rather than a side plate! A guide of say "200g gammon steak" would have been better.  Having said that i suppose we have to use common sense and not choose large portions when the recipe is non specific.  So in summation, its a great book with lots of choices and very helpful meal plans for all 8 weeks in the back, and i am pleased with the purchase. Just have to remember common sense must prevail when shopping for unspecified amounts of meat etc.

profile.name: karen

title: The best recipe book I have ever bought
body: We're on a low carb diet to lose weight and I had been strugggling to find suitable recipes for tasty dishes using ingredients that I recognised and could buy locally. I am so glad that I happened upon this one - it is fantastic! It has been especially useful during lockdown, when we have been able to plan our menus for the week, make a comprehensive list of what we need to buy, and look forward to our evening meal each day. We have started to be more adventurous in trying out new recipes as well as thoroughly enjoying familiar meals such as chicken and musroom pie (cabbage leaves instead of pastry), pork steaks in mustard sauce, and fish bake using celeriac or cauliflower mash instead of potato for the topping. The calorie and carbohydrate content is given for each recipe, and in four months we have steadily lost more than two stone between us, about half of our long-term target. I can't recommend this book highly enough. Thank you Drs Clare Bailey and Sarah Schenker!

title: Tasty
body: I bought this in addition to the same author's 8 week blood sugar diet book. It was helpful to increase the meal suggestions. The meals are mostly very tasty although some less so but that is like any recipe book, some appeal more than others. I did find it a little frustrating that some recipes were for 2 people, some 4 or 6. However it didn't take a lot of working out. There are menu planner suggestions at the back of the book. While this is great, there are no links to what page the recipes are on, so you have to plough through the book. I started writing the page number on the chart for future ease. My gripes are minor. It is a good recipe book for those wishing to reduce blood sugar or weight. I have lost 20lbs in under 8 weeks but could easily have lost more if I hadn't had a couple of meals out and wine!

profile.name: BT

title: Useful book, if you are on board with the concept that is.
body: The book is definitely useful, if you wish to follow the diet idea as expounded in "the 8 - week blood sugar diet" by Michael Mosley, which is basically - low calories and low carb. I have been looking into this idea, but also the contrasting (and what some would consider more radical) idea as expounded in "The Reverse Diabetes Diet" by Dr Neal Barnard, which is basically - vegan, low fat, and low GI (good) carbs aplenty. I haven't tried either diet in any serious way yet. Went into it due to relative's diabetes, but thought it could do me some good too, as my waist measurement is too large for my height (an indicator of visceral fat, perhaps). I suspect the vegan diet, if done properly (and including Marmite for the B12!) could be more sustainable, as there's no bothersome calorie counting.

title: Brilliantly researched exposé of the link between food additives and obesity
body: Why is there an obesity epidemic in the west and why are populations becoming more unhealthy? Why are “ethnic” foods healthy, and why do remote peoples become unhealthy when exposed to western diets? This book sets out to explain why in an easy to understand and engaging way.  The author explains that the obesity crisis has not been caused by the “usual suspects” of salt, sugar, fat, lack of exercise and abundant, delicious food. It’s not even about sugar and carbs, which I must admit is something that I myself have bought into in the past.  Instead, it’s all about Ultra Processed Food (UPF) – so what is that? There isn’t a short, slick definition, but broadly, if the food is packaged, branded, heavily marketed and crucially, contains more than five ingredients then it is probably UPF. The types of ingredients to watch out for are, for example, modified starches, gums, E numbers, flavour enhancers and emulsifiers etc. In fact there are approximately 2000 such ingredients allowed in the EU but the number in the US is over 10,000. No one knows the true figure because there are no realistic restrictions on what food makers can do and no centralised registration system.  The author describes in some detail Kevin Hall’s experiment (Cellular Metabolism 2019; 30:67-77). This was done under strict laboratory conditions whereby a sample group of people were fed two diets containing exactly matched quantities of sugar, carbs, protein and fibre etc. The only difference was that one group was given food with these additives and the other not. After a few days, the group with additives were eating 500 calories more per person per day. In fact the other group members started losing weight. This experiment has been widely quoted in scientific literature – but it hasn’t really entered the mainstream.  Another eye-popping study was conducted by Herman Pontzer (Energy Expenditure and adiposity in Nigerian and African American women. Obesity 2008; 16: 2148-54). The results were so counter-intuitive that they ran the test several times. The study proved that office workers in the US burn as many calories every day as hunter gathers in Africa. Everyone burns about the same number of calories a day whether they are couch potatoes or have active lifestyles. And there are good evolutionary reasons for this. So if you want to lose weight, going to the gym every night won’t help – it all comes down to diet, and specifically, the quantity of factory produced additives that you put in your mouth every day.  How did we westerners arrive at this situation? It's the logical end point of having global food companies compete with each other to maximise sales and minimise costs without regard to the long term health costs which is the (inevitable) by-product. It is an example of a market failure, except the author is not an economist but a scientist, so this is my personal summary of the point. This also leads to deforestation, global warming and climate change which is not a direct theme of the book, but which is mentioned a few times.  But the author is quite clear about the solution to the problem and this is endorsed by food industry insiders – there has to be government regulation. This point leads to another thesis of the book: Food companies are massive global companies with multi-billion pound market capitalisations – it is in their interests to protect this wealth and they do this in many ways, not all of which are strictly honest.  For example, there are many examples in the pharmaceutical sector of industry funded research which offers skewed results. The food sector is no different. Worse still, the author gives specific examples of “independent” studies where the authors state they are independent, but have actually been funded by food industry sources.  Food companies also have massive political clout with lobbying. In the EU, a large chunk of the budget of one of the food safety ministries comes from industry sources. The author states several times that the relationship between “big food” and government should be confrontational and antagonistic – not cosy and friendly like how things currently are.  There is a section at the end of the book about formula milk for babies – the takeaway being that you should breast-feed your babies for as long as possible and avoid formula, particularly if you are a poor, illiterate peasant living in an area with low quality water.  Even though this is not sold as a weight loss book, I think this is the most influential diet, weight loss book I have ever read. It has had a profound effect on me since I finished reading it a few days ago. I found myself rushing home from work in order to continue reading – it is that full of interesting information. This book should be read by healthcare professionals, politicians, economists, climate activists and anyone who wants to live healthily and lose weight.

Why is there an obesity epidemic in the west and why are populations becoming more unhealthy? Why are “ethnic” foods healthy, and why do remote peoples become unhealthy when exposed to western diets? This book sets out to explain why in an easy to understand and engaging way.

The author explains that the obesity crisis has not been caused by the “usual suspects” of salt, sugar, fat, lack of exercise and abundant, delicious food. It’s not even about sugar and carbs, which I must admit is something that I myself have bought into in the past.

Instead, it’s all about Ultra Processed Food (UPF) – so what is that? There isn’t a short, slick definition, but broadly, if the food is packaged, branded, heavily marketed and crucially, contains more than five ingredients then it is probably UPF. The types of ingredients to watch out for are, for example, modified starches, gums, E numbers, flavour enhancers and emulsifiers etc. In fact there are approximately 2000 such ingredients allowed in the EU but the number in the US is over 10,000. No one knows the true figure because there are no realistic restrictions on what food makers can do and no centralised registration system.

The author describes in some detail Kevin Hall’s experiment (Cellular Metabolism 2019; 30:67-77). This was done under strict laboratory conditions whereby a sample group of people were fed two diets containing exactly matched quantities of sugar, carbs, protein and fibre etc. The only difference was that one group was given food with these additives and the other not. After a few days, the group with additives were eating 500 calories more per person per day. In fact the other group members started losing weight. This experiment has been widely quoted in scientific literature – but it hasn’t really entered the mainstream.

Another eye-popping study was conducted by Herman Pontzer (Energy Expenditure and adiposity in Nigerian and African American women. Obesity 2008; 16: 2148-54). The results were so counter-intuitive that they ran the test several times. The study proved that office workers in the US burn as many calories every day as hunter gathers in Africa. Everyone burns about the same number of calories a day whether they are couch potatoes or have active lifestyles. And there are good evolutionary reasons for this. So if you want to lose weight, going to the gym every night won’t help – it all comes down to diet, and specifically, the quantity of factory produced additives that you put in your mouth every day.

How did we westerners arrive at this situation? It's the logical end point of having global food companies compete with each other to maximise sales and minimise costs without regard to the long term health costs which is the (inevitable) by-product. It is an example of a market failure, except the author is not an economist but a scientist, so this is my personal summary of the point. This also leads to deforestation, global warming and climate change which is not a direct theme of the book, but which is mentioned a few times.

But the author is quite clear about the solution to the problem and this is endorsed by food industry insiders – there has to be government regulation. This point leads to another thesis of the book: Food companies are massive global companies with multi-billion pound market capitalisations – it is in their interests to protect this wealth and they do this in many ways, not all of which are strictly honest.

For example, there are many examples in the pharmaceutical sector of industry funded research which offers skewed results. The food sector is no different. Worse still, the author gives specific examples of “independent” studies where the authors state they are independent, but have actually been funded by food industry sources.

Food companies also have massive political clout with lobbying. In the EU, a large chunk of the budget of one of the food safety ministries comes from industry sources. The author states several times that the relationship between “big food” and government should be confrontational and antagonistic – not cosy and friendly like how things currently are.

There is a section at the end of the book about formula milk for babies – the takeaway being that you should breast-feed your babies for as long as possible and avoid formula, particularly if you are a poor, illiterate peasant living in an area with low quality water.

Even though this is not sold as a weight loss book, I think this is the most influential diet, weight loss book I have ever read. It has had a profound effect on me since I finished reading it a few days ago. I found myself rushing home from work in order to continue reading – it is that full of interesting information. This book should be read by healthcare professionals, politicians, economists, climate activists and anyone who wants to live healthily and lose weight.

profile.name: Lois Neal

title: Not an easy read.
body: Knew we were being manipulated by the food industry but this is more than I ever thought. This book, although can be very technical is very informative. What can I eat that's not been interfered with additives. Everyday bombarded with 'you should be eating this as it's healthy' to find out it's not as healthy as claimed. Well written book that I was inspired to read after seeing the author on morning tv. Just now make my own healthy choses.

profile.name: Denise Bolan

title: Makes you reconsider what groceries you buy
body: Brilliant, albeit shocking, book about ultra processed food, how it is making us sick and how the ultra processed food industry is destroying the planet, while making false health claims about their products. The book is well researched, personal and highly informative with practical insight into how we can all make personal changes. I started reading labels of food in the supermarket a few years ago. The more I learn, the more I put back. Great book! Will revisit over and over again.

profile.name: Amazon_Customer

title: Very good book
body: This is a very influential book. It covers many points that people probably know already. But putting them together makes a compelling case for avoiding ultra processed food. The author also identified UP food examples that some people will not be aware of.  The next step is to follow the recommendations, based on the evidence.

profile.name: Amazon Customer

title: A vital book for all
body: Whatever your lifestyle there are things in this book you need to know, facts about UPF's that, as far as I could find, appear nowhere else. Search on the internet and the most you'll find is a dozen items, none of them specific and no mention at all of burger chains or fast food outlets. This book bares all, the companies, the products the vast amount of money being made - billions of dollars - and the devastation of human health, especially in low income groups but also in high pressure jobs where quick food is is the norm as one review here testifies. Whatever your life style I suspect you consume more UPF food than you realise. The sad fact is that the poorest have no other option. NOTE. UPF is just one aspect of our sad food production, the other is the vast amount of insecticides, herbicides, fungicides etc that are poored over our ftuit and veg every year.

profile.name: Kindle Customer

title: This will change the way you think about convenience food!
body: I thought I knew a lot about food, nutrition and healthy eating - but this was definitely a missing piece for me.  The unnecessary additives in food that drive cravings and addictive eating are shocking - and it’s not just food that most of us would recognise as junk - even if we do indulge now and again. The mass produced food that is part of every day diets it crammed with extra stuff that is purely there for commercial reasons - to make it cheap to produce, longer lasting for stock control and attractive for people to heat and eat/use quickly - and want to buy more of.  On the downside, this book is written by a proper scientist, so it is technical and heavy going at times (that’s why only 4 stars) - but that said, there is probably no real way some of the information can be made more accessible.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 20 May 2024
profile.name: biffy

title: Impressive
body: This was a very captivating and thought-provoking novel and I was sucked in from the very beginning.  The main character is incredibly unlikeable, and while I tend to struggle with these types of protagonists, I was mesmerised by what was going on in her head, her thoughts were just insane. She's a witty and fascinating character and it was so believable, I can fully imagine there being people like this out there. Her story was a train wreck and I couldn't look away!  The plot was so interesting and despite the intricate and mature writing, I read it with complete ease. It was just so clever and enthralling and I really enjoyed it.  Such an entertaining read - highly recommend.
body_html:

She's a witty and fascinating character and it was so believable, I can fully imagine there being people like this out there. Her story was a train wreck and I couldn't look away!

The plot was so interesting and despite the intricate and mature writing, I read it with complete ease. It was just so clever and enthralling and I really enjoyed it.

Such an entertaining read - highly recommend.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 4 February 2024
profile.name: Laura

title: An unlikable protagonist you can’t help but root for
body: 📚 Book Review: “Yellowface” by Rebecca F. Kuang  🌟 Rating: 4.5/5  Cover - iconic. Blurb - enticing. Reviews - all round fairly good. Of course I had to ask my friend if I could borrow it and it didn’t disappoint!  👍🏼 Things I Loved:  ~ Oooh do I love the main character, FOR all her flaws. She’s selfish, double-faced and desperate. But you can help but root for her the whole time and hope the whole thing works out 😅 ~ The level of research that’s gone into this is phenomenal, which is awesome and puts us in the same boat as the protagonist, so you’re literally having to keep up at the same pace she is having to deal with too. ~ This makes the level of stress in my life look like child’s play, so putting the book down I was like PHEW 😫😅  👎🏼 Things I Didn’t Like:  ~ Ahhh…the ending. It was a little flat. Kind of wanted someone with a bit more substance to be the antagonist.  Overall Thoughts: This is an excellent read, really witty and has some real oomph about it which helped get me back into reading when I read it last year. Expect some stress and some questionable decisions, but you have to ride it out!
body_html:
📚 Book Review: “Yellowface” by Rebecca F. Kuang

🌟 Rating: 4.5/5

Cover - iconic. Blurb - enticing. Reviews - all round fairly good. Of course I had to ask my friend if I could borrow it and it didn’t disappoint!

👍🏼 Things I Loved:

~ Oooh do I love the main character, FOR all her flaws. She’s selfish, double-faced and desperate. But you can help but root for her the whole time and hope the whole thing works out 😅
~ The level of research that’s gone into this is phenomenal, which is awesome and puts us in the same boat as the protagonist, so you’re literally having to keep up at the same pace she is having to deal with too.
~ This makes the level of stress in my life look like child’s play, so putting the book down I was like PHEW 😫😅

👎🏼 Things I Didn’t Like:

~ Ahhh…the ending. It was a little flat. Kind of wanted someone with a bit more substance to be the antagonist.

Overall Thoughts:
This is an excellent read, really witty and has some real oomph about it which helped get me back into reading when I read it last year. Expect some stress and some questionable decisions, but you have to ride it out!
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 26 May 2024
profile.name: edudham

title: Cracking start, less than cracking ending
body: This book started so well, with a great concept (although it has been done before) and many revealing insights into the fake and shallow worlds of publishing and social media. In many ways it's astonishing the novel got published... but it did, and it seems that publishing is quite happy to expose itself with this book... any other industry might be mortified, but publishing is a law unto itself: should be deeply embarrassed, but isn't. This level of apparent arrogance illustrates just how much truth there is in this novel!  The story fades as it goes on, and the last third is stodgy and daft. I guessed very early on who was going to figure at the end (but perhaps that obvious direction was deliberate?) and the increasing implausibility was rather tiresome. It's a shame that the novel had to descend into eye-rolling melodrama and cheaply bland "psychological thriller" tropes. It was clever and sharp enough to not need any of that nonsense. Poor editorial decisions were made... again, though, perhaps they were deliberate? We'll never know.  All in all, it’s a great (but not original) idea, with a pacy start, stodgy mid-section, and a ridiculously poor ending.
body_html:

The story fades as it goes on, and the last third is stodgy and daft. I guessed very early on who was going to figure at the end (but perhaps that obvious direction was deliberate?) and the increasing implausibility was rather tiresome. It's a shame that the novel had to descend into eye-rolling melodrama and cheaply bland "psychological thriller" tropes. It was clever and sharp enough to not need any of that nonsense. Poor editorial decisions were made... again, though, perhaps they were deliberate? We'll never know.

All in all, it’s a great (but not original) idea, with a pacy start, stodgy mid-section, and a ridiculously poor ending.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 3 February 2024
profile.name: Patchwork Queen

title: Controversial and very well written
body: I had seen this book everywhere. It’s pretty distinctive with its bright yellow cover, controversial title and huge publicity campaign. I wasn’t sure if this was going to be a good book (I had never read any Rebecca F. Kuang work before) or whether it was all just hype but I grabbed a Kindle copy on the Amazon Black Friday sale for 99p.  The main character is June Hayward. June is a struggling author, her only book had a mediocre reception, and she cannot seem to find that next big story that will see her gain the adoration she feels she deserves. June is best friends with fellow author Athena Liu. Athena’s books are much more successful and June is jealous and feels like she’s living in Athena’s shadow. When Athena dies, June is left in possession of the only copy of Athena's very final and very brilliant manuscript. No one has previously read this manuscript so the temptation for June to pass this off as her own work is strong.  I did no research before starting this book so I didn’t realise how it has split reviewers. It does seem that you either love or hate this book. I have to say that I really enjoyed it. June is a great character; she is jealous, racist, petty, scared, strong, confident and miserable and we get to follow her entertaining downward spiral. I watched with horror at some of the things she did or said, she was like a horrific event that I couldn’t look away from. I also really enjoyed the other characters in the book, they all had their role to play and usually with their own motives.  Although I don’t usually like books about books, I thought the storyline was original and interesting and I actually enjoyed learning a bit more about the publishing industry. There are so many themes in this book, some obvious and some less so and Kuang makes us sit with our discomfort through an excellent choice of an unreliable narrator and forces us to confront our own opinions on the matters.  This book moves at a slow pace as the characters and the central thread of the story is established so if you come expecting big thrills and high stakes tension, you'll be disappointed but I appreciated the approach. I did predict the ending but this didn’t take any enjoyment away from the book for me. I didn’t know how I should feel about June at any given time and this kept me on my toes and kept me thinking about the book and its themes when I wasn’t reading it.  Overall, although controversial, I really enjoyed this book. I liked how it made me think and feel and I enjoyed the storyline and characters. I’ll check out more of Kuang’s work.
body_html:

profile.name: S Payne

title: Rollicking good read
body: I must be a horrible person because I didn’t find the main character utterly repulsive.  That’s one of the skills of the writer.  Others are fast pacing, dancing between genres (while creating one of her own), and silky smooth prose.  I’m a SLOW reader but I lapped up the last 150 pages in an afternoon.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 6 June 2024
profile.name: London Dan

title: Plot makes absolutely no sense
body: * vague spoilers *  This novel doesn't work because the plot makes no sense. It is inevitable that the central character will be found out, yet inexplicably this seems to come as a surprise to her.  Unlike other reviewers I have no problems with an unsympathetic narrator, but we're supposed to believe June is highly intelligent even as she makes a series of irreparably bad decisions.  There's a faint glimmer of an interesting interrogation of the line between a fiction writer researching vs "stealing"/appropriating others' life experiences, but this is ultimately abandoned in favour of a pivot to tediously drawn-out melodrama.  The author knows how to hook in a reader but I was mainly invested because I was trying to fathom how she would dig herself out of the plot hole she had created (answer: she didn't).

date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 3 April 2024
profile.name: SC-20

title: Basic and overhyped - sorry!
body: The start of this novel is promising, although there are some walloping plot holes and a lot of aspects of the opening scenario that are very convenient.  However, this wasn’t why I disliked it. I felt that, after a dramatic start, the book just didn’t go anywhere. Worse than that, parts were just plain boring. It felt like the same plot device over and over again, and the ’reveal’ at the end was so highly predictable that I wondered if it was designed to be a parody of itself? Cover endorsements of the book called it ‘hugely entertaining’, but I felt bored most of the time. The points were so laboured and the whole thing very self-indulgent. I felt there were a myriad other ways of doing this book better.

profile.name: Amazon Customer

title: It’s my novel!
body: Mmm but is it? Scary novel about the crime (or not) of taking someone else’s story. I’m actually glad that you don’t connect so much with the highs and lows of the main character - too painful. Great title - combining the shame with the race issues. And as for the social media importance- scary, very scary. Conclusion: different, raises many questions (great book club choice), you want to keep reading and yet you also don’t at the same time….
body_html: Mmm but is it? Scary novel about the crime (or not) of taking someone else’s story. I’m actually glad that you don’t connect so much with the highs and lows of the main character - too painful. Great title - combining the shame with the race issues. And as for the social media importance- scary, very scary. Conclusion: different, raises many questions (great book club choice), you want to keep reading and yet you also don’t at the same time….
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 18 April 2024
profile.name: Lily-Rose

title: Scarily plausible - are you sure you want to be a writer?
body: I can see why this has been a book that has divided readers. I think, if you work in or around the publishing industry, you will appreciate some elements of the story more than this who remain blissfully unaware on the outside of all that goes on. Then again, if you pay even the remotest bit of attention to what goes on in the sordid world of social media then you can perhaps understand many elements of this story. After all there have been many careers made, and ruined, at the hands of social media keyboard warriors, and so many aspects of this story, so many of the key themes, are fresh, current and, for some, still very raw. You don't need to be in publishing to recognise dogpiling when you see it, or to understand the negative side of 'fame'. Or maybe, in this case, infamy.  For me, kind of on the outside as a reader, but not entirely, I really enjoyed this book. Understood some of what the author was portraying, laughed along in all the right (wrong) places, became infuriated in the right ones too, and recognised this story for what it is. A warts an all portrayal of an industry that is far more complex, and cut throat, than many people might realise. Exaggerated for effect? Possibly. But behind every exaggeration is a seed of truth. For most authors, who don't have legacy backlist and a longstanding reputation and fan base to hang their hat on, you live and die by your last sales total, dropped from the schedule the moment your figures don't meet expectations, or when there is a hint of a scandal that, even by the best spin doctor, cannot be exploited for commercial gain. And that, for most, is a very hard place to exist.  This is the story of June Hayward, and author whose only title had a mediocre reception at best, and who is struggling to find that next big story that will see her gain the adoration she feels she deserves. She is best friends with Athena Liu whose fortunes have proven far greater than June's. When a very unfortunate foodie incident (yes really) sees Athena meet a premature end, June is left with a dilemma. She has in her possession the only copy of Athena's very final manuscript. Will she do the right thing and hand it over to Athena's estate? Or will she take advantage of the fact that no-one else knows about the book, and use it to further her own career? Now, if she did the right thing, this would be a very short book. In fairness to her, she does rewrite huge elements of the text, but the core -the inspiration, the tone, the story - still belongs to Athena. When her agent, and a prominent Indie publisher, snap up the book, it's too late to turn back, and what follows is a mixture of karma, pride, arrogance and revenge, a sorry tale that escalates beyond anything June could ever have foreseen.  The opening of this book is slower in pace as the characters and the central thread of the story is established. If you come expecting big thrills and high stakes tension, you'll be bitterly disappointed. If anything the book initially mirrors the slow and painstaking process of creating that perfect story to begin with. The story is told from June's perspective, so from the outset we get a very skewed view of events, everything geared towards her own justification for her actions and that mental back and forth between the rights and wrongs of her decisions really has an alarming feeling of authenticity. A moral dilemma indeed, but the promise, and presence, of a healthy advance soon provides a balm to sooth June's conscience. I can't say I liked June - I didn't much like any of the characters to be honest with you, other than probably Athena's mother. But it's not important for this book to succeed that we like any of them. In fact, it feels almost the direct opposite is true.  The story that June 'enhances' is one that Athena was ethically well placed to write, one to which June has little to no connection - the story of Chinese labourers used for the war effort. It opens up discussion and consideration, not only in the book but on a wider scales, about cultural appropriation. Is it okay for a white American woman to write a book about Chinese immigrants as long as the portrayal is sympathetic and authentic, or is it simply exploitation and something that Chinese-American readers can feel rightfully outraged about. Of course, June, and her publisher, would argue the former, but the use of an ethnically ambiguous name somewhat muddies the waters, allowing readers to make assumptions about the author that may not be true. And there are other elements that June allows to happen that start to create conflict in an already contentious situation. Plagiarism, or manuscript theft, aside, This is a very complex situation, not helped by June's defensiveness, something else that creates a rift that may yet prove to be her undoing.  So many elements of this book - the cultural appropriation argument is just a drop in the ocean - ring true. The dogpiling on social media, the needs of certain characters to rip apart June for nothing more than their own smug satisfaction, felt almost uncomfortably true to life. I've seen it myself - active campaigns against a particular author or celebrity because they shared an opinion that differs from someone else's. There is, at the end of the day, no defending June's initial actions, but there is no defending the campaign against her either. The author's exploration of the impact of social media on mental health, that constant nagging need to see what is being said about you despite knowing that it will not be good for your soul, is so en-pointe that I'm sure for many author's it will cut to the bone. If the 'antagonist' (and there is a very loosely defined antagonist in this book) could claim their actions are coming entirely from the moral high ground then I might have felt more sympathy for them. But they weren't and I didn't. They acted in a way as indefensible as June. In fact, I kind of despised them a little. More than a little. Quite a lot actually.  There is a comedic element to this story too, and for anyone in the know you will find yourself smiling a grudging smile. References to an author's nemesis "GoodReads" made me chuckle. It does have a reputation as being a cesspit for reviewers who have no filter and who delight in slamming books for nothing more than their satisfaction. It's a site where you can even leave a one star review for a book that isn't even available in proof form, which some folks seem to delight in doing. I know - call me a hypocrite - I post there too, but largely as a way to counter the negativity with a little bit of light. But, debates about review sites aside, there are many other moments which made me smile. Many folks would be forgiven for thinking that authors are loaded, living the dream on yacht's and in luxury apartments around the globe. The height of June's ambition from spending her royalties is being able to afford an Ikea sofa to match the rest of her recently acquired Ikea furniture. I'm saying nothing more ...  Funny yet sometimes dark, this is a fresh, beautifully written foray into the mind of a very troubled, young, author. I really enjoyed this book. I can see why many authors enjoyed this too. Maybe it is a little bit conflated, with tongue in cheek exaggeration, but there is so much of this book that feels scarily authentic that there's a danger Rebecca Kuang will have people thinking twice about pursuing a career as an author. Or maybe that was the point. After all, less competition can only be a good things for sales, right?

Of course, June, and her publisher, would argue the former, but the use of an ethnically ambiguous name somewhat muddies the waters, allowing readers to make assumptions about the author that may not be true. And there are other elements that June allows to happen that start to create conflict in an already contentious situation. Plagiarism, or manuscript theft, aside, This is a very complex situation, not helped by June's defensiveness, something else that creates a rift that may yet prove to be her undoing.

So many elements of this book - the cultural appropriation argument is just a drop in the ocean - ring true. The dogpiling on social media, the needs of certain characters to rip apart June for nothing more than their own smug satisfaction, felt almost uncomfortably true to life. I've seen it myself - active campaigns against a particular author or celebrity because they shared an opinion that differs from someone else's. There is, at the end of the day, no defending June's initial actions, but there is no defending the campaign against her either. The author's exploration of the impact of social media on mental health, that constant nagging need to see what is being said about you despite knowing that it will not be good for your soul, is so en-pointe that I'm sure for many author's it will cut to the bone. If the 'antagonist' (and there is a very loosely defined antagonist in this book) could claim their actions are coming entirely from the moral high ground then I might have felt more sympathy for them. But they weren't and I didn't. They acted in a way as indefensible as June. In fact, I kind of despised them a little. More than a little. Quite a lot actually.

There is a comedic element to this story too, and for anyone in the know you will find yourself smiling a grudging smile. References to an author's nemesis "GoodReads" made me chuckle. It does have a reputation as being a cesspit for reviewers who have no filter and who delight in slamming books for nothing more than their satisfaction. It's a site where you can even leave a one star review for a book that isn't even available in proof form, which some folks seem to delight in doing. I know - call me a hypocrite - I post there too, but largely as a way to counter the negativity with a little bit of light. But, debates about review sites aside, there are many other moments which made me smile. Many folks would be forgiven for thinking that authors are loaded, living the dream on yacht's and in luxury apartments around the globe. The height of June's ambition from spending her royalties is being able to afford an Ikea sofa to match the rest of her recently acquired Ikea furniture. I'm saying nothing more ...

Funny yet sometimes dark, this is a fresh, beautifully written foray into the mind of a very troubled, young, author. I really enjoyed this book. I can see why many authors enjoyed this too. Maybe it is a little bit conflated, with tongue in cheek exaggeration, but there is so much of this book that feels scarily authentic that there's a danger Rebecca Kuang will have people thinking twice about pursuing a career as an author. Or maybe that was the point. After all, less competition can only be a good things for sales, right?
