profile.name: JenMedBookLover

title: More satirical literary than thriller
body: What to make of this book? I honestly don't know! I liked the plot: 2 authors, 1 highly successful star of the moment Athena (Asian American yes its important to know), the other unsuccessful with a failed debut novel Juniper (white American). They are supposedly friends, however June is highly jealous of Athena. One night whilst having been drinking celebrating Athena's latest success, June witnesses Athena's death by choking having been unable to help. Now moments before her death, the secretive Athena had showed June her newest and completed 1st draft of her latest book. She says no one else has seen or heard about it, so June steals it in the proceeding commotion of Athena's death and subsequently publishes it as her own work to much success. The book is a historical WW1 fiction piece about Chinese labourers and as June is a white woman, a lot of criticism is thrown at her for it. What ensues is a racial satire about the publishing world and social media influence.  The book is marketed as a thriller? It is hardly a thriller more a satirical literary piece with a tiny thriller element towards the end. The book was somewhat slow paced the majority of the time focusing too much on the negative aspects of social media and highlighting racism and reverse racism, mental health connected to bullying and the negative aspects of publishing which were interesting to learn about.  The beginning was good setting up the plot, the middle dragged on and on more or less repeating itself in slightly vsrying ways and the ending fell a bit flat for me. I wanted more, it almost just stopped. I enjoyed it but could not give the 5 stars due to pacing, not being what it was marketed as and I felt the message was a bit confusing perhaps even contradictory? Perhaps I just don't 'get it' which is fine too.
body_html:
What to make of this book?
I honestly don't know!
I liked the plot:
2 authors, 1 highly successful star of the moment Athena (Asian American yes its important to know), the other unsuccessful with a failed debut novel Juniper (white American). They are supposedly friends, however June is highly jealous of Athena. One night whilst having been drinking celebrating Athena's latest success, June witnesses Athena's death by choking having been unable to help. Now moments before her death, the secretive Athena had showed June her newest and completed 1st draft of her latest book. She says no one else has seen or heard about it, so June steals it in the proceeding commotion of Athena's death and subsequently publishes it as her own work to much success. The book is a historical WW1 fiction piece about Chinese labourers and as June is a white woman, a lot of criticism is thrown at her for it. What ensues is a racial satire about the publishing world and social media influence.

The book is marketed as a thriller? It is hardly a thriller more a satirical literary piece with a tiny thriller element towards the end. The book was somewhat slow paced the majority of the time focusing too much on the negative aspects of social media and highlighting racism and reverse racism, mental health connected to bullying and the negative aspects of publishing which were interesting to learn about.

The beginning was good setting up the plot, the middle dragged on and on more or less repeating itself in slightly vsrying ways and the ending fell a bit flat for me. I wanted more, it almost just stopped.
I enjoyed it but could not give the 5 stars due to pacing, not being what it was marketed as and I felt the message was a bit confusing perhaps even contradictory? Perhaps I just don't 'get it' which is fine too.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 25 February 2024
profile.name: Girl_ontv

title: Ingenue or Enfant Terrible?
body: This is a writer’s novel in every sense of the word. It examines the issues of racism and cultural appropriation in literary writing, the attraction of cancel culture on social media, the volatile allure of celebrity authors and the ugly cutthroat world of publishing.  But R.F. Huang’s novel does all these things and much, much more. In a metafictive way, Huang deploys her identity as an Asian American author and assumes the persona of a white young writer Juniper Song Hayward who finds herself with her dead Asian writer friend’s unpublished manuscript about Chinese immigrants in World War 1.  By taking on the first-person perspective of a white young writer who finds herself in a literary maelstrom amid accusations of plagiarism and appropriation of her dead friend’s work and Asian voices (e.g. who has the right to write about someone else’s suffering, even if it is fiction?), Huang heads off criticism of reverse racism (also something she explores through Juniper’s own experiences), problematises the readers’ perspectives and sides they should take as she stands these issues on their heads.  Huang’s anti-heroine Juniper is an unreliable and morally ambivalent character which complicates the readers’ empathy for her. Athena Liu, the doe-eyed and pretty ingenue of the literary scene that is Juniper’s supposed close friend and from whom she (steals/borrows?) her manuscript (is it really stealing if it is sketchy and unpolished?) after Athena accidentally chokes on some midnight pancakes, arguably shares a more similar background with the author, but that Huang chooses to write from Juniper’s story is quite an ingenious sleight of hand.  The pace of the novel is unrelenting and Huang’s fine prose (aside from her overuse of words and phrases such as “melatonin” and “dry heaving”) engages effortlessly, and the reader is both hopeful and afraid that the truth will surface and destroy Juniper.
body_html:
This is a writer’s novel in every sense of the word. It examines the issues of racism and cultural appropriation in literary writing, the attraction of cancel culture on social media, the volatile allure of celebrity authors and the ugly cutthroat world of publishing.

But R.F. Huang’s novel does all these things and much, much more. In a metafictive way, Huang deploys her identity as an Asian American author and assumes the persona of a white young writer Juniper Song Hayward who finds herself with her dead Asian writer friend’s unpublished manuscript about Chinese immigrants in World War 1.

By taking on the first-person perspective of a white young writer who finds herself in a literary maelstrom amid accusations of plagiarism and appropriation of her dead friend’s work and Asian voices (e.g. who has the right to write about someone else’s suffering, even if it is fiction?), Huang heads off criticism of reverse racism (also something she explores through Juniper’s own experiences), problematises the readers’ perspectives and sides they should take as she stands these issues on their heads.

Huang’s anti-heroine Juniper is an unreliable and morally ambivalent character which complicates the readers’ empathy for her. Athena Liu, the doe-eyed and pretty ingenue of the literary scene that is Juniper’s supposed close friend and from whom she (steals/borrows?) her manuscript (is it really stealing if it is sketchy and unpolished?) after Athena accidentally chokes on some midnight pancakes, arguably shares a more similar background with the author, but that Huang chooses to write from Juniper’s story is quite an ingenious sleight of hand.

The pace of the novel is unrelenting and Huang’s fine prose (aside from her overuse of words and phrases such as “melatonin” and “dry heaving”) engages effortlessly, and the reader is both hopeful and afraid that the truth will surface and destroy Juniper.

profile.name: J. Ang

title: harsh but important
body: Basically this page turner is a horror story. Explores lots of key issues of the day and provides a pretty scathing take on the publishing machine in which GoodReads plays a huge part. It’s very uncomfortable which makes it a rather i enjoyable read, but that doesn’t mean it’s not brilliant, I think it is.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 14 April 2024
profile.name: Chloe

title: Not as bad as Babel
body: After DNFing Babel, I was curious to see whether this book would live up to the hype. Well, at least I finished it, but I just find Kuang's writing a bit flat and lacking in substance. She certainly knows how to labour a point, which makes the narrative seem repetitive and preachy. The different voices get a bit jumbled towards the end as everyone turns out to be a self-interested narcissist, so it feels like the plot descends into a rant against...well practically everyone connected with the publishing industry and social media in general. The main character was portrayed as so odious that I found myself feeling sorry for her, and the stereotyped characters made me cringe more than once. At least the plot went somewhere but I don't think I'll be reading anything else by this author.

At least the plot went somewhere but I don't think I'll be reading anything else by this author.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 10 May 2024
profile.name: jardinera

title: Fascinating Read
body: Yellowface follows the friendship of two authors who are at opposite ends of the success ladder. June is struggling to get noticed by publishers and the wider book community while Athena is at the height of her publishing career with millions of followers. That is until June makes a decision that changes her life forever.  As someone who is part of the online book community, I must admit I found this story fascinating. It was a train wreck from the moment June stood by and watched Athena choke to death and did nothing to help her. And when you think June can’t sink any lower, she then steals Athena’s unpublished manuscript and passes it off as her own gaining her overnight success.  Every decision June makes from here made her seem more and more unstable; the jealousy, the lies, and delusions were a lot…but I honestly ATE IT UP…June is definitely a frustrating and an unlikeable character, certainly not someone you can root for as you read, but she does makes a very realistic two-faced manipulator and it kept me turning those pages right to the very end.
body_html:
Yellowface follows the friendship of two authors who are at opposite ends of the success ladder. June is struggling to get noticed by publishers and the wider book community while Athena is at the height of her publishing career with millions of followers. That is until June makes a decision that changes her life forever.

As someone who is part of the online book community, I must admit I found this story fascinating. It was a train wreck from the moment June stood by and watched Athena choke to death and did nothing to help her. And when you think June can’t sink any lower, she then steals Athena’s unpublished manuscript and passes it off as her own gaining her overnight success.

Every decision June makes from here made her seem more and more unstable; the jealousy, the lies, and delusions were a lot…but I honestly ATE IT UP…June is definitely a frustrating and an unlikeable character, certainly not someone you can root for as you read, but she does makes a very realistic two-faced manipulator and it kept me turning those pages right to the very end.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 30 January 2024
profile.name: Karen Louise

title: Wow!
body: A really gripping read - particularly impressive as I disliked the main character, Juniper, from the beginning and she just got worse! This was an extraordinarily biting and wicked exposition of the publishing world - not an area I've ever felt strongly about so, again, it was so clever to make it suddenly really interesting! This book made me want to seriously consider what I buy in the future - am I being manipulated by the hype? Am I being dragged into whatever the publishers think will sell to the masses? I do hope I'm a more discerning reader than that but who knows? The racist issue was used cleverly, reminding me how it can be used in so many different ways to drive different agendas - not always those that help the people who actually suffer from it. As an elderly reader of many thousands of books, I've encountered lots of stuff about online trolling and it always fascinates and horrifies me. Here, it did the same and as a driving force behind some of June's quite weird behaviour it worked well. As a dire warning never to go anywhwere near any of the scary social platforms, it worked brilliantly! As a reminder that internet fame and infamy blooms and shrivels without ever touching reality it was also brilliant. Overall, I thought this was a really good novel. I absolutely recommend it.
body_html:

As an elderly reader of many thousands of books, I've encountered lots of stuff about online trolling and it always fascinates and horrifies me. Here, it did the same and as a driving force behind some of June's quite weird behaviour it worked well. As a dire warning never to go anywhwere near any of the scary social platforms, it worked brilliantly! Overall, I thought this was a really good novel. I absolutely recommend it.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 24 April 2024
profile.name: Mig Bardsley

title: Review
body: I've heard a lot about Yellowface over the last year or so, so I was very keen to see what it is all about. I can see why it's been on social media a lot, as it raises a lot of questions about not just the publishing industry, but our lives in general, particularly in terms of our attitudes to racism and diversity.  The premise of the novel is set up fairly early, and it was fairly easy for me to see, at least in general terms, where the plot was going. However, this doesn't mean I didn't enjoy it - quite the opposite - as I got to know each of the characters. The novel is written in first person from June's perspective, and it's clear almost immediately that she's insecure and jealous. Her perspective was almost uncomfortable, yet so compelling and it was difficult to stop reading. I wasn't sure if I should feel angry towards her or sorry for her, but it's these kind of moral questions that make Yellowface a really interesting story.  I'm always rubbish at guessing the end of books, so it will come as no surprise to anyone that I didn't guess this one. However, the ending does have a much more tense feel than the rest of the story and I enjoyed reading as this played out. The ending isn't neatly tied together and I will be thinking about the future for the characters after I finish reading.
body_html:

I can see why it's been on social media a lot, as it raises a lot of questions about not just the publishing industry, but our lives in general, particularly in terms of our attitudes to racism and diversity.

The premise of the novel is set up fairly early, and it was fairly easy for me to see, at least in general terms, where the plot was going. However, this doesn't mean I didn't enjoy it - quite the opposite - as I got to know each of the characters. The novel is written in first person from June's perspective, and it's clear almost immediately that she's insecure and jealous. Her perspective was almost uncomfortable, yet so compelling and it was difficult to stop reading. I wasn't sure if I should feel angry towards her or sorry for her, but it's these kind of moral questions that make Yellowface a really interesting story.

I'm always rubbish at guessing the end of books, so it will come as no surprise to anyone that I didn't guess this one. However, the ending does have a much more tense feel than the rest of the story and I enjoyed reading as this played out. The ending isn't neatly tied together and I will be thinking about the future for the characters after I finish reading.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 2 January 2024
profile.name: Kate

title: I inhaled this book
body: I was gripped by this book and inhaled it rapidly so will probably go back again and read it at a slower pace. I’ve worked in publishing, although it was a while ago before social media became a huge factor and “being cancelled” was something that happened to flights rather than cultural figures. It was fascinating to ride the first-hand wave of someone desperate to be seen, to get recognition and feel “good enough” as a writer. I found myself siding with June even through some of her worst moments, and rooting for her even as her downfall became inevitable.  I don’t think this was a perfect book — it didn’t really end as convincingly as it started and the conclusion was too ambiguous for me at the pace I read it (which is why I need to go back and slow down). I felt there were some unexplored characters (what happened to her father?) and some of her past wasn’t clearly drawn, while there was quite a lot of repetition as her breakdown progressed in waves.  I also didn’t agree with the “serotonin” bumps she kept talking about. Isn’t that dopamine? But a minor detail and a good read: I’d put this one off for a while and am glad I got round to it.
body_html:
I was gripped by this book and inhaled it rapidly so will probably go back again and read it at a slower pace. I’ve worked in publishing, although it was a while ago before social media became a huge factor and “being cancelled” was something that happened to flights rather than cultural figures. It was fascinating to ride the first-hand wave of someone desperate to be seen, to get recognition and feel “good enough” as a writer. I found myself siding with June even through some of her worst moments, and rooting for her even as her downfall became inevitable.

I don’t think this was a perfect book — it didn’t really end as convincingly as it started and the conclusion was too ambiguous for me at the pace I read it (which is why I need to go back and slow down). I felt there were some unexplored characters (what happened to her father?) and some of her past wasn’t clearly drawn, while there was quite a lot of repetition as her breakdown progressed in waves.

I also didn’t agree with the “serotonin” bumps she kept talking about. Isn’t that dopamine? But a minor detail and a good read: I’d put this one off for a while and am glad I got round to it.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 4 January 2024
profile.name: Symbolist

title: Not sure about this book- although a very clever concept.
body: I am not sure if I enjoyed this book although it was well written. I learned a lot about the publishing process and the literary world- including all the aspects of whitecentricism that I was oblivious to. I looked up a few of the recent controversies relating to cultural appropriation in publishing, including the controversy surrounding the R.W.A. and I read a bit of background about the Chinese Labour corps in World War One. I also learned a few new words which is quite novel at 52. A novel that causes me to undertake a bit of background research is usually a good read, however I am just not sure about the book. It was a little tiresome at times. It probably held a mirror up to me that I didn’t enjoy- but I am not sure if that is what I particularly want from a book. I read to escape from my uncomfortable feelings and I think that this book gave me a few more. Although the narrator is not a very likeable character, I identified with a lot of the emotions that she felt and being slightly embarrassed and ashamed to be white. In that sense- I suppose it is a literary triumph but an uncomfortable read. Having reflected on my review- I have given it an extra star.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 2 January 2024
profile.name: Amber D

title: Overhyped…
body: I saw this book on Reese Witherspoon’s monthly picks and I immediately had to buy it! I love the books she picks 🤩 Also it’s yellow and I’ve developed a strange obsession with yellow books 🤣 And just look how pretty the sleeve and the hardback cover is 🤩  I really enjoyed this book but it did feel like there were 3 separate themes going on that didn’t really mesh together.  Firstly, there is the main story which is a disturbing tale of a young unsuccessful author who steals her dead friends work. Told in her sociopathic POV which was disturbing at times and yet impossible to stope reading. It can of gave me YOU vibes 😅 I caught myself agreeing with her too many times and then going WTF she is psycho 🤣  Secondly, was an incredibly accurate depiction of racism and reverse racism was given which I loved! I haven’t read such an accurate description of these theme before. And I applaud the author for being bold enough to be so open about this.  Thirdly, an interesting inside look at the book publishing process which was so interesting. I honestly didn’t realise how hard it was to publish a book before 😅  So while I loved all these themes individually, they didn’t mesh that well at all. So I really wouldn’t class this as a thriller at all.. maybe a book with some thriller notes 🤣 But I still think it’s a very unique and interesting book. I highly recommend it if you enjoy any of these themes 😊

date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 21 February 2024
profile.name: Ellenor Geraffy

title: Disappointing
body: I didn't love this book but I didn't hate it either...so where to start?  This is the story of June. June is an aspiring writer who has struggled to make the kind of splash that she wanted. Her debut was only slightly successful and her agent doesn't really engage with her much at all. Meanwhile, who sometimes friend from college, Athena, is hugely successful. Athena's first novel was wildly successful, winning awards left, right and centre. June is jealous of Athena's success so tries to avoid her at all costs. However, during one of their semi regular meet ups they end up back at Athena's apartment where Athena chokes to death on pancakes.  Suddenly June becomes semi famous, and this is built on when she publishers Athena's unseen manuscript about Chinese labourers during World War One as her own work. Now June is stratospherically famous....but she is being plagued by accusations of cultural insensitivity, specially as the book is published under her given name and middle name: Juniper Song. Soon the twitter messages turn aggressive and threatening and before long June is jumping at shadows....or is she?  I didn't know what to expect from this book. I'd heard a lot of buzz around it on Instagram and Twitter but didn't really have any expectations as to what the book would be like - I didn't even know what it was about. I didn't like the character of June at all - she comes off as whiny, jealous and entitled and this is something that sticks around right through the novel. The climactic ending scenes at the steps were thrilling but felt a bit out of place with the rest of the novel. It seemed to take a long time to get anywhere and I kept wanting to skip bits as I was thinking 'yes we know this...move on!'  As I said at the start, I didn't hate it but I didn't love it either and I very much doubt I'll be re-reading this.

profile.name: Kindle Customer

title: An Enjoyable But Often Uncomfortable Read
body: Plagiarism, lies, webs of deceit, despair, and amazing insight into the publishing world and the nasty side of the social media are all covered beautifully in this book. For me, it was a book of three parts. A great start, followed by a slump in the middle, and then a gripping race to the end.  June and Athena are friends and writers. Whilst June failed to get her book published, Athena's book proved itself to be the darling of the literary fiction world, catapulting Athena to stardom as a published author. June can only dream of what it must be like to have Athena's lifestyle. But then the unthinkable happens, and June, on discovering Athena's unpublished manuscript for her next book, decides to present it as her own work.  Finally, June finds herself under the spotlight she has totally convinced herself she deserves. But soon the spotlight starts shining on her for all the wrong reasons.  This book struck a chord with me because quite a few years ago now, I was a member of a group where an author was found out to be a plagiarist and I can clearly remember the shock and horror it caused. As awful as it was for that person to have done what she did, I'm truly grateful that social media was not the dark place it can be these days, and I sincerely hope she didn't face half of what June does in this book.  A really good, enjoyable and often uncomfortable read.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 7 December 2023
profile.name: Philippa Mckenna

title: Worth The Hype!
body: Heavily influenced by the Instagram book community, Yellowface was EVERYWHERE as a must read, and who am I to resist becoming involved? I couldn’t wait to get stuck into this book! Athena Lui is royalty of the Literature world. Her closest friend – actually, her ONLY friend - June is a polar opposite in terms of success, having published a book that wasn’t such a hit. Jealousy is deeply rooted in June (whether she wants to admit this or not) but when Athena dies in front of June in a freak accident, an opportunity strikes for June to steal Athena’s unpublished manuscript. No one knew Athena was working on it, so if she claims it has own, where’s the harm?  The book becomes a massive success and throws June into the spotlight, allowing her to experience Athena’s way of life as master of her craft. I was rooting for June throughout this novel, despite her being completely unsympathetic to her situation and actions. I honestly felt flurries of anxiety when things were closing in on her and was totally on edge when she was about to be discovered as a fraud.  I really made me consider what authors go through to bring their story to us. We pick up a book with complete faith in the author with confidence that they’re going to give us a great story and confidence we’re going to like it but the pressure that must be on them to give a good story or be compared to previous novel – I’d never considered it before. This book gave me an insight into the publishing world, which was fierce, savage and very, very interesting.  There were points in this book where I laughed out loud. The language the author uses is the language I use with my friends so completely relatable and comfortable to read. I didn’t really like any of the characters, but I don’t think I was meant to, keeping in mind everything is from June’s perspective, and June isn’t exactly our most stable source!  Overall, I enjoyed the book. I didn’t rush through it like I usually do when I get a novel I love but it still kept me very entertained!

The book becomes a massive success and throws June into the spotlight, allowing her to experience Athena’s way of life as master of her craft. I was rooting for June throughout this novel, despite her being completely unsympathetic to her situation and actions. I honestly felt flurries of anxiety when things were closing in on her and was totally on edge when she was about to be discovered as a fraud.

I really made me consider what authors go through to bring their story to us. We pick up a book with complete faith in the author with confidence that they’re going to give us a great story and confidence we’re going to like it but the pressure that must be on them to give a good story or be compared to previous novel – I’d never considered it before. This book gave me an insight into the publishing world, which was fierce, savage and very, very interesting.

There were points in this book where I laughed out loud. The language the author uses is the language I use with my friends so completely relatable and comfortable to read. body: A lovely story about sisters , family and loss. I loved the nostalgia of this book - it is set in 1990 about a girl called February who is devastated by a family tragedy and how she comes to terms with this through the help of a friend and a canary.

profile.name: Claire

title: Junie, Junie, Junie
body: You are insane.  I spent a lot of my time reading this book just laughing in shock. The way Rebecca Huang has written June is just so perfect for a certain type of person. I still read it with an underlying feeling of “first person POV isn’t enough, I need to share literal brain space with June” because gosh I need even more detail on how her mind works.  I don’t feel like the ending was really an ending - I think similar to June Rebecca Huang had written herself into a corner and couldn’t find an appropriate ending so left a halfway ending instead. I still had fun on the ride though!

profile.name: Julia M

title: a great read with an unusual story line
body: Yellow face is the story of June, a young author struggling to establish a writing career. June is fiercely jealous of her University friend Athena, who on the other hand, seems to have it all -bestsellers, good looks, money and a wide fan base. In a cosmically ironic incident, Athena fatally chokes in front of June, seconds after revealing a disgruntled June, her latest manuscript. June grabs the manuscript, edits it and goes on to publish her first bestseller, finally realising her dream career. June’s euphoria jumps out from the pages of the novel but while she is basking in this new found glory ghosts from the past come to haunt her. As the story unfolds the writing is both addictive and compelling. As well as a series of clever twists and developments, Two key themes are carefully explored. The isolation and struggles faced by authors in a toxic and competitive environment as well as the negative impacts of social media and cyber bullying, the latter in particular will resonate with many young readers. Overall a very enjoyable read and an incredible protagonist. In fact I am still not sure what I think of our June …?

Still, very thought-provoking, and great to see a writer of one ethnicity writing from the perspective of another, and doing it so well.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 23 January 2024
profile.name: Chris

title: Plot derailed by bewildering decisions
body: I've just finished this and come hurtling here to review it, which I don't often do but is inevitably a sign of a very good or very bad novel.  I share the pain of other reviewers about the ludicrous protagonist. The decisions she makes are ridiculous enough, but her repeated belief that they're sane decisions that will benefit her bear no resemblance to the actual universe we inhabit. She does something stupid, she assumes it'll be great for her, we all know it won't and it isn't, over and over again. On the fourth time of asking the reader has lost all sympathy for the character and by the seventh we actively want her to fall off something tall. (If you read this book, the fourth time is probably the one when you'll shout "BUT YOU'RE NOT CHINESE".)  As others have said it shows great promise in the first half, then starts tunnelling hard into those mad decisions and by the last quarter you're skipping whole paragraphs about dreams and ghosts. And (mild spoiler, maybe) it's so obvious who the 'villain' is it's almost sweet the author actually went through with it.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 8 February 2024
profile.name: JANET MALLORIE

title: On cultural appropration or revolutionary revisionist review of the publishing industry?
body: I read this having completely forgotten I'd fairly recently also read Babel by the same author. The latter book has a very very clever metaphor for colonisation through the lens of magic wrought be a steampunk victorian empire exploiting translation and translaters and the power of words. And a great plot & character.  This novel is less fantasy and more rooted in the real world of celebrity books and their writers, but pivots off of appropriation, literal and figurative, actual and cultural. It would be a spoiler to say exactly how, but the layers of guilt (who is enitled to write a book set in a certain time about a certain people, and who might not be) and authenticity (its fiction, doh!), but also friendships (genuine, or explotative). Very clever stuff (like Babel). On the other hand the author, like one of the protagonists, both is and isn't from the same milieu as the key character in this story either, so (and if this is true, I'm on same side) we assume that the writer believes that the creative process is of course about inhabiting other people's minds, and capturing that for us, the readers, and that journey can be to foreign places and times, otherwise we'd all just be telling stories about ourselves, and that's why social media is largely so banal, since that's what 90% of scribblings there amount to.  I'm reminded of a recent story about a K-pop band who got some flak as none of the women singers was Korean. I'm just gonna say that pop music's greatest exponents are people like Abba and Kylie Minogue, so if you're gonna say you have to be australian or swedish to sing pop music, you are going to look pretty silly.  Anyhow, the most interesting musing in Yellowface, for me, is right near the end when the idea of tearing down the whole publishng industry and replacing it with something more equitable and less predatory appears, sadly too briefly - what that alternative might be would be really interesting to hear more about.  Meanwhile, while there is a very superficial resemblance to The Plot here (which I massively recommend), I really liked this - but here's a thought experiment: What if Juniper Song Hayward was (say) Latina or African American? How would that change your sympathies?

It would be a spoiler to say exactly how, but the layers of guilt (who is enitled to write a book set in a certain time about a certain people, and who might not be) and authenticity (its fiction, doh!), but also friendships (genuine, or explotative). Very clever stuff (like Babel). On the other hand the author, like one of the protagonists, both is and isn't from the same milieu as the key character in this story either, so (and if this is true, I'm on same side) we assume that the writer believes that the creative process is of course about inhabiting other people's minds, and capturing that for us, the readers, and that journey can be to foreign places and times, otherwise we'd all just be telling stories about ourselves, and that's why social media is largely so banal, since that's what 90% of scribblings there amount to.

I'm reminded of a recent story about a K-pop band who got some flak as none of the women singers was Korean. I'm just gonna say that pop music's greatest exponents are people like Abba and Kylie Minogue, so if you're gonna say you have to be australian or swedish to sing pop music, you are going to look pretty silly.

Anyhow, the most interesting musing in Yellowface, for me, is right near the end when the idea of tearing down the whole publishng industry and replacing it with something more equitable and less predatory appears, sadly too briefly - what that alternative might be would be really interesting to hear more about.

Meanwhile, while there is a very superficial resemblance to The Plot here (which I massively recommend), I really liked this - but here's a thought experiment: What if Juniper Song Hayward was (say) Latina or African American? How would that change your sympathies?
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 5 September 2023
profile.name: Jon A. Crowcroft

title: Savvy or cynical?
body: In all honesty, I kept reading this because a small group had taken it up at the same time. I think I was the last one to complete it.  Initially, I became bored quite quickly. I didn't care about any of the characters. I persevered because I suspected that I was missing something.  Rival friends who are both writers. Plagiarism. Cultural appropriation. Publishing industry attitudes. Everyone gets some sort thrown at them in this novel.  I can't decide if the author is extremely savvy, intelligent, Zeitgeist aware. Or, if she's cynically using everything she mentions within the tale to sell books.  I have not read anything else by this author, but might.  I found the 'reveal' a little unbelievable. Beyond melodramatic.  I wasn't engaged with the story, but completed it out of a sense of obligation.

profile.name: Chloe

title: Publishing and its quirks
body: I loved learning more about the publishing industry from this book. From acquisitions to promotions and sales, discussions about cultural authenticity and intellectual property.  Juniper Hayward (June Song) is a white author whose ‘friend’ Athena has a much more successful writing career than she does. An incident leads to Juniper stealing her friend’s manuscript and the whole story begins.  A character has never had me so conflicted, one minute I hate her and think she is a thieving racist and other times I found myself understanding (ish) her motives.  Being written in first person, it gives the reader access into the mind of the protagonist.  This book is fast paced, you will find yourself turning the page to see what happens next. I didn’t get dark humour or thriller as advertised but I didn’t miss it.  I think this would be a great bookclub pick because there is so much to discuss. I also think it’s a good book for authors and book bloggers to read.
body_html:
I loved learning more about the publishing industry from this book. From acquisitions to promotions and sales, discussions about cultural authenticity and intellectual property.

A character has never had me so conflicted, one minute I hate her and think she is a thieving racist and other times I found myself understanding (ish) her motives.

Being written in first person, it gives the reader access into the mind of the protagonist.

This book is fast paced, you will find yourself turning the page to see what happens next. I didn’t get dark humour or thriller as advertised but I didn’t miss it.

I think this would be a great bookclub pick because there is so much to discuss. I also think it’s a good book for authors and book bloggers to read.

profile.name: Kirsten

title: Ya Durty Thievin'.........!
body: Well, what would you do? And how far would you go to do it? As far as you could really, but how far does too far go? Do you lift the manuscript, or do you leave it? The second, the book stops there! I'm not one to get sooked up by the hype of a book, but 99p (Kindle offer) didn't seem like a very risky sook, so penny for penny, this is the best nearly a pound I've spent on literature for a good while. I'd say it was a steal, but well, y'know, that's a bad word amongst writers! The event in question split the protagonist completely in 2, 50/50, right down the middle. I was never sure if I wanted good things or bad things to happen to her. Did she deserve both, or was she entirely beyond good and evil? You can talk yourself into anything! Did she deserve what she got? That's a lot of questions! Thoroughly deserving of the attached hype, it is a superb read, compelling, absorbing and entirely without waste. Beg or borrow a copy.....better not steal it!

profile.name: Nuno Santos

body: I really enjoyed Babel and was hoping for something similar in Yellowface...... Babel it's not!  The storyline follows one author stealing an unpublished manuscript from her deceased friend, editing it and claiming it as her own.  Things start to go wrong when other authors notice the similarities between the new book and the deceased authors published works.  Even after writing her own stand-alone novel, June can't escape the critics claiming it as Athena's work again and her whole world falls apart.  It's an interesting look at the world of publishing but it's not earth shattering.
body_html:
I really enjoyed Babel and was hoping for something similar in Yellowface...... Babel it's not!

The storyline follows one author stealing an unpublished manuscript from her deceased friend, editing it and claiming it as her own.

Things start to go wrong when other authors notice the similarities between the new book and the deceased authors published works.

Even after writing her own stand-alone novel, June can't escape the critics claiming it as Athena's work again and her whole world falls apart.

It's an interesting look at the world of publishing but it's not earth shattering.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 13 October 2023
profile.name: JRoper

title: Over-hyped
body: It's very hard to feel you were robbed of 0.99p, but this book accomplished that. Ironically, the best thing about it was its depiction of a disfunctional publishing industry that enables a piece of tedious, puerile nonsense like this to get published in the first place, let alone subsequently hyped to the heavens. Having struggled to get about a quarter of the way through, I then started skimming and skipping and soon gave up altogether.  Is there something I am missing? Surely all those rave reviewers can't be wrong?? I don't think so. Other reviewers on Amazon have struggled to the end hoping the book would finally divulge some hidden merit or a point that makes it all worth while, but apart from some kind of feeble twist at the end they've been disappointed. As for me, I'm not wasting any more time on it. The author clearly has talent, but she's been badly served here by her publishers, who shouldn't have allowed this book to go to print in its current form. Let's hope she can find a better voice in the future. The danger is that if she does produce something worthwhile, many potential readers like myself will probably just ignore the inevitable hype surrounding it.
body_html:
It's very hard to feel you were robbed of 0.99p, but this book accomplished that. Ironically, the best thing about it was its depiction of a disfunctional publishing industry that enables a piece of tedious, puerile nonsense like this to get published in the first place, let alone subsequently hyped to the heavens. Having struggled to get about a quarter of the way through, I then started skimming and skipping and soon gave up altogether.

Is there something I am missing? Surely all those rave reviewers can't be wrong?? I don't think so. Other reviewers on Amazon have struggled to the end hoping the book would finally divulge some hidden merit or a point that makes it all worth while, but apart from some kind of feeble twist at the end they've been disappointed. As for me, I'm not wasting any more time on it. The author clearly has talent, but she's been badly served here by her publishers, who shouldn't have allowed this book to go to print in its current form. Let's hope she can find a better voice in the future. The danger is that if she does produce something worthwhile, many potential readers like myself will probably just ignore the inevitable hype surrounding it.

profile.name: Mike Judy

title: Some good and some flawed recipes
body: I was attracted to this book because I needed to lose a bit of weight after Christmas and I am also a Type 2 Diabetic so the low carb recipes were just what I was after. Also the title suggested that the recipes do not need a high degree of culinary skill. My wife and I have been using the recipes for about 2 months now and have found them to be effective in reducing my blood sugar levels after meals and to reduce my weight by about 4 kg from 77.5 kg, which is slower than I hoped.  However, we have a number of issues with the recipes as follows. We have found that we liked less than half the recipes tried, which were mostly those for evening meals. Nearly all the recipes take at least twice as long to prepare as stated. Some recipes were only successful after we modified them to reduce the amount of water, i.e. they came out too watery if the recipe was followed exactly. Also the recipes require a lot more fresh food than we are used to, such that we really need a bigger fridge. Finally many of the breakfast or lunch recipes take too long to prepare, especially if you have to get up early for work. Also most of the lunch recipes are only suitable for preparation at home, which is no good for work, and who wants to spend 30 minutes preparing a light lunch anyway.  To end on a positive note some of the recipes are truly delicious in their own right, e.g. the mackerel fish cakes, egg curry.
body_html:

Also the title suggested that the recipes do not need a high degree of culinary skill. My wife and I have been using the recipes for about 2 months now and have found them to be effective in reducing my blood sugar levels after meals and to reduce my weight by about 4 kg from 77.5 kg, which is slower than I hoped.

However, we have a number of issues with the recipes as follows. We have found that we liked less than half the recipes tried, which were mostly those for evening meals. Nearly all the recipes take at least twice as long to prepare as stated. Some recipes were only successful after we modified them to reduce the amount of water, i.e. they came out too watery if the recipe was followed exactly. Also the recipes require a lot more fresh food than we are used to, such that we really need a bigger fridge. Finally many of the breakfast or lunch recipes take too long to prepare, especially if you have to get up early for work. Also most of the lunch recipes are only suitable for preparation at home, which is no good for work, and who wants to spend 30 minutes preparing a light lunch anyway.

To end on a positive note some of the recipes are truly delicious in their own right, e.g. the mackerel fish cakes, egg curry.

profile.name: deni

title: Changed my body and my life
body: This and the other Recipe Book literally changed my life. After 25 years of hating my body, and therefore, wrongly, myself, I eventually decided 'For Once and For All!' when the Lockdown Lard started nearing 15 stone. Yes, you need some willpower, but not much if you *actually* want it and it's therefore your number one priority. You've got to actually want to lose weight and improve your health. Not half-heartedly because you know you should. Small amount of willpower, a week or so of adjustment (again, you're prepared to put up with it because of the main goal you actually want), but actual meals to look forward to. Yes, probably smaller than you would have otherwise, and no, you can't have carbs, but they're still yummy and filling. I really don't miss carbs, I just have more veg now which is lovely. You have how many stones/kilos of energy (fat) hanging off you to use, you don't need to be eating more lol. Enough cooking to make it enjoyable and make you play an active part in changing your life and mindset, but both books easy enough that they can be done mid-week when you're tired after work. Everything is very straightforward, including explaining the science and reasoning behind what you're doing in the introduction - ketosis etc. I wish I'd done this years ago, but the science behind intermittent fasting hadn't happened, and that's all this is but every day, for a period, except only two a week, as I've also done for a few years now. Best thing ever. Never looking back now. Don't need to. I can do this for the rest of my life.

profile.name: pinkwatanabe

title: Really tasty and works very quickly
body: I’ve added a picture of my lunch v the picture in the book. I only made 1 portion and didn’t cut mine too neatly as I cut in half to test and put it back in the oven but you can see you get nice portions.  I’ve been using this book for the fast 800 Keto diet so I’m counting up the carbs and protein which is easy.  I’ve been doing the diet for 3 days now and I’ve already lost 5lb. I’ve bought the Keto sticks and those show it’s working well they’ve been getting darker each day.  I prepared myself for a week before I started so I could make sure I knew what I was doing and get the right things for the recipes. I was looking forward to starting and now I have I wish I’d done it sooner.  The food is delicious and very filling too. Ive not had any tummy rumbles so it’s not hard to resist eating other things.  I can see this working long term as I will like to eat this food after I’ve finished, there will be no wondering what to do when I achieve my goal.  Update 17 October 2022 I’m having a break at the moment but I managed to loose 3 stone over 12 weeks. I’m going to have another go to loose the last weight before Christmas. Really pleased with this book.

profile.name: Rozzi

title: This diet works!!!
body: I am diabetic [type 2] and needed to bring my blood sugars down to an acceptable level and lose some weight in the process. I read about this diet and the results people had achieved in a very short time and decided it was worth trying so I bought the book and started the diet. This diet is roughtly 800 calories a day and sounded a bit daunting but I can honestly say I was never hungary on it despite having to give up some foods and drinks such as bread, alcolhol, potatoes and pasta as it is low on carbs and high on protein but it works and I lost 8 kgs in 12 weeks the maximum time for the diet and then it is up to you to change your eating habits to keep the weight off and control your blood sugars. I have kept the weight off and 18 months later have lost a further 2 kgs and brought my blood sugars down to a point where I have reveresed my diabetic status and sugars are in the normal range.

profile.name: MrsM

title: A good selection of easy to cook recipes with straightforward ingredients
body: I have only had the book a few days but I have bookmarked a lot of recipes that sounded nice. So far we've had the one-pan breakfast and the prawn and pasta salad. Both were easy to prepare and very tasty (although the one-pan breakfast was very small - I think I would pack it out with more of everything - maybe double and double the calories).  Good pictures, tasty recipes and its easy to find things to keep to the 800 calories on fasting days (which is every day for me as I am at Stage 1). In fact I was under on the first day because I chose the one-pan breakfast which was so low in calories.  The recipes are similar to Joe Wicks and The South Beach Diet, which isn't surprising as they are all advocating a low carb, high protein diet with a focus on fish and chicken rather than beef and pork. However, don't be alarmed there are still beef, pork and duck recipes.

profile.name: BananaTricky

title: Outstanding book, beautifully presented
body: I already have the blood sugar recipe book and I have to say I have lost 2 stones without fasting just following recipies and advice in the book. I honestly haven’t felt hungry as the recipies are designed to leave you fuller for longer. I bought the 800 easy book as I am on ‘maintenance’ and wanted to try some new recipes. It’s a great place to start if you do want to lose weight. The book Looks amazing, nice and big , great sized font and beautifully photographed.! I am so excited to get shopping. My tips are 1. Get all your nuts and pulses in nice jars in a cupboard of their own (tip from 8 week blood sugar diet book which is a great beginners book) get your tins in order! 2. Online shopping is great for getting only what you need store wise and you can check your stores there and then. 3. Plan plan and plan. This takes a bit of time initially but now it’s second nature. 4. My shopping bill is quite reduced as the ingredients are largely cheap and so filling and I’m not wasting food. 6. Get the ‘junk’ out of the house! 7. This does not feel like a diet, just the healthy eating my dietician and endocrinologist told me to do ... but they did not tell me how... and most of all that’s what this book does.  Enjoy! X
body_html:
I already have the blood sugar recipe book and I have to say I have lost 2 stones without fasting just following recipies and advice in the book. I honestly haven’t felt hungry as the recipies are designed to leave you fuller for longer. I bought the 800 easy book as I am on ‘maintenance’ and wanted to try some new recipes. It’s a great place to start if you do want to lose weight.
The book Looks amazing, nice and big , great sized font and beautifully photographed.! I am so excited to get shopping.
My tips are
1. Get all your nuts and pulses in nice jars in a cupboard of their own (tip from 8 week blood sugar diet book which is a great beginners book) get your tins in order!
2. Online shopping is great for getting only what you need store wise and you can check your stores there and then.
3. Plan plan and plan. This takes a bit of time initially but now it’s second nature.
4. My shopping bill is quite reduced as the ingredients are largely cheap and so filling and I’m not wasting food.
6. Get the ‘junk’ out of the house!
7. This does not feel like a diet, just the healthy eating my dietician and endocrinologist told me to do ... but they did not tell me how... and most of all that’s what this book does.

Enjoy! X
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 23 January 2021
profile.name: CaWa

title: A Must if you are on the Fast 800 diet.
body: The trouble with being on a restrictive diet is that you can easily run out of ideas for meals. I have the red book (the first Fast800 recipe book) but I was getting a little bored with those, so this was very welcome. A lot of the recipes are variations on or similar to other recipes in the diet book or previous recipe book, but there are some new ideas which I think make it worth purchasing to add variety to your diet plan. These dishes are also very popular with non-dieters - but they can have things like potatoes!  The Garden Chicken Casserole, Cardamom Chicken, Simple Beef Casserole and Simple Fish Stew are probably my favourites. Some things are so simple, they don't really need a recipe (Simple roasted veg) but they give you menu ideas.  A tip from me though, nearly all the casserole type dishes both in this book and the previous one tell you to add water. If you don't like your casseroles thin and watery, play it by taste - only add water as needed because everyone complains about them being too watery, and they either end up having to thicken it with flour, or reduce it through simmering without lid.
body_html:
The trouble with being on a restrictive diet is that you can easily run out of ideas for meals. I have the red book (the first Fast800 recipe book) but I was getting a little bored with those, so this was very welcome. A lot of the recipes are variations on or similar to other recipes in the diet book or previous recipe book, but there are some new ideas which I think make it worth purchasing to add variety to your diet plan. These dishes are also very popular with non-dieters - but they can have things like potatoes!

The Garden Chicken Casserole, Cardamom Chicken, Simple Beef Casserole and Simple Fish Stew are probably my favourites. Some things are so simple, they don't really need a recipe (Simple roasted veg) but they give you menu ideas.

A tip from me though, nearly all the casserole type dishes both in this book and the previous one tell you to add water. If you don't like your casseroles thin and watery, play it by taste - only add water as needed because everyone complains about them being too watery, and they either end up having to thicken it with flour, or reduce it through simmering without lid.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 4 April 2021
profile.name: Mariel

title: So many tasty recipes!
body: Great book. I have the other recipe book and the fast 800 original book and this still has lots of great new ideas. There are loads and loads of recipes that I can’t wait to try. Some reviewers mentioned that some of the recipes are just ingredients put together on a plate but I actually really appreciate that about this book. They’re great ideas of combinations of ingredients that make up a nice interesting meal which really helps me stay inspired and looking forward to meal times. Not all of the recipes are like this, many are “proper cooking” and it’s so nice to have a recipe book that is more focused on eating healthy food that tastes nice, rather than trying too hard with “fakeaways” and replacing everything with artificial sweetener. Massive thumbs up from me.  Update: I’ve had this a little while now so have had a chance to try lots of recipes and I’ll truthfully say I’ve loved every single one. My favourites are the lamb moussakas and the prawn chilli and lemon spaghetti but I can happily flick through this book and easily plan a week of meals. The curried broccoli and paneer reheated really well the next day as did the tex mex chipotle chicken. Hands down my favourite cookbook right now.

title: It works
body: I have just completed 21 days on the Fast 800. I am not a big cook so only used a few of the recipes, but it did give me a bit of variation. The most important thing is that following the diet really does work. I stayed pretty strictly to under 20g of carbs, except of 2-3 days on about 25g, calorie intake between 750 -1000 per day and I lost an amazing 8.3kg (yes I know some of that is water weight). After eating normally for the last 2 weeks, I'm still a stone under my previous weight. Very happy with the result! 4* given as most of the recipes were too involved for me. Easier to just eat salad and protein.

title: Brilliant!
body: I was Diagnosed as being pre-diabetic as I’d put on weight over lockdown my blood pressure was up too so I wanted a safe way to lose some weight and change my outlook. This book along with listening to some podcasts by Michael Mosley. And I was convinced this was a way to get back my future! I’ve yo-yo dieted for years but this is A healthy way of losing weight and keeping it off. I love the recipes and all the calories carbs and protein are counted for you. So easy to follow I’ve lost 19lbs in 8 weeks I have 4 weeks to go to reach my target and up my diet to the 5/2 fast maintenance. I wish I’d learned this in my teens. ☺️

This book along with listening to some podcasts by Michael Mosley. And I was convinced this was a way to get back my future! profile.name: Mummyblossom

title: An excellent addition to the 'Fasting' Library.
body: I will start by saying that I have been Intermittent Fasting for some time, initially with the 5:2 plan and then following the refinements in the Fast 800. This approach to eating has quite simply changed my life.  'The Fast 800 Easy' starts with an introduction by Dr Michael Mosley and then moves into a brief overview of the concept.  Then come the recipes. A really tempting assortment of meals, 'light bites' and even a few treats.  At the back of the book is a Fast 800 Tool Kit - hints and tips for making the pan work for you. Also included are some sample meal plans.  My book arrived today, and I am already planning on making the Courgette Soup (it includes coconut milk and some spicy ginger)...the apple 'blinis' (I'm already an aficionado of courgette 'canapes') ....Chicken Katsu Curry (who doesn't love a curry!!!)..the Chickpea Patties...and then there is the fascinating sounding Chocolate and Black Bean Torte (which serves 12 but is thankfully freezable!!)  Beautifully illustrated with photographs throughout, this book is packed with inspiration.
body_html:
I will start by saying that I have been Intermittent Fasting for some time, initially with the 5:2 plan and then following the refinements in the Fast 800. This approach to eating has quite simply changed my life.

Beautifully illustrated with photographs throughout, this book is packed with inspiration.

profile.name: jax

title: Great recipe book in it's own right
body: I bought this book to give me some inspiration whilst I embarked on the 800Fast diet. I don't often review things but I felt I had to as I my wife and I have enjoyed the food from this book immensely! It has made meal times something to look forward to even though I am on a diet. The instructions are clear, the recipes easy to make and contain a large variety of textures and flavours to make the mouth water.  Particular favourites so far have been Curried broccoli and paneer (though we substitute halloumi for the paneer), cashew and butternut squash curry, portabella mushroom pizza's. I'm veggie so have focused on the veggie meals.  If you are starting the 800 fast then I would thoroughly recommend buying this book as well!

profile.name: RLA

title: Great value for money
body: Even if you don't want to go on epic starvation diet this book is great with its yummy and easy to prepare recipes. After cooking few of these meals you get the understanding what is good for you and what to avoid as ingredients in your future meals. It contains recipes from your staters through your mains to your puddings which makes it different from most of others similar diets and books. The recipes are illustrated with great pictures and the preparation instructions are sample and easy to follow. So far I have never had a problem finding the ingredients for these recipes in my local shops which is a big advantage compared to these cooking books that require you to hunt down some exotic ingredients from various shops. Great value for money indeed!!! And the diet works!

profile.name: Vlad and Andi

title: Good - but not as good as the first 2
body: This is a good follow on book - but not as great as I had hoped. In kindle it has some annoying differences - such as no direct links to the recipes when you are in the index, and I bought it because of the potential of meal planners (which I find really useful to help me stick to it) - but in reality there are only a couple (1 veg, 1 meat, 2 or 3 meals), and some of the recipes are very similar to those in the earlier books (recipes in previous books are also as quick and easy… which the title suggests this book will be better..) Anyway, that being said, the majority of the recipes look good - and if it’s like it’s like the earlier ones, I will use it lots to make lots of yummy things and still be healthy and loose some pounds…even if I do have to plan my own recipes (not the end of the world!!)

title: Very Good Recipe Book, apart from one disappointing recipe
body: Purchased 3 books by the Author, all of them very good. Loved most of the recipes in the Fast 800 Easy Book - easy to prepare, cook and filling. I was disappointed with the Banana Loaf, I followed instructions to the letter, expecting a really good banana tasting slice of cake to go with a cup of tea, however, loaf turned out bland and tasteless. There was a considerable amount of almond flour in it which overpowered the bananas. If it hadn't been for the blandness of this loaf I would have given the Fast 800 Easy book 5 stars.

title: Full of recipes that you'll want to make
body: I have all the Fast 800 recipe books now, & can honestly say I have never used other recipe books as much as these! The recipes are easy to follow & don't have strange ingredients that you wouldn't normally use. The meals are really tasty & have become real favourites in our house. My partner says that they are the best meals I've ever made, I'd be offended, but I totally agree! Since following this way of eating I have lost 2 & a half stone in less than 3 months. I never thought that would be possible & most importantly it hasn't felt like a 'diet', its been a very positive experience.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 25 March 2021
profile.name: Amazon Customer

title: Well worth the wait!
body: My book arrived last night and today, being time-poor and disorganised, I cooked the store-cupboard bean soup for a late lunch. Dead easy, 20 minutes to cook and totally delish! There is a language shift in this book from low carb to 'moderately' low carb, and greater use of regular (pre-prepared) ingredients you would typically have in your cupboard or freezer. Having skimmed through (more thorough scrutiny this weekend!), I can see so many recipes I know I'll love, and nice variations on some of my favourite recipes from the original Fast 800 recipe book. Every recipe I've made from the Fast 800 books has been fantastic, so much so that I'm seriously considering donating my other increasingly superfluous cook books to charity! You won't be disappointed.

profile.name: SB&C

title: Empowering, thoughtful and gripping
body: Yes! It really does live up to the hype. Beautifully written, it’s relatable but could be triggering in parts, it’s sad but there’s hope and a way out. You get invested in the hope.  Yes it does have some rather steamy scenes but with a cold realistic take on what abuse can do to a young woman and how she’s brave enough to put a stop to it holding her abuser accountable. It’s empowering, thoughtful and gripping.  However I do agree with other reviews I’ve seen. The way it’s portrayed by a lot is more focused on romance when there is domestic abuse involved which shouldn’t just be swept under the rug when promoting the book to others.  I think the book is a real page turner and your sucked in by tear jerker moments and finally relieved after you’ve been routing for Lilly throughout.  Overall, I really connected with this book and I would recommend it. Coleen Hoover is a fantastic writer and I’ll definitely be reading it starts with us next.
body_html:
Yes! It really does live up to the hype.
Beautifully written, it’s relatable but could be triggering in parts, it’s sad but there’s hope and a way out. You get invested in the hope.

Yes it does have some rather steamy scenes but with a cold realistic take on what abuse can do to a young woman and how she’s brave enough to put a stop to it holding her abuser accountable. It’s empowering, thoughtful and gripping.

However I do agree with other reviews I’ve seen. The way it’s portrayed by a lot is more focused on romance when there is domestic abuse involved which shouldn’t just be swept under the rug when promoting the book to others.

I think the book is a real page turner and your sucked in by tear jerker moments and finally relieved after you’ve been routing for Lilly throughout.

Overall, I really connected with this book and I would recommend it. Coleen Hoover is a fantastic writer and I’ll definitely be reading it starts with us next.

profile.name: K Whyte

title: I couldn’t put it down
body: After hearing a lot about Colleen hoover’s books, I thought I would try one of her best sellers when my lovely in laws bought me a kindle for my birthday. Oh my goodness, it stayed permanently in my hand for the entire reading. I won’t ruin it for others wanting to read but it really has opened my eyes to didn’t perspectives when dealing with abuse. However, I was quite disappointed that the book cover updated half way through my read to the leading actors face which distorted the image I had of Lily and others when reading. It’s great it’s been made into a film but it does take you out your reading bubble when you see who’s been cast! If you do read this, try not to search about the film before afterwards! Rookies mistake! Please read this, for someone who doesn’t like chic girly books, this really was one of the best books I’ve read in the past 5 years. I’ve already purchased the second to find out how it finishes!

profile.name: R.Blabla

title: A simple read. Easily forgettable. Not a book that you will think about time and time again
body: It's a very basic and over done story. A damaged girl meets damaged boy and they lose touch. Damaged girl then meets another damaged boy, they have a series of traumatic events. Damaged girl becomes very self aware and leaves damaged boy eventually running into the arms of the other (less so) damaged boy. It took me 7 months to really give it a go, picking it up 2 or 3 times before I commited. Slow to start, reads like a GSCE level story. I don't know if it gets better as the book goes on, or if the story took my interest. It was an easy read with hard subject matter. The characters sort of developed but sort of didn't. I could see she was trying but felt she never really managed to get it to it's full potential. There are some attempts at erotic scenes that are just meh, there are attempts at violent scenes that just read like actions without really portraying then feelings behind them. We're told to believe that these two were deeply in love, without actually knowing anything about their relationship. The finite details that make a story such as this so addictive and stomach churning just weren't there. I gave it 3 stars as it was a simple read. A holiday book perhaps, it's not very taxing nor does it evoke deep thoughts or the need to "read just one more page". I won't be buying book 2.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 29 March 2024
profile.name: Sarah.m

title: An emotional rollercoaster from the beginning
body: 🌟🌟🌟🌟🌟This was an emotional rollercoaster from the beginning. Both the past and present storylines pack an angsty punch. The fairy-tale seeming relationship that despondent Lily finds with Ryle was exciting and loving until his true colours show and his manipulative, abusive and controlling nature rears its ugly head. Lily was an easy character to connect with and this fact made it so sad to watch her struggle with her deep love for Ryle being eroded by his harmful behaviour and her mental health suffer as she was continuously traumatised. Meanwhile, her past love story with Atlas was beautifully poignant and so rich with a mutual devotion and understanding. I fell in love with Atlas straight away as the damaged but tender boy in need of love. This book was by no means an easy read and dealt with topics of domestic violence, child neglect, mental, physical, and emotional trauma while also covering the process of trying to find help and freedom from oppressive situations. It’s strange to say I loved this book but it’s true. I want to know more, and I eagerly await reading the sequel.  TW: Domestic violence, child neglect and emotional manipulation.

profile.name: Jill h.

title: Impactful
body: It Ends With Us is the story of Lily as she navigates her way through an abusive relationship. Her boyfriend, and later husband, Ryle, can be kind and funny and enigmatic, he is successful and driven, however none of that changes the fact that at his worst she is terrified of him. Growing up witness to a father who abused her mother, Lily always swore to herself she would never be such a woman, and yet now she finds herself making allowances for Ryle time and time again. Matters are only complicated further when a face from her past shows up, Atlas, her first love. What path will Lily choose for herself, and will she find the strength to break this cycle of abuse?  I've put off reading this book for a while, despite all the hype around it. However, having read Verity, also by Colleen Hoover not long ago, I finally decided to give this book a try. My overall thoughts are that this book is far from perfect, indeed there were parts that really grated on my nerves, however, despite its flaws, its overall message was really strong, and resonated even more after reading the author's note at the end. As such I have to applaud Colleen for writing a story that was so close to home, and for trying to get into Lily's mindset, as her story is surely one that will resonate with many.  As Colleen points out many times in the book, from the outside it seems such a simple and straightforward matter, that if you are in an abusive relationship you walk away from it. However, the reality is never so easy, and there can be so many factors in play. I particularly liked the emphasis on cycles and patterns of abuse, how Lily found herself in the same situation as her mother all those years ago, and the fact that we have glimpses into Lily's childhood helps to gain a deeper insight into her character and background. Ultimately, this story is about finding the strength to break such a cycle, and I think Colleen did a good job of showing Lily's journey to this point.  My main criticism is that I felt some of the writing and characters came across as immature. Lily and Ryle, and even Alysa often acted more like teenagers as opposed to grown adults, and Lily and Ryle's relationship felt rather adolescent. Strangely enough, the teenage Lily and the actual adolescent relationship depicted between Lily and Atlas felt more mature in comparison, such that it was as if Lily had regressed later on in life.  I'm sure that Colleen wants the reader to like Ryle to begin with, and yet to me he felt off from the very beginning. He was simply so intense and self-centred, and the relationship that develops between Lily and Ryle felt superficial such that I was never really invested in it to begin with. To be honest their relationship felt a bit too Fifty Shades of Grey, with Ryle too much a Christian Grey type character. As such I often found myself irritated at the chapters that focused on Lily and Ryle's developing relationship and when they're all loved up, as the tone just wasn't really for me, and to be honest was a bit cringey.  In contrast the chapters we have that focus on Lily as a teenager and her relationship with Atlas I loved. As well as showing the impact that her parents' relationship has on her growing up, we have this touching and sweet relationship that develops between Atlas and Lily. Atlas' personal story is also a really sad one, with important subjects such as homelessness explored, and I loved his resilience and how these two were always there supporting each other through all their trials. I did like though that later on Atlas doesn't necessarily rescue Lily like some knight in shining armour; he is there when she needs him certainly, but she has to rescue herself.  I loved that Alysa was there for Lily as a friend, despite the fact she was Ryle's sister. There was also a touching scene towards the end between Lily and her mother that I particularly appreciated.  Overall there were parts of this book that I adored (namely anything to do with Lily and Atlas) and parts that were very powerful and impactful. Unfortunately, elements of the writing and character development did for me personally affect my enjoyment of the story, and I would have likely rated it higher had the overall tone been more mature than it was.
body_html:
It Ends With Us is the story of Lily as she navigates her way through an abusive relationship. Her boyfriend, and later husband, Ryle, can be kind and funny and enigmatic, he is successful and driven, however none of that changes the fact that at his worst she is terrified of him. Growing up witness to a father who abused her mother, Lily always swore to herself she would never be such a woman, and yet now she finds herself making allowances for Ryle time and time again. Matters are only complicated further when a face from her past shows up, Atlas, her first love. What path will Lily choose for herself, and will she find the strength to break this cycle of abuse?

I've put off reading this book for a while, despite all the hype around it. However, having read Verity, also by Colleen Hoover not long ago, I finally decided to give this book a try. My overall thoughts are that this book is far from perfect, indeed there were parts that really grated on my nerves, however, despite its flaws, its overall message was really strong, and resonated even more after reading the author's note at the end. As such I have to applaud Colleen for writing a story that was so close to home, and for trying to get into Lily's mindset, as her story is surely one that will resonate with many.

As Colleen points out many times in the book, from the outside it seems such a simple and straightforward matter, that if you are in an abusive relationship you walk away from it. However, the reality is never so easy, and there can be so many factors in play. I particularly liked the emphasis on cycles and patterns of abuse, how Lily found herself in the same situation as her mother all those years ago, and the fact that we have glimpses into Lily's childhood helps to gain a deeper insight into her character and background. Ultimately, this story is about finding the strength to break such a cycle, and I think Colleen did a good job of showing Lily's journey to this point.

My main criticism is that I felt some of the writing and characters came across as immature. Lily and Ryle, and even Alysa often acted more like teenagers as opposed to grown adults, and Lily and Ryle's relationship felt rather adolescent. Strangely enough, the teenage Lily and the actual adolescent relationship depicted between Lily and Atlas felt more mature in comparison, such that it was as if Lily had regressed later on in life.

I'm sure that Colleen wants the reader to like Ryle to begin with, and yet to me he felt off from the very beginning. He was simply so intense and self-centred, and the relationship that develops between Lily and Ryle felt superficial such that I was never really invested in it to begin with. To be honest their relationship felt a bit too Fifty Shades of Grey, with Ryle too much a Christian Grey type character. As such I often found myself irritated at the chapters that focused on Lily and Ryle's developing relationship and when they're all loved up, as the tone just wasn't really for me, and to be honest was a bit cringey.

In contrast the chapters we have that focus on Lily as a teenager and her relationship with Atlas I loved. As well as showing the impact that her parents' relationship has on her growing up, we have this touching and sweet relationship that develops between Atlas and Lily. Atlas' personal story is also a really sad one, with important subjects such as homelessness explored, and I loved his resilience and how these two were always there supporting each other through all their trials. I did like though that later on Atlas doesn't necessarily rescue Lily like some knight in shining armour; he is there when she needs him certainly, but she has to rescue herself.

I loved that Alysa was there for Lily as a friend, despite the fact she was Ryle's sister. There was also a touching scene towards the end between Lily and her mother that I particularly appreciated.

Overall there were parts of this book that I adored (namely anything to do with Lily and Atlas) and parts that were very powerful and impactful. Unfortunately, elements of the writing and character development did for me personally affect my enjoyment of the story, and I would have likely rated it higher had the overall tone been more mature than it was.
