profile.name: Kindle Customer

title: Disappointing
body: I wasn’t a big fan of O’Brien prior to reading this but I like to read things that challenge my views and a few other reviewers had said that people who disagree with him should read this book so I thought I’d give it a go.  It’s way worse than I imagined it would be. For a start he doesn’t even attempt to argue for the central thesis of the book (that things have got worse over the last ten years under the Conservative Party) many of the points he makes go back decades. Such as the collusion between government and the press. He admits this went on under Blair. In fact, he doesn’t really make arguments at all in the traditional sense. He starts with ad hominem attacks on people, straw mans their argument and then makes a sarcastic comment. This may be entertaining reading for someone who already agrees with him but it's not going to convince anyone on the fence.  For example, when he talks about Suella Braverman, he starts talking about dehumanising language. He doesn’t quote anything she says though but says someone else said she uses language such referring to refugees as a ‘swarm’. Although O’Brien has to admit she never actually said that. Then he starts talking about Priti Patel and a couple of pages later he’s talking about how a certain newspaper is ‘infested’ with people he doesn’t like and in an interview with politics Joe he called Braverman ‘ a rash’. There’s a lot of personal attacks being thrown around and not much substance. Goodwin is ‘obscure’, Cameron is a ‘Patrician’, someone else is a racist and a bigot. He’s got labels for everyone he doesn’t like. It’s reads like a fiery diatribe rather than a well researched book.  He will outright lie when it suits him as well. Such as his claim that crime in Sweden has fallen since 2006. I found this hard to believe given there have been several documentaries and news articles talking about the rise in violent crime in Sweden, so I googled it and all the data I could find showed that crime had risen. So to be fair, I had a look at the article he had referenced when he made the point and this article specifically states that crime has risen. It’s unbelievable. I guess he thought no one would check. He’s not a data person and when an issue like this arises it’s baffling that he only relies on news articles. Looking at the end notes I couldn’t find a single book he has referenced. He wrote the entire book only using news sites which shows how lightweight and undercooked this analysis is.  I understand that it is comforting to read things that support your views and we are all susceptible to confirmation bias, but I really couldn’t understand why people would recommend this book to people who don’t already agree with him as it really feels like it’s written for his own audience. I didn’t get the impression he wanted to convince me of anything and like I said, he doesn’t really argue that things have got worse over the last ten years. To do that you would need to look at what things were like ten years ago and make a comparison. A better title for this book would be ‘why I don’t like the Conservative Party and right wing press’.
body_html:
I wasn’t a big fan of O’Brien prior to reading this but I like to read things that challenge my views and a few other reviewers had said that people who disagree with him should read this book so I thought I’d give it a go.

It’s way worse than I imagined it would be. For a start he doesn’t even attempt to argue for the central thesis of the book (that things have got worse over the last ten years under the Conservative Party) many of the points he makes go back decades. Such as the collusion between government and the press. He admits this went on under Blair. In fact, he doesn’t really make arguments at all in the traditional sense. He starts with ad hominem attacks on people, straw mans their argument and then makes a sarcastic comment. This may be entertaining reading for someone who already agrees with him but it's not going to convince anyone on the fence.

For example, when he talks about Suella Braverman, he starts talking about dehumanising language. He doesn’t quote anything she says though but says someone else said she uses language such referring to refugees as a ‘swarm’. Although O’Brien has to admit she never actually said that. Then he starts talking about Priti Patel and a couple of pages later he’s talking about how a certain newspaper is ‘infested’ with people he doesn’t like and in an interview with politics Joe he called Braverman ‘ a rash’. There’s a lot of personal attacks being thrown around and not much substance. Goodwin is ‘obscure’, Cameron is a ‘Patrician’, someone else is a racist and a bigot. He’s got labels for everyone he doesn’t like. It’s reads like a fiery diatribe rather than a well researched book.

He will outright lie when it suits him as well. Such as his claim that crime in Sweden has fallen since 2006. I found this hard to believe given there have been several documentaries and news articles talking about the rise in violent crime in Sweden, so I googled it and all the data I could find showed that crime had risen. So to be fair, I had a look at the article he had referenced when he made the point and this article specifically states that crime has risen. It’s unbelievable. I guess he thought no one would check. He’s not a data person and when an issue like this arises it’s baffling that he only relies on news articles. Looking at the end notes I couldn’t find a single book he has referenced. He wrote the entire book only using news sites which shows how lightweight and undercooked this analysis is.

I understand that it is comforting to read things that support your views and we are all susceptible to confirmation bias, but I really couldn’t understand why people would recommend this book to people who don’t already agree with him as it really feels like it’s written for his own audience. I didn’t get the impression he wanted to convince me of anything and like I said, he doesn’t really argue that things have got worse over the last ten years. To do that you would need to look at what things were like ten years ago and make a comparison. A better title for this book would be ‘why I don’t like the Conservative Party and right wing press’.

title: A thorough & engaging account of what & who shaped the sociopolitical fabric of the U.K
body: James O'Brien is well known due to being a valid sociopolitical commentator via various platforms over the years, including his show on LBC. Those of us familiar with his show should have an inkling of what to expect.  And he doesn't disappoint at all. It's all here, fully researched & choc laden with fantastic rhetorical flourishes and anecdotes that emphasise the subject matter with an almost tragi-comic clarity which almost softens the actual blows we've suffered for years in the UK  It took longer to read than i expected, simply because some of the people mentioned within, weren't readily identifyable figures. As a result, it can be difficult relating to them without further research using the internet.  Nonetheless, if you have more than a passing interest in how & why the UK has changed socio-economically and sociopolitically in the last fifteen or so years, this is well worth reading.
body_html:
James O'Brien is well known due to being a valid sociopolitical commentator via various platforms over the years, including his show on LBC. Those of us familiar with his show should have an inkling of what to expect.

It took longer to read than i expected, simply because some of the people mentioned within, weren't readily identifyable figures. As a result, it can be difficult relating to them without further research using the internet.

Nonetheless, if you have more than a passing interest in how & why the UK has changed socio-economically and sociopolitically in the last fifteen or so years, this is well worth reading.

profile.name: susanne crayton

title: Coruscating!
body: If anyone hasn’t already come across JO’B on the airwaves, like a latter-day Robbie Vincent for our times … Here he is in full flow, utterly debunking the immoral twerpitude of our recent ‘govt’ politicos and their aiders / abetters / condoners / bankrollers in the meeja & elsewhere. Forensic & anecdotal it may be, but he stonkingly clarifies the title premise as to how the old ‘establishment’ &/or ‘system’ has been (probably irretrievably) trashed from within. Those still too blind in that sense will probably not deign to look at it, or if they do, will deny multitudinous, balefully interconnected and provable facts just as they did when incapable/unwilling to consider ‘Project Fear’; others of us, who never felt any urge to align with the ‘Do-Badders’, should at least draw wry consolation from this thorough confirmation of what (and who) went wrong. If ever the fates aligned in Britain’s apparent favour (eg at the Imperial zenith, 100-odd years ago), it now seems to have been our turn for just about everything to tumble the other way (eg J Poo-byn ‘opposing’ various things, yet not The Topic Of The Day in June 2016). ‘We now are where we are’ … but J O’B sheds penetrating light on quite how we got here. Powerfully & unhesitatingly recommended to anyone of a like mind (or indeed others, whatever they might still find fit to make of it)!

profile.name: Peter O'Brien

title: The Truth, the Whole Truth and Nothing But the Truth
body: James O'Brien's latest book - following tomes on how to be right and not be wrong - is arguably his most polemical yet. Chapter by chapter, he dissects the roles that media moguls, politicians and newspaper editors have played in generating a generation's worth of failure, incompetence and downright illegality as this country has lurched from crisis to crisis, with seemingly no sign it will ever stop. Research here is key, and O'Brien's scalpel precision in both recording and retelling so many of the key stages between Rupert Murdoch's rise as a press baron to the laughably brief tenure of Liz Truss as Prime Minister. In between is made up of a frankly unbelivable-unless-it-was-true catalogue of cronyism, ill-preparedness, political gain at the expense of public wellbeing and criminal negligence. While I don't personally keep with every facet of each individual given their chapterial shame sheet, theres never the less ample fuel to stoke my personal ire. Standouts are inevitably the eviscerations of Nigel Farage, David Cameron, Dominic Cummings and Boris Johnson - key architects and beneficiaries of the Brexit referendum in 2016 which provides this book with its raison d'etre. O'Brien's skilful ability to plot piece by piece how a campaign of fear-mongering, racism, divergance and sheer bloody lies enabled these crooks and swindlers to point the blame at anyone other than themselves and somehow rise their own greasy poles in the meantime. It's telling that even the data obsessed and clearly non-parliamentarian Dominic Cummings is damned by O'Brien with faint praise for often being the smartest guy in a room filled with incompetence and promotion above and beyond any actual achievement. Privilege, entitlement and a willingness for self-service above the public need are the recurrent themes that emerge, and O'Brien's book is as important a testament to How they broke Britain as the Nuremberg trials were in accounting the events of World War II. Essential reading for anyone who still thinks it's all the fault of immigrants, the badly off, the disabled and the most needy of society, who have all been betrayed by the actions of nine white men and one white woman.

title: I’d begun to wonder if it was just me…
body: This was a depressing but also consoling read for me. I was starting to wonder if I was wrong about how destructive and dangerous these awful people are but this book revealed I am not alone. O’Brien is obviously much more informed than I am but he confirmed all my suspicions about how far to the right the Tories, their media and unofficial thinktanks have gone, how incompetent, self-serving, corrupt and mediocre politicians like Cameron, Johnson and Truss really are and how greedy, entitled, unscrupulous & selfish they all are. It’s a bracing read. Let’s just hope Britain can recover from this wretched crew

profile.name: C. M. Allwood

title: Essential reading
body: James O'Brien is a great chronicler of our times. His forensic approach is joined by unerring aim - he does more than point the finger, he delivers a rapier thrust to the vital organs of those who have done the damage. The major flaw about this book is hardly the author's fault: those who should read it won't. Anyone who ever voted for the politicians at the heart of this book, and responsible for the harm done to Britain's reputation, should also take some of the blame. Democracy is flawed - it's the worst system there is, except for all the others. The damage is partly caused by those who don't pay attention, but turn out to vote once every 4 or 5 years, giving an ego boost to charlatans and crooks who pretend to have our interests at heart. Perhaps the truly guilty are not those who gained positions from which they could do such harm - proroguing Parliament and lying to the sovereign for example - but the backbench MPs who thoroughly understood that their leaders were unfit for high office, but stuck by them, trooped through the division lobbies, hoping to curry favour and preferment. Shame on them too.

title: Alarming

It describes a system of wheels within wheels and I’m coming away feeling that although the machine is running the majority of the population are on the outside of it. Quite concerning the power that the British media has. Also concerning the influence people can have over what should be an independent media, Eton old boys network seems to have let us all down but they themselves seem to have done very well out of it. the wheels within wheels centre of being churning since the 80s, sadly they are now beginning to come off

title: Brexit Britain On Its Knees
body: As expected, a gripping if depressing read. What’s really astonishing is how so many could fall for the mendacious untruths cooked up by the clique of entitled chancers analysed in the book. I’m no genius, but wasn’t it 100% obvious that taking Boris Johnson, Liz Truss, Nigel Farage and chums on trust was never going to end well? I’m just relieved none of the historic self-harm inflicted over the last decade-and-a-half never had my vote or support. I don’t think I’d be able to sleep at night.

profile.name: Olesha

title: I Refreshing Dose of the Truth About Brexit
body: I’m a huge fan of James O’Brien and I listen to him on the radio almost every day, so this book was always going to be a must-read for me. I remember thinking during the Brexit madness of 2016 to 2020 that the entire saga would make a great book. Well here it is!  The title of this book is misleading (if not dramatic): Britain is not broken; but it has been severely damaged by the madness and stupidity of Brexit. This book really should have been called "How Brexit managed to happen" because that's what it's actually about. In these pages O'Brien carefully and meticulous detail explains the process by which the UK voted for something that he sarcastically calls "self-imposed economic sanctions".  The way that O'Brien lays out the book is very clever. Each chapter is dedicated to one of the 10 people who O'Brien believes is responsible for the Brexit disaster happening and for subsequent later problems. From Rupert Murdoch to Liz Truss, O'Brien shows how and why theses people damaged the UK so much. The writer points to the Conservative Party and its "client media", i.e. the Right-wing press, Like the Daily Mail and The Telegraph; and how that close relationship was and still is used to influence millions of ordinary people in this country to vote agains their own interest.  The three characters that O'Brien has the most contempt for are Paul Dacre (the former editor of the Daily Mail), Nigel Farage and Boris Johnson. O'Brien provides a forensic examination of these people and exposes just how toxic their influence has been on British society.  This is a great read.

From Rupert Murdoch to Liz Truss, O'Brien shows how and why theses people damaged the UK so much. The writer points to the Conservative Party and its "client media", i.e. the Right-wing press, Like the Daily Mail and The Telegraph; and how that close relationship was and still is used to influence millions of ordinary people in this country to vote agains their own interest.

The three characters that O'Brien has the most contempt for are Paul Dacre (the former editor of the Daily Mail), Nigel Farage and Boris Johnson. O'Brien provides a forensic examination of these people and exposes just how toxic their influence has been on British society.

This is a great read.

title: Brilliant could not put it down!
body: So well researched and written. I am ashamed to say I 'enjoyed ' reading this book, shame because there should never be any joy or pleasure in reading about such obviously horrible people and events. I can though hold my head up, because apart from some of the more shadowy figures that I did not know about, but now do, I have always hated all of them and called them out for what they always were and are. So James was preaching to the converted with me, but he did the preaching ever so well!

profile.name: Nigel H

title: Lisa has not lost her touch!
body: I often read the 2 or 3 star reviews before I buy a book, on the basis that there are too many good books waiting out there to waste time on bad ones; and having several of Lisa Jewell's books before and enjoyed them, I'll admit I was a a bit unsure about this one based on comments like 'this is not as good as her other books,' and, worse, 'she's lost her touch,' which of course can happen to writers - but I can promise you it has not happened here. This is as good as anything Ms Jewell has written before, and I'd say one of her best. 'None of This Is True' is as fast, complex and as clever as can be, and actually made me gasp out loud at a stunningly audacious 'really did not see this coming' moment early on. At first it all seems pretty par for the course - Alix is character you're not going to feel much sympathy for, with her seemingly perfect and privileged lifestyle, and Josie is the one with the hard knocks and the dead ends...and yes, while'none of this is true,' but it's not a straightforward truth-for-lies swap at all, and isn't what you might expect at all. The plots twists are just superb. In terms of a reading experience, it's all there - the usual Jewell sharp eye for detail, the nailed-it descriptions and the keen ear for dialogue, all there in spades, so very skilful, and never grates; but on top of that, the plot is clever, elegant, and my gawd, is it pacey! I read it in an afternoon. Don't believe what another reviewer said - Lisa has not lost her touch at all. Just fabulous.
body_html: I often read the 2 or 3 star reviews before I buy a book, on the basis that there are too many good books waiting out there to waste time on bad ones; and having several of Lisa Jewell's books before and enjoyed them, I'll admit I was a a bit unsure about this one based on comments like 'this is not as good as her other books,' and, worse, 'she's lost her touch,' which of course can happen to writers - but I can promise you it has not happened here. This is as good as anything Ms Jewell has written before, and I'd say one of her best. 'None of This Is True' is as fast, complex and as clever as can be, and actually made me gasp out loud at a stunningly audacious 'really did not see this coming' moment early on. At first it all seems pretty par for the course - Alix is character you're not going to feel much sympathy for, with her seemingly perfect and privileged lifestyle, and Josie is the one with the hard knocks and the dead ends...and yes, while'none of this is true,' but it's not a straightforward truth-for-lies swap at all, and isn't what you might expect at all. The plots twists are just superb. In terms of a reading experience, it's all there - the usual Jewell sharp eye for detail, the nailed-it descriptions and the keen ear for dialogue, all there in spades, so very skilful, and never grates; but on top of that, the plot is clever, elegant, and my gawd, is it pacey! I read it in an afternoon. Don't believe what another reviewer said - Lisa has not lost her touch at all. Just fabulous.

profile.name: Lexi

title: A must read, dark psychological thriller! 🩸
body: 'When she doesn't like the reality of things, she finds a reality she prefers.'  This is the story of Alix Summer and Josie Fair, two women both celebrating turning 45 at the same pub. In the pub toilets, they first meet and discover they are 'birthday twin's - born on the same day. Not only that, born in the same year at the same hospital. Soon, both of their lives become intertwined and nothing will ever be the same again.  I read this book at the beginning of last week and have delayed reviewing it until now, as I just couldn't find the words to describe how much I love it! It is a dark psychological thriller, full of suspense, that only gets darker the more you read- and at certain points I would say revolting. The inclusion of podcast transcripts, social media as well as the documentary aspect all add another dimension to the story. I was gripped and on edge, uncomfortable from the beginning until the end.  It is amazing to have two female protagonists at the forefront of this story, with a particular spotlight on how social media is not an accurate reflection of someone's life and nobody knows the reality of life behind closed doors. Josie is particularly complex and unhinged. She is very odd, narsasistic, obsessive and manipulative. She really is quite terrifying! Everything she does is calculated and whilst being very unlikeable, I was totally captivated by her and I can't stop thinking about her. I loved Alix. She is a woman who wants to have it all - the career, house, marriage and family. While there where times I wanted to shake her, for her to stand her ground - in relation to both Josey and Nathan, ultimately I found her very relatable. Her love for her family and wanting to protect them, shone through everything.  This is a tale about the fragility of life and how things are never as they seem. This is my favourite Lisa Jewell book by far. I'm well and truly fascinated and want to know more! 🎧🩸

profile.name: Colette Hunter

title: Spoiler alert. Well sort of.
body: I live Lisa Jewell books. So I was really looking forward to reading this. It was an OK book mostly. But I found the characters annoying and the way 2 of the characters in particular were portrayed. One is a paedophile who we are feeling sorry for (supposedly) by the end. And the other is a complete nut job who actually had a very disfunctional childhood, who we end up having no sympathy for by the end of the book?! . Only 2 real twists and not enough went into why these happened. A little disappointing overall. Easy read for some but a wee boring for me. I'm glad I waited for the price to come right down before downloading.

title: Worth reading as kept entertained from start to finish.
body: Podcaster, Alix is celebrating her 45th birthday with her husband when she cross paths with Jolie who is also celebrating her 45th birthday. They meet again and after chatting to Josie, Alix feel’s her story would make for an interesting podcast. Josie is quite happy to oblige and an unknowing Alix does not realise who exactly she has now invited into her family’s life. I felt very sorry for Alix’s husband Nathan. It was a very good book to read as I was kept entertained from start to finish with a slightly unclear “was it one or two baddys” ending.

profile.name: Liz

title: Anther great read from Jewel
body: Jewel never disappoints and she certainly delivers here in this brilliant holiday read, full of twists and turns that have you guessing throughout.-It's a plot of obsession, lies and murder. Alix and Josie meet by chance at a pub where they are celebrating their forty fifth birthdays. From the outside one has it all, friends, looks and fame: she produces successful podcasts while the other is full with bitterness, regrets and what could have been. After their initial introduction in the pub loos, Josie initiates another meeting whereby she offers to be the next subject on the podcast. An opportunity Alix jumps at despite her initial doubts about this rather strange woman. Josie excitingly informs her that something big is going to happen to her but first she must tell her side of her story. She begins to detail a toxic life of grooming, child abuse and domestic violence. As Alix falls deeper into her web of lies and deceit she puts her husband and family at risk and danger. Soon it is Josie calling the shots and Alix who is following blindly always one step behind. Unfortunately she realises too late just how dangerous and manipulative Josie is. Jewel's style and structure for this novel is interesting as it flips back and forth between narrative and interviews, which will contribute to a Netflix documentary series. As it progresses it captures the unraveling of Josie. highly recommend
body_html:

Soon it is Josie calling the shots and Alix who is following blindly always one step behind. Unfortunately she realises too late just how dangerous and manipulative Josie is.
Jewel's style and structure for this novel is interesting as it flips back and forth between narrative and interviews, which will contribute to a Netflix documentary series. As it progresses it captures the unraveling of Josie.
highly recommend

title: Gripping
body: After a chance meet whilst both Josie and Alix are celebrating their 45th birthdays, Josie becomes obsessed with the connection between them and finding ways to bump in to Alix. Josie suggests that Alix uses her as the subject for one of her podcasts with the subject of changing her life. This podcast 'birthday twins' is kept secret whilst recording, as Josie reveals her dark past beginning with her grooming by her current husband. Both Josie and Alix are great characters and we really delved into their lives. This book was fast paced and compelling. I didn't want to put it down. I alternated between kindle and audio for this and the audio book really does have the wow factor.

profile.name: Amazon Customer

title: Spiciest book yet!
body: “Your damn mouth, is the most obscenely lovely thing I've ever had the burden of seeing."  No one is writing a man as down bad as Eli Kilgore!! Oh and he also used to play hockey!! Ali’s spiciest book yet, definitely spice first and romance much later. So much angst.  Rue and Eli meet to have a casual night on a dating app. Their night gets interrupted by her crazy brother, meaning nothing happens and he drives her home. They think they’ll never see each other again. Except she runs into him the next day and his company is trying to take over the company she works for.  She’s adamant that nothing will happen between them and he’s more than happy to chase after her.  Rue she is socially awkward, often feels out of place and that she doesn’t fit in. She’s emotionally unavailable because of childhood trauma she’s still healing from. Eli is so patient with her and is willing to take anything she will give him (queue lots of spice). There is nothing I love more than a fictional man being completely smitten and that’s exactly what Eli was. His inner monologues were hilarious.  I absolutely adored Rue and was rooting for her the whole time, she was such a relatable character.  It was a little slow to begin with, but I enjoyed it a lot more than I expected. This book had spice, sweetness, hilarious moments, but also sad and devastating moments that had me tearing up. I absolutely loved all of the side characters. Low-key want a Maya and Hark book!  Tropes:  💗 Reverse grumpy sunshine 💗 Forbidden romance 💗 STEM setting 💗 Dual POV 💗 Enemies with benefits 💗 Angsty  Thank you to NetGalley and the publisher for the arc!
body_html:
“Your damn mouth, is the most obscenely lovely thing I've ever had the burden of seeing."

No one is writing a man as down bad as Eli Kilgore!! Oh and he also used to play hockey!! Ali’s spiciest book yet, definitely spice first and romance much later. So much angst.

Rue and Eli meet to have a casual night on a dating app. Their night gets interrupted by her crazy brother, meaning nothing happens and he drives her home. They think they’ll never see each other again. Except she runs into him the next day and his company is trying to take over the company she works for.

She’s adamant that nothing will happen between them and he’s more than happy to chase after her.

Rue she is socially awkward, often feels out of place and that she doesn’t fit in. She’s emotionally unavailable because of childhood trauma she’s still healing from. Eli is so patient with her and is willing to take anything she will give him (queue lots of spice). There is nothing I love more than a fictional man being completely smitten and that’s exactly what Eli was. His inner monologues were hilarious.

I absolutely adored Rue and was rooting for her the whole time, she was such a relatable character.

It was a little slow to begin with, but I enjoyed it a lot more than I expected. This book had spice, sweetness, hilarious moments, but also sad and devastating moments that had me tearing up. I absolutely loved all of the side characters. Low-key want a Maya and Hark book!

Tropes:

💗 Reverse grumpy sunshine
💗 Forbidden romance
💗 STEM setting
💗 Dual POV
💗 Enemies with benefits
💗 Angsty

Thank you to NetGalley and the publisher for the arc!
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 11 June 2024
profile.name: Grace

title: Ali Hazelwood's best book yet...
body: Thank you to Little Brown Book Group and NetGalley for an advanced copy.  I absolutely loved Not in Love. I read it in a single day. It's definitely more erotic and mature than Hazelwood's previous work. There isn't an adorable meet-cute or satisfyingly slow burn. For example, the book opens with our two main characters, Rue and Eli, meeting up for no-strings-attached sex after communicating and sharing their kinks via a dating app.  The sexual chemistry is undeniable and very much at the forefront of their relationship/arrangement. The romance element, along with any vulnerability or true intimacy, slowly develops throughout as their secret affair unravels and becomes more and more complicated.  I think Rue is possibly my favourite FMC that Hazelwood has ever written. She's socially awkward, possibly neurodivergent, intelligent, brutally honest, and fiercely loyal. Both characters have a lot of past truma that effects their ability to commit to one another and I found that Rue's difficulties around food and her inability to invest in relationships was really thoughtfully written and handled beautifully. There's a lot to unpack with Rue, and I appreciated the depth Hazelwood went into in terms of her past and what motivates her professionally.  On a side note, I personally appreciated that Rue wasn't the petite and small breasted heroine I've come to expect from romance books. Her body is described as soft, curvy with a rounded stomach and hips with little imperfections that Eli counts enthusiastically and worships. I loved how this book is both body and sex positive throughout. This is my favourite romance book of the year so far.
body_html:
Thank you to Little Brown Book Group and NetGalley for an advanced copy.

I absolutely loved Not in Love. I read it in a single day. It's definitely more erotic and mature than Hazelwood's previous work. There isn't an adorable meet-cute or satisfyingly slow burn. For example, the book opens with our two main characters, Rue and Eli, meeting up for no-strings-attached sex after communicating and sharing their kinks via a dating app.

The sexual chemistry is undeniable and very much at the forefront of their relationship/arrangement. The romance element, along with any vulnerability or true intimacy, slowly develops throughout as their secret affair unravels and becomes more and more complicated.

I think Rue is possibly my favourite FMC that Hazelwood has ever written. She's socially awkward, possibly neurodivergent, intelligent, brutally honest, and fiercely loyal. Both characters have a lot of past truma that effects their ability to commit to one another and I found that Rue's difficulties around food and her inability to invest in relationships was really thoughtfully written and handled beautifully. There's a lot to unpack with Rue, and I appreciated the depth Hazelwood went into in terms of her past and what motivates her professionally.

On a side note, I personally appreciated that Rue wasn't the petite and small breasted heroine I've come to expect from romance books. Her body is described as soft, curvy with a rounded stomach and hips with little imperfections that Eli counts enthusiastically and worships. I loved how this book is both body and sex positive throughout. This is my favourite romance book of the year so far.

profile.name: Miss Roxanne Feguson

title: Another great read from the spicy STEM queen!
body: TW for this book: Food insecurity, ED, parent loss, child neglect  At this stage I'm a devoted Hazelwood stan, she's as much part of my spicy shelf as Macfarlane. Absolutely adored her previous STEM books and this one definitely followed suit.  In "Not in Love" it feels like Hazelwood's trying to tackle trickier characters with more complex back stories, while still trying to weave their narrative into a romp across STEM politics and (in the case of this book..) copious sex scenes!  That's right - I reckon this is the spiciest yet! Whicccch... might not be the best thing? As a spice fan, I never thought I'd say that. However, it did feel like there was *a lot* of sex in this one, especially in comparison to "Check and Mate". Lots of it did feel rather indulgent and personally I'd have preferred a couple of scenes less (who even am I?).  That said, it was (as usual with Hazelwood's books) very enjoyable and readable, and I devoured it in a few sittings. The duel POV was a highlight throughout, maybe in the next one we can have duel POV and TWO couples? Now who's being indulgent..!

date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 11 June 2024
profile.name: Kim Lawler

title: Hazelwood levels up with a complex, witty and nuanced enemies-to-lovers STEM romance
body: This is such a complex and rewarding read, with plenty to enjoy as a fan of romance, enemies-to-lovers and all the good things. This is my first Ali Hazelwood book, incredibly, but I very much liked what I read: her writing is vibrant and witty and moreish, and not at all superficial. The story, these characters - they had a distinct identity and life, and I enjoyed spending time with them. As the heroine, Rue is a breath of fresh air - complicated, uncompromising, unabashedly herself; her vulnerability and the chemistry she shared with Eli meant that I was 100% rooting for her to come out of the whole thing with her version of a HEA. Eli was delightfully contradictory, and his self-assuredness and not-so-hidden sweetness were the perfect foil for Rue. I also loved the relationships the pair had with their respective friends, and the exploration of personal loyalty, and the difficult choice between personal interest and doing the right thing.  This is a nuanced, mature romance novel, with the right level of spice for the story - this may be more than readers of Hazelwood's previous work are used to (I'm not in a position to compare), hence the gentle 'heads up' at the beginning of the novel, but for what it's worth these scenes never feel gratuitous or anything other than grounded in character and serving the plot of the story.  Perfect for fans of Elle Kennedy and Tessa Bailey, or anyone wanting a sweet and spicy read with substance and a STEM flavour.
body_html:
This is such a complex and rewarding read, with plenty to enjoy as a fan of romance, enemies-to-lovers and all the good things. This is my first Ali Hazelwood book, incredibly, but I very much liked what I read: her writing is vibrant and witty and moreish, and not at all superficial. The story, these characters - they had a distinct identity and life, and I enjoyed spending time with them. As the heroine, Rue is a breath of fresh air - complicated, uncompromising, unabashedly herself; her vulnerability and the chemistry she shared with Eli meant that I was 100% rooting for her to come out of the whole thing with her version of a HEA. Eli was delightfully contradictory, and his self-assuredness and not-so-hidden sweetness were the perfect foil for Rue. I also loved the relationships the pair had with their respective friends, and the exploration of personal loyalty, and the difficult choice between personal interest and doing the right thing.

This is a nuanced, mature romance novel, with the right level of spice for the story - this may be more than readers of Hazelwood's previous work are used to (I'm not in a position to compare), hence the gentle 'heads up' at the beginning of the novel, but for what it's worth these scenes never feel gratuitous or anything other than grounded in character and serving the plot of the story.

Perfect for fans of Elle Kennedy and Tessa Bailey, or anyone wanting a sweet and spicy read with substance and a STEM flavour.

profile.name: Jess

title: One of my favourites with bonus air fryer tips and tricks!
body: Summary: I really love this air fryer cookbook, well explained guides and LOADS of handy tips and tricks.  The cookbook style is really inviting, has well explained recipes and is perfectly suited for any air fryer!  What is a nice bonus is that it includes a lot useful tips on air frying techniques and maintenance, ensuring optimal results and longevity of your appliance, which I thought was a really nice addition.  For example, it recommends you absolutely avoid using sprays like fry light on your air fryer. I googled it and it was absolutely correct. I'm really glad this was included in the cookbook because it has potentially saved our air fryer from damage in the future!
body_html:
Summary: I really love this air fryer cookbook, well explained guides and LOADS of handy tips and tricks.

The cookbook style is really inviting, has well explained recipes and is perfectly suited for any air fryer!

What is a nice bonus is that it includes a lot useful tips on air frying techniques and maintenance, ensuring optimal results and longevity of your appliance, which I thought was a really nice addition.

For example, it recommends you absolutely avoid using sprays like fry light on your air fryer. I googled it and it was absolutely correct. I'm really glad this was included in the cookbook because it has potentially saved our air fryer from damage in the future!

profile.name: Steve

title: Disappointing
body: I have recently been converted to using an air fryer, and I'm always looking for an excuse to buy a cookery book, so, having read the reviews, I plumped for this. I suppose I should have been alerted to the content by the cover, as it's not what I call a grownup cookbook. It's very much geared towards kids' meals and, basically, recreating fast food at home. The recipes are very simplistic, and there's an awful lot of 'filler'. Even the names of the recipes jarred with me; I don't care whose uncle or which grandad gave you the recipe, and I find that sort of thing very self indulgent and egotistical. What shocked me most, I think, was the paucity of fish recipes. One salmon dish? Really? Another extremely irritating aspect is the index. You have to know what the dish is called (probably the name of a relative) but it doesn't list main ingredients. It's not what I call a cook's cookbook. All in all, I can't see this getting much use in this house, if any.

profile.name: L. driver

title: Gave me what I needed - I think
body: I had bought an air fryer and, apart from making chips, I didn't know what else to do or how to go about it properly; that's why I bought this book. I'm now progressing to other things, having done a (small) roast chicken (v nice) and about to try a roast loin of pork.  Now, there's not a LOAD in this book - after all, most recipes seem to involve spraying on a bit of olive oil, bunging whatever it is into the fryer, and doing it at between 180 and 200C for a variable amount of time. BUT I got useful hints from this book - which is very clearly written, well illustrated, etc - and it has given me the increased confidence to try the fryer in many different ways.  If you've just bought an air fryer and you need tips and encouragement and some ideas, then this is just the book for you.

If you've just bought an air fryer and you need tips and encouragement and some ideas, then this is just the book for you.

profile.name: Mr. Patrick N. G. McCabe

title: Good book for beginners and others.
body: This book, unlike many others on this subject, starts with the basics, e.g. a full English breakfast. Most books seem to think that "If you have an Airfryer, then you know how to convert frozen food oven/microwave times and temperatures into Airfare times and temperatures - this book at least gives you some advice on how to convert the information. It also tells you how to do simple meals right through to quite complex ones. Many people purchase ready meals from the major stores, so I would have liked some examples of air frying some of these instead of having to work out the time and temperatures. Even so, this is the best book I have found to date and, as a widower , it has helped me solve what to have at meal times. A good book.

title: Good for first timers
body: It is very good for first timers and one can follow the recipes easily. However timings will depend on what type of Air Fryer you have and whetehr you have one draw or two. Make certain you have a meat thermometer to check the meat is cooked before you serve it. Can you use it all the time instead of an oven? Depends on your cooking skill and expertise. Some things are still best done in the oven or on the stove. But if you can use an Air Fryer then it is generally quicker.

profile.name: Lil

title: Challenging but fun
body: I have always enjoyed activity books like these, but the description of this one caught my eye: "How many times have you bought yourself a puzzle book or a trivia game and found it far too easy?" Challenge accepted!  For less than the price of a pint, this book will definitely get your brain working. It started off relatively easily, but by the time I got past a really challenging sudoku and a nearly impossible acrostic puzzle, I had to admit that it was quite tricky.  It has a good mix of puzzles that will keep you busy, and I personally find doing activity books like these more rewarding than streaming something on phone. Great for the train or doing together as a family (I did have to call in some assistance for some of the trivia games).
body_html:

title: Totally misrepresented
body: Can’t think what the other reviews are seeing. This is sold as an especially challenging puzzle book allegedly aimed at “intelligent men” demanding extra challenges.  That being said I’m really not sure how simple maze puzzles like we did in school, or childish quizzes asking what language certain words derive from is supposed to be taxing. Add to that a bunch of simple word searches, and the usual mid range sodoku adds up to a bog standard easy puzzle book dressed up in the Emperor’s clothes.  Now I have to return it!
body_html:

profile.name: Jessie Leigh

title: Sceptical at first but not now.
body: I’ve tried every diet. My most successful was a similar one to this where I stopped eating certain food groups . I decided to try this after all the hype and having just come back from an all inclusive holiday…enough said about weight gain there. This promises a fast weight loss if you stick to 800 cals a day, also good to factor in some fasting, all explained in the books. I looked through the books and chose some breakfasts and meals for a week, did a shopping list and did a delivery shop to avoid temptation. It cost around the same as my weekly shop, the second week cheaper as I didn’t need a lot of the store cupboard items like herbs. I’ve varied the meals and they are easy to cook and very tasty. I’m quite impressed, I’ve eaten things I’ve never had before. Easy and quick, I can really recommend lovely recipies. Weigh in day tomorrow, I do believe I will show a weight loss of around10lbs in my first week as I had a sneaky jump on the scales. A good start but I don’t expect it every week !! It would be nice though .

profile.name: Kewtieone

title: Tasty, Easy, Variety, Lose Weight, Healthy
body: I absolutely love this book, i have it out in the kitchen and i’m browsing it all the time. It’s become my ‘bible’. I am in no way a cook, i’m a Mom with grown up kids that now has time to cook for myself without accommodating a houseful. (My grown up kids, girlfriends etc and gym enthusiast husband, all like to do their own food) Usually i can’t be bothered with recipes as too many ingredients puts me off. Apart from some store cupboard items that i needed to get going, all the other items are fresh ingredients and readily available. You will need digital scales, proper measuring spoons to make sure the quantities are right. Most recipes are for two, just halve the ingredients or some meals can be frozen for another day. I’m not a big fan of red meat so the fish, chicken, food on the move and salads are perfect for me. I cook the casserole’s and roasts at the weekend for everyone. Absolutely brilliant book. After one week i’ve had comments on how well i look and shifted 5 lbs week one. I’m not particularly overweight but like everyone during lockdown gained a little weight, which i don’t like. I’ve tried all sorts of low carb diets and i’m quite controlled in the main, but usually get bored as i can’t think of things to eat. This book has solved the problem, the recipes are easy, quick, and taste fabulous. I honestly don’t feel like i’m missing out. There’s even a ‘speedy pizza’ which i feel like i’m having a real treat. Get the book and follow it to the letter. Can’t recommend it enough. 10 out of 10

profile.name: Ann Fouracre

title: Excellent Recipes, excellent diet
body: I've never ever been able to stick at a diet due to my appalling discipline and a lack of ideas on what I could eat (I'm an extremely fussy eater with a terrifyingly extreme sweet tooth).  However, the meals in this book are exceptional and as a result I managed to stick at this one for a good 4 or 5 weeks, and then broadly stick to it in the 5:2 regime for another 7. The end result was that I lost 21.7kg / 48lbs / 3st 6lbs (depending on your weight format preference) in the 83 days between getting the book and writing this review.  So, it worked for me. Possibly saved my life, in fact. It may not work for you and I know that some people should absolutely not try this diet for health reasons as it is a little "shock and awe" in terms of how hard it is at times. But for those that are wavering over whether to give it a go, here's a bit of advice  - I found that once you get over the shocking hump (low energy, hunger etc) after a couple of weeks it's fairly easy thereafter, so do stick at it - It also helps if you properly count calories via a smart watch or app as it gives you objectives to hit - Get most of the cupboard essentials that it recommends in the back of the book. Absolutely invaluable. - Plan and shop for your full week of meals in advance. Know what you're having each day and have the ingredients in the house already. That a) gives you something to look forward to and b) removes the risk of panic-buying a microwave meal or takeaway or something else unhealthy if you feel you're in a rush or can't be bothered to cook. - The meals can take a little while to prep so make sure you give yourself the time to do it, but I really enjoyed learning new recipes and techniques, so I included this as part of the positive experience. - Fill yourself up on green veg with every meal. The portion sizes are obviously small but you really can load up with the "free" extras. It's healthy and it stops you being hungry - I've found that uncooked spinach (which I've never really liked before now) goes with most of the meals, for example.  As I said above, this was all made possible due to the quality of the recipes in this book - the tikka masala and all of the fish dishes in particular are genuinely and rather surprisingly outstanding - as they gave me something to look forward to rather than some pathetic, boring salad that would have got very dull after a day or two and helped me maintain the discipline that you have to have to get through the first few weeks (I didn't repeat a single recipe from the book in those first 21 days).  So, I hope other people have as much joy as I did with this book. It was a genuine, transformative, life changing experience. Good luck.
body_html:
I've never ever been able to stick at a diet due to my appalling discipline and a lack of ideas on what I could eat (I'm an extremely fussy eater with a terrifyingly extreme sweet tooth).

However, the meals in this book are exceptional and as a result I managed to stick at this one for a good 4 or 5 weeks, and then broadly stick to it in the 5:2 regime for another 7. The end result was that I lost 21.7kg / 48lbs / 3st 6lbs (depending on your weight format preference) in the 83 days between getting the book and writing this review.

So, it worked for me. Possibly saved my life, in fact. It may not work for you and I know that some people should absolutely not try this diet for health reasons as it is a little "shock and awe" in terms of how hard it is at times. But for those that are wavering over whether to give it a go, here's a bit of advice

- I found that once you get over the shocking hump (low energy, hunger etc) after a couple of weeks it's fairly easy thereafter, so do stick at it
- It also helps if you properly count calories via a smart watch or app as it gives you objectives to hit
- Get most of the cupboard essentials that it recommends in the back of the book. Absolutely invaluable.
- Plan and shop for your full week of meals in advance. Know what you're having each day and have the ingredients in the house already. That a) gives you something to look forward to and b) removes the risk of panic-buying a microwave meal or takeaway or something else unhealthy if you feel you're in a rush or can't be bothered to cook.
- The meals can take a little while to prep so make sure you give yourself the time to do it, but I really enjoyed learning new recipes and techniques, so I included this as part of the positive experience.
- Fill yourself up on green veg with every meal. The portion sizes are obviously small but you really can load up with the "free" extras. It's healthy and it stops you being hungry - I've found that uncooked spinach (which I've never really liked before now) goes with most of the meals, for example.

As I said above, this was all made possible due to the quality of the recipes in this book - the tikka masala and all of the fish dishes in particular are genuinely and rather surprisingly outstanding - as they gave me something to look forward to rather than some pathetic, boring salad that would have got very dull after a day or two and helped me maintain the discipline that you have to have to get through the first few weeks (I didn't repeat a single recipe from the book in those first 21 days).

So, I hope other people have as much joy as I did with this book. It was a genuine, transformative, life changing experience. Good luck.

profile.name: Matt D

title: Wow it works
body: Bought this book last October nearly a year ago and looked through it and to be honest I thought I don’t think I can be bothered to mess about with this so it got shelved until two weeks ago when I found myself having an irritable pain feeling in my gut so I thought I could do with loosing some weight and eating a lot healthier than I was so got the book of the shelve and after the first week to my surprise both myself and my husband agreed the meals were delicious and surprisingly filling and by the end of the week I was actually enjoying prepping and cooking all the meals it’s so easy to follow the step by step guide to adding ingredients and cooking times and have just finished two weeks on this great healthy eating plan and my stomach feels 100% better and I have lost 7 lb already so I wished I hadn’t shelved it . It does take some preparation for some of the meals but once you get in to the swing of it it’s great soooooo pleased with the results it has a two week plan at the back of the book which is fantastic and you can tweak it if you don’t like the look of something but some things I didn’t think I’d like were actually really really yummy so should I recommend this book DEFINITELY it’s a big thumbs up from me just wished I’d started it sooner and once your body adjusts to it you feel pretty good

profile.name: Timi

title: Definite Recommendation!
body: I wanted to wait and see if this would help me to lose weight as I am a bit rubbish when it comes to willpower and I am a little fussy with what I can eat. I started on 6th June but it took a couple of weeks for me to properly start as I had to use up the food in the house that I already had. It's now 24th July and I have lost 10lbs which, for me, is pretty impressive. I also like a lot of the recipes as they are quick to make so lunches are easier to prepare when I have an hour to make it and eat it with time left to relax. The most important thing is that this teaches you where the calories come from and I feel like it's changed my lifestyle forever. I was worried the portions would leave me really hungry between meals but it's actually fine and if I need a bridge I just have a cup of coffee or herbal tea.  I seriously recommend this book, I've been telling all of my friends about it. It also saves you a small fortune on your grocery shop! For the rare times I don't feel like cooking I just have a slimfast shake so it's still on the diet theme. Eat your dinner early-ish and get that ketosis in motion overnight while you sleep. If I feel peckish after dinner I just chew some gum, it works a treat.  If you're serious about losing weight and often struggle please do try this book. I was, I did and now I feel like a different person.

I also like a lot of the recipes as they are quick to make so lunches are easier to prepare when I have an hour to make it and eat it with time left to relax. The most important thing is that this teaches you where the calories come from and I feel like it's changed my lifestyle forever. I was worried the portions would leave me really hungry between meals but it's actually fine and if I need a bridge I just have a cup of coffee or herbal tea.

I seriously recommend this book, I've been telling all of my friends about it. It also saves you a small fortune on your grocery shop! For the rare times I don't feel like cooking I just have a slimfast shake so it's still on the diet theme. Eat your dinner early-ish and get that ketosis in motion overnight while you sleep. If I feel peckish after dinner I just chew some gum, it works a treat.

If you're serious about losing weight and often struggle please do try this book. I was, I did and now I feel like a different person.

profile.name: Lesley

title: HMMM...
body: This is my second time round (using the 3 meals a day with meat option) and since I forgot to submit my first review two years ago I found it lurking here...  So, first review: Bought with the Fast800 book. Read that then followed these recipes exactly, reached my target weight in 14 days (ie lost 10.5 lbs.) The recipes work well for that and calorie measurements for each one really useful. My 'But...' is because a) Not made clear that quantities often not for one person, so had to re-measure a lot b) Recipes look different but are often samey c) Best to buy the more exotic ingredients before you begin (they do advise this, but I missed that) as when you're into your initial 14 days you will be in no mood to hunt down hot paprika, smoked peppers etc etc.  Second review: I'm using it to lose weight post-Xmas, as it works a treat. The recipes do not leave you feeling hungry except on the third day. However... it is (in my view) essential to buy ALL the ingredients for EVERY reciped you'll be using before starting, except the fresh one's like broccoli. If you're working, whether at home or not, it's best to cook in advance and freeze, so each day the preparation is virtually nil. It's true the portion are for 2 or 4 sometimes and I'm just one. So... I cook them as listed and then freeze the resulting extra portions. Then I use these as substitutes as I go along, saving time and money. I also substitute ingredients (eg yoghurt fior creme fraiche) because otherwise I end up with something I won't use soon again. The two stars is because of the above and also too many of the recipes (as other reviews have noted) are either tasteless (the stews); need experience (anything with beans, do NOT buy standard cheap tins, go for Biona type in-water-only beans without the firming agent - much nicer); take too long to prepare; or are disgusting (cold breakfast porridge, fry up including broccili, yuk yuk). So 5 stars for a quick 14 day 3 meals a day weight loss method and education course in healthy eating but a miserable 2* for practicality, lask of clarity and taste.
body_html:
This is my second time round (using the 3 meals a day with meat option) and since I forgot to submit my first review two years ago I found it lurking here...

So, first review:
Bought with the Fast800 book. Read that then followed these recipes exactly, reached my target weight in 14 days (ie lost 10.5 lbs.) The recipes work well for that and calorie measurements for each one really useful. My 'But...' is because a) Not made clear that quantities often not for one person, so had to re-measure a lot b) Recipes look different but are often samey c) Best to buy the more exotic ingredients before you begin (they do advise this, but I missed that) as when you're into your initial 14 days you will be in no mood to hunt down hot paprika, smoked peppers etc etc.

Second review: I'm using it to lose weight post-Xmas, as it works a treat. The recipes do not leave you feeling hungry except on the third day. However... it is (in my view) essential to buy ALL the ingredients for EVERY reciped you'll be using before starting, except the fresh one's like broccoli. If you're working, whether at home or not, it's best to cook in advance and freeze, so each day the preparation is virtually nil. It's true the portion are for 2 or 4 sometimes and I'm just one. So... I cook them as listed and then freeze the resulting extra portions. Then I use these as substitutes as I go along, saving time and money. I also substitute ingredients (eg yoghurt fior creme fraiche) because otherwise I end up with something I won't use soon again. The two stars is because of the above and also too many of the recipes (as other reviews have noted) are either tasteless (the stews); need experience (anything with beans, do NOT buy standard cheap tins, go for Biona type in-water-only beans without the firming agent - much nicer); take too long to prepare; or are disgusting (cold breakfast porridge, fry up including broccili, yuk yuk). So 5 stars for a quick 14 day 3 meals a day weight loss method and education course in healthy eating but a miserable 2* for practicality, lask of clarity and taste.

title: Great recipes
body: For someone who hates salad but needs to loose a bit of menopause weight and reduce high blood pressure I thought I needed a hand as I have never been on a diet. Great tasty recipes which I have to admit I wasn’t expecting. Works for the whole family as just add potatoes rice or pasta to oh and sons meals. Even great ideas for lunches to take to work. Yes I’m hungry but going from my usual diet to below 800 was never going to be easy. I don’t eat much sugar in my diet and rarely drink alcohol so not noticed the loss of this. Lost 6kg in first week so feeling pretty good. Highly recommend the recipes even if I don’t lose weight.

profile.name: Amazon Customer

title: Straightforward recipes with 'normal' ingredients
body: I've only tried a few recipes so far (hence the 4 star rating) but I have been impressed. The recipes don't have too many outlandish ingredients (salad, chicken, bacon, avocado, tinned sweetcorn, eggs, mushrooms etc) so I haven't mortgaged my house to buy things I might not like.  Although some portions are very small (speaking as someone who loves to eat lots of food) but you can always add a huge salad to bulk it out.  Recipes are quick to make (okay I did a chicken, bacon and avocado salad last night and a salmon and chive omelette for brunch today) with minimal washing up, unlike some recipe books which require you to use about six bowls and three pans!  I've definitely found drinking 2 litres of water a day helps to stave off the hunger pangs and eating earlier in the evening has left me feeling less bloated at night. Very early days yet but there is a Prawn Nasi Goreng and a Beef Rendang recipe I've got my eye on for the weekend.

profile.name: BananaTricky

title: Easy to follow recipes, good variety
body: I got this one and the Fast 800 Easy recipes book, I have tried intermittent fasting in the past, and need to lose weight after a bought of medication. I have tried several other diets over the last year and none have helped me. I have been using these books for a couple of weeks and lost 8lbs. The recipes are easy to follow and there Andre some for when you have time to cook and some for when you need to make it quick. The premise is easy to follow. I read the intermittent fasting book when the first one came out so I didn’t get the new fast 800 one I just jumped to the recipe books. There is an outline of how it works in the recipe books, so you aren’t in the dark about what to do and how it works. I really like the variety and flexibility. And if you have particular requirements (I have problems with dairy) it does have suggestsions. I don’t eat a lot of meat and there are plenty of meat free recipes. It’s not great for vegans, it does say this in the book though. There are meat free sections in both books though and some of those recipes would be suitable for vegan diets.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 7 May 2021
profile.name: Delpha

title: Makes losing weight easy
body: I had lost a stone in less than four weeks on MM's Fast 800 diet, so I was keen to try more recipes from the more extensive range in this book. I am vegetarian, so many aren't suitable for me, though they can be tweaked by using low-carb meat substitutes.  I like this diet as the food and ingredients are not too outlandish or expensive, and meals can be batch-cooked (most mains are for four people) and frozen, which takes a lot of the nuisance out of preparing a meal for one person. It is also good to do a diet which has no restrictions on eating nuts, oil or full-fat milk!  Some of the recipes seem to have a rather high calorie count for someone on an 800-a-day regime so I guess you are meant to do a bit of recalibrating with your other meals.  The science of the Mosley/Bailey plan is very clear and it is actually quite a simple diet which consists of low-carb, low-sugar wholefoods. I feel fantastic on it and this book is very helpful.

profile.name: Bob

title: Pre-diabetic/diabetic?  Approach with caution.
body: Positives - a selection of recipes to introduce a change up from the usual day in day out meals we prepare with some good suggestions for alternatives to bread such as lettuce leaves and asparagus.  If you want to prevent or reverse Type 2 diabetes, 'the 8 week blood sugar diet recipe book' in my opinion is the one to go for and the more important recipes are in both books (with some changes eg pear instead of apple). This Fast 800 recipe book uses too much fruit (including bananas and mango with ingredients which have too high sugar content for me - the breakfast section (not the brunch elements) are fruit or syrup ingredients based in the main. Recipes also include shakes (really!), maple syrup, honey, breads and pasta which are sugar and carb ingredients. The main meals are in the main pretty diabetic friendly and the treats sections speaks for itself.  Interestingly the nutritional content breakdown doesn't give you the sugar content at all and perhaps this should be traffic lighted as you see on food packaging. I found the book and recipes a little disappointing and misleading. Hence a 3 star - good elements and less good elements in my opinion .....  To remain positive though if you know your stuff in relation to diabetes - you know what you can and can't eat to keep good blood sugar control and the book does have some good recipes that will do what it says on the packet.  If you are new to this style of eating and are pre-diabetic or diabetic - I would definitely go for the 8-week blood sugar diet recipe book instead.

profile.name: JH

title: So motivating to lose weight fast and feel so darn healthy
body: This book is transforming my life! Was looking for inspiration to get myself back on to a decent diet. I saw Michael Moseley’s ‘lose a stone in 3 weeks’ on TV, felt inspired so I went for it. I lost 6lb in the first three days (admittedly the final 3lbs I had put on were after a Chinese takeaway and a particularly piggy barbecue!) Three weeks later and I had lost 1 stone 1lb - and I had been on holiday for four days trying hard to stick to Michael and Clare’s advice but inevitably falling off the wagon a bit. Going on five weeks since I started, I’ve lost another five pounds (another meal out outside my TLE hours and probably too many carbs are to blame for a bit of a stall last week). So motivating to lose weight quickly and I already have so much more energy. Sparkling water is my new ‘glass of wine’! And Clare is a genius cook - my whole family love the recipes - I just give them extra rice, air-fried chips etc to make it more substantial for the teenagers. I can’t wait for three weeks time when I hope to have achieved my target weight and get back into to the ‘normal’ range. Thoroughly recommend.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 10 September 2020
profile.name: YorkshireSarah

title: ITS A PRICKLY PROBLEM ...
body: Book one of this much lauded YA Fantasy series is, to put it mildly, an extraordinary reading experience. It must be said, however, that ACOTAR starts off relatively slowly. The reader is introduced to the book’s principal character - Feyre - who is a huntress who kills for her own survival and that of her family. Her father is a broken man. Crippled, both physically, financially, and metaphorically. Her mother died when she was younger. He sisters are two unloving, and facetious twats. Her brothers are something our heroine (and the story) were not blessed with.  Fate brings Fayre and a beautiful, fully grown wolf together in the sunlight dappled reaches of the nearby Forest. Destiny steps forth to convince Fayre to kill the wolf. She does so, and her life is never the same again. For the wolf she killed was anything but. Fayre is captured for the kill and punishment is either instant death, or lifelong banishment into the enemy’s kingdom. She chooses the latter to save her family, and this is where the book’s true nature takes form and steals the reader’s heart.  For this is where we meet Tamlin, and Lucien. The sworn and hated enemies who aren’t. It is easy to detest them both, but read on, and your feelings toward them will soften. Moments of breathtaking excitement and beauty follow. Chapter after chapter, after chapter, feature cliffhangers and profound plot twists, that quite literally, take your breath away, and make it impossible for the reader to put the book down. A chain of truly stupendous OMG moments leave the reader in tatters when they realise they must put the book down eventually to rejoin society. Chapter thirteen is where the book finds it’s street cred from a fantasy perspective. And chapter eighteen is a good way for the reader to determine if they are still human, and if they still have a heart than can be broken.  This book is structured, and written beautifully. Pacing is perfect, too. A harsh critic would give it four stars and say, 'its only book one of a trilogy, and you need to leave room for improvement...’ Well, I ain’t no harsh critic. This book is worth full marks, and if the rest are even better, then no doubt the world will get to hear of it. ACOTAR is the first Sarah J Maas book that i have picked up and it is truly gorgeous in just about every way imaginable. My good fortune lies in the fact that book two is less than three months away. That gives me time to read this one again (and again, and again) in readiness, or go and purchase the other titles in her world wide best selling catalog.  Either way, I can’t lose. It’s a prickly problem that I am delighted to find myself in a quandary over.  Yo to that.
body_html:
Book one of this much lauded YA Fantasy series is, to put it mildly, an extraordinary reading experience. It must be said, however, that ACOTAR starts off relatively slowly. The reader is introduced to the book’s principal character - Feyre - who is a huntress who kills for her own survival and that of her family. Her father is a broken man. Crippled, both physically, financially, and metaphorically. Her mother died when she was younger. He sisters are two unloving, and facetious twats. Her brothers are something our heroine (and the story) were not blessed with.

Fate brings Fayre and a beautiful, fully grown wolf together in the sunlight dappled reaches of the nearby Forest. Destiny steps forth to convince Fayre to kill the wolf. She does so, and her life is never the same again. For the wolf she killed was anything but. Fayre is captured for the kill and punishment is either instant death, or lifelong banishment into the enemy’s kingdom. She chooses the latter to save her family, and this is where the book’s true nature takes form and steals the reader’s heart.

For this is where we meet Tamlin, and Lucien. The sworn and hated enemies who aren’t. It is easy to detest them both, but read on, and your feelings toward them will soften. Moments of breathtaking excitement and beauty follow. Chapter after chapter, after chapter, feature cliffhangers and profound plot twists, that quite literally, take your breath away, and make it impossible for the reader to put the book down. A chain of truly stupendous OMG moments leave the reader in tatters when they realise they must put the book down eventually to rejoin society. Chapter thirteen is where the book finds it’s street cred from a fantasy perspective. And chapter eighteen is a good way for the reader to determine if they are still human, and if they still have a heart than can be broken.

This book is structured, and written beautifully. Pacing is perfect, too. A harsh critic would give it four stars and say, 'its only book one of a trilogy, and you need to leave room for improvement...’ Well, I ain’t no harsh critic. This book is worth full marks, and if the rest are even better, then no doubt the world will get to hear of it. ACOTAR is the first Sarah J Maas book that i have picked up and it is truly gorgeous in just about every way imaginable. My good fortune lies in the fact that book two is less than three months away. That gives me time to read this one again (and again, and again) in readiness, or go and purchase the other titles in her world wide best selling catalog.

Either way, I can’t lose. It’s a prickly problem that I am delighted to find myself in a quandary over.

Yo to that.
date.raw: Reviewed in Australia on 13 February 2016
profile.name: Greggorio!

title: Definitely getting the rest of the series
body: Definitely an enjoyable read that I'll be recommending to my other book loving friends.  The first half of the book I'd rate 3/5, it's a little bit slow but not in a boring way. We learn about Feyre and what a strong female lead she is, the sacrifices she has to make for her family and also about the layout of the faerie court. Great world and character building, it makes the reader feel like this is mostly a love story about overcoming difficultiws together. However, once the plot twist hits it seems more of an action/adventure and really picks up the pace.  All of the characters are likeable I'd say minus Feyre's family who really invoke frustration and anger from the reader. The main love interest isn't really that interesting in my opinion but it could be because he was only one of the many aspects of the book that drove feyre's motivation. And he may build a lot more depth in character in the next books in the series.  I still kept thinking about the book even the next day after I'd finished it which is always a positive sign for me. I'll definitely be reading the rest of the series in the near future.  Though I feel like the first book itself tied up many loose ends where if someone wanted to they could definitely just stop after the first book.
