title: A must for every young athlete!
body: I am a dance instructor and youth empowerment coach. I read this book before one of our intensives this summer and spoke with my competitive dancers about some of the techniques and why they are necessary. They were so engaged and interested because it all made SENSE. This was my biggest take away from this book…it is written to engage a young mind.  I am in to read the parent’s guide and finally Mental Toughness volume 2.  I will be highly recommending these books to my athletes and parents!

title: Great Book!!!

This book provoked deeper conversations and gave my children and I action steps on how to pursue excellence. This is a book that we'll be re-reading multiple times. I'm thankful to Troy and his son Moses Horne for putting together such a great book! As a former competitive track and field athlete, I wish I would've had this book when I was younger, but I'm glad that I can now use this book to help my own children and the ones that I coach.

title: Inspire any teen to greatness with this powerful and fun read!
body: I'm the least athletic person I know but I fell in love with the structure of this book--hearing from a kid and his dad. Honestly didn't even look too closely at author names when I ordered it. I'm using it to support my daughter who is on an intense performing arts trajectory and is 13. While reading, I kept thinking that this was the perfect book for a kid who is doing musical theatre over 20 hours a week and found the tips to be super helpful. When I was finished, I wanted to know who wrote this incredible book. And to my delight I saw the picture of Broadway star Troy Horne. Moses and Troy, you guys are A-M-A-Z-I-N-G! Any parent or teacher who wants to help a young person of excellence needs to read this book. Thank you, Moses and Troy!

profile.name: Ann

title: a little editting goes a long way!
body: The idea of the book is great. The execution, not so much. There's a lot of incomplete sentences, poorly written ones, crazy amount of redundancy and inacuracies. I like the idea, but this book could be simplified into half the lenght or even less than that and still deliver the desired message. I like that it encourages you to go to their website to watch videos and interviews. It's annoying that you have to enter your email to access this info. I paid for the book, why do I have to give you my email now? I just want to watch the videos you refer to in the book. I still give it 3 stars regardless of all the gramatical issues and my personal pet-peeves with the email, because the message is wholesome and it's a message that young athletes should listen to and apply in order to become resilient. I don't like that it implies that if you do this you will become a pro... But it does not hurt to think positively.

profile.name: Mel Schilthroat

title: Can’t put it down…. Buy it…
body: I had an interest in this book when I started watching all the negativity that surrounds these young athletes. Kids, yes kids who are going to school, working out, navigating life as a whole and busting their butts to be great at what they love to do. Only to see posts and articles and conversations in general from parents or coaches or people who really think their opinion matters knocking them down. It was honestly pissing me off. I wonder when did people stop routing for these kids to succeed. Isn’t that what it’s all about??? I wasn’t sure how to help then I found this book.. I’m hoping this helps the kids I get to share it with. Allow them to block out the noise and be great.

title: Great fun read
body: I have had this book sitting in my shelf since it was released but hadn’t picked it up yet, well I am so happy that Danny picked this as my next read. What a truly funny and endearing book this turned out to be, it had me laughing and smiling throughout.  I really enjoyed Miles and Daphne a lot, they met under very strange circumstances but they hit it off in no time. I loved all the different things they got up to together, they laughed a lot and just had fun being together, even if they were only friends.  I enjoyed Ashleigh and of course Julia, these ladies were so different but with them along with miles and Daphne they just had this really fun friend group.  I should add that the self growth throughout this storyline was brilliant and something I love in a book.  A great fun easy read that you will devour, I absolutely recommend you pick it up soon.

profile.name: Caz the bookworm /Caroline O'Sullivan

title: My favourite Emily Henry book so far!!
body: As an already exisiting fan girl of Emily Henry's, I can confidently say that Funny Story is my favourite book from her so far. Daphne & Mile’s story had me laughing, tearing up, and nodding along in recognition with her journeys and struggles the entire way. Never before have I resonated with a story on such a deep level. The main character's experiences mirrored my own in many ways, making it feel like I was reading about a close friend rather than a fictional character.  Emily Henry has once again captured my heart with her captivating storytelling and relatable characters. I highly recommend this book to anyone looking for a good laugh, a beautiful romance and a touching story of self-discovery!!
body_html:

profile.name: Bec Whitford

title: Loved every second!!!
body: I did my best to try to savour this book. I absolutely loved every second of it and when I wasn’t reading it, I was thinking about it.  Daphne and Miles gah, I just loved how it all happened between them. The finally seeing each other and the slow build of tension to the friendship they build to more? It was just all so exquisite. I absolutely loved both of them together and separately. Both are a bit damaged with baggage, but the way that they both work through it was so great.  Then you have the other friendships, found family and what not, that were beautiful. The soul searching and figuring out life. So much was just so damn relatable. I teared up, I barked out laughs, I was caught unawares by this amazing book that stole my heart. Emily’s writing just keeps getting better and better.

date.raw: Reviewed in Australia on 24 April 2024
profile.name: Alison

title: My favourite EmHen leading man, Miles
body: Funny Story Emily Henry  I adored this book! It was lighthearted, happy go lucky and so bingeable. Set to the most perfect summer backdrop, it was fun and filled with fantastic banter and lovable characters. Emily Henry is an automatic buy author for me, she always delivers.  There’s something magical about an Emily Henry rom com. Always heartwarming and wisdom filled, full of wit and heart. It’s more than the surface level emotions but grants you true insights into the characters emotional states and in particular the upheaval and acceptance that occurs when your life is flipped on its head. Themes of heartbreak and learning to love again, loneliness and avoidance provide relatability that will touch and warm every heart.  Miles is my favourite Emily Henry leading man. He’s obviously hot, but charming and easygoing, selfless and adventurous. The man can do no wrong! In particular I adored the domesticity of Daphne and Miles time together. They were so sweet.  100% recommend you give Funny Story a try.
body_html:
Funny Story
Emily Henry

I adored this book! It was lighthearted, happy go lucky and so bingeable. Set to the most perfect summer backdrop, it was fun and filled with fantastic banter and lovable characters. Emily Henry is an automatic buy author for me, she always delivers.

There’s something magical about an Emily Henry rom com. Always heartwarming and wisdom filled, full of wit and heart. It’s more than the surface level emotions but grants you true insights into the characters emotional states and in particular the upheaval and acceptance that occurs when your life is flipped on its head. Themes of heartbreak and learning to love again, loneliness and avoidance provide relatability that will touch and warm every heart.

Miles is my favourite Emily Henry leading man. He’s obviously hot, but charming and easygoing, selfless and adventurous. The man can do no wrong! In particular I adored the domesticity of Daphne and Miles time together. They were so sweet.

100% recommend you give Funny Story a try.
date.raw: Reviewed in Australia on 28 April 2024
profile.name: Nadine A

title: Best one yet!
body: I feel like I say this with every Emily Henry book, but this is my favourite one so far! Funny Story has the best humour, my favourite tropes and puts you through the emotional ringer.  The sense of humour in this book is EXCELLENT. It isn't full-fledged banter, but it's subtle jokes and the best kind of blunt humour.  Some of the tropes include: Forced proximity Room mates Opposites attract  Miles is my favourite of Emily Henry's MMCs so far, he's an absolute cinnamon roll of a character - He's genuine and compassionate, and reading how he worked through his family issues definitely made me teary.  Funny Story elicits all kind of emotions, it's a real roller-coaster of a journey. This book shows that even the worst of circumstances can bring about a positive change, even in the most unexpected manner.  I also liked the little countdown at the start of each chapter, and how the wording of this changed as Daphne's mind changed.
body_html:
I feel like I say this with every Emily Henry book, but this is my favourite one so far! Funny Story has the best humour, my favourite tropes and puts you through the emotional ringer.

The sense of humour in this book is EXCELLENT. It isn't full-fledged banter, but it's subtle jokes and the best kind of blunt humour.

Some of the tropes include:
Forced proximity
Room mates
Opposites attract

Miles is my favourite of Emily Henry's MMCs so far, he's an absolute cinnamon roll of a character - He's genuine and compassionate, and reading how he worked through his family issues definitely made me teary.

Funny Story elicits all kind of emotions, it's a real roller-coaster of a journey. This book shows that even the worst of circumstances can bring about a positive change, even in the most unexpected manner.

I also liked the little countdown at the start of each chapter, and how the wording of this changed as Daphne's mind changed.
date.raw: Reviewed in Australia on 25 April 2024
profile.name: Rachel

title: Emily Henry’s new best
body: Emily Henry is the Queen of the romance genre right now and this is her new best.  Daphne has just been left by her fiancé weeks before the wedding, and her only option for a roommate in a short notice is Miles, who girlfriend just left him for Daphnes fiancé. Between trying to cheer each other up from their breakups, and getting a little revenge … their forced proximity grows to a very unlikely friendship.  Just like every one of her other romance novels, the characters are fleshed out and real and the chemistry between them is to die for. I think what makes Emily Henry’s novels stand out is how she includes really emotional subplots and difficult real-life struggles for these. There is so much substance and depth in the story that the emotional moments hit harder.  But the reason why I think this is Emily Henry’s best work yet, is because (true to its name) it’s incredibly funny. I can’t name a book I have laughed at more. The banter between Miles and Daphne is snappy and funny. I think uniquely to her other romances, Miles and Daphne are an unlikely pair which only made their interactions more laugh out loud hilarious.  You will absolutely fall in love with these characters and this story, and if you haven’t been convinced on Emily Henry yet, this is the one to grab.

profile.name: Ethan Toll

title: A beautiful and tender romance
body: The day that Peter decided that he was actually in love with his childhood best friend, Petra and not his fiancé, Daphne, was the day that Daphne’s new life story began. Stranded in beautiful Waning Bay, Michigan, without friends or family but with a dream job as a children’s librarian, she begins her countdown to when she can leave and begin a new life, far away from Peter and Petra. The only person who could possibly understand her predicament is Petra’s ex, Miles Nowak. When Daphne proposes to Miles that she be his roommate, begins their friendship. Upon discovering that Petra and Peter are engaged, their friendship goes one step further, when they post misleading photos of themselves together as a couple. Yet, as Miles and Daphne explore Waning Bay together, they discover their feelings are more than those of friends. This was such a beautiful and tender romance, where I found myself savouring every conversation between Miles and Daphne, as they revealed their past hurts. I did not want to miss one part of it. Here are two characters that were quite destroyed by their exes and yet, took solace in each other, never complaining when one of them divulged parts of their past relationship. Emily Henry manages to gradually unpeel the layers away from all her characters so that by the time I finished reading this story, I could see how the first impressions of Miles was not who he was deep down. Likewise, I loved how Daphne grew in confidence from her friendship with Miles and could see Peter for who he truly was. Great secondary characters which further added to this wonderful story. I loved every minute of this book.

date.raw: Reviewed in Australia on 25 April 2024
profile.name: SH

title: 5 stars
body: Well, I *think* I've found my new fave Emily Henry story! I mean, I always love her books, but there was something about this one that just really hit deep. I haven't laughed/cried so deeply and interchangeably in a long time, and it was an absolute delight to read Henry's latest book.  Funny Story is about two characters, Daphne and Miles, whose (now ex-)partners leave them to be together. Understandably, Daphne is devastated when her ex-fiancé, Peter, breaks off their engagement to shack up with his childhood best friend Petra.  Suddenly finding herself fiancé-less and homeless, Daphne moves in with also newly single, Miles. And, funny story... it might be the best thing that ever happened to either of them!  One of my favourite things about this story was how two completely opposite characters dealt with their horrible break-ups and fell into a seemingly unlikely friendship. At face value, they couldn't be more different, and yet, underneath it all, they were more similar than imagined.  It was also really enjoyable to see the differences between Daphne's relationship with Peter (ugh) and Miles (happy sigh). And, it wasn't necessarily even big things/moments. It showed a lot of hidden depth about how people are often willing to accept the love/effort we think we deserve. Daphne went through a lot of personal growth in this book and I was absolutely here for it.  And Miles. I don't even have words for how much I adored Miles. He also had some thinking/growing up to do, but I have nothing but heart eyes for that man.  If you enjoy contemporary romance and/or opposites attract, check out this book! It was so enjoyable, I stayed up half the night to binge-read it in one sitting; I have no regrets. Five stars all around.
body_html:
Well, I *think* I've found my new fave Emily Henry story! I mean, I always love her books, but there was something about this one that just really hit deep. I haven't laughed/cried so deeply and interchangeably in a long time, and it was an absolute delight to read Henry's latest book.

Funny Story is about two characters, Daphne and Miles, whose (now ex-)partners leave them to be together. Understandably, Daphne is devastated when her ex-fiancé, Peter, breaks off their engagement to shack up with his childhood best friend Petra.

Suddenly finding herself fiancé-less and homeless, Daphne moves in with also newly single, Miles. And, funny story... it might be the best thing that ever happened to either of them!

One of my favourite things about this story was how two completely opposite characters dealt with their horrible break-ups and fell into a seemingly unlikely friendship. At face value, they couldn't be more different, and yet, underneath it all, they were more similar than imagined.

It was also really enjoyable to see the differences between Daphne's relationship with Peter (ugh) and Miles (happy sigh). And, it wasn't necessarily even big things/moments. It showed a lot of hidden depth about how people are often willing to accept the love/effort we think we deserve. Daphne went through a lot of personal growth in this book and I was absolutely here for it.

And Miles. I don't even have words for how much I adored Miles. He also had some thinking/growing up to do, but I have nothing but heart eyes for that man.

If you enjoy contemporary romance and/or opposites attract, check out this book! It was so enjoyable, I stayed up half the night to binge-read it in one sitting; I have no regrets. Five stars all around.
date.raw: Reviewed in Australia on 23 April 2024
profile.name: Bookishly Nomes

title: Emily Henry does it again!
body: “You’re worth it, Daphne,” he says, hand soft on my jaw and eyes closed.  Rating: 4.5/5  - Fake dating - Roommates to lovers - Ex’s new fiancé’s ex! - Librarian FMC & bartender MMC - Single POV  I just love Emily’s writing so much! It’s like coming home – the perfect blend of witty banter, descriptive prose, and tender moments. Her banter always delivers, and I freaking love it!  “You are either the friendliest man on the planet or a world‑class serial killer.” "Why not both?"  The premise of Funny Story is captivating from the get-go! An awkward librarian who loves schedules and can’t handle small talk gets dumped by her fiancé after he declares his love for his “platonic” best friend.  So what else is she supposed to do but move in with her ex’s new fiancé’s ex? And when they get sent wedding invitations, it makes sense to fake a relationship to make them jealous. And for Miles, the nicest guy on the planet, to show her around and make her fall in love with their town… and maybe him in the process.  Daphne and Miles were very much opposites, but I loved their comradeship and dynamic. He had this easygoing, natural way of pushing her out of her shell and supporting her while cataloguing all the small things that made her HER.  But as with all of Emily’s books, Funny Story is not without its layers. In this instance, it’s complex family dynamics. It’s Daphne being left behind by those who love her, making her scared to take that leap with Miles for fear he’ll end up not wanting her around, too. It's Miles letting Daphne see all the parts of himself.  “I do want all those parts of you.” “Good. They want you too.” Then he kIsses me. It’s perfect.  Also, this is 100% Emily’s h0rniest book yet, and I was here for it.  Eternally grateful to Viking Books for the early copy!
body_html:
“You’re worth it, Daphne,” he says, hand soft on my jaw and eyes closed.

Rating: 4.5/5

- Fake dating
- Roommates to lovers
- Ex’s new fiancé’s ex!
- Librarian FMC & bartender MMC
- Single POV

I just love Emily’s writing so much! It’s like coming home – the perfect blend of witty banter, descriptive prose, and tender moments. Her banter always delivers, and I freaking love it!

“You are either the friendliest man on the planet or a world‑class serial killer.”
"Why not both?"

The premise of Funny Story is captivating from the get-go! An awkward librarian who loves schedules and can’t handle small talk gets dumped by her fiancé after he declares his love for his “platonic” best friend.

So what else is she supposed to do but move in with her ex’s new fiancé’s ex? And when they get sent wedding invitations, it makes sense to fake a relationship to make them jealous. And for Miles, the nicest guy on the planet, to show her around and make her fall in love with their town… and maybe him in the process.

Daphne and Miles were very much opposites, but I loved their comradeship and dynamic. He had this easygoing, natural way of pushing her out of her shell and supporting her while cataloguing all the small things that made her HER.

But as with all of Emily’s books, Funny Story is not without its layers. In this instance, it’s complex family dynamics. It’s Daphne being left behind by those who love her, making her scared to take that leap with Miles for fear he’ll end up not wanting her around, too. It's Miles letting Daphne see all the parts of himself.

“I do want all those parts of you.”
“Good. They want you too.”
Then he kIsses me. It’s perfect.

Also, this is 100% Emily’s h0rniest book yet, and I was here for it.

Eternally grateful to Viking Books for the early copy!
date.raw: Reviewed in Australia on 25 April 2024
profile.name: Hayley

title: Best summer read💕
body: Review: Funny Story Rating: ⭐ ⭐ ⭐ ⭐ ⭐ Spice:🌶️🌶️ Overall: HIGHLY RECOMMENDED Vibes: Summer, Romance, Found family, Love, Cozy.  If you're in the mood for a heartwarming, cozy summer read, "Funny Story" is the book for you! The tale begins with Miles and Daphne, both freshly dumped by their respective partners. With nowhere else to go, Daphne ends up moving in with Miles, who graciously offers her a place to stay. What starts as a lie to save face soon blossoms into a beautiful love story.  Daphne's strength in the face of heartbreak and the unwavering support she receives from Miles are truly inspiring. Despite the family trauma they each carry, their journey together is filled with sweet, tender moments that will make your heart melt. Daphne's resilience and Miles's steadfast support make this story incredibly relatable and endearing.  Miles has quickly become my new fictional boyfriend, thanks to his caring nature and the way he stands by Daphne through thick and thin. "Funny Story" is packed with good quotes and moments that will leave you feeling all warm and fuzzy inside. I couldn't put it down and felt so good reading it.  This book is the perfect companion for a lazy summer day, and I wholeheartedly recommend it to everyone looking for a feel-good read this season. Don't miss out on this charming, sweet romance!

If you're in the mood for a heartwarming, cozy summer read, "Funny Story" is the book for you! The tale begins with Miles and Daphne, both freshly dumped by their respective partners. With nowhere else to go, Daphne ends up moving in with Miles, who graciously offers her a place to stay. What starts as a lie to save face soon blossoms into a beautiful love story.

Daphne's strength in the face of heartbreak and the unwavering support she receives from Miles are truly inspiring. Despite the family trauma they each carry, their journey together is filled with sweet, tender moments that will make your heart melt. Daphne's resilience and Miles's steadfast support make this story incredibly relatable and endearing.

Miles has quickly become my new fictional boyfriend, thanks to his caring nature and the way he stands by Daphne through thick and thin. "Funny Story" is packed with good quotes and moments that will leave you feeling all warm and fuzzy inside. I couldn't put it down and felt so good reading it.

This book is the perfect companion for a lazy summer day, and I wholeheartedly recommend it to everyone looking for a feel-good read this season. Don't miss out on this charming, sweet romance!
date.raw: Reviewed in India on 30 May 2024
profile.name: Sakshi Gaur

title: Romantic, sexy, heart-warming and funny
body: In Funny Story we meet Daphne who was engaged to marry Peter – he loved to tell people the funny story of how they met. But during his bachelor party, he realised he was in love with his childhood best friend, Petra and he calls off the wedding, kicking Daphne out of the house which he reminds her is his. Daphne is devastated and plans to leave Waning Bay in Michigan as soon as the readathon at the public library where she works as a children’s librarian is over. She finds herself sharing an apartment with Miles, Petra’s ex who is similarly devastated. They are both shocked when Peter and Petra announce a wedding date very quickly and Daphne in a moment of madness agrees to go with Miles, pretending that they are now dating. To start off with she thinks Miles is a pot smoking looser but as she gets to know him, she realises that this was Peter’s opinion, and she discovers he is much more than that. Funny Story was an absolute joy to read, I loved everything about this book. It has • A character who is a dedicated children’s librarian and who loves reading • A very sexy and kind man • A bit of a guide to all the best places to visit in Waning Bay (I want to go!) Daphne realises she had essentially uprooted her life to be with Peter, seeing his friends and family and having none of her own. Even one of her old friends seems to have taken Peter's side. She makes friends with the wonderful Ashleigh whom she works with, and she soon starts to make more connections. We hear about her upbringing – a loving single mum who worked hard but whose changing jobs meant they moved around a lot, meaning she struggled to make and keep friends. Her dad was big on the promises but not so much on the following through. My first Emily Henry (I know – I’m sorry!) I always knew she would be an author I would love but there are just so many other books to read (most of them on my shelves). I’m now on a mission to complete my Emily Henry collection and read them all as soon as possible. An absolute joy – romantic, sexy, heart-warming and funny! I absolutely loved this!
body_html:

But during his bachelor party, he realised he was in love with his childhood best friend, Petra and he calls off the wedding, kicking Daphne out of the house which he reminds her is his. They are both shocked when Peter and Petra announce a wedding date very quickly and Daphne in a moment of madness agrees to go with Miles, pretending that they are now dating.
To start off with she thinks Miles is a pot smoking looser but as she gets to know him, she realises that this was Peter’s opinion, and she discovers he is much more than that.
Funny Story was an absolute joy to read, I loved everything about this book. It has
• A character who is a dedicated children’s librarian and who loves reading
• A very sexy and kind man
• A bit of a guide to all the best places to visit in Waning Bay (I want to go!)
Daphne realises she had essentially uprooted her life to be with Peter, seeing his friends and family and having none of her own. Even one of her old friends seems to have taken Peter's side. She makes friends with the wonderful Ashleigh whom she works with, and she soon starts to make more connections. We hear about her upbringing – a loving single mum who worked hard but whose changing jobs meant they moved around a lot, meaning she struggled to make and keep friends. Her dad was big on the promises but not so much on the following through.
My first Emily Henry (I know – I’m sorry!) I always knew she would be an author I would love but there are just so many other books to read (most of them on my shelves). I’m now on a mission to complete my Emily Henry collection and read them all as soon as possible.
An absolute joy – romantic, sexy, heart-warming and funny! I absolutely loved this!

profile.name: Aaron

title: Heartwarming and perfect !
body: Happy place was my favorite romance book from last year so my expectations for Funny Story were high ! They were so high that I was scared of not liking this one. But, Emily Henry did it again !  At first, I had trouble liking Daphne. She was always complaining and playing the victim. Sure her ex was an idiot but girl, just punch him in the face and get your life back on track (ok, I’m a bit heartless there). But, if Emily Henry is good at one thing it’s how she writes relationship. And Daphne and Miles’ was perfect. Nearly strangers to friends to lovers. The evolution was slow and so well done. It could have been a friendship story and it would still have been perfect. I was in love with Miles and his imperfections from the start. Come on, the guy wears Crocs and Emily makes you love him in a second ! If that’s not great writing, I don’t know what it is !  The other thing I like about Emily’s story is how the supporting characters are great and the found family trope is heartwarming and beautiful. As always for Emily Henry it’s a 5/5 read !
body_html:
Happy place was my favorite romance book from last year so my expectations for Funny Story were high ! They were so high that I was scared of not liking this one. But, Emily Henry did it again !

At first, I had trouble liking Daphne. She was always complaining and playing the victim. Sure her ex was an idiot but girl, just punch him in the face and get your life back on track (ok, I’m a bit heartless there). But, if Emily Henry is good at one thing it’s how she writes relationship. And Daphne and Miles’ was perfect. Nearly strangers to friends to lovers. The evolution was slow and so well done. It could have been a friendship story and it would still have been perfect. I was in love with Miles and his imperfections from the start. Come on, the guy wears Crocs and Emily makes you love him in a second ! If that’s not great writing, I don’t know what it is !

The other thing I like about Emily’s story is how the supporting characters are great and the found family trope is heartwarming and beautiful.
As always for Emily Henry it’s a 5/5 read !

title: Classic Emily Henry Story
body: Another classic Emily Henry story… Same basic structure 🫣 new, fun, witty, characters and setting. I devoured this book in two days primarily because i had to take care of the kids.  I loved Daphnes character and watching her uncover how her childhood “trauma” affected her in the present. I loved watching her grow into herself. The same with Miles.  The small Michigan town feeling was very comforting. Best of all, i LOVED the random book references, from Jane Austen, to station eleven and beyond. A book about books, no matter how subtle, is one of my favorites.  The only reason it wasn’t a 5star was because of the predictability of it. Still a wonderful book!

profile.name: Elegant Fantasy

title: It’s kind of a funny story…
body: Is Funny Story going to change your life? Probably not. Does it turn the genre on its head? Not really.  But is it a comfortable, loving exploration of two people figuring out how to allow themselves the space to find happiness alone and together?  Yes. It is.  It’s also quite funny.  I can’t offer you anything you don’t already know, but I’ll share some things that resonated with me.  It’s a love letter to libraries, a safe place for me as an awkward teenager, a welcoming place when I was a struggling new mom, a familiar place for me as an adult — all of which are touched on in this book, too. And Daphne is…well, me, in many ways.  There are songs (and not Taylor Swift ones, natch) that bring a few scenes even more vibrance: Neil Young, Tommy James, the Eagles. Shout out to unexpected deep dives, songs I pulled up when they were mentioned so I could groove along with Miles and Daphne.  The premise includes familiar tropes: forced proximity, roommates to lovers, fake dating, but honestly those take a back seat to the actual belief that you’re watching these two fall in love. It’s slow and purposeful and so sweet.  The banter is laugh out loud funny and romantic, the setting (I spent a week one summer traveling around the entirety of the Michigan mitten!) feels a little bit travel brochure, a little bit love letter, and the difficult realizations Miles and Daphne come to are hard fought.  —— Miles and Daphne are heartbroken when her fiancée dumps her for his girlfriend, once his childhood best friend. Confused? Well, it’s kind of a funny story. They end up roommates of convenience, but end up in love inconveniently. Daphne counts down the days until she can move anywhere else — after her big read-a-thon event — and Miles uses the time to make her fall in love with Michigan.  That’s not all she falls in love with.
body_html:
Is Funny Story going to change your life? Probably not. Does it turn the genre on its head? Not really.

But is it a comfortable, loving exploration of two people figuring out how to allow themselves the space to find happiness alone and together?

Yes. It is.

It’s also quite funny.

I can’t offer you anything you don’t already know, but I’ll share some things that resonated with me.

It’s a love letter to libraries, a safe place for me as an awkward teenager, a welcoming place when I was a struggling new mom, a familiar place for me as an adult — all of which are touched on in this book, too. And Daphne is…well, me, in many ways.

There are songs (and not Taylor Swift ones, natch) that bring a few scenes even more vibrance: Neil Young, Tommy James, the Eagles. Shout out to unexpected deep dives, songs I pulled up when they were mentioned so I could groove along with Miles and Daphne.

The premise includes familiar tropes: forced proximity, roommates to lovers, fake dating, but honestly those take a back seat to the actual belief that you’re watching these two fall in love. It’s slow and purposeful and so sweet.

The banter is laugh out loud funny and romantic, the setting (I spent a week one summer traveling around the entirety of the Michigan mitten!) feels a little bit travel brochure, a little bit love letter, and the difficult realizations Miles and Daphne come to are hard fought.

——
Miles and Daphne are heartbroken when her fiancée dumps her for his girlfriend, once his childhood best friend. Confused? Well, it’s kind of a funny story. They end up roommates of convenience, but end up in love inconveniently. Daphne counts down the days until she can move anywhere else — after her big read-a-thon event — and Miles uses the time to make her fall in love with Michigan.

That’s not all she falls in love with.

title: Emily’s done it again… *slow clap*
body: What a wonderful, heartfelt and funny read. I’ve read all of Emily’s books and been a big fan from her debut. She has not disappointed with this new release. I’m sure I’ll be re-reading this in years to come - I only wish I didn’t devour the book so quickly.

profile.name: Amazon Customer

title: This book is both heart warming and heart breaking.
body: For anyone who carries around baggage from a less than wonderful childhood, there are portions of this book that might hit too close to home and make you feel that somehow the author is talking about you. You may find yourself sobbing from a place deep in your heart as I did.  At the same time, the authors’ character development is so complete and her use of language so good that you feel the joy of the two main characters as they come together and as they heal from their childhood trauma.  The book offers hope to those working on their own self healing. For me, this book came along at just the right time in my life for which I am grateful.

profile.name: Nicole Holloway

title: Sweet romance
body: Fun, sweet romance. Well structured with enjoyable dialogue and plot. I liked it and would definitely recommend it for a light, easy read. There were a few themes in this book that I'm finding more commonly used by contemporary authors that I didn't love. First, the assumption that self-discovery requires irresponsible, rebellious, and self harming behavior. (smoking cigars, smoking weed, excessive drinking, gambling, one night stands, etc. Etc). Maybe for some people that's what it looks like (and that's OK) I just don't like the implication that that's the route for everyone and that those that don't at least at some point in their lives try those things are repressed and stunted. That is simply not true and should not be hocked as if it is Second, can we stop blaming our parents for everything? This theme is taking over in contemporary literature, and it's annoying. Grow up people and take responsibility for your own actions and stop acting like your whole life is a victim to your parents. Parents are people, and they screw up their kids. Be an adult and get over it. I'm not saying there aren't some very traumatizing things that create lifelong hurt, but to blame every relationship issue and personal flaw on your parents is childish and a trope way too often used these days. End of rant. And to leave on a positive note, lol. While those themes are frustrating and gaining way too much traction, I don't think they ruin the book. So if you are looking for something to binge read and not feel like it was a total waste of time, give this book a try. Happy reading!
body_html:
Fun, sweet romance. Well structured with enjoyable dialogue and plot. I liked it and would definitely recommend it for a light, easy read.
There were a few themes in this book that I'm finding more commonly used by contemporary authors that I didn't love. First, the assumption that self-discovery requires irresponsible, rebellious, and self harming behavior. (smoking cigars, smoking weed, excessive drinking, gambling, one night stands, etc. Etc). Maybe for some people that's what it looks like (and that's OK) I just don't like the implication that that's the route for everyone and that those that don't at least at some point in their lives try those things are repressed and stunted. That is simply not true and should not be hocked as if it is
Second, can we stop blaming our parents for everything? This theme is taking over in contemporary literature, and it's annoying. Grow up people and take responsibility for your own actions and stop acting like your whole life is a victim to your parents. Parents are people, and they screw up their kids. Be an adult and get over it. I'm not saying there aren't some very traumatizing things that create lifelong hurt, but to blame every relationship issue and personal flaw on your parents is childish and a trope way too often used these days. End of rant.
And to leave on a positive note, lol. While those themes are frustrating and gaining way too much traction, I don't think they ruin the book. So if you are looking for something to binge read and not feel like it was a total waste of time, give this book a try.
Happy reading!

profile.name: Jasmine Harvey

title: Engaging story, unnecessarily woke
body: Engaging story and relatable characters, as always.  The glorification of drugs and alcohol felt forced and unnecessary. Which stoner goes sober from Chapter 2? The attempt to include so many LGBTQ+ characters only mentioned in passing also felt forced. The writer is too talented to try to be woke; her craft does not require gimmicks.  But, as always, insightfully written to appeal to even a cynical romance reader like me. I read the whole book in a single seating. Henry drew a cast of flawed, introspective, communicative, positive characters but felt a bit film-oriented to me this time.
body_html:

But, as always, insightfully written to appeal to even a cynical romance reader like me. I read the whole book in a single seating. Henry drew a cast of flawed, introspective, communicative, positive characters but felt a bit film-oriented to me this time.

profile.name: Books and Compassion

title: Sweet, hilarious romcom with depth and spice. Highly recommend!
body: I had to take a few days and gather my thoughts after reading this book. This was my 2nd Emily Henry book and I really loved it. From the very first chapter I was completely enthralled in her characters and storytelling. Being told solely from the FMC Daphne’s perspective made me feel like I was her and her struggles were so relatable to me.  The insecurities she felt, and the difficulty she had feeling like she “fit in”, her buttoned up persona that desired to be more spontaneous but found it hard to make that leap, her relationship troubles with her family and her “almost” in laws, and of course her love of libraries and books.  The ache she felt for a place to belong and to feel wanted and chosen was so beautifully written and made it even more special to watch her “found family” come together.  Ok mushy deep feelings aside… this book was so funny. The snarky internal monologue she had about the terrible situation she found herself in by no fault of her own was so perfect.  And then there’s Miles… oh my goodness. This guy is her polar opposite and exactly what she didn’t know she needed. He SEES her in a way that no man ever has and the chemistry between them is so undeniable that it never felt like a rebound and you couldn’t help but cheer them on! He’s the eternal optimist to her pessimistic self and the guy that can make a friend anytime anywhere without even trying while she is the girl that watches with awe from the sidelines. I absolutely love couples like this who are opposite but bring out the best in each other.  The setting was perfect for a spring or summer read with the adorable small town full of sweet side characters. Scenes at the beach, library, wine bar, and farm stand. Delicious food and wine…It made the story so cozy.  This book was one that I did not want to put down. I laughed. I cried. I was smiling at the very last line which wrapped the whole book up so perfectly and brought everything full circle.  I highlighted so much of this book… here are a few favorites:  “For someone with the innate social charm of a mounted fish (me), watching Miles befriend this stranger felt like seeing Michelangelo paint the Sistine Chapel: impressive, but also dizzying. Like any second, he might fall off his ladder and splatter on the marble below.”  “I remember loving a story. Feeling like I was living it. Being, even as a child, bowled over by how something imaginary could become real, could wring every emotion from me or make me homesick for places I’d never been.”  “Things were allowed to be complicated. They were allowed to be messy. We were allowed to disagree and argue and even hurt each other, on occasion, and it didn’t mean it was time to let the revolving door of life carry us away from each other. Sometimes things are hard. They just are.”  ARC was provided by the publisher via Netgalley in exchange for an honest review.  CW: F words, multiple open door scenes, recreational drug use
body_html:
I had to take a few days and gather my thoughts after reading this book. This was my 2nd Emily Henry book and I really loved it. From the very first chapter I was completely enthralled in her characters and storytelling. Being told solely from the FMC Daphne’s perspective made me feel like I was her and her struggles were so relatable to me.

The insecurities she felt, and the difficulty she had feeling like she “fit in”, her buttoned up persona that desired to be more spontaneous but found it hard to make that leap, her relationship troubles with her family and her “almost” in laws, and of course her love of libraries and books.

The ache she felt for a place to belong and to feel wanted and chosen was so beautifully written and made it even more special to watch her “found family” come together.

Ok mushy deep feelings aside… this book was so funny. The snarky internal monologue she had about the terrible situation she found herself in by no fault of her own was so perfect.

And then there’s Miles… oh my goodness. This guy is her polar opposite and exactly what she didn’t know she needed. He SEES her in a way that no man ever has and the chemistry between them is so undeniable that it never felt like a rebound and you couldn’t help but cheer them on! He’s the eternal optimist to her pessimistic self and the guy that can make a friend anytime anywhere without even trying while she is the girl that watches with awe from the sidelines. I absolutely love couples like this who are opposite but bring out the best in each other.

The setting was perfect for a spring or summer read with the adorable small town full of sweet side characters. Scenes at the beach, library, wine bar, and farm stand. Delicious food and wine…It made the story so cozy.

This book was one that I did not want to put down. I laughed. I cried. I was smiling at the very last line which wrapped the whole book up so perfectly and brought everything full circle.

I highlighted so much of this book… here are a few favorites:

“For someone with the innate social charm of a mounted fish (me), watching Miles befriend this stranger felt like seeing Michelangelo paint the Sistine Chapel: impressive, but also dizzying. Like any second, he might fall off his ladder and splatter on the marble below.”

“I remember loving a story. Feeling like I was living it. Being, even as a child, bowled over by how something imaginary could become real, could wring every emotion from me or make me homesick for places I’d never been.”

“Things were allowed to be complicated. They were allowed to be messy. We were allowed to disagree and argue and even hurt each other, on occasion, and it didn’t mean it was time to let the revolving door of life carry us away from each other. Sometimes things are hard. They just are.”

ARC was provided by the publisher via Netgalley in exchange for an honest review. 

CW:
F words, multiple open door scenes, recreational drug use

profile.name: Kate D

title: Disappointed and didn't feel it had quite the same caliber as her previous books unfortunately.
body: 3 very disappointing stars. 😔  I am so sad to report that I didn't enjoy this book. And shocked to be quite honest. When I pick up an Emily Henry book, I can always guarantee I am going to have a good time. I usually never give any of her books anything less than 5 stars. I anxiously await them every year, and because they always release around this time of year, I know when to expect them and I count down the weeks til its arrival! But I just couldn't connect with her latest and found myself oftentimes bored. I usually have trouble putting her books down and I found myself going hours without picking this one up nor was I excited to. Emily can't always get it right I suppose.  They say if you loved People We Meet On Vacation, you'll love Happy Place, and if you loved Beach Read, you'll enjoy Book Lovers. Although as I mentioned I loved all her prior books, I'm definitely in the Happy Place/PWMOV category and if I had to rank them, Happy Place would definitely be my #1! I'm curious to see where this one falls for everyone else. I saw mixed reviews early on, but I scoffed at them and kept my expectations high, because I've never had an EH book flop for me!  While reading this book, I kept trying to put my finger on what it exactly it was that wasn't working for me. And although, there wasn't a concrete "ah-a" moment, I do believe it was a combination of things, so let me try to break them down.  One issue for me was the main characters. I didn't jive with either one. Daphne was too much of a stick in the mud and ironically enough, I did relate to her in certain ways, so I don't know what that says about me. 😅 Unfortunately, it wasn't enough for me to become attached to her though. Then we have Miles. I don't know if it was just how I pictured him or Henry didn't do a great job playing him up, but the mental picture I had of him made me think he was unkempt and just wasn't doing a good job pulling off his beard. 😂 So yea, I had trouble with him winning me over as well. He seemed nice and charming! And I loved how they were opposites, but I just didn't feel like they were memorable.  Another issue I had with the book was the overall story. It was just kinda too sad and depressing. I know we are coming in on the two main characters ending their serious relationships and picking up the pieces of their broken heart. I also know she couldn't just have them move on over night to make it feel realistic. But it felt like the majority of the story we were slugging through this part of their story to where I was just ready to move on! Give me the good stuff!  The banter and even alot of the jokes fell flat for me also. When the side characters started playing a more important role, I thought it improved, but if the main characters aren't giving it to me, we have a problem.  I never got giddy or the butterflies in my stomach I come to expect from her writing. I had no emotional attachment to the story or the characters making this book completely unremarkable to me and completely forgettable.  I will say I thought it was very clever how Henry started this book and then ended the book! I loved that part and it gave me a little glimmer of why I love her writing so much! I'm really hoping this one was a one off for me and this time next year I will be back raving and begging anyone and everyone to go read her latest book. I know it is unrealistic for me to love every book and we all have different opinions, but I am so bummed it didn't work out. I'd recommend loaning this from the library versus purchasing and hopefully you won't be like me and will absolutely adore it!
body_html:
3 very disappointing stars. 😔

I never got giddy or the butterflies in my stomach I come to expect from her writing. I had no emotional attachment to the story or the characters making this book completely unremarkable to me and completely forgettable.

I know it is unrealistic for me to love every book and we all have different opinions, but I am so bummed it didn't work out. I'd recommend loaning this from the library versus purchasing and hopefully you won't be like me and will absolutely adore it!

profile.name: Celene

title: Emily Henry can do nothing wrong
body: I am so sad to have finished funny story so quickly as now I have to wait another year for another great Emily Henry book. As per usual she had wonderfully developed 3D characters that you cannot help but love. If there is one thing Emily Henry knows how to do its showcase her characters vulnerability and sincereity. In this book we watch Daphne grow, make meaningful relationships for the first time ever and learn how to be her own person again in a delightful and bumbling way. This book was lovely and for once unlike every other book she has ever written did not make me cry. Whilst there where some sad moments in the book the positivity of the main characters shone through easing the sting.

profile.name: Kindle Customer

title: There’s a Reason EH is an Automatic Buy.
body: I’ll be honest, I was hesitant to pick this one up. Because Happy Place was such a deeply emotional read for me, and caps the front end of what has been a record-breaking reading year for me, I had doubts this book would live up to HP or any of the 100+ other books I’ve read since last April.  Well I should have known it would all be fine. Emily it’s a stunning writer to me. She writes these incredibly flawed/traumatized/confused/beautiful/lovable/relatable characters that I can’t help but feel kinship with. I care so deeply about each of them and would root for them to find happiness in the end even if it wasn’t together - though, of course, I’m pleased as pie when there is a HEA. I am a diehard contemporary romance (+smut) reader, and yet I never annoyed at the limited spice, nor do I think what she does include could be cut out without changing the story. I think that takes some skill!  I loved that this interaction of “book industry lady” in Daphne was a librarian, and to see the beautiful community that blossomed there. The neighbors of Waning Bay were so cozy and just made me want to visit a tiny town in Michigan this summer (though when do EH books not inspire that).  The chemistry between Daphne and Miles was so natural and lovely and believable. Sometimes there are people you don’t think you’d connect with in a million years, and then you just slip into this wonderful, easy dynamic. Their banter was great, and you could really see the ways they GOT one another and brought out good, healthy things/change in one another. Their flaws and conflicts and miscommunications felt so true to life, and even the way they found their ways back (to one another and to other characters) was everything I wanted. Not too quick or easy, and with markers of a well planned character arc.  I love that Emily does “show not tell” so well in her writing, allowing characters to wrestle and struggle and doubt themselves and their own love story, rather than falling in love because they’re supposed to and expecting the reader to just get on board.  I feel like I could go on and on with the positivity, which is why this is a 5⭐️ read for me (even if I was leaning towards a 4 while reading). Not a life-changing book, but one I’ll surely be returning to again and again, could absolutely throw me into a reading slump, and that I enjoyed over and beyond enough to recommend.
body_html:

profile.name: mickie

title: The Hyper is Real
body: The hype is REAL. Funny Story is so good that I could not put it down, getting only four hours of sleep in order to finish this amazing, heart-clenching, swoony rom-com. I loved every page of this book and after finally getting some sleep, my husband woke me and all i could say was, "i wish i could read it again for the first time."  Qᴜɪᴄᴋ ᴏᴠᴇʀᴠɪᴇᴡ: ᴡʜᴇɴ ᴅᴀᴘʜɴᴇ'ꜱ ꜰɪᴀɴᴄÉ’ ʟᴇᴀᴠᴇꜱ ʜᴇʀ ꜰᴏʀ ʜɪꜱ "ᴘʟᴀᴛᴏɴɪᴄ" ʙᴇꜱᴛ ɢɪʀʟꜰʀɪᴇɴᴅ, ꜱʜᴇ ɴᴇᴇᴅꜱ ᴀ ᴘʟᴀᴄᴇ ᴛᴏ ꜱᴛᴀʏ ꜱᴏ ꜱʜᴇ ᴇɴᴅꜱ ᴜᴘ ʙᴇᴄᴏᴍɪɴɢ ʀᴏᴏᴍᴍᴀᴛᴇꜱ ᴡɪᴛʜ ʜᴇʀ ɴᴏᴡ ᴇx-ꜰɪᴀɴᴄÉ’ꜱ ɴᴇᴡ ꜰɪᴀɴᴄÉ’ꜱ ᴇx-ʙᴏʏꜰʀɪᴇɴᴅ, ᴍɪʟᴇꜱ. ᴍɪʟᴇꜱ ᴀɴᴅ ᴅᴀᴘʜɴᴇ ʙᴏɴᴅ ᴏᴠᴇʀ ᴛʜᴇɪʀ ꜱʜᴀʀᴇᴅ ʜᴇᴀʀᴛʙʀᴇᴀᴋ ᴀɴᴅ ꜱʟᴏᴡʟʏ ʙᴇᴄᴏᴍᴇ ꜰʀɪᴇɴᴅꜱ. ʙᴜᴛ ᴡʜᴇɴ ᴛʜᴇɪʀ ᴇxᴇꜱ' ᴡᴇᴅᴅɪɴɢ ɪɴᴠɪᴛᴀᴛɪᴏɴ ꜱʜᴏᴡꜱ ᴜᴘ, ᴛʜᴇʏ ʙᴏᴛʜ ʀꜱᴠᴘ "ʏᴇꜱ" ᴀɴᴅ ʙᴇᴄᴏᴍᴇ ᴇᴀᴄʜ ᴏᴛʜᴇʀ'ꜱ "ꜰᴀᴋᴇ ᴅᴀᴛᴇꜱ". ᴡʜᴏ ᴅᴏᴇꜱɴ'ᴛ ʟᴏᴠᴇ ᴀ ɢᴏᴏᴅ ꜰᴀᴋᴇ ᴅᴀᴛɪɴɢ ᴛʀᴏᴘᴇ?  This entire story is from our FMC Daphne's POV but the character growth for both Daphne and Miles is spectacular. Daphne and Miles are both opposites: Daphne is pessimistic, reserved, and has a hard time connecting with people, where Miles makes friends wherever he goes. They both have family trauma that drives both of their actions. The friendship and ultimate love story unfolds almost take a backseat to the growth and self-discovery, especially for Daphne who has been neglected much of her life. She moved to this small town for her ex and now needs to decide if she can make this place her home or does she pack up and go somewhere else?  Miles is the perfect imperfect man. He is upbeat and optimistic, but his underlying emotional flaws really tugged at my heart for him. I also loved the way he encouraged Daphne to open up and guided her to become more comfortable with herself.  The romance was so sweet and swoony, the banter is phenomenal, not only between our MCs but also the supporting cast of characters like Ashleigh and Julia. There's some spice and conflict, all of which makes this such a fantastic romantic comedy. It's what you expect but also so much more. This needs to be a movie ASAP.  Tropes & Elements: 🏡 Small Town Romance ❤️ Fake Dating 🛏️ Roommates 🫶 Found Family 😂 Great Banter ⛓️‍💥 Opposites Attract ☝🏻 Single POV (FMC) 🩷 Friends to Lovers ➶ Amazing Character Growth  My rating: 5 out of 5 ⭐️

The hype is REAL. Funny Story is so good that I could not put it down, getting only four hours of sleep in order to finish this amazing, heart-clenching, swoony rom-com. I loved every page of this book and after finally getting some sleep, my husband woke me and all i could say was, "i wish i could read it again for the first time."

Qᴜɪᴄᴋ ᴏᴠᴇʀᴠɪᴇᴡ: ᴡʜᴇɴ ᴅᴀᴘʜɴᴇ'ꜱ ꜰɪᴀɴᴄÉ’ ʟᴇᴀᴠᴇꜱ ʜᴇʀ ꜰᴏʀ ʜɪꜱ "ᴘʟᴀᴛᴏɴɪᴄ" ʙᴇꜱᴛ ɢɪʀʟꜰʀɪᴇɴᴅ, ꜱʜᴇ ɴᴇᴇᴅꜱ ᴀ ᴘʟᴀᴄᴇ ᴛᴏ ꜱᴛᴀʏ ꜱᴏ ꜱʜᴇ ᴇɴᴅꜱ ᴜᴘ ʙᴇᴄᴏᴍɪɴɢ ʀᴏᴏᴍᴍᴀᴛᴇꜱ ᴡɪᴛʜ ʜᴇʀ ɴᴏᴡ ᴇx-ꜰɪᴀɴᴄÉ’ꜱ ɴᴇᴡ ꜰɪᴀɴᴄÉ’ꜱ ᴇx-ʙᴏʏꜰʀɪᴇɴᴅ, ᴍɪʟᴇꜱ. ᴍɪʟᴇꜱ ᴀɴᴅ ᴅᴀᴘʜɴᴇ ʙᴏɴᴅ ᴏᴠᴇʀ ᴛʜᴇɪʀ ꜱʜᴀʀᴇᴅ ʜᴇᴀʀᴛʙʀᴇᴀᴋ ᴀɴᴅ ꜱʟᴏᴡʟʏ ʙᴇᴄᴏᴍᴇ ꜰʀɪᴇɴᴅꜱ. ʙᴜᴛ ᴡʜᴇɴ ᴛʜᴇɪʀ ᴇxᴇꜱ' ᴡᴇᴅᴅɪɴɢ ɪɴᴠɪᴛᴀᴛɪᴏɴ ꜱʜᴏᴡꜱ ᴜᴘ, ᴛʜᴇʏ ʙᴏᴛʜ ʀꜱᴠᴘ "ʏᴇꜱ" ᴀɴᴅ ʙᴇᴄᴏᴍᴇ ᴇᴀᴄʜ ᴏᴛʜᴇʀ'ꜱ "ꜰᴀᴋᴇ ᴅᴀᴛᴇꜱ". ᴡʜᴏ ᴅᴏᴇꜱɴ'ᴛ ʟᴏᴠᴇ ᴀ ɢᴏᴏᴅ ꜰᴀᴋᴇ ᴅᴀᴛɪɴɢ ᴛʀᴏᴘᴇ?

This entire story is from our FMC Daphne's POV but the character growth for both Daphne and Miles is spectacular. Daphne and Miles are both opposites: Daphne is pessimistic, reserved, and has a hard time connecting with people, where Miles makes friends wherever he goes. They both have family trauma that drives both of their actions. The friendship and ultimate love story unfolds almost take a backseat to the growth and self-discovery, especially for Daphne who has been neglected much of her life. She moved to this small town for her ex and now needs to decide if she can make this place her home or does she pack up and go somewhere else?

Miles is the perfect imperfect man. He is upbeat and optimistic, but his underlying emotional flaws really tugged at my heart for him. I also loved the way he encouraged Daphne to open up and guided her to become more comfortable with herself.

The romance was so sweet and swoony, the banter is phenomenal, not only between our MCs but also the supporting cast of characters like Ashleigh and Julia. There's some spice and conflict, all of which makes this such a fantastic romantic comedy. It's what you expect but also so much more. This needs to be a movie ASAP.

profile.name: justbookedup

title: it’s not even funny how much i loved this book
body: !!!!! I can’t even put into words how much I love this book. I love Daphne and Miles so much, but especially Miles. To be honest, I don’t think i have ever been more in love with a fictional character in my life (LOL). There are obviously parts of this book that are a little unrealistic, though I adore the fictional little town of Waning Bay Michigan more than i can say and i would move there in a heartbeat if i could. I think the thing that stood out to me most about this book was how real the things the characters struggled with were. I loved the fact that Daphne didn’t have one best friend her whole life (which i feel like is a common issue in a lot of books i read) and tried so hard to fit in with Peter’s family and friends and based her whole life around him only to feel like she lost her whole identity when they broke up (another common occurrence I believe). Being in her 30s, she’s never felt like she had a close friend she could tell everything to until she meets Ashleigh and i am just so happy Emily Henry included that part. The other thing I loved about this book is that there were no characters I didn’t like. Everyone was likable and relatable in some way (except maybe Peter and Petra lol) and maybe it is the introvert in me but I liked that Daphne didn’t have a million friends and wasn’t surrounded by a ton of people all the time. It’s hard to find characters that are relatable, and i found myself relating to her in many ways throughout the book. Just perfection in every way.

It’s hard to find characters that are relatable, and i found myself relating to her in many ways throughout the book. Just perfection in every way.

title: Emily Henry has the Midas touch
body: “sometimes the unexpected is better than what you plan." •  honestly, what can I say? it’s Emily Henry. she’s pure magic; she’s got the Midas touch. I never imagined she’d write a book that could usurp Beach Read as my favorite of hers, but here we are.  Funny Story is like rain on a sunny day. it’s full of joy and wonder and happiness, and while you can’t ignore the sprinkling of heartache, it’s not overwhelming; it’s just part of the beautiful adventure.  when Daphne and Miles are each dumped for the other’s ex, ultimately leaving them roommate-less, they do the only thing that makes sense: they move in together.  although Daphne’s countdown is on for when she can escape the small Michigan town she relocated to for her ex-fiancé, Miles makes it his mission to show her the magic of their community and how she can be a part of it regardless of what brought her there in the first place. sprouting small roots and building relationships along the way, Daphne begins to dream of a life that includes more than her ex and his desires. is it possible Miles could be a part of her new life and future? •  this and that: ♡ action movies ♡ Bridget Jones ♡ children’s story time ♡ detailed calendars ♡ dyslexia rep ♡ fake dating ♡ forced proximity ♡ found family ♡ he cooks for her ♡ he is sunshine in human form ♡ heartbreak ballads ♡ hidden beaches ♡ jilted lovers unite ♡ kayaking ♡ open door ♡ opposites attract ♡ our exes are dating ♡ pessimist / optimist ♡ poker nights ♡ roommates ♡ secret beaches ♡ she’s a librarian ♡ small town Michigan ♡ wine connoisseurs •  triggers: ☞ absent and unreliable fathers ☞ emotionally abusive parents ☞ heartbreak ☞ infidelity ☞ loneliness
body_html:
“sometimes the unexpected is better than what you plan."
•

honestly, what can I say? it’s Emily Henry. she’s pure magic; she’s got the Midas touch. I never imagined she’d write a book that could usurp Beach Read as my favorite of hers, but here we are.

Funny Story is like rain on a sunny day. it’s full of joy and wonder and happiness, and while you can’t ignore the sprinkling of heartache, it’s not overwhelming; it’s just part of the beautiful adventure.

when Daphne and Miles are each dumped for the other’s ex, ultimately leaving them roommate-less, they do the only thing that makes sense: they move in together.

although Daphne’s countdown is on for when she can escape the small Michigan town she relocated to for her ex-fiancé, Miles makes it his mission to show her the magic of their community and how she can be a part of it regardless of what brought her there in the first place. sprouting small roots and building relationships along the way, Daphne begins to dream of a life that includes more than her ex and his desires. is it possible Miles could be a part of her new life and future?
•

this and that:

♡ Bridget Jones
